HEADLINE: 3 IN COUP FEARED U.S. DEPENDENCY

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Plotters who tried to overthrow President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in August acted partly because they feared that he was making the Soviet Union dependent on the United States, according to the confession of one plotter published in the German news magazine Spiegel.
"Gorbachev often traveled abroad in recent years, and frequently we had no idea what important issues he discussed there," former Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov reportedly told interrogators. 
 "Take Gorbachev's report to the G-7 meeting in London -- none of us knew what he said there," Mr. Yazov said, referring to the Soviet President's meeting with leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized countries in London in July. "We were naturally not ready to increase our political, economic and even military dependence on the United States."
 
Excerpts From Videotapes
 In its issue to be distributed on Monday, Der Spiegel published what it said were excerpts from videotaped interrogations of Mr. Yazov and two other organizers of the coup, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, former K.G.B. chief, and Valentin S. Pavlov, former Prime Minister. Advance copies of the article were made available today.
Der Spiegel did not say how it had obtained the material, but in the past it has paid for exclusive information.
According to the article, Mr. Yazov cited the Soviet Union's economic decline and internal unrest as other factors that motivated the coup plotters.
The accounts reportedly given by the three imprisoned plotters suggest that their coup was haphazardly planned. Mr. Pavlov, for example, said the plotters simply hoped that the Supreme Soviet would approve their action and that afterward "things would be worked out."
Mr. Yazov said that at a key meeting on Aug. 18 at which the coup was planned, he, Mr. Kryuchkov and a third plotter, Boris K. Pugo, former Interior Minister, who later committed suicide, were all drunk.
Mr. Pavlov told his interrogators that he also consumed "quite a decent amount of alcohol" at that meeting.
Of the three plotters, Mr. Yazov, formerly a senior military officer, was the most contrite. All three men face trial and possible death sentences for their roles in the coup.

HEADLINE: Pressing for United Front in Regional Vying for Companies

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
It has become a familiar scene of seduction: other cities and states trying to lure businesses from New York City, wooing them with promises of lower taxes and a better quality of life.
Now a few officials are trying to make the case that New York City is not the only loser when a company leaves the city but that the economy of the whole region is undermined. The solution, they say, is for officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to stop competing among themselves and to begin to forge policies that present a united front. 
 "It's not farsighted vision that's changing people's actions, it's economic reality," said Thomas M. Downs, New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner. In a competitive world economy, he said, a company considering where to have a new plant or office does not think in terms of Manhattan versus Jersey City. It considers alternative metropolitan areas, like New York versus Philadelphia or Los Angeles or Dallas. Truly global companies think even more broadly: New York versus Tokyo versus London versus Hamburg, for example.
"Our real competitors aren't each other," said Mr. Downs of New Jersey's immediate neighbors. "It's other big urban areas that are attempting to steal the bacon." Just recently, Saab Automobile said it was moving its United States headquarters from Orange, Conn., to Atlanta, citing opportunities to reduce overhead through reduced costs, tax rates and property values.
Getting public officials to approach policy issues from a regional perspective is difficult in the best of economic times, when resources are plentiful and budgets are expanding. But getting them to do so in a recession is a significant challenge.
Over the last few years, bidding wars have been common, with New Jersey, New York and Connecticut all offering generous tax breaks and other incentives to keep companies from leaving or to persuade others to stay.
In what was perhaps the most striking example of this every-state-for-itself approach, New Jersey and New York made a series of offers and counteroffers to the commodities exchanges, even though the building the exchanges were planning to leave, 4 World Trade Center, is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, an agency created by the two states to promote commerce and to operate the area's major airports, bridges and tunnels.
And Jersey City's Mayor, Gerald McCann, acknowledged on a recent television talk show that he kept raising his bid for the exchanges despite serious doubts that they would ever move to New Jersey -- just to make the process more expensive for New York. He said that although he favored regionalism, he engaged in the bidding war out of spite because he thought New York City officials were instrumental in getting the Hartford Life Insurance Company to reverse its decision to move its regional office with 140 employees from Manhattan to Jersey City.
Speaking of the exchanges on the WABC-TV program "Heart of the Matter," Mayor McCann said, "We knew they weren't moving to New Jersey, but we figured that New York did it to us on the Hartford, so we're going to do it to them on the commodities exchanges." Convinced that the exchanges were serious about moving, officials of New York City and New York State ended up offering them a package of tax breaks and other incentives worth more than $145 million.
"I don't know of any area in the country where there's more cutthroat competition than here," said Ted M. Levine, president of Development Counsellors International, a New York City-based company that advises states and municipalities on how to attract business.
In one of the first formal efforts to reverse this trend, the economic development agencies of the three states, as well as some cities and counties within them, have agreed to meet today to try to put aside their differences and concentrate on policies that will help promote the region as a whole.
 
A Barge-Ferry Link
 "We all have the same problem, which is we ain't cheap," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development for New York City, whose idea it was to convene the meeting. "Unless we make a concerted effort to join forces, we will be increasingly at a competitive disadvantage."
Among the hoped-for outcomes of the meeting are a pact to avoid all negative advertising by one local government against another, and commitments to promote the region internationally and seek to retain companies in the region, rather than in an individual state.
So far, examples like that are rare. New York City and New Jersey did work together on a package to encourage the company that produces Maxwell House coffee, Philip Morris, to keep its coffee-roasting operation in Hoboken, N.J., principally because most of the coffee beans it processes there comes through Brooklyn. But the effort, which would have involved incentives like a barge-ferry link between Brooklyn and Hoboken, was not enough to keep the company from deciding to move to Jacksonville, Fla.
By and large, it is easier to find cooperation in areas like transportation and the environment, where geographic boundaries are more obviously irrelevant. Both New Jersey and New York, for instance, are considering a shift to electronic toll cards that would be installed on windows or windshields of cars and trucks to allow drivers to be billed as they pass through certain toll points, without stopping their cars.
 
Emission Control Standards
 The system is intended to reduce traffic congestion while simplifying the toll-collection process, both of which would make the region more attractive to companies transporting goods. But until the two states and the many transportation authorities within those states agreed to use the same technology, drivers could have found themselves needing different cards for roads operated by different authorities.
Similar efforts toward regionalism are are coming on the environmental front. New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania are moving to adopt California's strict auto-emission standards, and lately there has been more cooperation between New York and Connecticut on the water pollution problems of Long Island Sound.
"We're now finding many efforts at regional cooperation," said Thomas C. Jorling, New York State's Environmental Conservation Commissioner.
Perhaps the greatest test of regionalism involve tax policy. New York City's Finance Commissioner, Carol O'Cleireacain, feels that she is working at a distinct disadvantage. The city's economic base covers at least 10 counties in 3 states. Yet despite the benefits that businesses and residents in those states derive from New York City, either directly or indirectly, Ms. O'Cleireacain has little authority to tax them. On the contrary, companies and individuals in New York City always have the constant option of moving from the city to flee its taxes.
"There are real border-issue problems here," she said. "If you were in Chicago, you'd only have to go to two neighboring counties, and they're in the same state."
The model for tax revenue-sharing is Minneapolis and St. Paul in Minnesota, where the concept was first introduced in the early 1970's. It was seen as a way to combat flight by businesses and residents from the inner cities to the suburbs, by eliminating tax rate discrepancies among the various communities and allocating more revenues to poor urban areas despite their lack of high-income taxpayers. Since 1975, when the revenue-sharing plan began, governments in the Twin Cities area -- seven counties, all told -- have been putting part of their property-tax revenues into a pool and distributing them according to population and need.
Of course, the seven counties that undertook this unusual policy are all within one state. Ms. O'Cleireacain, the New York City finance chief, believes that such regional cooperation is unlikely to occur in the New York area, pointing out that the city could not even get its own State Legislature to accept an increase in the city's 0.45 percent commuter tax on wages, which is one of the lowest in the country.
And Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, has proposed that the three states consider a regional gasoline tax, which would raise revenues for infrastructure projects without creating disparities that one state or another could try to exploit for its own advantage.
"Fiscal problems do not stop at the New York City line," he warned in a speech in late May.
Mr. Vallone has proposed that greater emphasis be placed on regional planning, with some areas in the region encouraged to specialize in making themselves more attractive to manufacturers, for instance, and others focused on doing the same for, say, the computer industry or telecommunications. "We need to think more about what unites us rather than what divides us," he said.

HEADLINE: Room for Differences;
Amid Accord Over Tactical Nuclear Arms, Less Progress to Cut Long-Range Weapons

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The American and Soviet arms control initiatives have left the superpowers in agreement on eliminating their battlefield nuclear weapons, but the two sides still have major differences about how to cut their long-range, intercontinental nuclear arms.
In responding to President Bush's arms control initiative, the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said he would match the American move to destroy or withdraw from service most tactical nuclear weapons on land and at sea. 
 And in what might be an important reversal of Moscow's adamant opposition to anti-missile defenses, Mr. Gorbachev was surprisingly warm to President Bush's proposal to discuss the deployment of limited defenses.
But on strategic arms -- the intercontinental missiles and bombers that make up the heart of each side's nuclear deterrent -- Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush are, for the most part, still talking past each other.
Put simply, Mr. Gorbachev's agenda is deep cuts in long-range nuclear arms, a proposal that is likely to have considerable appeal on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers see arms control as a way to pare military spending.
In contrast, the Bush Administration has argued that the important thing is not to make reductions in strategic arms for their own sake, but to ban one category of weapons: land-based missiles with more than one warhead.
 
Room for Compromise
 Such a step would reduce each side's ability to carry out a first strike, but it would have a larger impact on Moscow, since land-based missiles are its strong suit in strategic forces. The proposed ban is the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's plan on strategic arms, but it was pointedly ignored by Mr. Gorbachev. While the Soviet President announced a variety of steps to halt the strategic arms race, he did not foreclose the option of building new multi-warhead land-based missiles.
Administration officials said that they expected Mr. Bush's sweeping initiative to prompt Mr. Gorbachev to propose more drastic cuts and that a compromise might ultimately be fashioned between the two approaches.
"There is clearly a different emphasis in their plan, but the two views are not necessarily at odds with each other," a senior Administration official said. "My sense is that based on their overall response on tactical weapons and on defenses, there is reason to think we have got beyond the comparative advantage approach of the past, where everything was looked at in terms of who got the edge over the other side," the official added.
 
More Talks Needed?
 But melding the two approaches would appear to require detailed, and perhaps protracted, negotiation, a process President Bush hoped to avoid when he announced his arms control initiative on Sept. 27. The differences on strategic forces should not diminish the significance of the convergence in the superpower arms control initiatives on tactical weapons, the main focus of concern for the Bush Administration.
In a change of the United States' traditional arms control priorities, President Bush labeled most tactical, or battlefield, nuclear weapons dangerous and obsolete and moved to eliminate them. This reflects a worry that some of the thousands of tactical nuclear weapons that are widely dispersed throughout the Soviet Union might fall into the wrong hands as Soviet central authority is reduced.
Mr. Gorbachev's move on tactical nuclear weapons is just about everything Mr. Bush could have hoped for. Mr. Gorbachev pledged to eliminate all nuclear artillery shells, nuclear mines and nuclear warheads for tactical surface-to-surface missiles. Washington would have preferred that Mr. Gorbachev also agree to destroy all nuclear warheads for Soviet anti-aircraft missiles, instead of keeping some in storage. But that is a small point and may reflect Moscow's disapproval of NATO's plans to keep an arsenal of nuclear bombs in Europe.
Mr. Gorbachev also agreed to match Mr. Bush's decision to remove all tactical nuclear weapons from ships and submarines. The Soviet President suggested that all of these weapons be destroyed instead of keeping some in storage, as Mr. Bush proposed. But Mr. Gorbachev was careful not to make this a condition for carrying out Mr. Bush's plan. The Pentagon wants to keep its nuclear-tipped sea-launched cruise missiles in storage, as a hedge against Soviet cheating and a deterioration of American-Soviet relations.
The Soviet response on anti-missile missiles has also encouraged Administration officials, who are accustomed to long Soviet diatribes against American plans to erect a "Star Wars" anti-missile defense. In his speech on Saturday, Mr. Gorbachev said that Moscow was prepared to consider American proposals on non-nuclear anti-missile systems and suggested that the two sides consider developing joint space-based and land-based systems to warn of a missile attack.
Talking about missile defenses and deploying them are two different things, and it is possible that Moscow is looking for a polite way to turn down Washington at a time when the Soviet Union has become increasingly dependent on the West for economic support. But it is also possible that Moscow has rethought its position as "Star Wars" has shrunk from Ronald Reagan's vision of a strategic umbrella designed to nullify the Soviet deterrent to the Bush Administration's concept of a limited system intended to protect against accidental launches of missiles and potential missile threats from third world countries.
 
Concerns on Early Warning
 Another Soviet consideration may be that its network of large early-warning radars on the periphery of its territory may be made less effective by a partial breakup of the Soviet Union, Administration officials said. Concern over the degradation of the network, some American officials say, may have prompted the new Soviet interest in sharing early-warning information and in discussing missile defenses.
From the Pentagon perspective, nuclear testing does not look like a promising area for bold new steps in arms control. Mr. Gorbachev's announcement of a one-year moratorium on testing comes as the number of American nuclear tests has declined for budgetary reasons. Nonetheless, Pentagon officials insist that testing is needed to insure the safety and reliability of old weapons and to develop new ones.
But the Pentagon is not the only audience. Congress, of course, will have the last word on "Star Wars" spending, funds for nuclear tests and the costly modernization of the American long-range nuclear forces. But the Soviet Union's arms cuts, its proposals for further reductions in strategic weapons and its interest in or opposition to anti-missile defense will influence the Congressional debate on the future of the American arsenal.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announcing weapons cuts on Saturday in response to President Bush's arms reductions. (Associated Press) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Gates's Task: Restoring Confidence and Purpose

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates appears close to winning a grueling fight this week to head the Central Intelligence Agency, but the battle has left both the man and the organization weakened, and the rush of history in the Soviet Union and elsewhere threatens to diminish them further.
The C.I.A. was a more vital place only last May, when Mr. Gates was nominated to become Director of Central Intelligence. Months later, he stands to inherit an organization whose primary purpose is vanishing, whose innermost conflicts have been aired for three weeks, and whose worst excesses under the former Director, William J. Casey, he has come, rightly or wrongly, to symbolize. 
 Within the agency that he served for 20 years, opinions of Mr. Gates are deeply divided, public testimony before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence demonstrated last week.
And if confirmed, Mr. Gates would have to shoulder the responsibility of healing and rebuilding an agency at perhaps the most wrenching hour in its 44-year history.
 
The Romance Is Gone
 The Central Intelligence Agency still commands an important role in national security, and most experts call it more responsible, professional and effective than ever before. But its image is suffering.
Gone forever is the romantic notion of a dashing, omniscient, slightly roguish vanguard in the war against Communism. The war is over and the C.I.A. has been demystified, accused of sleeping at the switch of history and pummeled almost weekly by assaults on its purpose and its credibility.
The demise of Soviet Communism in August all but obliterated the agency's primary mission of tracking Moscow's nuclear and conventional military movements. Its other major duty, insuring that Moscow is complying with arms-control treaties, lost some of its importance with President Bush's nuclear-weapons initiative in September and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's response on Saturday.
This month, new indictments in the criminal investigation of the Iran-contra affair are widely expected to involve former agency officials and resurrect old questions about the honesty and integrity of the C.I.A.'s clandestine operators during the Reagan years.
Mr. Gates's confirmation hearings touched all those exposed nerves. Then they laid bare doubts about the quality and objectivity of the intelligence analyses that the agency supplies to the White House and Congress, and on which major policy decisions are sometimes based.
The agency has survived criticism many times before. Congressional hearings in 1976 exposed what officials then called "the skeletons" -- botched assassination plots, domestic break-ins and wiretaps against American citizens. That devastated the C.I.A.'s clandestine service. It rebounded under Mr. Casey and his successor, William H. Webster, with record budget increases, renewed Congressional support and largely successful operations against the Soviet Union in Afghanistan and elsewhere.
But the sweep and speed of this autumn's developments have prompted accusations that the C.I.A. failed to predict the political collapse of the century and the rise of third-world threats like Iraq.
Even some Government officials who work closely with the agency admit to a growing conviction that the glory days of spying and covert operations are past.
"Intelligence is particularly important when you're dealing with forbidden countries," one senior official in the Reagan and Bush administrations said in an interview. "The comparative advantage of the intelligence community is going to go down, because more and more of the world is open."
Even Mr. Gates admits to a share of botched predictions. On Friday, he said the agency's most painful recent failures included flawed assessments of Iraq's thirst for military conquest, the full depth of the Soviet Union's economic troubles and the likelihood in 1982 that Israel would invade Lebanon.
But he argues, and many experts agree, that current suggestions that the C.I.A. simply overlooked the death throes of Communism are unwarranted. Although the agency did understate the crisis, the drift of Soviet politics and the likelihood of an upheaval in Eastern Europe were clear to analysts years before they climaxed in the late 1980's.
While the assertions sting, C.I.A. officials insist that their morale is high and that there is no shortage of espionage work to be done. What is missing, and has been since the first cracks in Communism's facade appeared in 1989, is a sense of purpose.
"We set up an intelligence apparatus in the 1940's for a specific purpose, to monitor a military and political challenge from the Soviet Union, a closed society," said one expert, a former intelligence official who advised the Government on espionage issues in the Gulf war. "It required us to stretch, to innovate, to do things we hadn't been capable of doing and to think in new ways. And we did it very well.
"When we were planning to meet this challenge, our assumption was that it would come in the form of war. But it didn't; it came in the form of peace. And we are basically unprepared to deal with it."
 
Agency's New Purpose
 Mr. Gates argued last week, and others agree, that the agency still has a purpose. It will now be freer to address concerns about rising military powers such as China and India and emerging security threats like nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking and foreign spying on American business and science.
Mr. Gates has said that his first order of business would be to prepare a new list of intelligence priorities for the next 15 years and then rebuild the C.I.A. around them.
"What's interesting now is to watch the shift from East-West conflict to North-South issues," one senior Administration intelligence official said in an interview. "Look at narcotics: The imagery technology" -- the use of satellite photographs -- "is the same as for spotting a Soviet missile silo. Our collection on the economic and social milieu in which drug trafficking survives, our analyses of trafficking organizations, are all on the same level that we use when analyze the enemy order of battle."
Mr. Gates's most urgent tasks, however, may be to rebuild confidence in the C.I.A. and to restore the image of integrity that Mr. Webster brought to the agency and which Mr. Gates's own confirmation hearings have damaged.
 
Obstacles Ahead
 He faces obstacles on several fronts. "Whatever his ability, his nomination was a terrible political judgment for Bush," said one official, in a comment typical of judgments about Mr. Gates's liabilities. "Casey's name still carries such a taint that it's difficult to believe that the President would nominate someone so closely associated with that era and expect it to sail through."
The same is true within the C.I.A., where Mr. Gates would begin with several black marks. His difficulties with the agency's intelligence analysts are now a matter of record. He may fare little better with the C.I.A.'s other major unit, its clandestine operations division, which has always viewed intelligence analysts with disdain. The first career analyst to be nominated to head the C.I.A., Mr. Gates is known for his dislike of covert actions.
Mr. Gates has already learned how closely his potential subordinates are watching his moves. After having made casual remarks about the reduced demand for analysis of Soviet conventional forces, he danced around the issue on Friday. "I have to be careful here. I got a call last night," he said."Now everybody in the theater forces division at C.I.A. is worried they're going to lose their jobs."

HEADLINE: Rocky Point Journal;
Students Are Sidelined By High Cost of Sports

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCKY POINT, L.I., Oct. 3

 BODY:
The soccer players are the lucky athletes at Rocky Point High School this fall. They still have teams -- even if their parents have to pay up to $340 a season so they can play.
But 200 other athletes are on the sidelines, victims of a nasty budget fight that has disrupted after-school routines for hundreds of students and has polarized this blue-collar Suffolk County community that was once generous with money for schools and sports. 
 "You have parents not talking to teachers, and relatives not talking to relatives," said Joe Spallina, a party store owner who paid $1,100 so his three teen-age sons could play soccer. "People are being belittled at board meetings. Friendships are breaking up."
The split occurred when voters here rejected the $25.4 million school budget in May and again last month because it included a 28.4 percent property tax increase, about $680 on the average assessed home. The vote meant the loss for now of the high school's yearbook, newspaper, drama club, math team, 220-member marching band, about three-dozen after-school clubs and much of the school bus system used by many of the Rocky Point School District's 2,600 pupils.
In past years, residents say, the school budget raised property taxes by 6 or 7 percent a year, which they were willing to pay. But with property taxes ranging from $3,500 to $5,000 a year and a deepening recession, residents were unwilling to support the new budget. Anti-budget posters popped up for the first time in recent memory on telephone poles. Foes staged rallies in parking lots of the mini-malls. Shouting matches erupted at Board of Education meetings.
"These aren't normal times -- 300 homes are for sale here," said Stephen Romano, the 38-year-old head of the main opposition group, Cease, which stands for Citizens for Economically Affordable Sound Education. "Guys are taking wage cuts, people are losing their jobs, taxes are ruining property values."
The Rocky Point School Superintendent, Dr. Ray V. Kwak, said the increase was necessary because New York State reduced education aid to Rocky Point by $1.6 million, to $10.8 million. After residents rejected the school budget, Dr. Kwak said, the school board decided to cut after-school programs, including salaries for coaches, placing the costs directly on those who participate.
To provide enough money for the sports programs and other after-school activities, Cease asked coaches and advisers to volunteer their time and appealed to teachers to give back half of their 8 percent pay increase for this year. Both refused, said Mr. Romano, whose group contends that other cuts could have been made in the budget.
"They haven't changed one thing one iota," Mr. Romano said. "They're still not listening to us. I don't know how they can be so insulated. We'll have to continue to hound them."
The fallout from the budget fight seemed most evident at Pizza Times, the after-school hangout near the high school. Many idle athletes in street clothes lingered about, while a few of the 105 boys and girls playing soccer grabbed snacks before games.
One victim of the budget defeat, a 10th-grade girl, said her parents could not afford the money for her to play soccer. "Now I just hang out or go to the handball courts and watch or go home and do my homework," she said. "We shouldn't have to pay for our sport if we want to play it."
A ninth-grade boy wanted to play soccer this fall and lacrosse in the spring. "But we'd have to pay nearly $1,000," he said. "So my parents said, 'Pick a sport.' I picked lacrosse."
Some residents worry about the stigma "pay to play" poses for the less affluent student-athlete.
"I don't want to see it perpetuated," said the high school athletic director, Dennis Desmond. "It becomes elitist, and only the best-off can play."
Although state education policy bars school boards from requiring students to pay fees for extracurricular programs -- on the theory that public education is free -- the practice is commonplace when voters reject school budgets.
Parents in school districts that cut extracurricular activites often skirt the state ban on such fees by collecting money and "donating" it to a high school. But this fall the costs per athlete have become too high for many parents here since the school board has refused to pay coaches' salaries. For instance, parents would have had to pay $610 for their child to play tennis, $400 for field hockey and $275 to run cross-country.
Pro-budget residents have gathered enough signatures on petitions to force a new vote on restoring $383,613 for winter and spring sports and all other extracurricular programs and $521,416 for the bus system. The vote will be on Wednesday.
Jim Colaneri, 60, said he would vote for both. But he said he wished that state law did not limit his voting options.
"What I'm really against is the overloading of administrators," Mr. Colaneri said. "Dump some of those guys with big salaries and you can pay for sports and buses."
Gene Waldman, 73, disagreed. "We're in a recession," he said. "Let the kids be like kids in Japan -- concentrate more on education and cut some of the sports out."

HEADLINE: Ghost of Reykjavik;
Soviets Are Not Just Shedding Arms, But an Emblem of Superpower Status

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Reading his response to President Bush's arms initiative on Saturday, Mikhail S. Gorbachev seemed unusually terse and solemn. The reason, perhaps, was that he was presiding not only over the dismantling of nuclear weapons, but also of his superpower.
It was, after all, Soviet nuclear arms that had confirmed the nation as a superpower and backed its claim to parity with the United States at the helm of world affairs. 
 The grand arms-control deals were always the glory of the Kremlin leaders. Sitting alongside an American President to sign pacts limiting strategic arms or issuing initiatives that transfixed the world, a Soviet leader was at the peak of power and influence.
It was no different for Mr. Gorbachev, and he tried bravely in his speech to reclaim some of that glory, suggesting perhaps one more summit meeting with President Bush and declaring that matched reductions really were descendants of the pioneering disarmament process started at the meeting with Ronald Reagan in Reykjavik back in 1986, at the glorious dawn of perestroika.
 
From Strength to Weakness
 Maybe the parallel reductions in tactical weapons announced by Mr. Bush a week ago and Mr. Gorbachev on Saturday night did derive from those earlier efforts, but in a way far different from whatever Mr. Gorbachev may have foreseen or wished.
The Reykjavik summit meeting, like those before and after it, was a meeting of the undisputed leaders of two indisputably great powers. The long and complex negotiations required to control or reduce nuclear arsenals in those days testified to the respect and fear each had for the other.
Yet the very processes Mr. Gorbachev set loose back in 1986 finally led to the abortive coup in August that sealed the collapse of Communism and the dismemberment of the old empire.
So this time, the driving force behind Mr. Bush's initiative was Soviet weakness, not strength. He could afford to withdraw most American tactical weapons from Europe not because of any elaborate arrangement with the Kremlin, but because a Soviet invasion of Europe was now implausible.
Moreover, Mr. Bush's readiness to act unilaterally was not a measure of trust in a Soviet land now free of Communists, but a measure of concern over a disintegrating superpower in which it was now unclear who really was in charge of nuclear weapons, or who would own them tomorrow.
And rather than negotiate, the Americans thought it was safer and simpler to lead by example, reckoning that the bankrupt remnants of the Soviet empire would have little choice but to follow suit.
This is not to say that the Soviet Union stands to lose its nuclear muscle. Mr. Gorbachev's pledge to reduce strategic warheads to 5,000 within seven years demonstrates that this is still a country with a vast and deadly arsenal that the world would long have to take into account.
Yet for the Soviets, that force is now more a burden than a shield, swallowing precious resources without yielding any discernible clout. In cutting armies and arsenals, Mr. Gorbachev was searching less for military security than for economic survival.
Some of Mr. Gorbachev's counterproposals to the Americans seemed only to underscore his plight. His declaration of a moratorium on nuclear tests, formerly a powerful propaganda weapon in Moscow's "peace campaign," reflected the fact that the armed forces have nowhere to test their weapons just now, when both the Russian federated republic and Kazakhstan oppose tests on their soil.
Mr. Gorbachev was also compelled to concede that he was no longer the paramount chief of his empire, stating at the outset of his address that the Russian republic's president, Boris N. Yeltsin, and the leaders of other republics had endorsed his action.
 
A Bold Response
 Yet none of that really detracted from the boldness or scope of Mr. Gorbachev's response. The world had never before experienced the dismantling of a nuclear superpower, and the fact that it was being undertaken peacefully, almost amicably, was ultimately a tribute to Mr. Gorbachev.
President Bush deserved credit as well. If the bankruptcy and breakup of their empire left the Soviets little choice but to radically reduce their armed might, Mr. Bush's initiative at least offered them a way to do it with dignity and without undue fear for their security.
And if Mr. Gorbachev was no longer in full control, the matching reductions in arms at least showed him to be the man with whom the West still has to deal. There was something almost wistful in Mr. Gorbachev's surprise call for a new summit with Mr. Bush -- "Obviously, the question also arises of a new Soviet-American summit meeting" -- as if a touch of the old bravado could still recoup the old glory.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
4th Generation Tries to Be Last In Welfare Chain

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
I told him, 'Look at you -- you was 18 when my mother got pregnant. How are you going to get on my case about having a baby?' It's like life repeats itself, you know?
Leticia C. will be 25 years old next month. She is a high school dropout, former crack addict and fourth generation teen-age mother. 
 She is also on welfare, like more than one in eight New York City residents. Statewide, relief rolls have hit a high; in New Jersey and Connecticut, they are growing again. Sometime soon, the city's welfare population is likely to surpass one million for the first time in 15 years. A million people standing in line could form an unbroken chain from New York to Washington.
I know he was very happy he had a baby, a little boy, but still he was wanting to do his own thing. He didn't want to grow up and face his responsibility.
Urban analysts once calculated the "tipping point" at which whites would flee an increasingly black and Hispanic school, neighborhood or city. But is there an economic tipping point, too -- at which there are not enough taxpayers of any racial or ethnic group left in a city to support the growing number of dependents?
All that New York City's one millionth welfare recipient can hope to win is sympathy. Even that, like hope itself, is becoming scarcer.
My father's mother had seven kids of her own. And she's raising another seven, cause her oldest daughter died and she had four daughters. And her other daughter's not doing so hot now from drugs either. So that makes another three. And her youngest son, Drake, her baby, he's in prison . . . They gave him 3 to 7 years about three years ago. And he's got two daughters now, cause he got married in jail. And his wife is having another baby. And they've broke up.
Each of Leticia's three children had a different father. She and her progenitors are profiled in "Before Their Time: Four Generations of Teen-Age Mothers" (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich), a nonjudgmental oral history by Joelle Sander, the associate director of continuing education at Sarah Lawrence College. When Mrs. Sander met them, Leticia (her real name) was 20 years old, her mother was 39, her grandmother was 63 and her great-grandmother was 83.
The recession has driven people to welfare, but the proportion of poor New Yorkers was rising even during the 1980's economic boom. If Leticia's testimony may be grist for some preconceptions about poverty, it is also evidence of why dependence has endured, what may shrink it, if only at the margins, and why a more ambitious commitment to do so may be beyond the capacity of any single city.
People make welfare seem so bad. I don't know why, but I don't feel it is. It's something to help you out for the time being until you're able to take care of yourself. It's true that there are some people who sit and wait for checks, who stay on welfare for years. But a lot of them do have children, and you can stay home until your child is six years old. Until your child goes to school and you can go to work. But I don't know how people can just live on welfare. They have to be getting money in somehow. They're doing something illegal or something, cause it's just not enough.
Lawrence Mead, a New York University political scientist, writes that job discrimination may be a lesser handicap than a broken family: "What matters for success is not whether your father was rich or poor but whether you had a father at all." Senator Daniel P. Moynihan estimates that five in six black and Hispanic children born in 1980 will be on welfare by age 20.
That night I saw Gavin, who is the father. His whole attitude changed. At the beginning of all this, he said, 'If it's my child, I'll help you pay for stuff.' But now he just said: 'You wanted a child. You kept her. Now it's your child.'
A new study by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation concludes that Ohio's Learning, Earning and Parenting program shows promise and potential savings. It focuses on teen-age parents, the group most likely to remain on welfare. It couples child care with financial incentives: For attending school regularly, a teen-ager who heads a household and has one child gets a $62 monthly bonus -- raising her welfare grant to $336. With too many unexcused absences, the grant can be cut to $212.
It's like what I tell Terry now. I say, 'I want to raise you to be a man that I would want to marry. Kindhearted. Understanding. Someone who would sympathize.' . . . He'd be able to compromise. Not get everything he wants. But I'm weird. I want a whole lot in a little bit of time.
Leticia is studying for a high school equivalency diploma again. She married a security guard and is seeking a job as a school crossing guard. In July, 7-year-old Terry was killed in an automobile accident. Leticia, who regained custody of her 4-year-old daughter after enrolling in a drug-treatment program, lives in Harlem with her husband. They have a 1-year-old daughter.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Plays Its Tax Card;
Hartford Fury Offers Big Payoffs and Risks

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 6

 BODY:
They gathered by the tens of thousands because they are enraged about the state's new income tax and mad about much else in Connecticut today.
The question they left behind for the Republicans, who organized what may have been the largest and angriest protest in modern state history, is whether members of Connecticut's all-but-perpetual minority party can ride the tax-repeal tiger they helped create, or whether they will be gobbled up too, along with every other politician. 
 Repeal leaders acknowledged today that the movement had taken on a life of its own and would probably go where it wished despite its handlers. The protesters are so numerous -- the police estimated that more than 1 percent of the state's population of 3.3 million jammed the Capitol lawn on Saturday -- and are angry about so many things, from working-class resentment toward the wealthy to frustration about the economy, that the ultimate expression of their anger is difficult to predict.
And there is another danger for the Republicans: What happens if the repeal effort succeeds?
 
Veto Fight Looms
 Lawmakers in both parties say a bipartisan majority in the legislature now stands ready to repeal the new income tax at a special session this month or next. But since Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has already said he will veto a repeal bill, regardless of the public mood, final victory or defeat for the repeal effort will really be determined by the vote to override that veto, which requires a two-thirds majority.
For the Republican leaders, the movement creates a predicament. If they win and the tax law is rescinded, the burden will be on them to come up with a budget that replaces nearly $1.5 billion in new income-tax revenues, probably through some unpopular combination of deep spending cuts and steep increases in other taxes, especially the sales tax.
Taxes were increased by $1.2 billion altogether under the new law, by far the biggest increase in state history. The increases were coupled with spending cuts in many areas, and more than 3,700 state workers are in line to be laid off even with the new revenues. Republican leaders say their alternative plan, which has not been fully worked out, will feature deeper spending cuts -- and possibly more layoffs -- than any budget yet contemplated.
If repeal succeeds, the Republicans will also lose what many politicians feel could be a devastating issue against the majority Democrats in the next statewide elections in 1992, when every member of the General Assembly is up for re-election and the public anger about the income tax could be tapped at the polling booths. Democrats in the General Assembly produced the majority of votes for the income tax.
 
Class Consciousness
 Until the passage of the income tax, the sentiments of the mainly middle- and working-class people represented at the rally had been more ably captured and articulated by Democrats in recent years -- notably by former Gov. William A. O'Neill, who squelched even the consideration of a wage tax. And many of the tirades against Mr. Weicker on Saturday centered on the fact that he is a rich man who protesters said did not understand middle-class concerns -- another mood that Democrats have tapped to their advantage.
But the crowd that seemed so ripe for the picking on Saturday could turn its rage on Republicans if voters come to believe that Republican orchestration of the repeal drive was just a cynical calculation, designed to fail but to promote party interests.
Repeal leaders said today that they realized the risks. They said that in self-defense they stood ready to openly attack any within their own ranks who might be considered less than zealous.
 
Two Missing Votes
 There was already evidence that members might soon be at each other's throats. A former Republican State Senator, Thomas Scott, who organized the rally and gave its keynote speech attacking the "craven deals in the gutter" that he said were used to ram the tax through the Legislature, has publicly questioned the commitment of the Republican leader in the House of Representatives, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr.
Mr. Krawiecki, a leading opponent of the income tax, allowed two of his party's members to go home on the day the tax was passed in August, thus removing two potentially pivotal "no" votes, and the decision has haunted him since. One of the lawmakers who missed the vote, Representative Robert J. Bogue, addressed the rally on Saturday and said in effect that he wouldn't get fooled again.
Mr. Krawiecki dismisses such talk. He said today that he knew of no Republicans who might secretly want repeal to fail so the issue could be used against the Democrats next year.
"I don't think it's the kind of an issue you can play games with," Mr. Krawiecki said. "The feelings run entirely too deep."
Both he and Mr. Scott said they believed the public anger against the income tax was so visceral that any alternative budget, almost regardless of how it was put together, would be more popular than the new a 4.5 percent flat-rate income tax.
Another unsettled question for the Republican Party is how successful its members will be in distancing themselves in voters' minds from Mr. Weicker, a third-party independent governor who proposed the tax early this year as the only alternative that would stimulate the economy and balance the budget. For more than 20 years, including three terms in the United States Senate, Mr. Weicker was one of the highest-profile Republicans in the state.
Party lines were further blurred during the budget deadlock as every alternative rose or fell on bipartisan votes.
The only consistent theme in the long battle since an income tax was first proposed has been discontent. United States Representative Gary A. Franks, a Republican from Waterbury, brought roars when he reminded protesters of Mr. Weicker's statement during last year's campaign for governor that imposing an income tax during a recession would be like pouring gasoline on a fire. He paused and looked out over the bristling sea of signs.
"Well, here's the fire!" he shouted.

HEADLINE: For 200 in the Tenzer Family, Grandpa's Circle Is Unbroken

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
In 1883, a 14-year-old youth named Michael Tenzer arrived in New York City from Europe with only $4 in his pocket and, even worse, not a scrap of family.
He soon made up for both, most strikingly with a clan of Biblical proportions, begetting seven children who produced 15 grandchildren, 32 great-grandchildren, and a fifth generation that now numbers 29. 
 What makes his story different from those of most other immigrant Americans is that his more than 200 descendants and other relatives have managed to stay in touch, even as they have scattered across much of America. They have done so through a little known but historically significant institution called the family circle or association, a phenomenon that began in the mid-19th century as families of the early American settlers found themselves dispersing ever westward.
 
Formality, Burials and Salami
 Experts say there are hundreds of these associations still functioning. Cutting across many ethnic groups, they hold regular meetings with parliamentary formality at which they assist faltering relatives, resolve family crises, arrange burial plots, trace clan history, and, in the case of Mr. Tenzer's family, dispense charity.
During World War II, for example, the Tenzers wrapped packages of salami and candy to send their sons fighting overseas, and they rescued dozens of relatives in Poland from the Nazis.
At a time when every day brings startling news of families sundered by violence and abuse, when nuclear families are dwindling almost as fast as nuclear weapons, the Michael Tenzer Family Circle has clung together. They have done so in a way that recalls a time when families had their social life, not in front of a television set or at nightclubs, but simply with each other.
So yesterday, 75 Tenzer relatives gathered in a midtown Manhattan kosher restaurant, Lou G. Siegel's, to celebrate the family circle's 65th anniversary and their enduring affection for one another.
"Not only do we have relatives, but our relatives are our very good friends," said Bernard Tenzer, a 70-year-old grandson of Michael.
Fred Wilson, a fourth-generation cousin, said: "You know your roots; you know the people who make up your family. "If you need help you know they're there."
As they sang the American and Israeli national anthems and lunched on stuffed cabbage and matzoh ball soup, they shared stories about the clan's stern but tender patriarch and the gentle matriarch, Rose. They marveled again at how vigorous the three surviving children, Eva Pion, 96, Estelle Schiff, 89, and Herbert Tenzer, 86, continue to be.
They remembered the Passover seders when 50 relatives, living within blocks of each other in Crown Heights and Flatbush, would crowd into a Brooklyn apartment, and a scorching glance from Grandpa Michael would silence all mischief.
They remembered how Grandpa would teach them to count "onezer, twozer, threezer" all the way to "tenzer," the number that always drew delighted cheers. They remembered how Grandma Rose would bake challahs -- braided Sabbath loaves -- for each of her children every week and insist they go to her house to pick them up as another pretext to see them.
"There wasn't a weekend we didn't go to Grandpa's and Grandma's," said Bernard Tenzer. "Those brothers and sisters were inseparable. It was almost incestuous. All of their social life was in each other's houses."
 
Virtues and Eccentricities
 The family stories, capturing the virtues and eccentricities of their relatives, have served to thicken the family bond, even if some have been considerably embroidered with time.
The monthly family circle meetings were carried out with near-Congressional protocol. There was a salute to the American flag and the reading of minutes. There were officers, including a sergeant-at-arms who disciplined unruly children. There were dues -- at first $5, now $10 -- that along with bequests and funds raised through parties added up to thousands of dollars, which was dispensed to organizations like the Jewish National Fund and Fight for Sight. And there was a periodic newsletter, the Standard Bearer, currently edited by Estelle Schiff, that kept everyone informed about weddings, illnesses and deaths.
With nourishment from Aunt Eva's and Aunt Estelle's sandwiches of egg salad and tuna salad, there were also games of pinochle and gin rummy, funny hat parties and shows produced by the children, who met separately in a family "junior league."
"It was to make sure that the children inherited the sense of family," said Bernard's wife, Shelley Kitzes Tenzer. "Naturally, it doesn't happen. You have to get together and do things as a family."
 
A Circle for Vanderbilts
 Mrs. Tenzer comes from a family circle herself. Indeed, there are hundreds of family circles, says Harry Macy, information director for the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society, including one for the descendants of Cornelius Vanderbilt, the railroad magnate. A family circle was a chief motif in the recent film "Avalon," about an immigrant clan.
"I think it helps present-day descendants know where they came from and what their connection is to this country," Mr. Macy said. "So many Americans live an essentially rootless existence."
Bernard Tenzer, who was president of his circle for 16 years, suggested that his family's experience could serve as a model for the current wave of immigrants from Latin America and Asia, though some groups like the Chinese have long sustained such associations here.
"For family units to be tied together they have to work at it," he said.
 
Humble Origins in Poland
 Many active family circles have origins as humble as that of Michael Tenzer's. A sturdily built man with penetrating eyes, who was born missing a left ear, he was born in the Polish region of Galicia that was then under Austrian rule. Some relatives claim he fled to the United States to escape the draft; others say it was to elude rabbinical school. One version says he left a sealed note to his Orthodox Jewish parents on a Friday before sundown because he knew they could not open the note until after the Sabbath.
In this country, his daughter Eva recalls, he peddled bobby pins, needles and combs from a back pack, climbing flights of stairs to earn pennies to buy a herring and a piece of bread. He met Rose because she was the daughter of a family with whom he roomed.
Soon Michael and Rose were able to open a small candy stand, and it eventually burgeoned into a prosperous wholesale candy business run out of a tenement at 191 Broome Street on the Lower East Side. Family legend has it that Michael Tenzer once loaned Milton Hershey $1,000 to start making chocolate bars. But the family also knows that Michael eventually lost much of his fortune.
The family circle was born at Eva Tenzer Pion's 10th wedding anniversary in 1927, which she celebrated, of course, with her entire family.
 
Charity, Not Just Lunch
 "We decided it was such a lovely gathering that we ought to have a family circle," Eva Pion remembered.
Michael Tenzer had always emphasized charity. He was a founder of a Lower East Side synagogue, Chasam Sopher, and Yeshiva Talmud Torah of Crown Heights, and, his children say, as the landlord of six buildings he deliberately slipped part of the rents back so tenants could buy food. So the Tenzer children decided charity would be the circle's mission.
"We weren't wasting our time just getting together and having lunch or dinner," Eva Pion said.
The family ethos stuck. At 96, Eva Pion is a volunteer clerk at the library of the Peninsula Hospital Center in Far Rockaway. Herbert Tenzer, who was a Congressman from Long Island, has a been a leading philanthropist for institutions like Yeshiva University.
The numbers of circle meetings, held in recent years at the America-Israel Friendship League in midtown Manhattan, have dwindled from monthly to three or four a year as more members, heeding the call of marriage or career, have settled in places like Wisconsin and Alaska. Robert S. Herbst, a 33-year-old Manhattan lawyer who is a fourth-generation cousin, points out that with the tribe's growing affluence and education, "we don't need the support of family because people are making it on their own."
And Eva, who has a great-granddaughter at Brown University and a great-grandson at Vassar, lamented: "Unfortunately the younger generation is not as interested. They have the time, but they devote their time to other things."
But at the celebration yesterday, relatives like Mr. Herbst and Gloria Batkin Kahn, a Westchester psychologist, suggested that they would work to keep the circle going. Beyond necessity and economics, Ms. Kahn said, it's simply "good to have cousins and family around."
Mr. Herbst added: "I have my wife, my friends. I watch the Giants on Sunday. Life goes on without it. But it's a treat to have something like this."

HEADLINE: To Avoid Deficit, Michigan Ends Welfare to Some Adults

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 4

 BODY:
For Ruth Williams, a middle-age grandmother who says she has asthma, high blood pressure and phlebitis, the welfare check for $87.50 she received twice a month from the State of Michigan "was like a life raft."
"I'm poor, very poor" she said. "The check wasn't much, but it gave me a chance to feel like a human being." 
 On Tuesday, the checks stopped coming.
Faced with a budget deficit and hoping to end "welfare dependency," the State Legislature eliminated the general assistance welfare program for more than 80,000 adults who are so poor that they can typically have no more than a car worth $1,500.
 
Aid for Able-Bodied
 Most states have some form of general assistance welfare program for poor, able-bodied adults without children. Now Michigan, after years of providing some of the nation's broadest welfare coverage, has rescinded welfare benefits for such people, joining a small but growing number of states that deny them aid.
"We don't have the money to pay for everything anymore," said John Truscott, a spokesman for Gov. John Engler, a Republican. "And it's forcing us to make some very painful and difficult decisions."
It is a refrain that can be heard across the country. Next month, Maryland, faced with budget problems of its own, will also eliminate its general assistance program, cutting off payments to 24,000 adults.
Many recipients of general assistance, experts on welfare issues say, are the walking wounded of society. They fall through the cracks of other programs; either they are too young for Social Security or too healthy for disability. They are often homeless, and many have been in and out of mental institutions or drug treatment centers.
Typically, recipients are single men with poor educations and few job skills, the experts say. But in Michigan, 46 percent of the recipients were women, many of them divorced or widowed homemakers in their 40's and 50's.
 
'Program of Last Resort'
 As the economy darkens, many recipients are low-level workers, like Richard Burnell, 49 years old, a Detroit florist's assistant, who have lost their jobs and have exhausted unemployment benefits.
"A lot of people coming into welfare offices are people who have never been on aid before," said Julie Strawn of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a not-for-profit research organization in Washington. "They're not necessarily all people who fit public sterotypes. But I don't think the public really understands how important G.A. is as the program of last resort. There is nothing else for people when G.A. goes away. Nothing."
Governor Engler's Administration, which pressed for the elimination of the general assistance program, repeatedly uses the words "able-bodied" and "employable" to describe those who have been taken from the welfare rolls. But Mr. Truscott acknowledged that not all recipients fit into those categories; he said several thousand former aid recipients could start receiving checks again if they were determined by a doctor or psychiatrist to be physically or mentally unable to work. The state's average monthly payment for general assistance was $144 plus food stamps.
New Jersey's general assistance program provides a maximum income of $270 a month, said Winnie Comfort, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Human Services. If the recipient is employable, job searches and, in some cases, training are offered.
New York State's program, called home relief, provides up to $352 a month, said Patricia Smith, deputy commissioner for income support programs. If eligible, a person can also receive additional food stamps of about $100. Most can also receive medical benefits, she said.
 
No Programs in 6 States
 Before Michigan and Maryland eliminated their general assistance programs, the Federal Health and Human Services in 1990 listed six states that deny all benefits to single adults: Arkansas, Oklahoma, Texas, Tennessee, West Virginia and Louisiana. In the last year, several other states have debated reducing their welfare programs. Illinois and Ohio have either cut or limited their general assistance programs to reduce costs and to help balance state budgets. And in Massachusetts this spring, the Legislature overhauled its general relief program and significantly reduced its scope. Officials there are still haggling over the program's budget but it appears it will be reduced by nearly $60 million, to $160 million from $220 million.
Ending the program in Michigan is expected to save the state $240 million. In addition, the Legislature, in which Democrats control the House and Republicans the Senate, cut $260 million from other social service programs.
Saving money is only one motive for eliminating the general assistance program, which has long long been a target of conservatives. Mr. Truscott said the Governor hoped to end "welfare dependency" by forcing "thousands of able-bodied people to find work."
"The jobs are out there," he said. "They may be minimum wage, but most people will be able to find one. And if they work full time at just minimum wage they could make twice as much as they did on G.A."
Currently, there are more than 400,000 unemployed people in Michigan, a rate of 9.7 percent.
 
Adding to Those Seeking Work
 "The state has just increased the number of people looking for work by a fourth," said Sharon Parks of the Michigan League of Human Services in Lansing. "And this is during a recession when jobs are scarce. It's crazy."
The public perception of general assistance, Mrs. Parks said, is of welfare rolls filled with able-bodied people too lazy to work.
State Representative David Jaye, Republican of Shelby Township, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying: "The most important thing is we took $300 million out of welfare for single, healthy employable adults and said, 'Get a job or hit the road, Jack.' We can't afford it anymore. These people are going to have to go cold turkey."
Of the more than 80,000 Michigan residents who lost their benefits on Tuesday, only about half had completed high school. They come from all racial and ethnic backgrounds and from farms as well as cities. Forty percent are more than 40 years old. Nearly half live in Detroit but have limited access to transportation to travel to job-rich suburbs. Sixty-one percent have never worked, many of them newly widowed or divorced who did not work because their husbands did.
"To call these people employable when there are so many educated people unable to find a job is insane," said Ed Rowe, the pastor of Cass Community United Methodist Church. "It's a lie. The real reason this is happening is that the poor are powerless."
Down the street from the church, one door down from a plasma center where type AB negative blood, a relatively rare type, will fetch $15 to $20 a pint, Jessi Young, a former welfare recipient, stood in a dimly lit homeless shelter and watched the place fill up with men, women and children.
"You think it's crowded now?" he said. "Wait a couple of days. Then it'll be packed because of these cuts. We can spend a trillion dollars fighting a war in some third world country
Mr. Young, 40, dropped out of school after the 10th grade. He said he had a ruptured disc in his back from a work accident in 1973 and a steel plate in his left hip after he was shot by a stray bullet a few years ago.
"With my present-day education, I guess I could get a job distributing hand bills," he said. "Cutting grass, washing windows. This is a slow death."
Mr. Young and his family moved to Detroit from Mississippi when he was a baby. His father had a third-grade education but quickly found a job at the General Motors Corporation, where he stayed for 40 years.
"Those days are gone, long, long gone," Mr. Young said. "Those jobs are gone. Robots do that work now."
Evert Vermeer, director of social services in Kent County in western Michigan, said it was too early to judge the full impact of ending the general assistance program. He said more than half of the 90,000 recipients were "hirable, if there was anything out there for them to get."
"There isn't," he said from his Grand Rapids office.
On the streets of a dilapidated Detroit neighborhood, Cass Corridor, the other day, rumors were running fast about evictions from apartments and about former welfare recipients slitting their wrists to avoid becoming homeless again.
People say they are selling their foods stamps to pay telephone bills and rent. Others mumble about "doing whatever it takes to survive."
Shirley Johns, director of the Community Service and Referral Center in Lansing, recently told the A.P. the advice she gives to those left without food or shelter: "I tell them to commit a simple larceny. Especially if they're sick, I tell them to do that. I explain to them it's a roof over their head. It's free food, free medical treatment for their pneumonia."
As a drizzle fell over the city, Mrs. Williams and several other former recipients talked about "how we're ever going to survive without G.A."
"I'm going to pray," Mrs. Williams said. "I'm also going to fight back. I'm willing to go to jail over and over until we get treated right. G. A. was all we had to get by."
Joyce Pelcher, 62, said: "If I have to, I'll sell my food stamps to pay my rent. Then when I run out, I'll go to the mission to eat."
"No, you won't," Mrs. Williams said. "The missions are turning people away. The missions are closing, too."

Richard Burnell, left, and Jessi Young are two unemployed workers who were cut from the program. (Photographs by Tracy Baker for The New York Times) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
That Championship Feeling!

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 6

 BODY:
As a hushed crowd sat primly in anticipation of the Southeastern Savoyards Light Opera Company's performance of "H.M.S. Pinafore" Saturday night, the music director, in white tie and tails, turned to the orchestra and raised not a baton, but a tomahawk.
In Atlanta, where gleeful crowds lined Peachtree Street this weekend exchanging Indian war chants and the Braves' signature "tomahawk chop" salute with passing cars, nothing is immune from the giddy euphoria set loose by the Atlanta Braves' unlikely ascent from perennial doormats to National League West champions. 
 But in addition to celebrating this journey from worst to first, which was completed Saturday afternoon when the Braves won and the Dodgers lost, Atlanta is in no small way celebrating itself. From Tara to tomahawks, from the prospect of the 1994 Super Bowl to that of the 1996 Olympics, Atlanta is reveling in its sense of itself as a city that's on a winning streak like that of no other place in the country.
"It seems like everything keeps happening here," Gary Laboda said this afternoon as he lounged in the back of his 1974 Chevrolet pickup truck, which was painted in Braves slogans and equipped with two plastic-foam tomahawks, before the Braves' regular-season finale, a loss to the Houston Astros. "All this money, fame and excitement has to be good for a city. It has to be real good."
Or, as John Sherman, a 21-year-old Georgia Tech student who joined a group of Saturday night revelers, many of them in headdresses and war paint, immodestly put it: "Atlanta is the center of the universe."
Truth to tell, the economy here is shaky, the crime rate is consistently among the nation's highest, and the bright image often masks one of the nation's poorest central cities.
But if, as the ad says, "Image Is Everything," Atlanta seems to have hit yet another home run in a remarkable two-year winning streak. The immediate cause of the most recent outbreak of fever was the Braves' feat of becoming the second team this century to go from the worst record in baseball one year to a division championship the next. The other team, the Minnesota Twins, also did it this year.
The Braves did it despite losing two of their best hitters, David Justice and Sid Bream, to injuries for most of the summer, and their leadoff man, Otis Nixon, for the season's last three weeks after he was suspended for drug use.
It was a feat sweetened by its coming at the expense of haughty and hated Los Angeles and accented by the euphoric support of fans starved for a winner. Even players seemed a bit taken aback by it all.
 
'Want It to Go On Forever'
 "It's hard to believe the season's over," second baseman Mark Lemke said as he listened to a packed house roaring in glee during batting practice on a crisp fall afternoon today. "This season has been so special, you want it to go on forever."
Much of the excitement is attributable to the travails of the long-suffering Braves, who have yet to win a post-season game in 26 seasons in Atlanta and went into the regular season with the worst record in baseball for that period. The combination of past futility and ever-more-elaborate tribal pageantry transformed baseball here from a game to an event.
"This has been incomparable; I've never seen anything like it," said John Schuerholz, the Braves' general manager, who has received much of the credit for putting a winner together and who was general manager in Kansas City when the Royals twice went to the World Series in the 1980's. "The fans in Kansas City were great fans, I don't want to put them down, but I can't imagine any fans being more emotional or more demonstrative than the fans here have been this year."
 
Talk of the Town
 Atlanta has always had a particular interest in the national spotlight.
Last week, topic A was "Scarlett" fever, the excitement brought on by the publication of the best-selling sequel to "Gone With The Wind." The local news is still dominated by plans for the Olympics, and the city has also been chosen as host for the 1994 Super Bowl.
"It's very much a part of the whole booster ideal," said Dana White, an urban historian at Emory University. "Back in the 19th century when Atlanta was a city of a few thousand people, it was comparing itself with New York or Chicago, and it goes on from there. Atlanta has always had a history of setting a goal that seems unachievable and then managing to achieve it."
But White says that more relevant than the expectations of the past century is probably a history of entrepreneurial success dating back to the years after World War II. In that sense, the excitement of the last two years is mostly an extension of the progress made in that era.
 
Here Come the Tomahawks
 He notes that recent surveys had found a substantial degree of economic pessimism, which indicates that sports and cultural events can only go so far in shaping the public mood.
But for now, the main number that seems to matter in town is 8:39, Oct. 9. That's when the Braves will take on the Pirates in Game 1 of the National League playoffs in Pittsburgh.
Atlanta has never had a team go the World Series, the Super Bowl or the National Basketball Association finals. But for now, in a city where grown men find themselves doing a goofy tomahawk version of the hokeypokey, anything seems possible.
The most difficult thing may be holding on to a good war bonnet.
"I bought about 10 of them at Toys 'R' Us for $4," said John Fitts, a student at Georgia State University. "People keep grabbing them away. They see feathers and they go crazy."

HEADLINE: More Vision, Please

BYLINE: By Joseph R. Biden; Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, is chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on European Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev, with Boris Yeltsin's backing, took only a week to match President Bush's cuts in nuclear arms and up the ante. We should not hesitate to raise the stakes even higher. Unlike poker, this is a game both sides can win.
For all President Bush's new thinking on short-range nuclear weapons, his proposal reflected a large dose of old thinking about intercontinental missiles and "Star Wars" -- and not enough thinking about a world order free of Armageddon arsenals and third-world nuclear threats. 
 The President said we should "dramatically shrink" the world's nuclear arsenals and "effectively discourage the spread" of nuclear arms. But this will require us to abandon policies to which the Administration still clings.
Having jettisoned tactical weapons as obsolete, the Bush team resists applying similar logic elsewhere. The current treaty permits each side 9,000 strategic warheads -- far more than most experts think deterrence requires. With Moscow ready to halve these levels, Washington can no longer spurn talk of radical cutbacks.
So far, the Administration has focused on an old priority -- "crisis stability" for rivals poised for mutual annihilation. It stresses cuts in land-based intercontinental missiles with multiple warheads, the area of Soviet strength. It claims exemption for sea-based missiles and bombers, including the extravagantly expensive B-2, which dominate the U.S. arsenal. It rejects a test ban as incompatible with the need for improving nuclear warheads. And it continues promoting the anti-missile defenses, which even in a cooperative climate are a barrier to cuts in offensive arms.
Why hasn't the President matched his revolutionary rhetoric with new strategic policies? Several reasons explain his reluctance:
Post-cold war defense cuts would eliminate jobs; Defense Secretary Dick Cheney spoke volumes last week when he inadvertently touted the B-2 as carrying a huge "payroll." The Pentagon is still geared to using nuclear weapons in war, despite the disappearance of the Soviet threat and the success of conventional power against Iraq. The cold war acclimated us to the perverse premise that superpower status depends on maintaining a capacity to eradicate civilization, even at the expense of American economic strength. Proponents of Star Wars have sold a beguiling technical fix to a new problem -- horrifying weapons wielded by irrational third-world despots -- that realistically can only be solved through collective economic and military containment.
These mind-sets must go if we are to spur deeper cuts in Soviet arms, revamp our budget and shape a new international security system.
How should we proceed with the Gorbachev-Yeltsin team?
First, the U.S. must make clear that all strategic arms, including submarine-launched missiles and missile defenses, are negotiable to the lowest level compatible with deterrence. To bypass military bureaucracies, we should appoint a joint commission of U.S. and Soviet experts to develop an answer to the question: how low can we safely go?
Second, we should involve the British, French and Chinese. A five-power conference should commit all to deep cuts, a ban on nuclear testing and producing new fissionable material and a U.N.-backed nonproliferation regime.
Third, we must build on the success of the nonproliferation treaty, which has worked but for a few rogue states like Iraq, North Korea and Libya. Global limits on ballistic missiles can supplement the treaty's constraints, and nuclear states such as India and Pakistan can be pressured to adhere. Rigorous U.N. enforcement would include severe economic sanctions and, where necessary, military action.
The key is China, which just pledged to join the nonproliferation treaty but has indiscriminately sold nuclear and missile technology. The test of President Bush's commitment will be his use of all available tools, including trade sanctions, to insure Beijing's cooperation.
When Mr. Gorbachev's launch-code briefcase was seized during the failed coup, one nuclear age ended and another began. In disassembling the Doomsday Machine, we can shape a containment policy directed against third-world nuclear dangers. It will take vision to lead the journey into this new nuclear age.
