HEADLINE: Another Blow to Westinghouse

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
For the second time this year, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has taken a major write-off as a result of real estate problems in its financial-services subsidiary. The company said yesterday that because of write-offs it had a net loss of $1.48 billion in the third quarter.
The company, based in Pittsburgh, also said it would eliminate 4,000 jobs from its work force of approximately 115,000. 
 Westinghouse's chairman, Paul E. Lego, termed the company's performance "disappointing." In an interview, Mr. Lego said the large amounts of real estate being sold at low prices by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency responsible for the savings and loan bailout, and tight credit conditions were forcing the company to sharply reduce the value of properties held by its credit subsidiary.
 
Writing Off $1.68 Billion
 The company said the write-off of $1.68 billion represented the reduction in value of its investments in real estate, leveraged buyouts and junk bonds. Earlier this year it cut the value of those investments by $975 million. The total value of the portfolio was listed at $22.03 billion at the end of 1990. In addition, Westinghouse took a write-off of $160 million to cover the cost of the job cutbacks.
Analysts said they had expected some kind of announcement, since the company had recently canceled a longstanding meeting with securities analysts. But some analysts said the size of the write-off had come as something of a shock.
"We have been surprised by the magnitude of the real estate depression," said Kemp Fuller Jr., who is with Baird, Patrick & Company. But he said the company had "put behind it as much as it is possible to put behind at this time."
In the interview, Mr Lego said: "We have not been able to do anything with real estate. There is no market and no third-party lending."
The write-off, he said, was a "decisive action" that would demonstrate to investors and rating agencies that "there is a reserve level sufficient to deal with the problems at the financial-services unit."
Mr. Lego said he hoped the real estate write-off would "put this behind us, and allow me to focus on the rest of the business."
The announcement was made before 9 A.M. yesterday, and trading in Westinghouse shares was delayed when the New York Stock Exchange opened at 9:30. When the stock opened at 10:17, it traded initially at $20.375, down $1.375 from Friday's close. It closed at $19.125, down $2.625.
After the announcement, Fitch Investors Service, a small rating agency, said it might downgrade its ratings for debt issued by Westinghouse and its credit subsidiary.
 
Trying to Raise Cash
 Mr. Lego said the company planned to bolster its cash position by selling $900 million in new equity, probably preferred or convertible shares, and by contributing $400 million in stock, rather than cash, to the corporate pension fund this year and next. Other employee programs, which he did not specify, will also be financed with stock rather than cash. Mr. Lego said the stock sale would result in dilution of less than 10 percent to earnings per share in 1992.
The quarterly loss came on revenues of $3.43 billion. It contrasts to earnings of $255 million, or 87 cents a share, on revenues of $3.18 billion in the third quarter of 1990.
Although real estate woes dominated the earnings report, other segments of the company's business reported problems as well. Operating profits at the broadcast division, which includes television stations in Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Pittsburgh and San Francisco, were reported to be "down substantially" because of reduced advertising as a result of the recession and the Persian Gulf war.
 
Other Troubled Sectors
 The company's environmental group also reported reduced profits, citing cost overruns in the construction of trash-burning plants. Operating profits were "down substantially" at the industries segment, which produces refrigeration and power distribution equipment. Similarly, earnings were "slightly lower" in the electric power generating machinery division because of reduced income from licensing and plant completions.
One bright spot was the company's Knoll Group, which makes office furniture. It reported profits were "up slightly" in the quarter and "substantially higher" in the nine months.
The company said Leo W. Yochum, who retired in 1988 as senior executive vice president for finance, would return as the chairman of the Westinghouse Financial Services Inc. subsidiary. Mr. Yochum, who is 64 years old, replaces William A. Powe, who was named a special consultant to the corporation

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul E. Lego, the chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. (Fred Vuich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Garment Makers Come Home

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The clothing racks at Macy's, Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue are more and more often showing off an unfamiliar tag: "Made in the U.S.A."
Apparel industry economists say about 50 percent of the clothing sold in the United States is made abroad, and in some segments, like women's garments, manufacturing is almost exclusively done overseas. 
 But slowly, some manufacturers of dresses, suits and blouses who fled the United States in the 1960's and 1970's for Hong Kong, China, South Korea and Taiwan in search of cheap labor are moving operations to Manhattan, Maine and North Carolina.
So far, the shift is imperceptible in the statistics collected by the American Apparel Manufacturing Association. And experts doubt that the spurt in domestic production will radically rewrite the history of American apparel manufacturing.
But more apparel makers are producing goods here thanks to an uncertain political outlook, especially in Hong Kong, increased labor costs in East Asia, some signs of poor workmanship and the growing complexities of moving goods quickly from half a world away.
"The numbers certainly don't reflect this, but I know there's a lot of talk about it being done," said Carl H. Priestland, chief economist for the manufacturers' association. "The Limited, the Gap and Esprit have all been saying they want to source more domestically." The Gap, in fact, has found that it can buy American-made men's pants for about the same price as those from Hong Kong.
Developments in America, ranging from growing pools of immigrant Asian laborers in cities like New York to leaner inventory management by retailers have made it convenient and profitable to sew garments in the United States.
Also, an influx of Asian immigrants from Hong Kong has provided a pool of skilled labor that works for low wages. Many American retailers have adopted "just-in-time" inventory controls to improve efficiencies and reduce costly inventories. That has made ordering and shipping from Asia cumbersome, especially when consumer moods swing sharply or goods arrive with flaws and need to be returned for corrections.
"Right now, Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan are very expensive -- for labor, for quotas, for import duties," said Wai Yuen-Shek, a transplanted Hong Kong native who says his five garment factories in New York are swamped with orders through the end of the year. "Manufacturers that used to take up three, four floors of a factory in Hong Kong are now shrinking, shrinking, shrinking to one floor or half a floor."
Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller, which makes women's ready-to-wear clothing sold in stores like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's, started to move manufacturing back to the United States in 1986. Virtually all dresses and suits bearing the label are now made in factories in Philadelphia and New York.
 
'Doomed to Overbuying'
 Mr. Konheim said making garments here enabled him to price them competitively. "Everybody contracting in Hong Kong is projecting three and four months ahead of time, which means they're almost always doomed to overbuying," he said. "The cost of that kind of inefficient guesswork is what has led to this phony price structure with guaranteed markdowns that we have now."
Two years ago, almost all of the children's clothing sold by Albert and Tina Betesh, founders of the Choozie Wear Corporation in New York, was made in Hong Kong, China and Taiwan. Today, 35 percent comes from places like Greensboro, N.C., and Sylvester, Ga. The quality still needs to be improved, Mr. Betesh said, "but we're willing to stick with it; there are just too many uncontrollable factors in overseas production."
Making clothes in the United States is problematic for other reasons. Labor costs are still high and the cost of some kinds of goods produced here still surpasses the cost of making and shipping goods from Asia or the Caribbean. Also, the doubts about American quality persist.
 
Aging Sewing Machine Operators
 "We're always looking for more production here, but I can't find labor in the United States for quality and for price," said Ely Barsel, president of the Arenzano Trading Company of New York, which makes suits under the Oleg Cassini and Richard Neal labels. "The average age of sewing machine operators is between 60 and 70, so I question whether it's within the realm of possibility to bring the sewing end of the garment business back into the United States in any full force."
Mr. Barsel and other apparel makers predict that eventually some of those manufacturers who have recently transferred their production to the United States will move it again, to places like the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico.
Mr. Barsel said the labor costs of making a jacket in Hialeah, Fla., where he has a cutting factory, are $18.50, while in Central America it costs about $6. Even with import duties and transportation, the jacket made there costs only $11.
At this stage the unions representing laborers in American apparel factories are not likely to see a sudden jump in their declining membership because technological advances in manufacturing, like computerized cutting and pattern-marking, will continue to displace workers, said Bruce G. Herman, president of the Garment Industry Development Corporation, a nonprofit company created by the industry's leading trade associations and unions.
 
A Caribbean Connection
 Mr. Barsel's company, like many others, manufactures women's clothes in the Caribbean under a Federal law that allows American contractors to ship cut pieces to offshore factories for assembly and pay duty only on the cost of assembly, which is cheaper there.
But Mr. Wai and his partner, Zee Wai-Chu, said that even though they were considering a joint venture with a factory in the Dominican Republic, the quality of the goods produced in Central America continued to be unpredictable and in many cases far below that in the United States.
As manufacturing flows back to the United States from the Far East, competition for America's remaining textile mills and sewing factories has heated up. Indeed, many manufacturers interviewed declined to give the location of their contractors because they fear others would bid up the price for those services.
Thomas F. Gayer, vice president of the Euro-American Textiles Corporation in New York, said that two small mills that do contract work for his company were investing millions of dollars to retooling factories and that Japanese and German companies were investing in American mills.
 
More American-Made Fabric
 In the last two years, Euro-American increased its volume of American-made fabric to $25 million, from $3 million, while European manufacturing dropped to 78 percent.
"By moving our production to the U.S., we have tighter quality control and shorter turnarounds," Mr. Gayer said. "It just made sense."
Beleaguered lenders, fearful of bankruptcies among garment industry customers, are indirectly causing some garment making to return from Asia by limiting the letters of credit used in international trade. David Gurwitz, president of the National Looms Corporation, a New York-based company that makes fabrics knitted and woven with Lycra, said the business he and his partners bought two years ago had doubled its sales in a year thanks to increased demand for American-made textiles.
"Clearly a lot of our clients have been affected by the shortage of credit available from a smaller credit-granting community," he said. "In addition to the worsened banking environment, the factoring community that finances apparel manufacturing is one-third the size of what it used to be."
 
A Decline in Quality
 Dealing with manufacturers in the Far East has long been complicated, and has grown more so as quality has fallen off. When apparel was delivered in shoddy condition, with crooked seams, poorly finished buttonholes or other problems, correcting the problems almost always meant returning the goods to the factory, a time-consuming process. Often, by the time the garments are returned from the factory, the season for selling them is nearly over and the clothes must be marked down.
The Limited, whose $5 billion in annual sales is generated largely by inexpensive clothing made in the Far East, is one of the largest buyers of apparel made in Asia, and it recently blamed poor-quality goods for its lackluster sales.
Workers in one of Mr. Wai's New York factories were repairing belts made by a Chinese contractor that were shipped twice as long as ordered and with the holes incorrectly punched in the middle instead of near the end of the belt. "You see the problems," he said.
 
Long-Range Commitments
 Several companies complain that they must place orders far in advance to overseas suppliers. A manufacturer whose garments are made in Hong Kong must commit to an order four to six months in advance, compared with a few weeks or even days for American-based companies.
"If you're producing domestically, you have the ability to knock out another 6 or 8 or 50 dresses within days," said Liz Goldsmith, vice president of sales and marketing for Dennis Goldsmith International Inc., a dress maker based in New York.
Retailers caught with bloated inventories during the recession are placing minimal orders to avoid markdowns. But they also want to be able to reorder garments if they sell well, and many have installed elaborate computer systems to tell them precisely what is in demand.
 
Need to Reorder Quickly
 "The retailer now knows precisely what's going out the front door, and he wants to be able to punch a button and tell the manufacturer, 'George, send 2,000 more T-shirts in tomato red right away,' " said Mr. Priestland of the manufacturers association.
The financial advantages of manufacturing in the United States have accomplished what the textile industry and labor unions sought for years with millions of dollars in advertising to American consumers to buy clothing, towels and other soft goods with the "Made in the U.S.A." label. But, manufacturers and industry analysts say, the recent return of some apparel making to onshore factories is purely a financial expedient.
"That campaign has not worked," said Alan G. Millstein, publisher of the Fashion Network Report. "What manufacturing is coming back is coming back because many people lack the financial resources to put out the letters of credit you need to order in Hong Kong and China."

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall Amid Concern Over Earnings

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Amid continued investor concern over corporate earnings, accentuated by Westinghouse Electric's news of a third-quarter net loss of $1.48 billion, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.01 points yesterday, to 2,942.75. Westinghouse is a Dow component.
"Without more interest rate cuts, the market must rely more on the outlook for profits," said Joseph Battipaglia, director of research at the Gruntal Company. "And seeing that outlook dim has given rise to the recent selloff in the market." 
 Mr. Battipaglia added: "The Fed has already given the market several months of lower interest rates, with expectations of an increase in housing and consumer spending. As a result businesses would begin to replenish inventories to meet new demand. But this has not happened because business activity has not picked up significantly. Consumers are paying down debt rather than using more of it. Hence, the recovery expectations for the second half of this year, have been dashed."
 
500-Stock Index Off
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was off 1.74, to 379.50, while the New York Stock Exchange composite slipped 1.06, to 209.16.
Volume on the Big Board was 148.5 million shares, down from 164.1 million shares traded on Friday, with losing issues outpacing gainers by a ratio of 2 to 1.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite fell 4.20, to 516.20, and the American Stock Exchange composite declined by 2.45, to 369.02.
By midday the market had settled at the low end of a tight trading range, with market participants saying that it may be approaching an oversold position, opening up some buying opportunities. Other traders, however, feared that if the Dow falls below 2,910, institutional selling will increase significantly.
National Medical Enterprises was the most heavily traded stock following newspaper articles about investigations into the company's aggressive efforts to recruit patients to collect health insurance payments. The company confirmed the reports in a statement, saying that its Psychiatric Institutes of America unit was under investigation in Florida, Texas and New Jersey and that it was cooperating fully with the authorities, as well as conducting its own internal investigation. The stock closed down 4 1/8, to 16 1/8.
Westinghouse Electric fell 2 5/8, to 19 1/8. The company in announcing its loss, which it attributed to a weak real estate market, said it planned to issue $900 million in equity. Trading was suspended for a half-hour following the dissemination of the news. General Electric, which has a huge finance arm like that of Westinghouse, was caught up in the market's sentiment and fell 1 1/8, to 67 1/4.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Installment Debt Shrank In August

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Recession-wary Americans shrank their installment debt at a 2.1 percent annual rate in August, according to a Government report today that showed consumer credit was lower for the eighth time in nine months.
"The contraction in net credit outstanding reflects the recession's impact on consumer spending as well as the consumers' concern about their personal finances," Michael P. Niemira, an economist, wrote in Mitsubishi Bank's Weekly Economic Indicator Report. 
 The Federal Reserve said consumer credit fell a seasonally adjusted $1.29 billion in August after declining 1.0 percent in July and 2.8 percent in June. The June drop was revised from a 1.4 percent decrease in the initial estimate last month.
Installment debt increased 1.9 percent in April, the only gain since last November.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It helps finance much of overall consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
The Commerce Department had reported earlier that retail sales -- one-half of consumer spending -- had slumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in August. Many economists have expressed concern that without strong participation by consumers, the economic revival may falter.
"The latest drop in outstanding installment borrowing again was led by auto loans," the Fed report said. These loans plunged at an 8.6 percent rate, or a seasonally adjusted $1.97 billion, after falling 4.1 percent in July.
Automobile sales, which represent one-fifth of retail sales, had fallen 2.7 percent in August, the Commerce report said.
Auto loans have fallen every month this year and manufacturers of North American-made cars reported the model year ending in September was the worst since 1983.
Consumers continued to use their credit cards, however. Revolving credit rose at a 6.2 percent rate, or $1.18 billion, after a gain of 2.4 percent in July. This category has not declined since dipping 2.8 percent last January.
The changes left consumers holding $728.7 billion in installment debt at the end of August, seven-tenths of 1 percent less than they held a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Court to Review Mail-Order Sales Tax Curb

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
In a case with enormous financial implications for the mail-order industry, the Supreme Court agreed today to reconsider one of its own precedents, a 24-year-old decision that has barred states from taxing an estimated $45 billion a year in mail-order sales.
The 1967 precedent, which has come under sustained attack in recent years from states eager to capture as much as $3 billion a year in lost tax revenue, held that the Constitution bars states from taxing sales made by out-of-state companies that have no physical presence in the state. 
 Such taxation, the Court ruled in National Bellas Hess v. Department of Revenue, would violate the constitutional guarantee of due process and would place an undue burden on interstate commerce.
Several dozen states have passed laws recently making out-of-state catalogue sales subject to a use tax, the equivalent of an in-state sales tax. But state courts had uniformly, if reluctantly, adhered to the Supreme Court precedent and refused to permit enforcement.
But recently state courts have begun to break ranks. The case the Court agreed to hear today is an appeal of a ruling last May by the North Dakota Supreme Court, which declared that the 1967 decision was an "obsolescent" precedent that would no longer be considered binding in North Dakota.
The appeal today was brought by the Quill Corporation, an Illinois-based catalogue retailer of office supplies that sends out 60 different catalogues a year and has more than $200 million in annual sales. Quill's estimated $1 million in sales to 3,500 customers in North Dakota makes it the state's sixth-largest seller of office supplies in terms of annual volume.
In 1987, North Dakota amended its sales and use tax to cover out-of-state retailers that regularly solicit business from state residents. In 1989, Quill refused a request from North Dakota tax officials to begin collecting the use tax. The state then went to state court for a declaration that the 1987 law was constitutional and could be enforced.
In its opinion last May, the state's Supreme Court concluded that the economic premises of the 1967 decision were no longer valid, and that it was now illogical and unfair to make a physical presence within the state the sole basis for tax liability.
 
Big Growth in Sales
 In 1967, the state court noted, national mail order sales totaled $2.4 billion a year, compared with almost $200 billion today -- nearly 15 percent of all sales. Last year, 98 million Americans made purchases from the 13.6 billion catalogues that were mailed.
North Dakota, while defending the ruling by its Supreme Court, urged the Justices to hear Quill's appeal, Quill Corp. v. N.D., No. 91-194, because of the importance of the issue. Twenty-two other states, including Connecticut and New Jersey, joined a brief urging the Court to overturn the 1967 decision.
In its last term, the Supreme Court turned down Connecticut's request to review a decision of the Connecticut Supreme Court that had refused to permit the state to tax the mail-order sales of Saks Fifth Avenue's catalogue subsidiary. The Justices do not give reasons for denying, or granting, an appeal. But at the time the Connecticut case was filed, no state supreme court had yet refused to apply National Bellas Hess. The subsequent North Dakota ruling, raising the prospect of national disarray on the issue, quite likely convinced the Justices that the matter required their attention.
Other cases the Court acted on today as the Justices began their 1991-92 term included the following:
 
Proposition 13
 The Court agreed to hear a constitutional challenge to the California property tax limitations known as Proposition 13. The action was expected, because the Justices had agreed last June to hear a similar challenge, only to have R. H. Macy & Company, the taxpayer that brought the challenge, drop the case in the face of a threatened consumer boycott.
The new case was brought not by a company but by an individual homeowner, Stephanie Nordlinger, who in 1988 paid $170,000 for a house in the Baldwin Hills section of Los Angeles. Her property tax is $1,700 a year, in contrast to the $400 a year that is paid by neighbors who have owned their homes since Proposition 13 took effect in 1978.
Under the proposition, which amended the California Constitution, assessments were rolled back to 1975 levels, local property taxes were set at 1 percent of assessed value, and subsequent increases were limited to 2 percent a year as long as the property remained in the same hands.
Newly acquired property, however, is reassessed according to the purchase price. With the rapid increase in property values, widespread disparity has resulted. According to Ms. Nordlinger's petition, new property owners in Los Angeles "commonly" pay property taxes 10 times as high as those paid by some neighbors. Forty-six percent of all California houses built before 1975 are still in the same hands, and so are protected.
 
Basis for Challenge
 The constitutional challenge in Nordlinger v. Hahn, No. 90-1912, is based on the Federal Constitution's guarantees of equal protection and the right to travel. The California Court of Appeal rejected the challenge, and the California Supreme Court refused to hear the case.
Ms. Nordlinger's appeal is supported by the League of Women Voters of California and by the Building Industry Association of Southern California, which filed a brief asserting that Proposition 13 has made it increasingly difficult for people to afford new housing in the state.
Proposition 13 affects businesses as well. In the Macy case, the tax assessment on a Macy's store in a Contra Costa County mall was more than double that of two other retailers in the mall, because Macy's, which had undergone a corporate reorganization in 1986, was deemed to be a new property owner.
 
Biotechnology Patent
 Without comment, the Court let stand a ruling in an important patent dispute over rights to a top-selling anti-anemia drug that is manufactured by genetic engineering.
Last March, the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit here, which has nationwide jurisdiction over appeals in patent cases, gave a complete domestic patent monopoly over the drug to Amgen Inc., based in Thousand Oaks, Calif.
The ruling was a serious setback for an Amgen competitor, Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., which brought the appeal the Supreme Court rejected today. The appeals court found that Genetics Institute's competing patent claims were invalid because the company had not proved that it isolated a protein with the biological characteristics described in the patent.
At issue is the domestic market for EPO, or erythropoietin, a drug that stimulates the production of red blood cells and is useful for combating serious anemia. Domestic sales last year were more than $300 million.
While vitally important to the two companies, the case, Genetics Institute v. Amgen, No. 91-13, was of limited legal significance for other biotechnology cases because it concerned the specific facts of the disputed patent.
The Supreme Court ruled in 1980 that life forms created through genetic engineering could be patented. That ruling gave a substantial lift to the biotechnology industry.
 
Bilzerian Appeal
 Without comment, the Justices turned down an appeal by Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor and former corporate raider who in 1989 was convicted of violating Federal securities laws. He was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $1.5 million after the trial judge, Robert Ward of Federal District Court in New York, said he believed Mr. Bilzerian had perjured himself in testifying in his own defense at his trial. The Federal appeals court in Manhattan upheld the conviction.
The Government had charged Mr. Bilzerian, former chairman of the Singer Corporation, with secretly accumulating stock in takeover targets and then hiding the stock in secret accounts until after the stock price had risen. His appeal was Bilzerian v. U.S., No. 90-1803.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
A Federal appeals court gave the Baby Bells permission to begin immediately providing information services like stock quotes, sports scores and news stories. The ruling overturns part of a July 25 decision by Judge Harold H. Greene that had lifted a longstanding ban prohibiting the companies from owning information services but also delayed lifting the ban pending appeals. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Figuring a Price On a Soviet Deal

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AMONG the Soviet Union's collection of industrial operations, the Volga Automotive Plant Association is the first big target for Western investment. A 30 percent ownership stake in this Russian version of General Motors is to be sold soon, probably to Fiat S.p.A. But what should Fiat pay? What is Volga Autos worth? Bear, Stearns & Company, the Wall Street firm, is using Western techniques to answer this question. Its price tag, due this month, is likely to reflect Soviet politics and guesswork as much as financial analysis.
The Bear, Stearns effort, undertaken at the request of the Soviet Government, is important because it offers an analytic approach for valuing a company that operates in a society without normal guidelines, like stock prices, real estate values and the cost of labor, once the Government no longer sets Soviet wages. The goal is to come up with a cash-flow figure -- a rough measure of Volga Auto's potential earnings in hard currency that would indicate the return on Fiat's investment. 
 "I think this approach is quite a good, indirect way of valuing a company's assets," Leonid Abalkin, a senior economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said in an interview during a visit last week to the United States.
But then come the uncertainties. Will the Soviet Union, for example, limit future imports of Western-made cars, thus increasing Volga Auto's sales in the Soviet Union and, presumably, the return on Fiat's investment? The Soviets don't say.
Or, will Fiat, as the minority shareholder in a soon-to-be privatized company still controlled by Russians, have a sufficient say in Volga's managment to maintain quality? If not, the cars might not sell well abroad, and Volga's earnings from future exports might decline. Right now, 300,000 of the 700,000 cars manufactured annually are sold in Western Europe, Britain and Canada.
Then there is the social issue. Is Bear, Stearns including in its calculations the expense of continuing to provide housing, hospitals, schools and the like for many of Volga's 120,000 workers? Bear, Stearns does not say, but Mr. Abalkin insisted that these "social functions" must be maintained. "This is a permanent peculiarity of Soviet enterprises," he said.
Finally, neither Bear, Stearns nor the Soviets have produced a Western challenger to Fiat. Given the Italian auto maker's long involvement in Volga's operations, that is understandable. But the absence of competition gives Fiat extra leverage to bargain down the amount that it ends up investing to acquire 30 percent of Volga Autos.
Fiat built Volga's main plant 500 miles from Moscow in the 1960's. It provided the technology, now outdated, for Volga's principal car, called the Zhuguli at home and the Lada abroad. And last spring the Soviet Government -- seeking new technology and Western money to update Volga -- signed a letter of intent with Fiat that seemed to commit it to Fiat as the minority shareholder.
"In the end, this is going to be a negotiation," said Maryann Keller, an auto analyst at Furman, Selz Inc. "You hire an investment banker so that you know what sort of value Western business would put on the company. But what you say Volga is worth does not mean that you will get it."
Still, Volga Autos is easier to value in hard currency than other Russian companies. The Lada, similar in style to the Ford Taurus and in quality to the Yugo of Yugoslavia, already sells in the West for $6,000 to $8,000 -- a price that might make the car worth $2,500 to $3,000 in the Soviet Union, once price levels are left to free-market forces, said Planecon Inc., a consulting firm that specializes in Soviet and Eastern European economies. (Bear, Stearns will not discuss such details.)
But if the future revenue flow of Volga can be estimated more or less accurately, its costs cannot. The level of wages or the prices of such basic materials as glass and steel in a centrally controlled, closed-off economy do not serve as guides for what these inputs will cost in a free market, says Robert D. Hormats, vice president for international investment at Goldman, Sachs.
This uncertainty, in turn, becomes part of the calculation. Volga's annual cash flow -- the revenue minus the cost of inputs and of replacing machinery as it ages -- might turn out to be, say, $600 million, a figure that reflects recent Volga data. Fiat's 30 percent investment would then yield $180 million, or 18 percent if Fiat were to invest $1 billion, an amount mentioned in the Soviet press. Given the uncertainties, Fiat might consider 18 percent too low.
But Mr. Abalkin said he would consider $1 billion a giveaway. "A 30 percent stake is worth no less than $4 billion," he said, suggesting that the Bear, Stearns valuation will be a bargaining tool, at best.

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C. About to Sell New Hampshire Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is expected to reorganize and sell five troubled New Hampshire banks by the end of this week.
The five banks, which together account for about 25 percent of the $20 billion of assets held by all of New Hampshire's banks and savings institutions, have been badly hurt by losses on commercial real estate loans, and have been the subject of F.D.I.C. negotiations for months. 
 Four of the five -- Amoskeag Bank Shares of Manchester, Dartmouth Bancorp of Hooksett, New Hampshire Savings Bank of Concord, and Numerica Financial of Manchester -- are insolvent. The fifth -- Bankeast of Manchester -- has filed for bankruptcy.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., told reporters Sunday evening that the rescues would be completed before his term ends on Oct. 16. The agency often announces the reorganization of failed banks on Friday, and makes arrangements for them to be open the following Saturday or Monday under new owners.
 
Divided Into 2 Groups
 Rather than sell each bank company individually, as is normally its practice, the F.D.I.C. is expected to divide the companies into two groups. One group will consist of the two commercial banks, Amoskeag and BankEast; the other group will comprise the three other savings institutions.
Gerrard Cassidy, a banking analyst at Tucker Anthony Inc., in Boston, said the bidders for the bank group would include the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, of Providence, R.I., which this year bought the Bank of New England and already owns the largest bank in New Hampshire, and Keycorp of Albany, which bought part of Goldome, a failed savings bank in Buffalo. Fleet/Norstar and Keycorp will also bid separately for the right to manage the pool of bad loans that the F.D.I.C. will keep while it sells the remainder for the banks, Mr. Cassidy said.
None of the potential bidders would comment on possible plans to bid for the New Hampshire banks.
Mr. Cassidy said that bidders for the three savings institutions included a group of investors led by William Craig, a former vice chairman of the Shawmut National Corporation, and First NH Banks, a subsidiary of the Bank of Ireland.
 
'A Critical Mass'
 "The two franchises offered for sale could provide buyers with a critical mass in the state," said Frank Barkocy, a banking analyst at Advest Inc., a securities firm based in Hartford. Because of the weak regional economy and a glut of vacant real estate, Mr. Barkocy said the rescue had taken several months to arrange, and "has been a hard sell for Federal regulators."
Even assuming that the F.D.I.C. retains the banks' bad loans, Mr. Barkocy noted that the New Hampshire companies might not have much near-term profit potential, "except for buyers who have other profitable outlets for the low-cost deposits they can collect in the state."
Because the F.D.I.C. rescue includes the merger of some companies, analysts expect branch closings and job cuts to follow the sales. Analysts at the First Albany Corporation noted that the mergers and sales to large banking companies would be helpful to healthier banking companies in the area "as excess banking capacity would be reduced, with no competitors introduced."
One of the problems for the New Hampshire banking market, analysts said, was the conversion in the early 1980's of companies like Amoskeag and the New Hampshire Savings Bank to shareholder ownership. The influx of shareholder capital encouraged them to lend heavily on real estate projects in the "golden triangle" in southern New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: In the New Albania, New Varieties of Chaos

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, Oct. 4

 BODY:
When schools reopened the other day after an extended summer pause, Albanian education authorities were horrified to discover that 740 of their buildings had been vandalized -- windows, desks and other furnishings smashed.
It was another symptom of the chaos in this Balkan country, whose 3.5 million people are Europe's poorest. After a summer in which 20,000 Albanians, most of them young, tried to leave the country, only to be returned by Italy, a wave of robberies and burglaries has swept the land. 
 In August alone, 27 railway freight cars were plundered of their loads of fertilizer and salt, which is in short supply.
School textbooks and instructors from the Communist Government that ruled Albania unopposed until last spring remain largely unchanged. But now, teachers are being assaulted.
With the dissolution six months ago of the secret police and with the demoralized uniformed police and the army receiving frequently changed commands or none at all at times of unrest, there has been a breakdown of public order.
The economy continues to deteriorate. Average wages range from $40 to $60 a month. Two-thirds of the Albanian labor force is involved in agriculture, for the most part with hand implements. Now, the peasants are intent on acquiring land under a privatization law after four decades of collectivization. Fields lie fallow. Orchards go unpruned. Grapes rot unharvested.
Gramoz Pashko, Deputy Prime Minister in charge of economic reform, said in an interview that Albania is burdened with foreign debts totaling $400 million. "If we had half a billion dollars in assistance, we could save Albania not only for this winter, but for the rest of life," he said. "We could have a real market economy and people would not die."
But with the exception of Italy, which is providing considerable food assistance, only a trickle of foreign aid has been delivered, including that promised by the United States.
Against this background, the political situation is also deteriorating. The Communist Party, which won about 70 percent of Parliament seats in March in Albania's first contested election since World War II, is moribund. It is split into as many as four factions under a new name, the Socialist Party.
After demonstrations last spring, the Communists agreed to share power with the opposition Democratic Party in a coalition Government of "national stability." Communists still hold most of the positions of power in Albania but are unsure of their grip.
The Democrats, led by Dr. Sali Berisha, a cardiologist, want to push the Communists the rest of the way out of authority with new elections.
But on the way to that goal, the Democratic Party leadership has split into two factions that are slinging bitter epithets at each other.
On one side is Dr. Berisha, a popular figure. On the other is a group of seven or more party leaders who include Mr. Pashko, the economist; Genc Rulli, the Finance Minister, and Azem Hajdari, a fiery young man who took command of a student uprising at Tirana University that started the process of Communist collapse last December.
The split began when Dr. Berisha dismissed Frrok Cupi, the editor of the party newspaper Democratic Revival, who had made a name for himself as a dissident during Communist rule. "I decided he was a spy," Dr. Berisha said, "and I fired him."
The other leaders were appalled, and they accused Dr. Berisha of acting in the manner of Enver Hoxha, the Albanian dictator who died in 1985.
The rift reached a low point over the weekend of Sept. 27 at a party national congress. On the agenda were the election of a chairman and a governing council, as well as a decision on when to push for national elections.
The seven opponents tried to persuade Dr. Berisha to step aside on the ground that he was overwhelming the party with his dominating personality. He refused. At the last minute, they put up two other candidates.
Dr. Berisha took his case to the floor of the 561-member convention, made a rousing speech, won standing ovations and received 449 votes.

HEADLINE: Haiti Legislature Declares the Presidency Vacant

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Under pressure from belligerent soldiers, Haiti's legislature tonight voted to apply a constitutional article that declares the presidency vacant and clear the way for the naming of a provisional leader who would be required to call new elections within 90 days. 
 The decision was announced during a visit by a delegation from the Organization of American States, which returned to Haiti this afternoon to demand the reinstatement of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, exiled in a military coup last Monday. The army accused Father Aristide of violating the constitution and seeking to create a separate armed unit as his own political tool.
Parliament's decision came shortly before 6 P.M., before the President of the National Assembly had returned from an airport meeting with the O.A.S. delegation.
Asked why the decision had been made in such haste, one senator said: "The declaration had already been decided upon. We had to do it this way because the army was angry. They wanted it done right away."
 
Violence at the Airport
 More than 100 armed soldiers milled about the Parliament building. While the legislators were voting, a group of soldiers became violent at Haiti's international airport, beating and arresting the Mayor of Port-au-Prince, Evans Paul, and forcing the cancellation of a trip by a group of politicians who were traveling to Venezuela to negotiate Father Aristide's return.
Father Aristide flew to Caracas, Venezuela, from Washington on Sunday night and met with the Venezuelan leader, Carlos Andres Perez. He flew to Kingston, Jamaica, today and met with the Jamaican Prime Minister, Michael Manley.
Soldiers at the Haitian airport beat on passing cars, saying, "We want a President today!" and "We want the country!" said one witness who had just arrived from Miami. He said at least one shot was fired at the airport.
Other soldiers surrounded a second-floor meeting room where members of the O.A.S. team, including Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, were discussing the country's crisis with Haitian officials. The delegation left the country shortly afterward.
 
Broadcasts Are Halted
 With the exception of Government programming, consisting of music punctuated by announcements of Parliament's action, all Haitian radio and television stations stopped broadcasting this evening. As night fell, automatic-weapons fire could be heard often around the city.
A Government radio announcement said there was no possibility of Father Aristide's return as President and attributed the gunfire around Parliament to the special military unit created by Father Aristide, even though Government soldiers in uniform were seen in the area.
The decision by Parliament, if applied, would call for the naming of Joseph Nerette, the senior justice on Haiti's Supreme Court, to serve temporarily as President.
The decision, made while soldiers nervously patrolled the streets after rumors circulated this afternoon of President Aristide's impending return, places Haiti on a collision course with Western Hemisphere nations that have vowed to enforce economic sanctions against the country until the ousted President is returned to office.
"We have come down with an extremely clear mandate that Aristide must be restored," said Carlos Iturralde, the Bolivian Foreign Minister who is chairman of the O.A.S. delegation, several hours before Parliament's decision was announced. "We want to make it clear that our position is very serious, that economic sanctions are there to stay and soon there will be a lack of oil."
 
Fears of Foreign Intervention
 Referring to the Haitian legislature's proposal to name a provisional President who would conduct elections within 90 days, Mr. Iturralde said, before the O.A.S. meeting began, "We cannot allow the presidency to be declared vacant."
After several days with little vocal support for Father Aristide among politicians not already tied to him, leaders of two political groupings said they were traveling to Venezuela tonight to meet with the President to help seek a way for his return.
Victor Benoit, a leader of Konakom, a left-of-center political organization that had backed Father Aristide's candidacy for President before distancing itself from him after he was elected, said he was seeking to avoid foreign military intervention in Haiti or the total isolation of the country.
With sentiment in the army strongly against Father Aristide's return and strong momentum in Parliament for an interim solution to the country's power vacuum, another O.A.S. official called the situation "very delicate and potentially very deadly."
Father Aristide, responding to strong concerns both in Haiti and abroad over his the reality of commitment to human rights, issued a statement denouncing violence and pledging respect for his country's institutions. His remarks included an explicit disavowal of "Pere Lebrun," the street-corner lynchings with burning tires that he has been widely seen as condoning in previous speeches.
"The three powers in our Constitution will have to mutually respect each other and respect the Constitution," the statement said. "As President of the republic, we condemn once again all forms of violence, all forms of violence from whatever source: Pere Lebrun or repressive violence."
Experts in Haitian military affairs expressed concern that any effort to bring about the return of Father Aristide quickly would provoke a violent reaction among ordinary soldiers, whom they described as being nearly unanimous in their opposition to the exiled President.
"The high command is in command insofar as there is no question of Aristide returning," one expert said. "They have no choice."
 
Soldiers' Banter
 Soldiers were talking extemporaneously on the Government-controlled radio during the night.
One soldier who said that he was "a little drunk" proclaimed: "There's no going back now." He asked the news media to "open their doors so that people can express their happiness" about the legislature's decision to vacate the presidency.
Several neighborhoods in the capital continued to report sporadic incidents of nighttime violence by heavily armed men, apparently undisciplined soldiers.

HEADLINE: Democrats Urge Study of Budget Before Cutting Money for Military

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The House Democratic leadership today moved to look at Federal budget issues for the next decade before trying to see whether last year's budget agreement should be altered to cut Pentagon spending.
The chairman of the House Budget Committee, with the backing of Speaker Thomas S. Foley, said his panel would start on that task tomorrow, and he hoped, would finish by the time Congress adjourns in November. 
 Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, the budget panel's chairman, offered some long-term recommendations that are intended to reduce the deficit by a trillion dollars over the decade. Those recommendations, which also call for major new spending in education and health, urge cuts in the military budget of as much as 33 to 40 percent below last year's levels.
He cited pressures to make those cuts quickly and to apply the money to domestic spending, and said his long-range approach was intended to forestall hasty action.
 
No Cuts in a Vacuum
 "But I do not believe we ought to simply proceed to revise the '93 budget" in a vacuum, Representative Panetta said.
"You can't simply, for example, go after the defense number unless you have developed a long-range path about where defense spending is going to wind up by the end of the decade," he added at a news conference.
Mr. Panetta acknowledged the need for cooperation with the Administration if a long-term plan is to be meaningful, saying, "There's no way that this is going to be done by the Congress alone, and there's no way it's going to be done by the President alone."
President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, while not commenting directly on the proposal for a 10-year look at budget needs, restated the Administration's opposition to reopening the budget agreement. "We do not want to open the budget, reopen the budget agreement," he said at his daily news briefing. "We don't expect it to be reopened and certainly have no plans to do that."
But Administration officials who spoke on condition that their names not be used acknowledged that discussions about using cuts in the military budget to help the Soviet Union were beginning within the Administration, although no strong advocate of such a move has emerged.
"There are some people in the Administration who would like to do it and there are some on Capitol Hill," a senior Administration official said. But two fears worry them, he added.
One is that aid might actually hurt the Soviets. For example, supplying free food might destroy domestic agriculture, he said.
The second concern, the official said, "is that once you open up the Pandora's box on defense, then cuts could be offsets for anyone's favorite programs."
For example, the official noted, domestic transportation programs might end up getting the money instead of the Soviet Union.
 
Urging a Shift
 A senior Treasury official said that while the Department had not adopted a position on such proposals, "we may get some benefit out of reductions in defense and part of that benefit may end up going to international things," particularly the Soviet Union.
Democrats in Congress, led by Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have been urging such a shift of resources, but Administration officials, especially Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, have rejected such proposals in public comments.
"I've never seen any willingness to compromise on that point," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana. When told that the Administration was considering the idea, however, he replied, "It doesn't surprise me too much," and he asked, "Where does the money come from," if not from defense?
Mr. Aspin has proposed leaving $1 billion in the military budget to be used for Soviet relief this winter. But most proposals call for taking money from the military category and using it for discretionary domestic spending.
Last year's budget law prohibited moving money from one category to another until the budget year beginning Oct. 1, 1993.
While ordinarily one Congress cannot bind its successors, the budget act approved last year and signed by President Bush did impose conditions on future spending, and changing those limits would require repeal or amendment of last year's act, a step that would be almost impossible without President Bush's agreement.
The Senate Budget Committee is also expected to look at the budget again this fall with an eye toward breaking down the so-called "firewalls" between different spending categories. But it is unlikely to try to look as far as 10 years into the future; several senators are skeptical about how useful projections that far ahead can be.
Representative Panetta said he believed Republicans on his committee would share his general objectives of streamlining the Government, concentrating scarce resources on essential problems, economic growth and deficit reduction over the next several years. But he predicted, "There are going to be differences with regards to the pieces."
For example, he said raising taxes would have to be one element of the program, and he spoke of higher taxes for the wealthy, gasoline taxes and excise taxes. Republicans regularly oppose proposals for such taxes and counter with proposals for major cuts in domestic spending. Mr. Panetta did identify increases in health care spending as an area that had to be curbed.

HEADLINE: RISING PERIL SEEN AT EUROPE A-SITES

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 7

 BODY:
New safety problems are piling on top of old ones at the nuclear reactors in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union because of the economic and political upheavals there, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.
The chairman, Ivan Selin, who recently returned from a trip to visit eight reactors in Eastern and Western Europe, said he was "uneasy" about the situation in the former East bloc. 
 Plants lack the resources to make needed improvements, he said, and because of overreliance on nuclear power, there is no chance to shut unsafe reactors. Regulators lack authority, he said, and the breakup of the Soviet Union is making the problem worse, as republics move to take control. Changes promised after the Chernobyl accident five years ago are still incomplete, he said.
His comments are part of a chorus of concern from Western experts, coming partly from increased openness in the East, and in part from a deteriorating situation there.
 
Pessimism on Soviet Plants
 "It is very hard to be optimistic in the short run about safe nuclear operation in the Soviet Union," Mr. Selin said in a session at the commission's headquarters this afternoon. "It isn't getting better."
Eastern European reactors have never been safe, Mr. Selin said, but now economic disclocations are creating new problems; for example, Bulgaria is short of operators for its Soviet-designed reactors. "There are plenty of people in Bulgaria who can run them, but no economic reason to do so," he said. "You can make more money as a cabdriver in Sofia."
And even steps that might seem to reduce risk are making things worse, Mr. Selin said. For example, public reaction to the Chernobyl accident has forced a moratorium on construction of many new reactors in the Soviet Union. But this requires the continued operation of older, primitive models, which lack containment buildings, the heavy steel and concrete structures routinely used in the West to hold in radiation in an accident, and emergency core cooling systems, which would provide water in case of a pipe break.
 
Dependency on Atom Power
 Four reactors in that category, at Greifswald, were shut by Germany after its reunification. The Soviets still operate two at Novovoronezhski and two at Kola, Bulgaria four at Kozloduy and Czechoslovakia two at Bohunice. The Bulgarian plant, he said, was an example of "extreme dependence" on nuclear power, providing 30 to 40 percent of the country's already-inadequate supply of electricity.
Mr. Selin called for an approach in which nuclear agencies like the International Monetary Fund would make reform a condition of aid; specifically, he recommended doubling or tripling the price of electricity to provide the plants with resources for things like control room simulators for training.
But the assessment by Mr. Selin and members of his staff was not uniformly grim. While control room instrumentation and procedures are deficient, Mr. Selin said, many operators are highly trained.
Moreover, Harold R. Denton, director of the commission's Office of Governmental and Regulatory Affairs, said while although the older Soviet-designed plants were not equipped to cope with pipe breaks, they have design elements that would allow them to survive many kinds of accidents.

HEADLINE: Europe Urges Rise in Soviet Aid

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The European Community today challenged the United States, Canada and Japan to match $2.4 billion in aid that it plans to give the Soviet Union to help meet an expected winter food shortage.
The finance ministers of the community's 12 member countries called for a total Western aid package of more than $7 billion, saying their loans and credit guarantees were conditional on getting a similar commitment from other major trading powers. 
 "Burden sharing is important," said the community's top finance offical, Henning Christophersen.
The ministers from Britain, France, Italy and Germany will prod their American, Japanese and Canadian counterparts to commit themselves to the aid package at a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations this week in Bangkok, Thailand.
 
$1.5 Billion More in Credit
 The European Community agreed last year to provide $900 million in emergency aid and credit guarantees, and today it promised an additional $1.5 billion in credit.
The United States has earmarked $2.5 billion in farm credits to the Soviet Union since last fall, officials said.
The European Community ministers have proposed sending a high-level mission to the Soviet Union within weeks to prepare contingency plans for food and medical aid. The Soviet authorities asked for Western aid to help them deal with expected shortages because of a poor food distribution system. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has requested $10.2 billion in food aid, a figure European officials consider inflated.
 
Soviet Cities Vulnerable
 Finance Minister Wim Kok of the Netherlands emphasized that the $1.5 billion credit was a contingency program and would "only be put in practice as soon as we know what the needs are."
But there is little doubt that the Soviet people are facing tough times, officals said. They said people in large industrial cities would be especially vulnerable to food shortages because there were no guarantees that farmers in the countryside would be willing to ship food to the urban centers.
Mr. Christophersen said the need for food aid was clear. "Everybody accepts that something has to be done," he said.
He added that Japan had been hesitant. "Japan has given a very small amount so far," he said, estimating Japanese aid at $36 million.
"They have the capacity" to do more, Mr. Christophersen said. "Why shouldn't they do it?"
The community nations are Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

HEADLINE: Shamir Again Criticizes U.S. on Loan Guarantees

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today delivered one of his more blistering attacks on the United States' postponement of loan guarantees for resettling Soviet immigrants here, saying the action struck at "the deepest foundations of Jewish and Zionist existence."
Mr. Shamir and his aides have vacillated repeatedly in their public remarks on the aid battle, swinging back and forth between anger and resignation, with an occasional pause to worry about the direction of Israel's relations with Washington. 
 But an underlying theme has been a consistent berating of the Bush Administration for having joined two issues: what this Government considers a humanitarian matter, help for Soviet Jewish emigres, and something that it considers purely political, President Bush's demand that the assistance take a back seat to Middle East peace talks he hopes to convene this month.
Opening a session of Parliament today, Mr. Shamir took an outraged stand.
He hardly went so far as one of his Cabinet ministers on the far right who accused Mr. Bush a few weeks ago of being an anti-Semite. Nonetheless, the Prime Minister raised Jewish consciousness as an integral component of the dispute, and he accused Mr. Bush of trampling it.
"The pain and disappointment are especially great because the American Administration chose to take a step that damages the deepest foundations of Jewish and Zionist existence," he said.
He praised Mr. Bush for having worked in the past, as Vice President, to win emigration rights for Soviet and Ethiopian Jews. But this time, he said, the Administration has neglected to recognize the decades of Arab opposition to Jewish immigration here.
"I want to believe that if the American leaders had known the extent of our sensitivity on this subject," he said, they "would have thought twice before taking the path they chose."
His Government's anti-Administration fire has been stoked anew in the last few days by reports from Washington challenging Israel's commitment to free-market changes needed to reshape a lumbering, centrally guided economy. The absence of such adjustments, according to credit analysts for the United States Export-Import Bank, raised doubts about this country's ability to repay the billions it intends to borrow to help Soviet immigrants.
Their analysis was handed to the Administration in July, and senior Government officials here assert that it was leaked to the press now to undermine Israel's fiscal credibility.
But Mr. Shamir's domestic critics accuse him of having brought problems upon himself by, in their view, neglecting economic and social needs, especially for new immigrants.
The research department of the Bank of Israel issued a report today asserting that the Government lacked a consistent overall policy for absorbing immigrants and for lowering the 11 percent unemployment rate.
Shimon Peres, head of the opposition Labor Party, signaled a likely campaign theme for the national elections expected next year when he criticized Mr. Shamir in Parliament for what he called his single-minded pursuit of new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
"That's the only thing that shows some sign of policy," Mr. Peres said. "And where is it leading us to?"

HEADLINE: DARTMOUTH BEGINS $425 MILLION DRIVE

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Dartmouth College, the smallest member of the Ivy League, yesterday kicked off a five-year campaign to raise $425 million, joining a growing list of prestigious colleges and universities that are trying to attract record amounts of voluntary support despite a weak economy and bad publicity.
Dartmouth's goal is far lower than the $1.25 billion sought by Cornell University in the highest goal set by any university so far, or the $1.1 billion already raised by Stanford University. But Dartmouth's goal is ambitious, given its size, 4,500 students as against Stanford's 13,000, and its budget, roughly one-quarter the size of Stanford's. 
 "On a per capita basis it's about as big a campaign as there is," said George A. Brakeley 3d, president of Brakeley, John Price Jones, Inc., a fund-raising consulting firm in Stamford, Conn.
 
Favorable Expectations
 Dartmouth's new drive is also notable for its timing, just a few semesters after an off-campus publication, The Dartmouth Review, drew unfavorable publicity for the college with its offensive treatment of blacks, homosexuals and American Indians.
But Dartmough officials said they believed the connection to the Review controversy would not dampen the response to their appeal to alumni and supporters, who are considered to be among the most loyal of any college.
E. John Rosenwald Jr., chairman of the campaign executive committee, said that in the last three fiscal years, while the controversy was playing itself out, Dartmouth's support has remained strong. Last year, giving from all sources exceeded $56 million, a record for the college.
Dartmouth's president, James O. Freedman, said yesterday that the money, raised over five years, would be used to strengthen faculty, academic programs and student financial aid and to improve the Hanover, N.H., campus.
In the Ivy League, Columbia University and the University of Pennsylvania are in the midst of $1 billion capital campaigns, Princeton University has no campaign under way and Brown University is planning one. Yale University and Harvard University were expected to begin billion-dollar campaigns, but neither has yet done so. Harvard's new president, Neil L. Rudenstine, last month postponed the new campaign for two years.
Over the weekend, the University of Chicago began a $500 million campaign drive to coincide with its centennial.

HEADLINE: Brew Battle On Campus: Ban the Can Or the Keg?

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 4

 BODY:
The beer keg, as much a staple of college life as the all-nighter or the incompatible roommate, is at the center of debate this fall over how to control alcohol abuse at two of New Jersey's largest campuses.
With the semester in full swing and beer flowing as freely as ideas, Princeton University and Cook College of Rutgers University have moved simultaneously to establish new restrictions intended to curb drunken carousing and worse. 
 But they have moved in opposite directions.
At Princeton, kegs have been banned in favor of cans and bottles. At Cook College, cans and bottles have been banned in favor of kegs, bucking a national trend.
Neither school is predicting that its policies will bring about the dawn of a golden age of sobriety, and each campus has reacted differently to the rules -- dismay at Princeton, a wait-and-see attitude at Cook.
 
Unspeakable Social Decay
 What is clear at both, however, is the power of the keg as a symbol. For some, particularly undergraduates, it represents independence and youthful exuberance, a rite of passage to the adult world, or, at the very least, the reason weekends were invented. For others, particularly the president of Princeton, Harold T. Shapiro, it is a sign of unspeakable social decay that required urgent measures.
"The keg has become a symbol of the free and easy availability of alcohol," Dr. Shapiro said. "The keg ban is just a step and I hope it will be replaced by better steps."
David Burns, vice president of student life policy and services at Rutgers, said: "The keg is a powerful cue in a psychological sense. It is a very visible thing -- the center of the party."
Theoretically, of course, it is a violation of New Jersey law, as well as college regulations, for most undergraduates to drink. Since 1983, when New Jersey raised its drinking age from 18 to 21, legal consumption of alcohol was automatically restricted to about a quarter of college undergraduates, mostly seniors. But it remains a daunting goal to achieve temperance among thousands of adolescents thrust into the social crucible of dormitories and fraternities beyond the reach of administrators.
With fake I.D. cards and the tribal loyalties of a close-knit campus, under-age drinking persists at fraternity houses (Rutgers), eating clubs (Princeton), off-campus residences and dormitory parties. A vigilant student can stay within the letter of the law and still get a drink from a sympathetic upperclassman.
For Cook, one of four residential colleges at Rutgers' New Brunswick campus, the decision to allow kegs was intended to choke off a larger black-market flow. Under previous guidelines, issued six years ago, kegs were deemed the font of retrograde social behavior and replaced by a roughly equal amount in cases at college-sanctioned dormitory parties. But counting cans proved fruitless, because many more cases were often concealed.
 
The Ultimate Prerequisite
 Now when a keg runs dry, so the theory goes, a host at a Cook College party would be hard-pressed to roll out a fresh barrel without quickly arousing the suspicions of the proctors.
But permission for kegs at Cook College runs counter to an increasing inclination to ban them. In the last year alone, Dartmouth, Skidmore, Purdue, Syracuse and William and Mary have banned kegs. Other schools, including Bryn Mawr, have tightened curbs on alcohol and authorized parties by invitation only.
In some cases, local fraternity chapters have banned kegs or otherwise restricted their parties, in part because the national organizations have come under pressure from their insurers.
At Cook, with about 2,900 students, the latest guidelines are rooted in a yearlong discussion by a student-faculty committee presided over by the dean of students, Lee D. Schneider. The rules, he said, are intended to "encourage students to act responsibly and to take responsibility for others." He requires seniors who want to hold keg parties to attend seminars at which the guidelines are explained and notions about alcohol abuse and safe partying are explored.
 
'Save the Rain Forest'
 Cook College began a one-year experiment this weekend, allowing kegs in certain senior apartments. Keg No. 058203 became the first to be inspected by a proctor for the dean's office, to the cheers of about two dozen guests at a "save the rain forest" theme party in the Newell Apartments, a senior dormitory complex.
Surrounded by strands of ivy taped to the walls and ceiling, some students grumbled about the limits on quantity, but there was a sense that the experiment was worth trying. Support ran stronger at another gathering in a nearby apartment just outside the realm designated for kegs.
"It's a lot stricter this year," said Kevin Melvin, 22, a senior from Smithtown, L.I. "But the theme parties are fun, and it's not just drinking. The college cares about what we do, and if this works out we'll be setting things up for the next class."
A keg party at Newell is covered by six pages of rules.
 
Bluto, Meet John Locke
 The hosts, who are required to register with the dean during the week, also have to sign a "social contract" under which they pledge to help "eliminate socially intolerable forms of behavior, specifically harassment, sexual abuse, driving under the influence, racism, sexism, homophobia, vandalism, vomiting, littering and disorderly conduct." Violations of the party guidelines can result in fines up to $500 and as much as 100 hours of campus service.
Under New Jersey law, anyone who serves alcohol to a minor is in violation, but the drinker, if he or she is in a private place, is not sanctioned. For that reason, kegs have always been outlawed in Princeton dorms, because by definition a keg is a vehicle for serving alcohol. Princeton's penalties for those caught serving to minors range from warnings to probation and campus service.
At Princeton, the style of the keg ban has caused as much debate as its substance. Dr. Shapiro's announcement amounted to a decree. Issued without consulting students, faculty members or alumni, it has drawn a uniformly unfavorable response. It came even as his own special assistant, Carl Wartenburg, was trying to evaluate campus drinking and propose ways to deal with it.
Paul McDonald, chairman of the Undergraduate Life committee, said most students agreed that alcohol abuse was a problem. But he argued that Dr. Shapiro's "high-handed" ban had undermined campus dialogue.
 
Oh, Ecology! Oh, Reunions!
 "College students like to be treated as adults, and when they are treated as children, it's bound to create a backlash," said Mr. McDonald, a junior from Sugarland, Tex.
Underlying the debate over kegs versus cans is an unbending law of campus economics -- kegs cost about a third of the equivalent amount of canned or bottled beer -- that has vexed not only the 4,500 undergraduates at Princeton but also its alumni, whose reunions will be kegless and more expensive.
At Community Liquors in Princeton, the owner, Stanley Parnett, said the demand by students for the traditional half-keg -- $33 for the equivalent of 190 12-ounce cans -- had been "soft but steady."
But the loudest and most sustained outcry may come from the reunion classes, who are famous for transforming Princeton's lush Gothic campus into an orange and black Mardi Gras.
Writing on behalf of the class of 1982, two of its officers, William D. Kissinger and Richard G. Coffey, criticized Dr. Shapiro for acting unilaterally and asked him to reconsider.
They asserted that the ban would make the reunion too expensive, would create an ecological nightmare in the form of 24,000 cans or bottles for the class of 1982 alone, and would threaten security because "the bottles and cans that will have to be used in lieu of kegs are much more likely to be thrown and to cause injury."
"One cannot throw a cup full of beer and expect it to cause damage," they wrote.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Panel to Recommend Raises of Up to 19% for City Officials

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A mayoral commission examining the salaries of elected officials will recommend raises this week of up to 19 percent for Mayor David N. Dinkins and other high-ranking elected city officeholders, city officials said.
But by all accounts, the proposed raises have no chance of becoming reality any time soon. The Mayor has repeatedly said he would not accept a raise for at least a year and has vowed to oppose raises for other officeholders because of the city's bleak financial straits. 
 And the Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, who in effect controls the ultimate fate of the raises in the Council, has said that although he supported raising Council members' salaries, he would staunchly oppose raises until the city's fiscal health improves.
Still, the three-member panel's recommendations, first reported yesterday in The New York Post, will give city officials a rationale for raising salaries in the future if the fiscal clouds clear. Doing it now, mayoral aides said, would be tantamount to political suicide.
 
Compared to Private Jobs
 Members of the commission did not return telephone calls yesterday seeking comment. First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the commission had arrived at the higher salaries by comparing the positions to similar jobs in other parts of the country and to jobs in private industry with comparable responsibilities. The commission also took into account the cost of living in New York and inflation.
The conclusion, Mr. Steisel said, was that top elected officials are underpaid for the level of responsibility they carry and could make much more in the private sector.
"Glory only carries you so far," Mr. Steisel said.
The biggest raise proposed by the panel would go to the Mayor, city officials said. The panel has decided to recommend that Mr. Dinkins's official salary be raised about 18 percent, to $153,000 a year from $130,000, which it is believed would make him the highest-paid mayor in the nation.
For the last year, Mayor Dinkins has voluntarily taken a 5 percent cut in pay -- to $123,500 -- along with his highest-paid commissioners and managers. In a speech on July 30, Mr. Dinkins promised he would freeze his salary for the next year at that level and urged other elected officials to join him.
Besides the Mayor's raise, the panel will recommend that Council member's salaries be raised to $65,000 from $55,000; that City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman's salary be increased to $122,500 from $105,000; that City Council President Andrew J. Stein be paid $115,000 instead of $105,000, and that district attorneys be given a raise to $115,000 from the $97,000 they now earn. The panel will propose that borough presidents be given a raise to $105,000 from $95,000, officials said.
 
Mayor's Recommendations
 The recommendations are expected to arrive on the Mayor's desk today or tomorrow, Mr. Steisel said. After reading them, the Mayor is to send his own recommendations to the Council, which has the power to approve the raises.
Peg Breen, the spokeswoman for the Council, said Mr. Vallone, the Speaker, has repeatedly said he would not urge passage of raises this year.
Created in 1986, the panel, known as the Advisory Commission to Review Compensation Levels of Elected Officials, scrutinizes every four years the salaries of the mayor, Council president, comptroller, borough presidents, Council members and the five district attorneys.
The commission is headed by Richard Shinn, a former chairman of Metropolitan Life Insurance. The other members are G. G. Michelson, a vice president at R. H. Macy & Company, and Donald C. Platten, a former chairman of Chemical Bank.
