HEADLINE: Groups Urge Tax Freeze By Dinkins

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In an unusually stiff warning, two leading business groups yesterday urged the Dinkins administration to freeze all taxes on property, businesses and individuals in New York City for the next four years, to cut its work force by 30,000 employees and improve efficiency to maintain vital services.
By making those demands, the groups, the New York Chamber of Commerce and the New York City Partnership, joined a growing chorus, including the City Council and the Real Estate Board of New York, which has urged Mr. Dinkins to hold down taxes and cuts in services, or risk losing businesses and taxpayers and hurting the economy further. 
 But the groups' statement, on the eve of a meeting of the state Financial Control Board to review the city's finances today, was more sweeping, since it called for freezing all taxes, not just those on property.
It was a sign of their members' frustration with the city's fiscal affairs and labor relations, and was particularly unusual for the Partnership, whose membership includes nonprofit groups. It has supported tax increases in the past and generally adopted a conciliatory approach to City Hall.
 
'Enough Is Enough'
 "We're not only moderates, we've supported taxes," said the president of both groups, Ronald K. Shelp. "But there's a real sense, not only among the business community, but, I think, citizens at large, that enough is enough."
Mayor David N. Dinkins's latest official plans call for $500 million in higher property taxes in each of the next three years, to help close projected annual budget deficits of $1.5 billion. Lately, he and his top aides have hinted that the city may propose some kind of partial tax freeze, or reduce selected taxes in an effort to spur the economy as it prepares its long-term financial plan for the next four years, to be released early next month.
But they have not been specific, and plan to offer only the most general outline of their goals for curbing costs at the Control Board's meeting today. A number of business people and fiscal monitors said they saw the Partnership's proposal, in a memo to Mr. Dinkins, as a way of keeping up the pressure on the Mayor, and mayoral aides said they saw it as a bargaining position.
If the Mayor vowed not to raise taxes for four years, it would extend beyond the expiration of his term in 1993, committing him far into the future or complicating matters for any successor.
 
'More Anxiety'
 "In 10 years, I have heard a lot of business people rail about the local government or the problems of high taxes and declining services," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit watchdog group financed by business. "But I've never heard it so forcefully expressed. There's more anxiety about the state of the city right now than I ever remember."
Mr. Dinkins's chief spokesman, Leland T. Jones, said the Partnership's position appeared to be based "on fairly simple mathematics and a fairly simply understanding of the service consequences" of cutting 30,000 full-time workers from the payroll over the next four years. That figure is based on the 220,000 workers financed entirely by city funds.
Since last fall, through layoffs, attrition and early retirement incentives, the administration has cut more than 10,000 jobs from the 247,000 posts financed by all funds, not including part-time workers or those employed by the Health and Hospitals Corporation, but it has not yet said how many more it plans to cut over the next four years.
The Partnership said it realized the difficulty of cutting so many jobs, and said it could not be done by layoffs or retirements alone but would require streamlining and reorganizing government functions, abandoning some and preserving others, freezing wages and changing union work rules and labor practices, reducing vacations and fringe benefits. The city has vowed to pursue similar options, so far without success.
Even as the Partnership warned of the dangers in the coming years, the city and state comptrollers said yesterday that the city may face gaps in its $28.5 billion budget for the current fiscal year, just three months after cobbling it together. City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, echoing her earlier assessment, put the gap at $419 million, because of lower tax revenues than the administration projects, and higher expenditures.
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said the budget may be out of whack by $283 million, because of greater than projected costs for labor, overtime pay and debt service on the city's bonds. City officials said they believed the budget was in balance, but they have drafted a $200 million contingency plan of cuts in spending for supplies and other programs if necessary.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
How to Beat System On Third and Long

BYLINE: By Thomas George

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Derrick Thomas knows what it is like to be young and full of despair and feel as if you are "a product of the system." He particularly understands that there is a direct link between education and self-esteem and effecting change.
He is a product of that system. 
 He is effecting change.
Before the Kansas City Chiefs clashed with the Buffalo Bills last night, Thomas, the Chiefs' rock-solid linebacker, reflected on growing up in Miami, growing up as a pro in Kansas City and on his Third and Long program, which seeks to help this city's inner-city youth understand that learning to read unlocks doors.
"I based my program on past experience," said the 24-year-old Thomas, who is in his third season with the Chiefs and who last season led the league in sacks with 20.
"I majored in criminal justice at Alabama, but before that I was a product of the system in Miami. From a period of age 11 through 16, I went through living two lives. I was a good kid -- well, a semi-good kid -- from 7:30 in the morning till 6 in the afternoon after football practice. At night I would go stand on the corner with the guys and get involved in all kinds of deviant acts.
"One fatal day I wound up in court in trouble and they took me out of public school for a year and put me into what was like a boot camp, the Day Marine Institute. I thought it was the worst thing that ever happened to me. I was a sophomore in high school and I thought my life was over. No football. No nothing.
"It turned out to be the best thing that ever happened to me. I gained a positive outlook and learned to set goals and see them through. I gained friendships, even with the judge in Miami who sentenced me, that have lasted. I gained a sense of pride and the value of reading. I guess what I learned most was this: If you educate a youth, you've won half the battle.
"Once you educate, they have the ability to make decisions and better choices. I guess I always remember what a professor once told me. He said, 'Once you habilitate an individual, he can be rehabilitated.' And a counselor once told me, 'Derrick, if you want to help the youth the most, teach them one thing: how to read.' "
Thomas, who wears No. 58, has 58 youths in the program. Each Saturday before Chiefs home games, Thomas gathers his group at a library where stories are read by a librarian, himself and other Chiefs' players. Reading skills are practiced. He also offers them an annual Christmas party and always a receptive ear.
The program has given Thomas inspiration on the field. At 6 feet 3 inches and 236 pounds, he is listed as a right outside linebacker but often lines up on the left side and in passing situations becomes a defensive end.
Opponents have paid more attention to Thomas and had limited him to 11/2 sacks this season. But he had four sacks last night in the Chiefs' 33-6 victory. His play is a reason the Chiefs' defense entered the game with the American Conference's No. 4-ranked defense (seventh against the run and third against the pass), allowing only 12.6 points per game.
Last season, Thomas had seven sacks in a Chiefs game at home against Seattle. Before the game, Air Force pilots offered a spectacular air show over Arrowhead Stadium and one gave Thomas a bandanna the pilots wear, which he wore under his helment in the game.
Thomas's father, Robert, was an Air Force captain lost in Vietnam during an operation called Linebacker Two. He was declared legally dead in 1980 and remains Thomas's chief hero.
The Chiefs think they are a Super Bowl caliber team, but their offense has barely reached that level yet. Kansas City relies on a crunching ground game and a sporadic passing attack, but the defense and Thomas shine. Thus, developing a consistent offense is the final ingredient for the Chiefs to reach their goals.
Thomas thinks the offense will improve. It is all a matter, he said, of making the right moves and, against complex defenses, the right reads.
"Our defense has played well, but our offense hasn't clicked yet," he said. "We will get it together. You look around the N.F.L. and scoring is down everywhere. I think it's injuries to key people on offense, like Joe Montana with San Francisco and Randall Cunningham with Philadelphia. We've missed key people on offense due to injury, too. Teams are more interested in ball control after what the Giants did last year, but I think things will pan out in scoring by the end of the season.
"One of the things I hope to do with my group is to bring them closer to the N.F.L. and to football and their dreams and maybe to come up with some type of uniform for them. Some have designer clothes, others barely nothing. I want them to know that no matter what your economic situation, you walk into my program and you are equal. And reading? It wipes out a lot of silly craziness that they go through."

HEADLINE: Cooperation Treaty Is Signed to Bolster Regional Economy

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Officials from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York City took the first tentative steps yesterday toward fashioning a regional approach to economic problems, signing what amounted to a nonaggression pact.
The agreement, endorsed by economic development officials amid the splendor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, commits them to work toward keeping companies in the region and attracting new ones, instead of concentrating on soliciting each other's business. It calls for them to forswear advertising that casts aspersions on another area in the region. And it pledges them to market the three states together to attract overseas companies and to increase tourism. 
 Many members of the audience, who were mostly other officials from cities and counties within the region, expressed concern that translating enlightened statements into reality would be very difficult, considering the role that politics plays in generating a culture of economic competitiveness. Nothing in the pact binds counties or cities other than New York, and even for the signers and their agencies, the agreement sets goals, not mandates.
Several noted that less than 24 hours after the pact is signed, New Jersey's largest utility, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, will begin a new advertising campaign called "New Jersey in the 90's," which will promote the advantages of doing business in that state. The campaign, which will begin with an address by Governor Jim Florio, is aimed primarily at businesses in the New York City area. "It's time for the state to go on the offensive, to identify where New Jersey should fit into companies' expansion or relocation plans," said Stephen J. Kukan, the utility's general manager in charge of area development.
Westchester County ran a similar radio advertising campaign aimed at New York City companies that earned the enmity of city officials. But since county officials did not sign yesterday's agreement, they would not be precluded from running such a campaign again.
Despite the inevitable difficulties of getting people to change a decades-old philosophy, many participants cheered the group's willingness to take the first step.
"What's important is that the meeting happened," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association.
Until preparation for the conference began several months ago, many of the region's economic development officials had not even met their counterparts face to face.
 
New Friends in Strange Places
 Stephen Morello, New York State's deputy commissioner of advertising and marketing, described how strange it was to discuss joint policies with people with whom he normally is "locked in mortal combat."
Usually, he said, his job is to convince people that the Adirondacks are better than the Berkshires, the Alleghenies or the Ozarks. Now he also finds himself trying to design tour packages that will allow tourists to take advantage of the best sights in the three states.
Robert B. Reich, the professor at the Harvard University John F. Kennedy School of Government who delivered the lunchtime address in the museum's Temple of Dendur, praised the group for forsaking traditional beggar-thy-neighbor policies.
But he warned them to expect three powerful forces attempting to undermine their efforts: politicians whose main concern is announcing the arrival of a new company and with it, more jobs; the news media, which he said are geared to keeping track of jobs won or lost, and the business community, which he described as very adept at talking about public-private partnerships one minute and then demanding tax abatements the next.
Still, he said, "This is a great step forward that you're all here talking to each other."
In addition to endorsing general peace principles, the officials accepted recommendations from four task forces they had created. The task force in charge of forging a regional economic development policy recommended that the three states work toward precluding active solicitation of individual companies within the region. It also called for a regional legislative agenda and for efforts toward reducing public subsidies in retaining and attracting companies.
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, New York City's deputy mayor for finance and economic development, cited an example where New Jersey spent $30 million trying to keep one company from leaving, while she had to offer a package of $50 million in incentives to keep the commodities exchanges in New York City. "It seems to me we could have spent that money in a much better way," she said.
Those in the trenches, the men and women who actually sit down and talk with companies about tax incentives to keep them in place, agreed to meet at least once a quarter to develop a longterm regional economic strategy and programs to promote the region. They also pledged to avoid economic development programs designed exclusively to attract businesses from one part of the region to another.
 
An Invitation to France
 Although none of this amounts to an explicit promise to stop bidding against one another, Carl Weisbrod, the president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation, said their recommendations represented a feat nonetheless.
The marketing group recommended that the three states jointly produce promotional materials aimed at specific countries overseas and industries within them considered most promising for bringing new jobs and visitors into the region. Besides obvious countries like Japan, Germany, Britian and Canada, the group also recommended going after less-developed but potentially more lucrative markets like France, Italy, the Netherlands, Korea and Hong Kong.
The group identified several industries where it believed the region had the advantage: banking and insurance, telecommunications and information processing, biotechnology and medicine, and electronics. While none of the three states, all on tight budgets, have been able to afford to participate in national trade shows, the group suggested that by pooling their resources, the states could market as one.
The fourth task force, on developing international businesses, had the fewest new ideas. It agreed to explore sharing office space abroad, and to give Connecticut access to the special export telephone number of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The conference, conceived by Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, was financed by James D. Wolfensohn Inc., an investment advisory firm.

The meeting took place in the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan yesterday. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times) (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Lower Lead Limits Are Made Official

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The Federal Government today officially lowered the threshold at which children are considered to have lead poisoning, thus increasing the number of children considered poisoned to four million or more from several hundred thousand.
The Federal Centers for Disease Control said that scientific evidence was "so overwhelming and compelling" that children suffer mental problems when their blood contains even 10 micrograms of lead per deciliter of blood that the threshold of poisoning, 25 micrograms per deciliter, must be lowered. 
 Even below 10 micrograms, the centers said, adverse effects in children have been reported, and if the evidence continues to accumulate, a still lower standard may be needed.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said all children should be tested for lead in their blood over the next few years, as cheaper and more convenient tests are developed. For now, he suggests that any parent who has concerns about the lead paint at home and has a child under 6 "should see their physician or go into their clinic" to get the child tested.
Children are typically exposed to lead by eating chips of lead paint or breathing in dust from the paint.
As he announced the new "threshold of concern" in Washington today, Dr. Sullivan called for a broad national program to clean up lead, particularly in houses. But he said that most of the burden of that program should fall on state and local governments rather than the Federal Government.
He said he has asked Congress for $14.9 million for the 1992 fiscal year for a testing program, an increase from $8 million from 1991. Dr. Henry Falk of the Centers for Disease Control said that amount would test only "some tens of thousands" of the millions of children considered poisoned under the new guidelines.
Beyond that small program, Dr. Sullivan said, other testing of children and houses and certification of contractors who perform the tests or clean up housing should be left to state and local governments or to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Dr. Sullivan said lead poisoning affected virtually every system in the body and was usually irreversible. "It has been linked to kidney disease and hypertension in adults," he said. But he said high lead levels were "especially devastating to children and fetuses and can cause learning disabilities and deficits in I.Q."
He said that American children from all social and economic groups were at risk. He said about four million children, or 17 percent of all American children, are believed to have lead in their blood at a level that requires intervention.
The new threshold represents a major increase in concern. In 1978 the Government banned lead in gasoline, and since then the amount of lead in children's blood has dropped greatly. But because children between 15 months and 6 years old can ingest large amounts of lead from paint dust or chips, the problem remains large.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, an author of a bill to end lead poisoning in children, criticized the Adminstration's position. "The urgent question raised by the new standard is, What are we going to do to help the millions of lead-poisoned children?" he said. "Unfortunately, the answer from the Administration is, 'not much.' "
Dr. Herbert Needleman, chairman of psychiatry and pediatrics at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, whose research was central in alerting regulators to the hazards of lead in children, said he was pleased with the new standard but disagreed with the Administration about what action should be taken.
He suggested requiring those selling their homes to have their houses tested for lead hazards, just as they do now for termites. He also suggested that the Government set standards to insure that those who test for lead and clean it up work according to reliable standards.
The Administration opposes a Federal role in those activities. And when Dr. Sullivan was asked today if he supported the right of a home owner, at a minimum, to find out if a house has already been tested and what the results were, he replied: "I would suggest we have a Secretary of Housing for that. I'm the Secretary of H.H.S. -- I have 250 programs I'm responsible for and I don't need additional ones."
An official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, John C. Weicher, said he had no comment.
The new threshold today suggested the following action levels: between 10 and 14 micrograms, children should be tested more frequently and preventive measures in homes should be begun; between 15 and 19 micrograms, a child should get special nutritional information on lead poisoning and how the right diet might prevent damage from doses of lead. If blood levels this high continue, testing and cleaning up the child's environment is necessary. A level from 20 to44 micrograms would require medical tests, perhaps drug treatment to remove lead from blood, and a cleanup of the child's environment. Medical emergencies begin at 70 micrograms.

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Refugees, Reconsidered

 BODY:
Vietnam has tentatively agreed to accept the forced return of tens of thousands of its citizens who left, often risking their lives in dangerous, leaky boats. The agreement, worked out with Britain and the United Nations, could fall apart under strong objection from the United States.
That would be unfortunate. The U.S. has adamantly opposed forced repatriation of the Vietnamese. But circumstances, including U.S.-Vietnam relations, are changing and this new policy may be more realistic. Rather than block it, the U.S. ought to help insure that it is carried out fairly. 
 More than 100,000 refugees from Vietnam are now living in camps in Southeast Asia, about half in Hong Kong. Sympathy for these escapees probably peaked at Christmastime 1989, when Britain deported 51 boat people, mostly women and children, from Hong Kong to Hanoi.
Britain's action may have been crude, but it vividly underscored the need to distinguish between genuine political refugees, who have a "well-founded fear of persecution" in their homeland, and economic refugees, seeking to escape poverty.
By international agreement, political refugees deserve the most generous treatment. But the same preferences do not apply to those fleeing economic deprivation. That points to the need for proper and relatively uniform screening procedures to distinguish. As long as the procedures themselves do not violate human rights, those screened out as economic migrants are candidates for return.
It's not a happy result. But no country can let in everyone who wants in; governments are constantly forced to make these decisions. Hong Kong sends illegal immigrants back to China. The U.S. forcibly turns back boat people from Haiti.
In any case, forcible return for the Vietnamese is not, arguably, any less humane than requiring them to stay in squalid resettlement camps where they are subject to robberies, murder and suicide.
Since 1989, about 6,000 boat people declared to be economic migrants have already returned to Vietnam voluntarily. An international fund for refugees provides them with living allowances and U.N. monitors check to see that they are not persecuted.
The United States now has some leverage to help insure that those who are returned to Vietnam are treated humanely. Last year, a plan was sketched out to normalize U.S.-Vietnam relations. The prospect of economic benefits that would result from normalization ought to be a powerful incentive to Vietnam to treat its returnees decently -- and could ultimately discourage more economic migrants from fleeing the country.

HEADLINE: Airport Rail Portion of Cuomo Plan Must Offer Travelers More

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's public-works plan to revive New York City's economy (news article, Sept. 24) includes a light-rail service to La Guardia and Kennedy airports that ignores the lessons of the defunct Train to the Plane. Most travelers with more than one piece of luggage find subway stairs and multiple transfers too difficult. The real market for an airport rail system would most likely be the unencumbered business traveler. They would not be attracted by lower cost, but only by speed. 
 Successful airport links, such as London's, Boston's and Washington's are the fastest way to the central business district. The defunct service offered by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was no swifter than bus or taxi. There is no evidence the proposed route, terminating in Long Island City, would be different.
Rail service could be made attractive only if the nonstop trip from Kennedy to Grand Central or Pennsylvania Station could be made in 30 minutes or less. Otherwise, taxis will be far more convenient and the rail link will become yet another financial burden to the M.T.A.
 
DAVID H. FOX
Linden Hill, Queens, Sept. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Old Butler Ploy

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
President Bush says the media did it. Not the butler. The butler never does it anymore. Everybody's been on to the butler for years. It must have been 1913 when I first heard a kid coming out of a movie tell a pal who was waiting to get in, "Don't waste your nickel, the butler did it." If not earlier.
Anyhow the butler hasn't done it in years. This is because hardly anybody has a butler anymore. The people who can afford butlers nowadays are mostly in prison, which makes you wonder why you never hear anybody say, "The butler's boss did it." 
 So knowing he couldn't pin the rap on the butler, President Bush called a news conference the other day and said the media did it. In politics these days and even in high-flown ideological disputation, it is almost always the media that do the dirty deed.
At any given moment half the population is pinning the crime of the given moment on the media. Monitoring organizations, each as relentless as Javert tracking a stolen loaf of bread, are constantly alerting us to media depredations.
Still, it's surprising to find President Bush doing the Charlie Chan, Hercule Poirot, Miss Marple number. Few Presidents have been jollied so tirelessly by the media. The burbling of journalists in print and television about Mr. Bush's mastery of practically everything can make you grind your molars down to stubs if you hold that the journalist's first duty is to keep an eye open for clay feet on the mightiest of gods.
But back to our story: It was a Friday on television. CNN featured Robert Gates, Bush's nominee to run the C.I.A. Gates was insisting that, if given the job, he would never refuse to tell Presidents things those Presidents didn't want to hear.
This foolhardy announcement seemed to mark Gates as hopelessly unqualified for the job considering the history of what usually happens to people who tell Presidents what they don't want to hear, which is that they don't last long. Anybody remember George Ball?
In Lyndon Johnson's reign, Johnson officially authorized Ball to tell him things he didn't want to hear. The deal was Johnson wouldn't make Ball disappear, he just wouldn't pay any attention to what Ball told him. So Ball told him he couldn't win in Vietnam and Johnson, keeping his end of the deal, ignored Ball and saw his Presidency destroyed by losses in Vietnam.
While Gates on CNN was reminding us of the reckless foolishness of telling Presidents what they don't want to hear, Bush interrupted with a news conference to counter Democratic efforts to depict him as indifferent to the shabby state of the country's domestic affairs.
Somebody at the office had obviously made bold to tell him the Democrats were scoring with the line that while he was a crackerjack President of the Whole Darn World, as President of the United States he left a lot to be desired. What's more, the economy wasn't too good either.
Such counsel goes to the problem of what Presidents must do to win the next election, one field in which most of them will tolerate hearing what they'd rather not. So the President spoke a good deal about "domestic agenda," as though to say: "Here now! Who dares say I'm too dazzled about being President of the Whole Darn World to be deeply involved in our domestic problems?"
What gave the public the unfair impression that he had time only for international problems? You guessed it, folks: the media. All that coverage the media devoted to foreign affairs distorted the public's idea of the true nature of his toil.
Take this very news conference. He had summoned the media to talk about the economy and how to get it hopping again by cutting the tax on income from capital gains, for instance. Yet these media people had persistently changed the subject to foreign affairs.
He had obviously come prepared to nail down his case, for he picked up a sheet of paper and said he'd been keeping score: how many questions on domestic issues, how many on foreign? He didn't give his tally, but the Times reporter, Andrew Rosenthal, later counted a total of 26 questions, 10 of them on domestic affairs, which may be enough to convict if the jury is saturated with great sound bites.
Makes you wish they'd bring back the butler.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

Cuomo's plan to revitalize New York's economy with a sweeping public-works program (news story, Sept. 25) is hard to fathom. HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Toshiba Rewrites a Hollywood Script

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
From a distance, Time Warner's talks with two big Japanese companies about a billion- dollar investment in the debt-laden American company seem familiar: another Japanese effort to buy into Hollywood and the software that will be critical for the next generation of consumer electronics.
But to hear the executives of the Toshiba Corporation talk, an alliance with Time Warner Inc. is very different from the recent forays of the Sony Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. 
 When Sony bought Columbia Pictures Inc. in 1989 and Matsushita purchased MCA Inc., the parent of Universal Studios, last year, both companies seemed intent on becoming Hollywood moguls. Only by buying an entire studio, both companies reasoned, could they get the expertise and the ill-defined synergy between hardware and software they needed.
Now the accepted wisdom in Tokyo, echoed in Los Angeles, is that both Sony and Matsushita are being milked for cash by their Hollywood partners. That may say volumes about why Toshiba is proceeding cautiously to work out its investment in Time Warner, the second-largest cable operator in the United States and a producer of cable shows through its Home Box Office.
Time Warner's chairman, Steven J. Ross, is currently in Japan, but it is likely that it will be a while before he completes the final negotiations on the $1 billion investment -- half from Toshiba and half from C. Itoh & Company, the giant Japanese trading concern. Together, the two Japanese companies would get a 12 percent stake in a new venture that would comprise most of Time Warner's film, cable and pay-television business.
Unlike its crosstown rivals, though, Toshiba seems uninterested in anything more than a loose link to Warner's movie business, saying it does not want to depend on the fortunes of hit movies for its profits. But cable television is another story, particularly as Toshiba feels an increasing squeeze in its traditional computer chip and electronics businesses.
"The first thing you have to understand about this deal is that it is not about the movies, it is about cable television," a senior executive of Toshiba said the other day, asking to remain anonymous because the company is not officially discussing the Time Warner talks. "We expect we will learn a lot about the entertainment business," he said, "but that is secondary."
 
Emergence of Cable
 While the cable market is nearly saturated in the United States, it has spread slowly in Japan, where direct broadcasting from satellites to small rooftop antennas has been the favored method of giving viewers a wider choice of programming.
But gradually, cable is starting to take off. And Toshiba sees tremendous possibilities for interactive cable systems that can bring this video-addicted society in-home services ranging from banking to custom-made business-news programs.
"The problem," the Toshiba executive said, "is that we have none of the software expertise. And Time Warner has no ability to develop the hardware" for things like interactive television.
For Time Warner, Toshiba's view of the future of television hardware -- from high-definition television to interactive television -- is crucial. C. Itoh also has ventures in satellite broadcasting and owns a number of cable television properties in Japan.
It was C. Itoh, according to several people involved in the deal, that introduced Time Warner to Toshiba after shopping the investment around to Hitachi Ltd. and other Japanese electronics companies. It is an unusual alliance because Toshiba is loosely tied to the Mitsui group, which includes one of C. Itoh's biggest trading rivals. Such relationships across "keiretsu," or affiliated companies, are still relatively rare in Japan.
One Time Warner area Toshiba does not appear interested in now is the politically sensitive business of publishing magazines, which one senior Toshiba executive characterized earlier this year as a "political time bomb." Time Warner publishes Time, People, Sports Illustrated and other magazines.
Toshiba is still smarting from the 1987 Toshiba Machine scandal, in which one of its subsidiaries was caught illegally shipping machine tools to the Soviet Union. The scandal, and the company's handling of it, was a bitter lesson about American politics. Though the parent company appeared to have no knowledge of the transaction, its leadership resigned and Congress imposed trade sanctions against it.
Toshiba also does not seem to feel the need to integrate the Warner Brothers studio into its consumer electronics plans. "Whether Toshiba or C. Itoh can make this work is up to them," said Michael P. Schulhof, vice chairman of Sony U.S.A., who has chosen a different path. "With Columbia Pictures, we have an openness, a willingness to exchange ideas, that from the Sony side we never would have had with an outsider."
But the limited nature of the proposed Toshiba-Warner alliance -- at least at its initial stages -- also reflects the fact that Toshiba is a far different company than Sony and Matsushita, with very different strengths.
While consumer electronics is Sony's and Matsushita's core business, Toshiba's might is in semiconductors, computing and industrial electronics. And that is where Toshiba's somewhat conservative chief executive, Joichi Aoi, is still betting the future lies.
 
Year of Heavy Spending
 Toshiba has been spending heavily this year -- about $2.5 billion on research and development and another $3.8 billion on new plants and equipment. Much of that is directed toward manufacture of a new generation of powerful 16-megabit memory chips in volume.
"You need to go ahead and build, even in recessions, if you are to stay ahead in this business," Mr. Aoi said earlier this year, "especially in semiconductors and computers." He conceded that "consumer electronics has been going through a decline" that few at Toshiba think will be reversed anytime soon.
Still, Toshiba wants to transform its consumer business. "Japanese electronics companies cannot anticipate another boom product like the Walkman until high-definition television takes off," said Mike Jeremy, the technology analyst at Baring Securities in Tokyo. "They have calculated that the cost of continuing to do what they are doing at the moment in consumer electronics will soon result in a decline in profitability. And so when a debt-laden company like Warner appears, it is an opportunity to make some money in a new part of the business and transform their image rather cheaply."
Mr. Aoi may also be motivated by the fact that Toshiba's core businesses are facing more profitability troubles than at any time in several years. In the computer-chip business, Toshiba's early dominance has been challenged by rivals, and in a weak market prices are low.
"They are definitely having trouble" because of the weakness in demand for the four-megabit chip, said Peter G. Wolff, who follows the company for Kidder, Peabody & Company in Tokyo. "They are postponing the investment on the 16-megabit as long as possible, but these chips are not as profitable as they once were."
Nor are Toshiba's other big hits of the late 1980's: laptop and notebook computers.
Toshiba was the pioneer of the laptop and captured the lead before other computer makers realized that portable computing would be a gold mine. But over the last 18 months, it has lost is magic touch, particularly in the United States.
While the company produced the first notebooks sold in Japan, it did not adapt its machines for the American market fast enough. As its products began to look dated, several top officials left the company and a host of clone makers raced in.
The early evidence suggests that Toshiba's 1991 market share in notebooks will be well below last year's 21 percent. There have already been layoffs in Irvine, Calif., where Toshiba manufactures many of its American products. And the problems continue: the NEC Corporation has beaten the company to market with a color version of its lightweight notebooks in Japan, and the Compaq Computer Corporation just announced a similar machine in the United States.
Toshiba's recovery depends mostly on the success of a new generation of notebook computers with color screens, which it is developing in a joint venture with the International Business Machines Corporation. But the product is not likely to be available until next year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher as Skepticism Is Voiced on Lower Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced in world trading yesterday amid renewed skepticism that American interest rates were heading lower.
Gold prices subsided worldwide on profit taking. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $357.60 an ounce, off $1.70 from Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York said later that gold had fallen $1.95, to $356.80 an ounce. 
 Trading was active, with the dollar posting its strongest gains against the Japanese yen, which has rallied over the last week, and the German mark. The dollar returned above the critical 130 level against the yen and broke technical barriers against the mark.
Helping to drive trading were "diminished expectations that the Federal Reserve is going to ease interest rates," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA, an advisory firm.
He said the market interpreted proposals outlined by President Bush yesterday on the nation's tight credit situation as being "in lieu of a Fed easing." Lower interest rates affect the dollar negatively because they lessen the value of dollar-denominated securities.
Separately, some nervousness occurred before the meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers this weekend in Thailand. Some market participants are said to be having second thoughts that the ministers of the leading industrialized nations will take steps to support a stronger yen to ease Japan's trade surpluses.
Fund managers and corporations were active dollar buyers, and many traders speculated that the dollar was poised for an advance, at least against the European currencies.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.93 Japanese yen, from 129.53 yen on Monday. Later in London, it advanced further, to 130.10 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 130.17 yen, up from 129.40 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7140, from $1.7360 late on Monday. In New York, it cost $1.7070 to buy one pound, less than $1.7335 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Monday, included: 1.6990 German marks, up from 1.6805; 1.4875 Swiss francs, up from 1.4735; 5.7865 French francs, up from 5.7230; 1,269.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.50, and 1.1285 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1293.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Money Supply Doesn't Tell All

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
FROM the White House to Wall Street, everybody is watching the weekly money supply numbers as if the economy's life depended on them. And some people who have been leaning on the Federal Reserve to ease for years, including the Bush Administration, have seized on anemic money growth as a rationale for pressing the Fed to lower short-term rates -- already the lowest since 1973 -- some more.
But Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs, contends that the latest obsession with the money supply is a little crazy, if not downright dangerous. Money growth is not a reliable guide to the economy's direction in the short run, he said. So tying Fed policy too mechanically to the money supply risks supplying more stimulus than the economy can safely handle and a future inflation flare-up. 
 The mechanical notion popular now is that the pace of money growth dictates, with a delay of a quarter or two, the pace of the economy's growth. It is an appealing idea partly because the relationship does hold perfectly over long stretches of time and partly because the money supply did stall last summer. Had the Fed reacted more quickly, some recent converts to monetarism say, the recession might have been avoided.
The Fed's favorite measure of the money supply is M-2, a broad amalgam of most checking and saving deposits in households, including certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds.
What makes many people anxious is that M-2 has expanded by just 2.5 percent in the last year, less than the Fed's lowest target for it of 2.6 percent. Indeed, for the last few months, the money supply has actually been shrinking. The only other time that happened for any length of time was from 1928 to 1933 when, as one businessman put it, money was sleeping. Hence the worry.
But the relationship between money and the economy is not all that tight, Mr. Giordano argued, and the money supply has sent some spectacularly wrong signals in the past.
In the 1970's changes in M-2 preceded, more or less reliably, shifts in the G.N.P. by a couple of quarters. But more recently M-2 and the economy have occasionally gone separate ways. In 1986, while M-2 raced, the economy ground to a halt. In 1987, when M-2 started to crawl, the economy took off. "If money were all that mattered," Mr. Giordano wrote, "real G.N.P. would have been flat from 1987 to 1989, and the recession would have arrived much sooner."
One reason for the breakdown, he said, is that people seem to be getting by with less cash and smaller bank balances. With more choices, consumers are freer to shift their money. From mid-1984 through 1986, the difference between long- and short-term rates averaged around three percentage points, and nearly $200 billion of household assets flowed into bond mutual funds. Such funds, which offer more liquidity than C.D.'s, were not widely available before 1983. The net inflow into bond mutual funds so far this year has been around $80 billion to $90 billion. Time deposits and money market mutual funds account for almost the entire shortfall in M-2 growth, which would have approached an 8 percent rate without them.
But other forces are also holding down money. One is that banks are reducing deposit rates because they do not need the money. Instead, they are trying to bolster their capital. Banks with bigger capital cushions are likely to be rewarded by the stock market and find it easier to get permission to enter new businesses.
The activities of the Resolution Trust Corporation are also depressing money growth. Assets it takes over are financed with Government debt, which is not part of the money supply, and are no longer bank liabilities, which are. Government borrowing to cover thrift liquidations amounts to $32 billion this year and held M-2 down by a percentage point, Mr. Giordano estimates.
Other measures of liquidity are looking livelier. The stock and bond markets are awash with funds. Commodity prices have recently firmed. The dollar has weakened. The gap between long- and short-term interest rates is wide. And the premium between AAA and BBB credits is very narrow. When there is little liquidity, lenders charge less creditworthy borrowers large premiums.
No one can ever be sure that stagnant money growth is not a portent of an economic downturn. But simply assuming that it is -- and putting pressure on the Fed to crank up the printing presses -- carries its own risks. At the very least, devotees of M-2 could wait until the G.N.P. report for the third quarter, due Oct. 29, comes out to see whether the economy's actual performance confirms or contradicts the story told by the money supply.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Drop Sharply in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to decline briskly for the week that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., that focuses on interest rates.
"New York's biggest commercial banks have cut short-term certificate of deposit yields by 29 basis points since the prime rate was lowered on Sept. 13," said Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher. "Assuming the strong downward direction in yields continues at its present pace, the banks' cost of funds would be lowered by 50 basis points by mid-November." (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) 
 "Based on past history," Mr. Heady added, "that could set the stage for further easing by the Federal Reserve System at that time."
Mr. Heady says he thinks an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve will come by the middle of next month.
Bank of New York Acts
According to The Monitor, the largest change in C.D. yields at New York area banks in the last week was made by the Bank of New York, which lowered its yield on its six-month certificate of deposit by 37 basis points, to 4.86 percent. It also dropped the yield on its three-month certificate by the largest amount among the banks, 53 basis points, to 4.60 percent.
In the case of yields on money market accounts, the largest cut was made by Astoria Federal Savings in Queens. It reduced its yield by 21 basis points, to 5.12 percent.
Among the commercial banks in New York, the average yield was cut to 4.70 percent, or a decline of 2 basis points on money market accounts, while the yields on their three-month certificates were off by 9 basis points, to 4.92 percent.
 
Savings Institutions' Yields Fall
 For depositors at savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut by an average of 4 basis points, to 5.29 percent, on money market accounts and by 3 basis points, to 5.36 percent, on three-month C.D.'s.
Nationwide, according to The Monitor, the average yields of 20 leading banks outside the New York region were cut by 3 basis points, to 4.95 percent on money market accounts, and by 4 basis points, to 5.20 percent, on six-month certificates.
At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 5.04 percent, compared with a rate of 5.11 the previous Monday, while the rate on the six-month bill averaged 5.08 percent, compared with 5.14 percent a week ago.
 
Bank Money Accounts
 Annual effective yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, October 9,1991. Some C.D. yields assume reinvestment after maturity. Yields are based on the method of compounding and the rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Mixed in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in slow trading yesterday, as credit market participants bid up prices of short-term issues and sold longer-dated notes and bonds.
Analysts attributed the strength among shorter-term issues to suspicions that the Federal Reserve Board might be gradually moving its target for the overnight Federal funds rate down another notch, to 5 percent. 
 For the third straight day, the Fed allowed the overnight rate for bank loans to trade at 5 1/8 percent, below the 5 1/4 percent level that is widely seen as the Fed's target. The Fed could have undertaken open-market operations to lift the rate back to the target level but did not do so.
 
Below Level Through Day
 "We have not seen the funds rate trade under its target for this long a period in many, many months," one Government securities trader said.
The funds rate remained below the current target level throughout the day, and traded as low as 5 1/16 percent.
"The consensus on the Street is that the Fed hasn't moved," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and analysis on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "But the funds rate trading consistently under 5.25 percent the past few days is a reason to scratch your head and wonder what is going on."
Ever since market participants misinterpreted the meaning of a Fed move just before Thanksgiving in 1989, the central bank has taken pains to send unambiguous signals about its policy intentions.
 
Action May Come Soon
 If the Fed is not lowering the funds rate at the moment, there remains a strong sense that it will soon.
Lincoln F. Anderson, an economic analyst at Fidelity Investments, the Boston mutual fund company, said the Fed would need to do more to spur the economy.
"At 5.25 percent, the funds rate is a lot lower than it was a year ago," Mr. Anderson said. "But inflation is a lot lower now than it was a year ago, and nominal growth in the gross national product has slowed more than rates have fallen."
Many economists note that in past recessions a sustained recovery did not commence until the funds rate fell below the economy's rate of growth.
Efforts announced yesterday by the Bush Administration to ease the tight credit situation and spur bank lending were seen as the main reason that traders sold long-term Treasury issues, even though analysts said the reforms were modest.
Before the changes were announced, rumors circulated that the Treasury would allow banks to use Treasury securities to satisfy reserve requirements, a move that would spur demand. That step, however, was not one of the measures announced yesterday.
 
Secondary Market Prices
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 103 3/8, down 3/8 point, to yield 7.81 percent, compared with 7.78 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 3/32, down 10/32, to yield 7.42 percent. But the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes rose by 1/32, to a late offered price of 100 14/32, to yield 5.88 percent.
In advance of today's auction of new seven-year Treasury notes, the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.17 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.99 percent late yesterday, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.03 percent.
 
High-Yield Pace Quickens
In other developments, the pace of new-issue activity in the high-yield junk bond market quickened yesterday, as two companies offered investors a total of $225 million worth of securities. On Monday, the Century Communications Corporation sold $204 million worth of high-yield debt.
Yesterday P&C Food priced an offering of $125 million worth of ten-year securities through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 11.50 percent notes were priced at $100, or par. They are rated Ba-3 by Moody's Investors Service and B by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
American Medical International priced a $100 million offering of senior secured notes.
The 11 percent notes, which mature Oct. 15, 2000, were priced at $100, or par.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Ba-3 by Moody's and B-plus by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the high-yield market said both issues sold out quickly.
In large part, the sudden spurt in new high-yield issues is seen as a response to the announcement late last week that RJR Nabisco intended to retire significant amounts of high-yield securities with the proceeds from a stock sale.
Elsewhere, participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bond market said prices of most issues were little changed in slow trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point, traders said.

HEADLINE: BUSH EASES RULES IN EFFORT TO SPUR LENDING BY BANKS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
President Bush approved a series of regulatory measures today that he said would encourage banks to make new loans and stimulate the economy, but the announcement was viewed by bankers as a largely symbolic response to growing political pressures.
Taking steps to alleviate what he called a "credit crunch," the President said the measures were intended to "insure that we have sound banks making sound loans." He added that more steps would be taken, but he did not specify them. 
 Most of the measures in today's package were announced in less detail seven months ago, and today's statement from the Treasury Department used language that was virtually identical in many places to its March 1 news release on the subject.
 
Indication of Worry
 The presentation today as a package of new measures was a clear indication of the White House's concern about the sluggish condition of the economy 13 months before the 1992 Presidential election.
Worried that voters may perceive Mr. Bush as concentrating on foreign policy and not interested in pocketbook issues, the White House has gone to lengths recently to make it appear that Mr. Bush is on top of the situtation. [Page D1.]
Today's announcement also included the outlines of two new proposals, neither of which has yet been fully developed. One would permit bank officers who believe that their institutions have been unfairly treated by examiners to circumvent the usual process and appeal instead directly and secretly to supervisors in Washington.
 
In Line With International Rules
 The other would give the banks more flexibility in raising capital, presumably freeing them to make more loans. Many other countries now permit banking companies to treat a greater amount of their preferred stock as capital than the United States does. Several years ago, the United States signed the Basel Accord, an international agreement that standardized banking requirements. When it takes effect, the new measure will bring American regulatory practice into line with most other countries.
A third part of the package involves the important area of valuing real estate. The Administration said the guidelines were being drafted and might be completed by the end of the month. The guidelines would cover how banks classify loans and when they recognize losses.
The issue of the weak economy is so politically charged that the Cabinet has been deeply divided for some time over whether the regulatory package should have been announced much earlier and been more substantial, according to a senior Administration official close to the President.
The official, an economic policy maker who insisted on not being identified, said that four Cabinet members had urged the President to act sooner, but that they had been resisted by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The official said the four were the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Jack E. Kemp; Labor Secretary Lynn M. Martin; Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, and Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner.
 
No Enthusiasm From Industry
 Industry reaction was largely unenthusiastic.
"There is a certain amount of silly season talk in response to an economy that is sputtering," said Herbert M. Sandler, chairman and chief executive of World Savings and Loan Association of Oakland, Calif., a $25 billion institution that is the nation's third-largest savings association and widely considered among the best managed.
"They're saying to examiners and bankers, 'be prudent,' " Mr. Sandler said. "But, of course, that is what they should have been doing in the first place. All this talk about a credit crunch is overblown. The people who aren't getting loans are those who got them in the 80's and shouldn't have. The good borrowers just aren't coming in to borrow."
Robert E. Litan, a banking specialist at the Brookings Institution who was on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration, called the proposal "thin gruel."
 
Reaction in Congress
 Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, accused the President of "playing games with bank regulation as a cover for the Administration's economic failures."
Mr. Gonzalez singled out the idea to permit bankers to go over the heads of examiners when they disagree with regulatory decisions as particularly dangerous. He said it would have a "chilling effect on examiners."
The Administration has tried to blame regulators for the anemic recovery. In the March announcement, Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson referred to bank examiners as terrorists. His language today was more muted, perhaps in response to vigorous objections from the nation's top regulators, including L. William Seidman, the departing chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and William Taylor, head of the Fed's bank supervision division, whose confirmation as Mr. Seidman's successor is expected shortly..
"We believe that regulation has been a contributing factor to limited credit availability," Mr. Robson said at a news briefing this afternoon. "It is by no means the only factor. We're trying to bring that factor back into balance."
 
Clearly on the Defensive
 But, Mr. Robson and other Administration officials, clearly on the defensive, asserted that the new guidelines were not tantamount to the 1980's style of deregulation, in which the savings and loan crisis occurred.
The bankers "need to know the situation is not going to be one of all the regulators hitting them either with powder puffs or with chain saws," Mr. Robson said. "You want to be somehwere in the middle."
Some industry representatives, including the American Bankers Association, the largest bank trade group, said they were encouraged because the steps showed that tight credit had become an important item on the President's agenda.
"It's important, if only because these are now Presidential concerns," said Robert H. Dugger, chief economist at the American Bankers Association.
Mr. Bush acknowledged during a picture-taking ceremony that the package was "not going to cure the whole thing, but we're trying to do everything an Administration can to assist an economy that we think is moving out" of recession.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Vows To 'Contain' Tax Growth

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins pledged yesterday to hold down taxes, to build up reserve funds to weather future fiscal storms and to cut New York City's work force further to keep its budget balanced over the next four years.
Reporting to the State Financial Control Board, Mr. Dinkins said he would "contain the overall level of tax growth" to "make sure it is well below" the $500 million annual property tax increases that he had previously planned to help close projected deficits in each of the next three years. He did not offer to freeze taxes, as some business and civic groups and the City Council have urged, but he did not flatly rule it out. 
 His language, carefully couched as it was, represented his strongest statement yet of his intention to avoid more taxes, on top of the big tax increases of recent years.
Mr. Dinkins said he was also committed to "significant work force reduction" and indicated he was prepared to lay off more workers if municipal unions did not agree to productivity savings and to concessions on wages, benefits and work rules. But he did not specify how many more jobs he planned to trim from the payroll of a quarter-million workers.
 
A 'Rainy Day Fund'
 The Mayor also proposed to create a special "rainy day fund" of unspecified size as a cushion against future economic downturns "so that we can keep taxes stable even in the toughest times." He did not say where he would get the money for this fund, which would require changes in state law to allow the city to roll over surpluses from year to year. But he suggested that some of the $1 billion in aid he was seeking from the Municipal Assistance Corporation could be used.
Mr. Dinkins's monthly report to the Financial Control Board, a state body set up to oversee the city's finances in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, amounted to buying time until he submits his formal four-year plan to the board next month for bringing the city's spending into line with revenues.
City and state officials said top mayoral aides were still debating what the administration's tax proposals should be, with some arguing for a total freeze and others for annual increases of one-half to one-quarter of the $500 million annual increases Mr. Dinkins had been counting on to help close projected deficits of $1.5 billion in each of the next three years. Still others were said to be urging that the Mayor make no definite promises.
 
'The Basics Are There'
 Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up by the state to borrow money on the city's behalf, has repeatedly conditioned its aid on a plan by the city to hold down taxes and cut costs.
Yesterday, Mr. Rohatyn said, "I think the Mayor has the main elements -- the basics are there." But he added, "to be truly credible, his plan should include the agreement, the support of labor" in paring costs while preserving vital services.
Municipal labor leaders have repeatedly resisted concessions until they see a plan for avoiding further layoffs and spelling out what the unions would receive in return.
 
'A Leaky Bucket'
 "This is a non-event today," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. "We would have been surprised if anything different had happened. The city is attempting to carry this water itself, and it's got a leaky bucket and it's getting its head wet. Without us as partners, they're going to fail."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who heads the control board, praised the Mayor for outlining his goals, but he said that the city still had to come up with a very specific plan by next month and that he would wait until then before passing judgment. He, too, said he believed it would be best if the city won the unions' cooperation.
Yesterday afternoon, the Mayor and the Governor met again to discuss cooperation on a range of issues, including Mr. Cuomo's pledge to have the state begin assuming the city's Medicaid costs.
On the Mayor's tax plans, Richard Riley, a spokesman for the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce, which on Monday called for a four-year tax freeze, said the Mayor was "going in the right direction, but so far he hasn't gone far enough."

HEADLINE: Regional Group Agrees to Increase Penalties on Haiti

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Organization of American States today agreed on a plan to toughen economic sanctions against the new Government of Haiti and also offered to send a civilian O.A.S. observer force to Port-au-Prince to help restore democracy.
The O.A.S. officials met in emergency session at their Washington headquarters after an O.A.S. delegation visiting Haiti on Monday failed to negotiate a return to power of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President. 
 O.A.S. officials insist that their team was close to negotiating a deal with Haiti's coup leaders for Father Aristide's return, under conditions that would have limited some of his powers, before military opponents of Father Aristide surrounded the Parliament and lawmakers named Justice Joseph Nerette of the Supreme Court as provisional President.
 
Rejects Interim Leader
 In an effort to pressure the coup leaders into resuming negotiations, the O.A.S. officials met throughout the day to hammer out a resolution that included the following key points, they said:
First, the O.A.S. officials categorically rejected recognizing the appointment of Justice Nerette, who was sworn in today, as provisional President, a move that the United States took the lead on earlier in the day.
"On the vote that was taken in the Parliament last night," the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said, "our view is that there is no constitutional vacancy and we will not recognize a provisional government.
"President Aristide was forced from office illegally by force of arms," she continued. "The Parliament acted yesterday at gunpoint. The legislators did not vote. They were forced to sign a petition. We do not accept the Parliament's forced action as a legitimate constitutional action."
Second, the O.A.S. resolution toughened earlier economic sanctions imposed on Haiti immediately after the coup on Sept. 30, by "urging" all member states to impose a total trade embargo against the impoverished island state, and particularly a cutoff of its oil supplies. Both Venezuela and Mexico, Haiti's primary oil sources, indicated that they would insure a total cutoff.
 
A Call to Freeze Assets
 The resolution also urged all governments in the Hemisphere to freeze Haitian assets, a move that only the United States has taken so far. The first O.A.S. resolution on Haiti passed on Oct. 2, two days after the coup, "recommended" that all 34 member states suspend their economic, financial and commercial ties with Haiti, as well as any aid and technical cooperation. Not all countries, however, have carried out those recommendations as tightly as has the United States, which cut off all $85 million of its economic aid.
Third, the O.A.S. officials said they were ready to accede to a request by Mr. Aristide that the O.A.S. dispatch a force made up of several hundred civilians that could mediate disputes between Haitian factions and monitor compliance of any agreements reached among them.
The proposed force would not be an invasion force, or a peace-keeping contingent, officials stressed, but rather something closer to the sort of mission that monitored the Haitian elections in December or worked to mediate disputes in Nicaragua between its rival factions. Officials said that as it was now being considered, the civilian force would only go to Haiti if invited in by all sides. All of the details, particularly questions of what sort of protection such a civilian team would be accorded, would have to be negotiated with the current leadership in Haiti, as well as with Father Aristide.
 
Limits on Aristide
 The logic underlying such a force is that the O.A.S. still wants Father Aristide returned to power, but given the intense opposition to him from certain elements in the Haitian military and parliament, O.A.S. officials are convinced that he could only come back in the context of an agreement that limited some of his powers, enjoined him to keep his popular mass supporters from intimidating opponents and insured that he did not take any retribution against the military that ousted him.
"The idea of the force would be to help create a sense of security throughout the country, as the O.A.S. did during the elections," one O.A.S. official said.
"The O.A.S. team that was just there came back impressed by the total distrust and fear that elements of the Parliament and the military have for Aristide and vice versa," the official said. "The idea is that Aristide might want someone around to assure him from threats by the army, and the army and the parliament might want someone around to make sure that Aristide does not abuse his powers again and use mob violence against them."
 
Exile in Venezuela
 Father Aristide, from his side, took the first step toward inviting in such a force by sending a letter from his exile home in Caracas, Venezuela, to the O.A.S. Secretary General, Joao Baena Soares, asking for such a mission. The tone and content of the letter also addressed some of the concerns expressed by the Bush Administration over Father Aristide's human rights record. Those concerns have led the Bush Administration in recent days to distance itself slightly from the Father Aristide, although American officials insist that they still prefer to see him restored to power over any other alternative.
In his letter sent Monday to the O.A.S. and released today, Father Aristide said that "I, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, solemly declare that the only solution to the deep crisis now affecting my country lies in peacefully restoring democracy with full respect for the Constitution, national institutions and the human rights of all Haitians."
O.A.S. officials said one of the problems they have now in trying to mediate in the Haiti crisis is that no one seems to be in charge in Haiti. The newly appointed President seems to take his orders from the coup leaders, and the coup leaders seem to be taking their orders from their enlisted men.

HEADLINE: Soviet Republics Back Gorbachev on Nuclear Cuts

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The four major Soviet republics with nuclear missile bases have been consulted on the latest disarmament initiatives and support President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Soviet officials said today. The officials insisted that Mr. Gorbachev's powers in the arms area were not eroding with the integrity of the union.
With the dissolution of the monolithic Soviet Union, there has been uncertainty and concern about the future control of the long-range nuclear missile bases in the Russian federation, the Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Byelorussia, even as President Bush and President Gorbachev make further pledges and proposals for disarmament. 
 But Kremlin officials insisted at a news conference that the initiatives were not being resisted and were being supported in the four republics. The indulgence of separate sovereignties and caution about union relations are now the hallmark of post-Communist politics in the republics, where views differ on how to deal with de facto membership in the nuclear club.
Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksei Obukhov, one of the principal Soviet arms negotiators, said the four republics had been kept up to date and consulted on the latest disarmament plans, in which President Gorbachev has matched or exceeded a range of unilateral reductions announced last month by President Bush. These include Mr. Gorbachev's pledge to reduce strategic warheads by an additional 1,000 beyond planned treaty limits to a total of 5,000 warheads.
In particular, President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federation, whose vast republic contains most of the strategic missiles, was "fully informed" on the current disarmament consultations and "accepted and approved them," Mr. Obukhov said.
Mr. Yeltsin, whose power has grown with the waning of the union, has been on a vacation retreat and has not commented on any involvement in the disarmament consultations.
Since the collapse of the union after the failed hard-line coup in August, Mr. Yeltsin has maintained that, to better guard against nuclear war ever occurring, the nuclear arms issue was no longer a matter solely for the Kremlin but must be one of joint jurisdiction with the republics where the missiles are based.
Tonight, the Interfax news agency reported that the Foreign Minister of the Russian republic, Andrei Kozyrev, met with an American disarmament consultant now visiting Moscow, First Deputy Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew, to discuss republic proposals to cut strategic warheads even deeper than President Gorbachev's most recent proposal. There was no comment reported by Mr. Bartholomew but the incident was evidence of how unpredicatble the disarmament subject has grown in the dissolved union.
Leaders of the Ukraine, where separatist fervor is strongest, have proposed making the republic free of nuclear weapons. But the precise details of how the this might occur have been left unsettled while the republic points towards a full declaration of independence and presidential elections in December. Some politicians have noted that the fate of the missiles could prove a valuable bargaining lever in future relations among the old union's sovereign republics.
Mr. Yeltsin has offered to store the other republics' missiles on Russian soil. But this idea has not been immediately endorsed and has in some cases fed the traditional fear that Russia, the largest and wealthiest of the republics, will come to dominate whatever survives of the post-Communist Soviet Union.
The nation's republics have been in political disarray since the collapse of the union, trying to create a decentralized economic community and talking vaguely of reviving some sort of looser political union rooted in republic sovereignty. Today, with Mr. Yeltsin still on vacation, his Vice President, Aleksandr Rutskoi, complained that "anarchy is descending on the republic" in the face of "mountains" of new laws that do little to solve the basic economic and political crisis.
Mr. Rutskoi, facing increasing intramural squabbling among the many factions of Russian politics, unexpectedly urged caution about the proposed free-market economic compact supposedly endorsed in theory last week by most republics, including Russia. He complained that Russia was standing as "a cow being milked" by other republics, which were turning the economic proposal into a "graphic instance of banditry." To the contrary, other republics worry that they might be exploited by Russia.
 
Politics Before Economics
 Reversing what had been an approach proposed by Mr. Yeltsin himself, Mr. Rutskoi said that in his view a new political union should first be created by the republics before an economic community is attempted. Such a political union would seem extremely difficult if not impossible to create under the current mood of rapidly escalating separatism in Russia and other republics.
The Vice President heightened the daily talk of "anarchy" as former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze warned that the threat of a right-wing coup did not die with the Communist junta's failed attempt in August.
As quoted by the Interfax news agency, Mr. Shevardnadze, who first warned of the coup danger last winter when he resigned from the Gorbachev Government, told a business meeting here that the coup threat "is still a reality to be reckoned with" because it is "rooted in the deteriorating economic situation and declining production."
Mr. Shevardnadze estimated the disjointed nation was in the critical period within which it needed to create an economic community and a new political union. "It is important to live through these six to eight months without political shocks or cataclysms," he said.
