HEADLINE: Saudi Arabia Pledges $1 Billion to Soviet Union

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia has agreed to send $1 billion in emergency humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union this fall and is working with Egypt to send Islamic "preachers" into Soviet Muslim republics to head off Islamic fundamentalism and "revolutionary themes" coming out of Iran.
The direct aid of food, clothing and medicine is in addition to $1.5 billion in credits pledged earlier to the Soviet Union by Saudi Arabia. The aid has been the subject of high-level discussions in Moscow, Cairo and Jidda over the last two weeks, Saudi and Egyptian officials say. 
 The Saudis have made a heavy financial commitment to the Soviet Union at a time when the Bush Administration is waiting to pledge direct aid until the economic reforms promised by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are carried out. The Bush Administration has accelerated food credits it has made available to the Soviet Union and officials have said they are considering further assistance.
Japan announced today that it would give the Soviets $2.5 billion in emergency credits and guarantees. The announcement was widely seen as a new initiative by Japan to win back possession of islands in the Kurile chain that the Soviet Union captured in the closing days of World War II.
The European Community tentatively approved a $2.4 billion aid package on Monday that includes loans, food and medicine for the Soviet Union.
In confirming the Saudi aid package, which has not been publicly announced by either government, the Saudi Arabian Ambassador to Washington, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, said in an interview that King Fahd believed strongly that industrialized countries should try to meet Moscow's immediate needs.
"The Soviet people would like to have freedom of speech, but that is not enough, they must have freedom to eat," Prince Bandar said. "The Americans, the Europeans and the Japanese should come through with more humanitarian aid from October to December if we are to avoid another shock to the system." He said he brought back a list of urgently needed food, clothing and medicine after meeting with Ivan S. Silayev, who is the chairman of Mr. Gorbachev's economic management committee.
Upon his return to Washington, Prince Bandar said he conveyed King Fahd's sense of urgency on the Soviet aid issue to the White House in a round of meetings here last week.
The Saudi royal family has expressed internal concerns over the stability of the Soviet Union and its Muslim republics in the wake of the unsuccessful August coup in Moscow and the wave of independence movements that have rolled across the country.
Riyadh feels that the role of Iran, as a traditional Western buffer against Soviet expansion into the Persian Gulf, has been diminished by the collapse of Communist control, Arab diplomats here say. But this has not diminished the need to contain the still fervent zeal of Iran's most radical revolutionary elements, which for now command a majority in the Iranian Parliament and have not come to terms with their Arab neighbors, the diplomats say.
Saudi Arabia has distributed about $250 million in aid already pledged to Moscow and the purpose of Prince Bandar's trip to the Soviet Union earlier this month was to clarify how Mr. Gorbachev's government was dealing with incoming aid since many of the central government's functions have been undermined by independence movements in the Soviet republics.
Officials familiar with the missionary plan said Saudi money and Egyptian religious scholars will be deployed to the Muslim republics in the Soviet Union, where they will finance the rebuilding of mosques and perhaps set up special Saudi-Egyptian banks for financing other projects.
"For 70 years, those people were cut off from religion," said one Saudi official. "We will send preachers en masse and they are Sunnis and they will calm the people down," he said, pointing out that the mission will counter the "revolutionary themes" from Iran.
Iran, in which Shiite Islam is predominant, has sought to extend its influence in the Muslim republics of the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Lavish Homes Seen Losing Luster in New Jersey

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 8

 BODY:
In New Jersey, where housing costs reached record heights in the 1980's, the next decade will be a time of maturing baby boomers whose consumption will be less conspicuous and whose home buying may be more modest, forecasters said today in presenting a census portrait of the state in the 1990's.
"The decade of yuppie spending is over," said Dr. James W. Hughes, a demographer who is a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University. "The three-car garage in the front of the house will be a thing of the past. The numbers of those waiting to board the housing train will be smaller and there will be more stability in shelter costs." 
 When the spending and building surge of the 1980's departed, it left behind millions of square feet of vacant office space and new housing production that got ahead of demographics. These population and housing trends are reflected throughout the Northeast.
The 1980's housing market, Dr. Hughes said, exceeded household growth by 25 percent, even as homes continued to bring high prices. The median cost of a home in New Jersey was the highest in the nation in 1990, at $162,000. In 1980, the New Jersey median price was $61,000, about average.
In the decade ahead, he said, the $300,000 house of the 1980's will surrender its popularity to the more modest $200,000 home, and the customary trading up by those in the 45-to-54 age group will be slowed. Some will stay put, while others will settle for building an addition onto their home.
Dr. Hughes's forecast came at a daylong conference at the Ramada Renaissance Hotel, the 12th annual meeting organized by the New Jersey State Data Center. The center is a cooperative of state and local agencies and the Census Bureau and is coordinated by the State Labor Department. Its mission is to provide information and analytical support to planners, academics and business-group representatives, dozens of whom attended the session.
The collapse of New Jersey's housing market has its roots in a steep and continuing slide in the number of households being formed in the state, as well as their size. "This is the lowest level of household growth since the Great Depression," Dr. Hughes said.
Combined with growth in the ranks of those middle-aged and older, and a sharp drop in the number of younger people, both the housing and labor markets could be adversely affected.
A big reason for the decline, he said, was the 3 D's: delayed marriage, deferred childbirth and divorced couples. In the last decade, census figures show, baby boomers -- those born between 1946 and 1964 -- increased by 556,045 people. In 1990, this category included 35 percent of all New Jersey residents.
Other "bulges" in the census place almost 15 percent of the population in the seniors category, those 65 and older. Right behind the seniors and the baby boomers come those of the so-called baby bust generation, those now 10 to 19 years old. That group dropped over the decade by 290,135 people, and it is the decline in this group that is expected to make houses and jobs harder to fill in the next 10 years.
But it is the maturing baby boomers, whose sensitivity to the aging label Dr. Hughes jokingly sought to ease by calling them the "chronologically gifted," who will dominate the economy and whose income and consumption potential are expected to define the 90's.
The last decade, a time of tax cuts and free-wheeling investment, is over, he added, and the 90's have already become a time of tax increases that will consume income, even as the high cost of college tuition takes a greater toll on the middle-aged pocketbook.
"The upscale outer-suburb life style will fade," he said, adding: "The 80's consumer would pay anything to save time. Now people will drive to outlet stores to save money."
 
'Little Land to Waste'
 Echoing Dr. Hughes's assessment was Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association, who urged regional cooperation to ward off the effects of what he said were overbuilding and a propensity to use up precious vacant land.
"We're consuming land faster than almost anything else," he said, "in a state with little land to waste."
Mr. Anderson said he was alarmed at a region becoming more segregated by race and income when the global job market was increasing competition for jobs that could just as easily be located in Ireland as in suburban New Jersey.
Twenty-five percent of all immigrants to the United States settled in the metropolitan area over the last 10 years, 8 percent of them in New Jersey, he said. But once the Federal Government opened the gates, it did little or nothing to help states and communities deal with attendant problems of literacy, job training or social services for them. He called on the Congressional delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to act jointly to resolve some of these shortcomings.
He also expressed alarm at the unsupervised expansion of office space throughout the state in the 1980's that not only glutted the market but also used up valuable land in the New Jersey countryside, far from public transportation, far from a labor market and far from affordable housing for workers. As much as 40 million square feet of space, he said, is still vacant in northern New Jersey alone.
He said land consumption had doubled in the region in the last 20 years.
"Stopping the land consumption madness is imperative," he said.

HEADLINE: Equality Plan on School Financing Is Upsetting Rich and Poor in Texas

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 7 -

 BODY:
For years "the Robin Hood plan" loomed as a dreaded last resort for Texas public schools, and now that it is operating, no one is very happy about it.
The rich say they are being robbed by the new system for financing public education. The poor say that despite sweeping revisions designed to eliminate financial inequities among school districts the state is still not giving them what they need. 
 Texas's success or failure will be closely watched in more than 20 states where education financing systems are under challenge in the courts. Among them are New Jersey, where the State Supreme Court last month ordered a new trial to determine whether the state's 1990 Quality Education Act adequately addresses equal financing between poor districts and rich districts, and New York, where arguments are scheduled this month in a lawsuit brought by a group of poor districts asking a state court to declare the school financing system unconstitutional.
 
Equity and Excellence
 In a groundswell of legal activity, the number of states with such lawsuits has grown to 22 from 8 two years ago. Poor school districts with a relatively small amounts of taxable property are contending in the suits that their students are unconstitutionally disadvantaged compared with those in rich districts, where large amounts of taxable property can raise more money for the schools.
The disadvantages may come in many forms, from the microscopes and computers available to students in richer districts to the crowded classes held in cafeterias or hallways in poorer districts. At a time of limited government resources, the increasingly urgent new question is whether equity and excellence can be achieved simultaneously.
"We were an exemplary district in Texas, and it is going to be much more difficult for us to maintain our standards now," said Charles Slater, superintendent of the Alamo Heights School District in an affluent predominantly white suburb of San Antonio. "The real solution to equity should be to raise everyone to the level of Alamo Heights, not to bring us all down to some level of mediocrity."
But John Augenblick, a Denver-based consultant who has worked for several state governments helping to design school financing plans, said, "For some districts to insist that they want to remain at high levels of spending is all well and good, except that there are other districts that have never had the chance to even come close to the national average."
 
Access to Equal Amount
 More and more often, he said, "the courts are ruling that state governments have a responsibility to insure that all school districts have access to about the same level of funding, and whether that level is adequate or not depends on what the state is willing to spend."
In October 1989, almost as soon as the Texas Supreme Court struck down the old school financing system that was based primarily on property taxes, some prominent politicians began predicting that Texas could pay for school equity only by imposing corporate or personal income taxes.
When that solution proved politically unpalatable, the Robin Hood approach of taking property tax money from rich districts and redistributing it among poor ones was adopted. The Texas plan sets in motion a spending proposal that would increase state spending on public schools by as much as $5 billion over the next four years. But the Legislature imposed no new state taxes to cover the additional spending. Texas is one of three states without corporate or personal income taxes.
"We got this started without any specific funding changes relative to public education," said State Senator John Montford, a Democrat from Lubbock, who is a crucial legislator on tax issues. "But I think we are inevitably headed towards a major fiscal crisis and some tough decisions, because the spending is going to increase and the money won't be there."
The plan sets up new regional taxing authorities and obliges all school districts within those regions to tax at the same rate to pay for a basic educational program, and to then share the money. The system earned its nickname because, in the sharing process, about $300 million in local property tax revenue will be taken from rich school districts to be given to poor ones this year, according to preliminary estimates.
 
Minimum Money Assured
 In addition, the state has committed itself to providing enough money to insure that poor districts have a minimum amount to spend if Robin Hood money falls short.
Rich districts are expected to take advantage of provisions allowing them to raise extra money through property taxes to enhance their programs, but they can do so only within certain limits.
Although the Robin Hood approach has been tried in different forms elsewhere, in Texas it has generated the most direct confrontation between rich and poor districts, which fought in court all summer and are promising further battles. Several rich districts have already challenged the new law, contending that the state is unconstitutionally appropriating local revenue.
In Utah, Wyoming and Montana, the state governments receive a portion of the revenue raised by local school districts and redistributes the money in districts around the state to equalize spending, Mr. Augenblick said. But, he said, Texas is the first state to redistribute money within regional districts.
 
Flowing Between Neighbors
 With money flowing among neighboring school neighbors, the potential for resentment is heightened, especially when many of the rich districts are predominantly white while most of the poor districts have large minority populations.
Some of the rich districts most determined to fight the Robin Hood plan are Dallas suburbs like Plano, Richardson, Carrollton and Farmers Branch, which have been able to attract residents from the city with the lure of better public schools. To the extent that the Robin Hood plan reduces the ability of such suburbs to spend more on their schools, it threatens to disrupt one of America's fundamental population dynamics.
In its unanimous 1989 decision -- which said the disparities in spending between rich and poor school districts were unconstitutional -- the Texas Supreme Court stated that "property-poor districts are trapped in a cycle of poverty from which there is no opportunity to free themselves." The 100 richest school districts spent an average of $7,233 a student annually, the court noted, while the 100 poorest -- even by levying much higher taxes on their residents -- could only average $2,978 a student.
As a matter of principle, the poor school districts see the new law as a victory.
"There is more equality of opportunity among school districts than ever before and the state has put in more money than ever before," said Al Kauffman, a lawyer with the Mexican-American Legal Defense Fund, who filed the original suit in 1984.
"For basically the same tax rates, almost every district will have similar revenues," he said, "and the tremendous disparities between the richest and the poorest school districts will be eliminated."
But many poor school districts feel they have so much catching up to do that the amount of new money they will receive is disappointing -- especially because they have had to raise taxes in order to take full advantage of the law. That was the way the law was written.
For example, the Edgewood School District in a poor, predominantly Hispanic area of San Antonio, raised its property taxes by 23 percent, and will get some Robin Hood aid from nearby districts, but even with both those sources of income, its school budget will increase by less than 10 percent.
Some of the new money will acquire things that used to be luxuries, like music teachers, said Earle Bolton, the deputy superintendent, but "for the main part, a lot of the money is going into maintenance and repair of physical facilities." Roofs that have been leaking for years will finally get fixed, and in two major buildings air conditioning units that date to the 1940's may be replaced.
Meanwhile, the rich districts are just as unhappy.
 
Giving and Raising Taxes
 For, example the Alamo Heights district will give up $4 million in Robin Hood money. It has raised taxes this year by 36 percent, but is still cutting its budget by about $1 million. Various economy measures taken included a salary freeze, cuts in clerical positions, elimination of some instructional programs like accounting and the closing of the district's swimming pool.
The state's two big-city school districts, Dallas and Houston, feel doubly cursed. Both cities are losing residents to suburbs that offer better schooling, and both are required to provide costly services to students with special needs, like bilingual education for recent immigrants. Even so, because of their large tax bases, both city school systems were categorized as rich districts under the Robin Hood plan.
School boards around the state are now coming up with their property tax rates and will be sending out their bills next month. With some school administrators predicting a tax revolt, the true impact of the law -- and its ramifications for other states -- may not become apparent until property owners learn its full price tag.

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS NOMINATION;
VOTE ON THOMAS IS PUT OFF AS SENATE BACKING ERODES OVER HARASSMENT CHARGE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
After a day of divisive, emotional debate over one of the most politically charged issues before it in recent years, the Senate tonight agreed to postpone until next Tuesday the vote on the confirmation of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
The White House reluctantly agreed to the delay to allow time for the Judiciary Committee to hold hearings into accusations of sexual harassment that have set off a storm of outrage against the Senate and caused many to demand closer scrutiny of Judge Thomas. 
 The highly unusual delay in the confirmation process resulted from the dramatic and carefully presented public accusation on Monday by Anita F. Hill, a law professor at the University of Oklahoma who is a former Thomas aide.
 
Integrity at Issue
 The decision to delay came more than two hours after the original 6 P.M. deadline for the vote had passed. Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, stepped onto the Senate floor and said that there were too many lingering questions about allegations against Judge Thomas to call a vote tonight.
"The delay approved," Mr. Mitchell declared, "is important to the integrity of the Senate, the integrity of the confirmation process, the integrity of the Supreme Court and the integrity of the individuals involved."
Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, also called for a delay, but only until Friday. He conceded, though, that Republicans were outnumbered. He said Republicans did not hold the Senate to a vote tonight on the nomination because the tide was running so strongly against Judge Thomas that he might have been rejected altogether.
 
New Scrutiny for Accusations
 Under the agreement, the accusations of sexual harassment against Judge Thomas will be examined in hearings scheduled to begin on Friday. Judge Thomas, in a signed statement distributed today by his chief defender, Senator John C. Danforth, said, "I totally and unequivocally deny Anita Hill's allegations of misconduct of any kind toward her, sexual or otherwise."
Professor Hill appeared briefly before reporters today in Norman, Okla., to say only that she would cooperate with the Senate, saying: "I will fully cooperate with the efforts of the Senate. I intend to cooperate and to go to Washington if it is requested." In explaining the delay, Senator Dole said that some of his Republican colleagues "would have rolled the dice at 6 P.M." But he added in a mellow, candid tone, "I couldn't put together 60 votes at 6 o'clock.
"It seemed to be that it was a gamble that should not be taken," he said, adding that "some questions remain" that probably should be answered.
Senator Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, adopting a tone intended to heal divisions, said the agreement was a result of events that were "unpredictable, unplanned and unfortunate."
Among the supporters of Judge Thomas who pushed for postponing the vote was Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, who declared, "The Senate is on trial at this point."
The decision to delay came after White House lobbyists and Senate Republicans realized that they might lose if they forced a vote on a group of Democrats who were leaning toward Judge Thomas but were being battered by criticism that the overwhelmingly male Senate paid too little attention to the allegations of sexual harassment.
The turning point came in an emotional speech less than two hours before the scheduled 6 P.M. floor vote. Senator Danforth stepped onto the Senate floor and said the nominee wanted time to clear his name from the "sharks" who, he said, were trying to use the accusations of Professor Hill to keep Judge Thomas off the Court.
The Missouri Republican said he had spoken to Judge Thomas by telephone and quoted him as saying: "They have taken from me what I have worked 43 years to create. They have taken from me what I have worked 43 years to build: My reputation."
 
Thomas's Denial of Charges
 Senator Danforth also distributed a statement signed today by Judge Thomas, asserting:
"1. As I told the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Sept. 28, 1991, I totally and unequivocally deny Anita Hill's allegations of misconduct of any kind toward her, sexual or otherwise. These allegations are untrue.
"2. At all times during the period she worked with me, our relationship was strictly professional. During that time and subsequently, the relationship has been wholly cordial.
"3. I am terribly saddened and deeply offended by these allegations."
The bitter emotional tone today on the Senate floor was in keeping with the tempest into which the lawmakers were plunged on Monday, when Professor Hill accused the Senate Judiciary Committee of declining to investigate her complaint.
Mr. Danforth portrayed Judge Thomas as seeking the delay, but most Senate officials agreed that it was forced on Republicans and White House strategists because they feared they could not hold their bare majority if the vote took place today.
 
Bleak Republican Tally
 By the estimate of Senator Dole, there were 41 votes for Judge Thomas, 41 against, and 16 to 18 undecided, "depending who you count." There are 57 Senate Democrats and 43 Republicans, and at least 7 of 13 pro-Thomas Democrats had come out openly for a delay by the time the Republicans decided not to risk a vote.
The postponement came after an extraordinary 24 hours of politicking on and off the Senate floor. The Senate was under great pressure for a delay so lawmakers could learn more of the allegations by Professor Hill, who said Judge Thomas had harassed her with remarks about sexual positions and practices, anatomy and pornographic movies when she was his assistant, from 1981 to 1983, first at the Education Department and later at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
It was a day of intense drama in the Capitol, a moment when issues of principle and political survival came together. It tested not only the fate of Judge Thomas, but also the standing of leading Senators, and the image of the institution itself.
From early this morning, it seemed clear that the 6 P.M. vote was in doubt, especially when Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, pulled the first surprise of the day, infuriating Mr. Mitchell. Senator Moynihan called for a six-day adjournment so senators could examine the allegations. Although Mr. Moynihan withdrew his request, senators were uncertain all day if the vote would proceed that evening.
For the first time since Professor Hill's allegations were made public, the nominee sought to defend himself by releasing the sworn affidavit in which he categorically denied the allegations.
As evidence that Professor Hill maintained a friendship with Judge Thomas, Mr. Danforth also released what he described as the nominee's secretary's telephone logs, showing that Professor Hill had called him 10 times from 1984 to 1990, with an 11th call made by a third party on her behalf. On Aug. 29, 1984, for example, an entry said Professor Hill "needs your advice on getting research grants," while on Aug. 4, 1987, she "wanted to congratulate you on marriage."
Professor Hill was quoted in Wednesday's issue of The Washington Post as saying the report about the telephone calls was "garbage." However, in a brief interview tonight with The New York Times, she refused to confirm that comment, simply reiterating that she would cooperate with the Senate investigation.
Even Mr. Danforth, who had expressed only optimism about his prospects since Judge Thomas was nominated by President Bush on July 1, for the first time raised the notion that the nomination was in doubt.
"If he loses the nomination because of this," Mr. Danforth said at a news conference, "if he is telling the truth and he loses the nomination because of this, that to me is an earth-shaking development -- to have the nomination of Clarence Thomas for Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court lost because of the illegal distribution or leaking of the content of an F.B.I. report, plus charges which are totally refuted by the nominee."
The unanswered questions about Judge Thomas were the center of the debate, and a critical issue in the talks between Republicans and Democrats was over how much further the Senate should go in seeking answers.
A crucial question is if the harassment took place, why did Professor Hill have continued contacts with Judge Thomas, even following him from one civil rights agency to another. The professor said Monday that she went to the second agency because she wanted to continue in the civil rights field and did not want to be unemployed, but Republicans hammered insistently at this question today.
There is also dispute over details. News reports have said that Judge Thomas acknowleged in the F.B.I. document that he had asked Professor Hill out but denied her other assertions. But Senator Specter, who spoke to Judge Thomas about the allegations before the committee vote, insisted again today that the nominee had denied that he even asked her out.
"I looked him straight in the eye and he looked at me straight in the eye," Mr. Specter said. "And he forcefully denied having dated or asked her out."
Democrats on the Judiciary Committee had been informed of Professor Hill's allegations before they voted on his confirmation Sept. 27. The committee was split 7 to 7, with only one Democrat voting for confirmation, and the nomination was sent to the Senate floor for action anyway.
 
Biden on Defensive
 But a mounting number of Democrats, including some who had pledged support for Judge Thomas, who sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, said today that questions about the Judiciary Committee's handling of Professor Hill's complaint made it impossible to proceed.
Implicit in many speeches was the idea that Senators were reluctant to repeat what many saw as the mistake of the Judiciary panel and its chairman, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware. Leading women inside and outside Congress said the committee has projected an image of indifference to women by appearing to brush aside the complaints of a woman of substance and rushing to judgment for reasons of political expedience.
"Judge Thomas has a cloud hanging over his head," said Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat who announced his support for confirmation late last month. "In my view, the only responsible course for us, as members of this body, to discharge the Constitutional obligation which is incumbent upon is, is to the best of our ability conduct a thorough examination of these allegations."
The Democrats on the Judiciary Committee, notably the chairman, were dogged with questions over why they did not delay the committee's vote and investigate the matter more fully.

HEADLINE: Haitian Legislators Name a Judge To Be President Until a New Vote

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Haitian National Assembly swore in a Supreme Court Justice as provisional president today to replace the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first democratically elected leader, who fled the country after being overthrown in a military coup eight days ago.
The appointment of Joseph Nerette, a Justice described as political centrist in his late 60's, came after the parliament overwhelmingly ratified a motion declaring the office of the president vacant. 
 The action officially vacating the office was first taken by parliament on Monday and repeated today. The initial vote Monday came as soldiers surrounded the National Assembly building and fired their automatic weapons into the air. The soldiers also briefly took over the airport Monday while a delegation of diplomats from the Organization of American States was meeting there.
 
Motion Declared Illegal
 Because of the actions by the soldiers and the absence of many members of Parliament, including its president, the motion to vacate the President's office was declared illegal on Monday by O.A.S. representatives and Western diplomats.
[In Washington, the Organization of American States drew up plans to toughen economic sanctions against the new Government of Haiti, and also considered an offer to send a civilian O.A.S. observer force to Port-au-Prince. Page A3.]
Asked if the soldiers had coerced the legislature to declare Father Aristide's office vacant, Haitian politicians said the soldiers may have forced the issue, but the outcome was inevitable. "We are repeating our vote today because there appear to be doubts about what occurred yesterday," said Senator Thomas Dupiton, referring to the ratification vote today.
While opposition by enlisted men in the Haitian military to Father Aristide's return is genuine, several politicians described Monday's action by the soliders outside the Parliament as intended to send a strong signal to the O.A.S. that Father Aristide's departure was irreversible.
"The thing was cooked up to present a fait-accompli before the international community," said the leader of one political party who acknowledged that in recent days there had been repeated contacts between soldiers and civilians opposed to Father Aristide's return to Haiti.
After being sworn in by Senator Dejean Belizaire, the president of the National Assembly, Mr. Nerette, a gaunt and diminuitive legal scholar, delivered an inaugural speech in which he made several references to complaints made frequently against Father Aristide during his presidency, including officially-sanctioned violence, class tensions and disregard for constitutional checks and balances.
 
Duvalier Aide May Be Named
 "The realization of this country's potential requires the reconciliation of all its sons," Mr. Nerette said. Haiti, he added, "does not belong to one man, or a small group of men. This country belongs to all its sons, whether rich or poor."
Uncertainty over how the provisional government would be received internationally was underscored by the absence of any diplomatic presence at the swearing-in ceremony.
The new President was expected to name Jean-Jacques Honorat as his Prime Minister. Mr. Honorat is a former director of tourism under the government of Jean-Claude Duvalier.
The naming of Mr. Nerette, who is charged with leading Haiti to new elections within 90 days, came after several days of of a power vacuum in which soldiers prowled the streets intimidating and sporadically attacking citizens.
Since Father Aristide was forced out of the country by a military rebellion on Sept. 30, diplomats estimate that as many as 300 people may have died.
In stark contrast to the swearing-in of Father Aristide in January, after the populist priest-turned-politician was elected in a landslide, the streets of the capital were nearly deserted this afternoon, and except for those invited to the inaugural ceremony, there appeared to be little celebration.
 
Aristide's Rights Record Cited
 In recent days, a high-level mission of the O.A.S. had repeatedly warned that Haiti would remain isolated and subject to an economic blockade unless Father Aristide were promptly returned to office.
Haitian politicians today reproached the O.A.S. team for coming to Haiti with what they called a predetermined and inflexible mission -- the return of Father Aristide -- without bothering to gather information on both the deposed president's record of alleged human rights violations and the exceptionally strong sentiment against him.
"I think they were uncouth to come here and tell us what to do," said Louis Dejoie, the leader of the Parti Agricole Industriel National, who applauded the naming of an interim government. "To blockade our ports and leave us without anything to eat would be genocide. It's an insult."
Asked how the international community would regard the provisional government, the Canadian ambassador to Haiti, Bernard Dussault, said: "The O.A.S. does not intend to break dialogue."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Asia Test for Mr. Bush

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
President Bush will soon face his biggest and most challenging test in shaping a new world order since the Persian Gulf war. Beginning in mid-November, Secretary of State Baker and later Mr. Bush himself will spend the better part of a month traveling in Asia, ending symbolically on Dec. 7 in Pearl Harbor.
They will be trying to pull together a policy for the Asian-Pacific rim, an area of the world that will probably have a greater impact on America than all the latest Soviet-American arms control announcements and the Middle East negotiations. 
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker will be dealing with the core issue of any new world order -- foreign economic policy -- in the largest, most dynamic economic region of the globe.
The Bush-Baker challenge will be to replace the historic anti-Soviet focus of U.S. Asian policy with a new emphasis on geoeconomics, to forge new economic bonds and use them to resolve political problems and prevent economic disputes from exploding into political confrontations.
The stakes are investment, jobs, growth, trade and trade wars, and -- most delicate and dangerous of all -- relations with China and Japan. Washington's troubles with these two Asian giants edge ever closer to a blowup.
No country is more important to the U.S. than Japan, and with no other country are its economic ties so strained. Mr. Bush has managed to keep things together through his personal relationship with the departing Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, but personal friendships will not substitute for the tough political decisions needed in both capitals to sidetrack economic warfare. The two sides are talking about the right issues (American budget deficits and education and Japanese restrictive trade and investment practices), but they just are not getting anywhere.
Japan will be Mr. Baker's principal stop in a trip that will begin with a Nov. 12 meeting with Asia's leading free-market countries. Later in November Mr. Bush will journey to Japan, South Korea, Indonesia and Australia. Neither now plans to stop in China.
Chinese leaders are approaching a full boil over Congressional pressures on human rights, Mr. Bush's visit with Tibet's Dalai Lama and a host of other such matters. U.S. leaders are steaming over China's $15 billion trade surplus with the U.S., some of it the fruits of slave labor.
Some China experts would like Mr. Baker to stop in Beijing and defuse the tension. But the Secretary and the President worry that such a high-level contact would send American human rights watchers into orbit. The solution, and Administration diplomats are working on it secretly, is to see if Beijing will agree in advance to certain concessions to be announced during a Baker visit.
America's hold on China turns on trade, technology and investment, all of which Beijing requires to modernize. That hold, tragically, has done little to alleviate Beijing's human and political rights abuses. But Washington has used its leverage well to gain China's critical neutrality at the U.N. during the war against Iraq, pressure on Communist rebels to end the fighting in Cambodia and agreement to restrict missile sales to the volatile Mideast and elsewhere.
The power of the purse is everywhere evident in Asia. Japan is using it to pry its northern islands away from the Soviet Union. Tokyo is employing the same bait to persuade North Korea to halt its none-too-secret nuclear arms program. North Korea is coming out of its nasty and dangerous shell because it is an economic basket case. Vietnam will also sink into economic oblivion without aid, which explains its recent help in concluding Cambodia's civil war.
Overarching all this are the worldwide GATT free-trade negotiations, a vast multilateral gabfest now in an ominous stalemate. A breakdown in these talks could lead to Western European and North American trade blocs. To guard against such possibilities, some Asians are flirting with establishing their own trade bloc.
Fortunately, Asian nations still depend on free trade, oppose protectionism and fear Japanese domination if America is excluded. Every Pacific rim nation wants full American involvement in the region, which gives the U.S. an inherent long-term advantage that Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker can start using next month to mold the emerging geoeconomic order.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Peru Accepts Wrong Kind of Aid;
Two Colossal Menaces

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Misadventures in Cocaland" (Op-Ed, Sept. 8), Gustavo Gorriti depicts the United States aid package for Peru as unbalanced and shortsighted, and worries that it will cause the campesinos, or peasants, to rise up and group behind the terrorist group Sendero Luminoso, or Shining Path. Furthermore, he describes the drug trade as indispensable for the survival of the Peruvian economy. I disagree with both statements. 
 I do not believe that the substitution of less productive crops for coca will push the campesinos into the ranks of the Shining Path. Peruvians are having harsh and difficult times. They are paying the price with a high unemployment rate, violence, corruption and other social maladies for the wrong national policies of the past. But their belief in democracy, a free press and individual rights is intact.
I agree that a rational and perfect policy should put more emphasis on the root of the problem, poverty, and less on the branches. But such purism will block any possible aid.
Peru faces two colossal menaces: the drug trade and Shining Path. They are intertwined in all aspects, and their defeat rests in consolidation of democracy and improvement of the economy.
 
JUAN M. D'BROT
Miami, Sept. 21, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Peru Accepts Wrong Kind of Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Peru's President -- A Good Bet" (editorial, Sept. 28), you cynically misrepresent the Bush Administration's latest bribe to Peru as "aid." In the last few months, your news columns have documented the negotiations between the United States and Peru that led to President Alberto Fujimori's eventual surrender to White House "diplomacy." 
 Mr. Fujimori at first rejected the Bush "aid" proposal as dangerously militaristic and blind to the economic realities underlying coca production in eastern Peru. The proposed package contains no serious alternative development strategies, nor does it offer sustained support for development of alternative cash crops.
Peruvians are concerned that brutal military suppression of the only viable peasant economy in the region will merely sharpen their nation's crisis, sweeping it into a vicious cycle of violence and guaranteeing the need for more such United States "aid" as Peru sinks into civil war.
The Bush Administration responded to Mr. Fujimori's rejection by threatening to curtail aid from the international lending institutions Washington controls. Mr. Fujimori reluctantly agreed to accept the United States package, rather than face economic isolation.
You attempt to gloss over the sad facts of this "aid" package. Of the $60 million in economic aid you refer to, almost all will go toward interest on outstanding loans, not crop substitution or road building in rural Peru. The meager amount for economic development is all Mr. Fujimori can show to save face and not be laughed out of his country as another incompetent weakling pandering to the interests of Washington and the banks.
Finally, to portray the Peruvians as the deserving recipients of "poison" disguised as "medicine" is a callous ruse.
 
KURT DILLON
New York, Oct. 1, 1991

HEADLINE: Recession and Re-election Don't Mix

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
From George Bush down, top officials in the Administration and other Republican strategists are convinced that the only obstacle in the way of the President's re-election would be a recession next year.
The White House does not believe such a recession is likely, and neither do most private economists. But the President's advisers cannot ignore the possibility. And what frustrates them, many said in interviews, is that unlike previous Presidents who found ways to boost the economy for their political advantage in an election year, this Administration feels its hands are tied. 
 An Administration official said he felt like someone becalmed at sea. No matter how confident he might be that the wind would soon spring up and blow him safely ashore, he said, he would feel better if he could do something about it.
One of Mr. Bush's chief political advisers put it this way: "If you look at the things that historically have given incumbent Presidents a difficult problem in an election, there's a lingering war. That's not likely to happen. There's a major scandal. I don't see that happening. The most common one is a very sour economy, and we can't completely rule that out."
Worried that voters may perceive the President as concentrating on foreign policy and uninterested in pocketbook issues, the White House has gone to lengths recently to make it appear that Mr. Bush is on top of the situtation.
The President held a news conference on Friday to emphasize his domestic and economic policies. "The economy's on the right track," he asserted, although he conceded that "all is not well." He offered no new proposals for turning the situation around.
On Monday, Mr. Bush met with a group of corporate chief executives and then held a Cabinet meeting to discuss the economy. Today, he met with his top economic advisers as a follow-up to two highly publicized meetings with the advisers week before last. After today's meeting, the President announced that he had approved a series of regulatory measures that he said would encourage banks to make new loans. [Page A1].
Asked about the flurry of activity, a top assistant to the President said, "There's a feeling that he hasn't been visible enough on this issue."
But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, suggested publicly Monday what other Presidential assistants have been saying privately -- that bold new proposals in the economic area are not in the offing.
"We just want to stay on top of the situation and nurture this process in any way we can," Mr. Fitzwater said.
 
Deficit Limits the Options
 With the Office of Management and Budget predicting a monumental budget deficit of nearly $350 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, the Bush Administration cannot afford to cut taxes or increase Government spending, the normal ways of stimulating the economy.
The collapse of the Soviet Union as a military threat may mean that the President and Congress will agree next year to reduce military spending and use the money to cut taxes, lower the deficit or expand social programs. But that would not have any effect on the strength of the nation's economy before the 1992 election. 
And monetary policy, which the Administration has depended on to regulate the economy up to now, seems lately to have had little effect generating economic growth. The Federal Reserve has already cut the interest rates it controls to their lowest levels since the 1970's, but that has not proved sufficient to generate enough new bank lending to increase the nation's money supply and thus give the economy a lift.
A recession occurs when the nation's total production of goods and services actually shrinks. The current view among economists is that the country pulled out of recession during the summer and that the recovery will be slow but steady. But Charles Black, a leading Republican strategist, has made a point of trying to drum up concern about the economy in party circles.
"In talking to our people who are in some danger of complacency about the President's chances," Mr. Black said, "I have been saying that I don't think any one Democrat is a threat to the President's re-election, but a bad economy is. If the economy is growing, he's going to be extremely tough to beat.
"But," Mr. Black added, "if the economy is sliding the way it seems to be doing now, a strong Democrat could take advantage of that and make it a competitive race."
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who is expected to become Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, said he believed the President's re-election chances would not be hurt if the economy merely grows very slowly next year. But he said an all-out recession would be politically damaging.
 
Sticking With the Forecasts
 Should 1992 find the nation in a recession, the President would of course have the power to initiate domestic-spending programs or propose jobs-creation legislation or take other steps to stimulate the economy. But to do so would probably increase the budget deficit, a situation that many economists believe would only worsen the recession.
Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that for the time being he was sticking by the forecast the Administration published in July: that the economy will grow at the rather slow rate of 3.6 percent next year. But, Mr. Boskin cautioned, "there are lots of reasons the economy could follow a different path, and it would be wise to recognize that the economy could do significantly better or significantly worse."
A lower-level Administration economist said he believed that if another official forecast were done today, the projection would be for a growth rate a bit lower than the July projection of 3.6 percent and more in line with Congressional and private forecasts.
 
History Casts a Shadow
 Any of the current projections are well below the 4.6 percent that is the average rate of economic growth in the six election years since World War II in which the incumbent party retained control of the White House. The current forecasts, in fact, lean slightly closer to the 2.98 percent average for the five election years since the war in which the incumbent party has lost.
Scholars who have studied the effects of the economy on Presidential elections have found that incumbents have serious trouble weathering election-year recessions but that voters are forgiving of recessions that occurred earlier in a President's term.
Allan J. Lichtman, a history professor at American University here, wrote in his book, "The 13 Keys to the Presidency," that all seven times since the Civil War when the economy was in recession in the fall of a Presidential election year, someone from the opposition party was elected President. The years he listed were 1876, 1884, 1896, 1920, 1932, 1960 and 1980.
Mr. Lichtman's calculation is subject to quibbles. Some lists show a recession in the fall of 1900, when William McKinley was re-elected, and the latest view is that the recession of 1980 ended that July. But no one disputes the main point Mr. Lichtman is making: recessions during election campaigns are generally disastrous for incumbent Presidents.
 
The Unemployment Factor
 Another way of looking at the situation is to examine the unemployment rate. Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a political scientist at the University of Iowa who is writing a book on election forecasting, found that all five times since World War II when the unemployment rate was falling in the second quarter of the election year, the incumbent won: 1948, 1964, 1972, 1984 and 1988.
On the other hand, the unemployment rate was rising or flat during the April through June quarter in six election years, and the incumbent party lost five of those elections, in 1952, 1960, 1968, 1976 and 1980. The only exception was in 1956, when Dwight D. Eisenhower was re-elected.
The Bush Administration is forecasting that the civilian unemployment rate, 6.7 percent last month, will be an average of 6.4 percent during 1992, a figure comparable with current predictions by most private economists. But some economists say that even if the economy is improving, the unemployment rate may not have begun to drop by next year's second quarter.
When recessions have occurred in the first three years of an incumbent's term or even early in an election year, voters have not usually held them against the President. So scholars do not expect the recession that began in the summer of 1990 to hurt Mr. Bush.
 
Incumbents Who Took Action
 Many recent Presidents going into the year of their re-election campaign have taken strong steps to show the country they were trying to turn the economy around. In 1963, President Kennedy pushed for the biggest tax cut in American history up to that time. In 1971, President Nixon imposed wage and price controls. In 1979, Jimmy Carter began to focus on controlling runaway inflation and named Paul A. Volcker to head the Federal Reserve Board. In 1983, Ronald Reagan retreated substantially from the economic philosophy of his first years in office and supported legislation to create new jobs.
Commerce Secretary Mosbacher is advocating an all-out push next year for a reduction in the capital gains tax. But others, including Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, say such action would be unwise given the strong opposition in Congress, the political beating the President took on the issue last year and the likelihood that Democrats would insist on an increase in other tax rates if the capital gains rate were lowered.
The best guess is that the President will sit tight next year, make no bold new proposals in the economic area and keep his fingers crossed that another recession can be averted.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 11, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a picture caption in Business Day on Wednesday about the effects of recession on Presidential elections referred incorrectly to the voting of 1876, during a recession. The incumbent party was re-elected: Rutherford B. Hayes, a Republican, received the most electoral votes and succeeded Ulysses S. Grant. But Samuel J. Tilden, a Democrat, received more popular votes, fitting the pattern in which challengers receive more votes during recessions.

HEADLINE: A Pole Asks Urgent Help In Privatizing

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
The Polish official who heads his country's sweeping privatization program says it has been sharply scaled back and American expertise is urgently needed.
"Our basic problem is that we have no domestic savings, and foreign interest is currently very guarded," Dr. Jerzy Thieme, the chairman of the Poland's so-called mass privatization program, said during what he described as a private visit to New York. 
 He said the number of state enterprises involved in the program, which was announced three months ago, had been cut to 230 from 400. He also said that a plan to give all Polish adults a stake in these businesses would be delayed.
 
Sees Delay Until 1993
 In June, Poland announced plans to transfer ownership in 400 state enterprises, or about 25 percent of all Government-owned industry, to a group of stock funds to be created and run by Western investment managers. The nation's 27 million adults were to receive vouchers giving them a stake in these funds.
Dr. Thieme said he did not foresee the public distribution of shares in the planned stock funds until 1993 because it would take until then to restructure the companies and assess their value.
"Real life has modified the plan quite radically," he said. On closer review, he said, 170 of the larger companies initially included in the program were found to be unsuitable because their problems were so severe.
As a result, the companies to be privatized now represent only about 6 percent of state industry, he said. Dr. Thieme declined to say which enterprises had been eliminated but did say they included some cement and sugar businesses. The 230 companies still to be privatized are currently being evaluated by officials from the accounting firms Price Waterhouse and Arthur Andersen, he said.
 
'Mass' Goal Now 'Moderate'
 Stanislaw Wellisz, a professor of economics at Columbia University and until recently a member of the supervisory board of the privatization program, said he had been informed of the cutback.
"From a mass privatization program, it has been scaled back to a more moderate one," Professor Wellisz said. "They did not want to distribute enterprises on the verge of bankruptcy."
Commenting on the changes, Tomaz Telma, an economist at Planecon Inc., a consulting firm in Washington, said the plan now seemed "more gradual and more realistic." A major problem, he added, is that "there is a very big mentality barrier to these market changes in Poland."
 
'We Need Everything'
 Dr. Thieme, a former vice president for Citibank in New York, said he would like to have a team of five American experts to help him design the capital markets essential to support the privatization plans.
"We need registration systems, modern banking technology to support trading -- in fact we need everything," he said. "And I would like to have experts from the U.S., the most sophisticated model of capital markets anywhere in the world."
But his ministry lacks funds to hire such experts, Dr. Thieme lamented, and he is having to rely on West European expertise that is paid for, in part, by the British and French Governments.
 
May Consult Nonprofit Group
 One possibility, he suggested, was that Poland would turn to an American organization, the Financial Services Volunteer Corps, a nonprofit group established last year and run by Herbert S. Okun, a former United States Ambassador to East Germany. The organization, partly financed by the State Department's Agency for International Development, provides financial experts on a volunteer basis for East European countries switching to market economies.
Mr. Okun said that he had met with Dr. Thieme last week and that if the organization received a formal request from Poland, "we would be happy to send our experts."
Parliamentary elections are scheduled in Poland this month, and Professor Wellisz of Columbia suggested that the privatization plans could face further adaptation or curtailment as a result of political pressures.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Platinum Higher After Soviet Supply Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold and platinum futures prices advanced yesterday on further news of dwindling Soviet gold reserves.
A report by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said that Soviet reserves were approaching 240 metric tons, lending credence to similar statements made earlier. 
 Tass reported that the economist Grigory Yavlinsky told the Russian Parliament yesterday that by 1992, gold reserves would drop to 240 tons.
"This is the third Soviet statement indicating that the reserves are at this level," said William O'Neill, an analyst in New York with Merrill Lynch Futures. He said the figure appeared to be the one the Soviets would report to the International Monetary Fund at its meeting this weekend in Bangkok, Thailand.
Gold also benefited from a weaker dollar and surging crude oil prices.
Traders of platinum futures perked up on the gold report in Tass.
 
Wondering About Soviet Platinum
 "They began wondering how much of the platinum reserves were left in the Soviet Union," said Peter Cardillo, research director of Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York. "If the gold reserves are that low, maybe platinum reserves are even lower."
The Soviet Union is known to have sold a relatively large amount of platinum in recent years.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum for delivery in January settled $7.10 an ounce higher at $367.
Gold on New York's Commodity Exchange was $1.90 an ounce higher for December at $362.10. December silver was 2.8 cents higher at $4.113 an ounce.
The advance in crude oil futures at the New York Mercantile Exchange was tied to concerns that the political turmoil in the Soviet Union would reduce oil exports even more than already feared.
Crude oil for delivery in November was up 17 cents a barrel, at $23.16; November heating oil was 0.99 cent higher at 68.05 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline was 0.29 cent lower at 63.20 cents a gallon, and natural gas for delivery in December was 2.9 cents higher at $2.152 for 1,000 cubic feet.
 
Harvest Assessment Due Today
 Most grain and soybean futures prices edged lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as the market awaited the Government's latest harvest assessment, due today.
Wheat futures turned higher at one point on a report that the Soviet Union had increased the amount of United States wheat it was seeking, but the market failed to hold the gains.
Corn and soybean prices were under pressure all week from bearish expectations surrounding the crop report. There is almost universal agreement that the Agriculture Department's estimates of crop yields for corn and beans will be significantly higher than they were a month ago.
Wheat for delivery in December settled 2 3/4 cents lower at $3.43 a bushel; December corn was3/4 cent lower at $2.48 3/4 a bushel; December oats were 1/2 cent higher at $1.28 3/4 a bushel, and November soybeans were 2 1/4 cents lower at $5.69 3/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Amid Uncertainty Over Trend of Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against leading foreign currencies yesterday in trading dominated by largely technical influences and uncertainty over the direction of interest rates in the United States.
Foreign exchange analysts said part of the dollar's drop was a technical correction after the currency's strong advance on Tuesday. 
 At the same time, they said, the market continued its debate on the direction of interest rates in the United States.
Some participants expect the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy and allow rates to decline further to stimulate the still-sluggish economy. Others predict that the central bank will leave rates unchanged.
The dollar is supported by higher rates, so the prospect of lower rates helped bring the American currency lower.
Earl I. Johnson, a vice president with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said traders believe "there's still the possibility of a rate cut as early as Friday."
Traders were hoping the release of money supply figures today would give them some clues about interest rates. The sluggish growth of money supply in the United States economy has played a role in Fed decisions in recent months.
Mr. Johnson said the dollar was fluctuating in a narrow range, but was unlikely to trade significantly higher because the direction of the economy remained uncertain.
The dollar fell to 129.80 Japanese yen in New York, from 130.35 late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to a closing 130.40 yen from 129.93 yen, and in London it fell to 130.15 yen.
The British pound rose in New York to $1.7195 from late Tuesday's $1.7070. In earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.7175 from $1.7140.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Bonds Plunge

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices plunged yesterday as credit market participants sold securities after the Federal Reserve Board gave a strong sign it had not yet eased monetary policy. Results of an auction of new seven-year notes also showed that demand was not nearly as strong as anticipated.
The decline in bond prices was the third in succession, but some market participants did not attach much significance to the drop. 
 "In bull markets, there tend to be violent corrections," one Government bond trader said. "This has been the first one in nearly three months. The fundamental story of weak economic growth and low inflation is still very much alive, but it will take a few days for the market to recover from this."
But other traders said that despite a very wide spread, or difference, between yields on two-year notes and 30-year bonds, demand for long-term securities was moribund.
 
'Absolutely No Sponsorship'
 "The long end has absolutely no sponsorship, and people are getting out and taking profits," another trader said. "I don't think the constant effort on the part of the Bush Administration to talk down interest rates and to push the Fed to ease continually is helping bond yields much."
Talk that the Fed was in the process of moving short-term interest rates down another notch ended yesterday, when the central bank entered the open market to drain reserves from the banking system at a time when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading at 5 1/16 percent.
Over the last few days the closely watched funds rate has been trading below the 5 1/4 percent level that is widely seen as the Fed's target.
Until yesterday, the Fed had not indicated to market participants that it had endorsed the recent softness.
Analysts said that yesterday's draining operation was a clear signal that monetary policy remained unchanged for the moment.
 
Results of Auction
 The Fed's action helped to push down prices early in the day, but the bulk of the downward move came after results of the seven-year note auction were announced.
At auction, the $9.25 billion worth of securities were sold at an average yield of 7.20 percent, down from the 8.26 percent average yield at the last seven-year note sale on July 10.
Unlike other Treasury issues, traders said there was no readily identifiable source of demand for seven-year notes. As a result, seven-year auctions have often been disappointing. Still, demand at yesterday's sale was a good bit weaker than expected, the traders said.
Prices of the new seven-year securities began to erode shortly after the auction took place and continued for much of the afternoon.
By late in the day, the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.25 percent.
While prices of longer-term notes and bonds took a beating, the prospect of another easing move by the Fed helped to limit the damage to short-term bills and notes.
 
Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 102 14/32, down more than a full point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 7.91 percent. Late Tuesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 7.81 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 19/32 late yesterday, down 1/2 point, to yield 7.49 percent. But the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes dipped by just 2/32, to a late offered price of 100 3/8, to yield 5.92 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.99 percent, unchanged from late Tuesday. Six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 5.04 percent.
Municipal bond participants said that an offering of $600 million worth of serial and term bonds sold by the Denver International Airport went well. The sale is part of the $2.66 billion project to construct a new airport for Denver.
Securities offered yesterday carried a maximum yield of 7.95 percent on term bonds that mature in 2025.
Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale. The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB-minus by Standard & Poor's.
 
Offering by Ontario
 New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a $750 million offering of 10-year securities for the Province of Ontario.
The 8 percent securities were priced at $99.925 to yield 8.011 percent, 50 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The noncallable securities are rated AA-2 by Moody's and AA-plus by Standard & Poor's.
The First Boston Corporation served as sole underwriter of slightly more than $109 million worth of floating-rate securities backed by auto loans from the Rochester Community Savings Bank.
The securities, which have an average life of 1.34 years, float monthly and will reset at 90 basis points above the six-month Treasury bill index.
The initial rate on the securities was set at 6.86 percent.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Fall and Assets Rise For Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of both tax-free and taxable money market funds declined for the week ended yesterday.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors funds and issues the Money Fund Report, noted that "a huge inflow of funds this past week reflects relative attractiveness of money funds compared with market yields of securities like the 90-day Treasuries." 
 He pointed out that yields on money funds reflect the two months' average maturity of portfolio holdings, which translates into a higher current yield that reflects the higher interest rates of two months ago.
Money funds, he explained, will always be more attractive during a period of sharp decline in interest rates than other comparable short-term investments that mostly reflect current rates.
He reported that total assets of tax-exempt funds reversed a downtrend and rose by $2.9 billion, to $89.2 billion. "A lot of this increase is seasonal flows of money at the end of a quarter," he said. The maturity of portfolio holdings rose to an average of 62 days, up from 59 days.
The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempts dropped to 4.23 percent from 4.49 percent -- a sharp decline of 26 basis points -- while the seven-day simple yield declined to 4.14 percent from 4.39 percent -- a matter of 25 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
As to the 30-day period, the compounded yields rose to 4.35 percent from 4.34 percent, and the 30-day simple yield rose to 4.26 percent from 4.25 percent -- by a basis point in each case. Mr. Frank explained that the 30-day yields still reflected rising yields in the municipal market that occurred in recent weeks up until the current week.
 
Highest-Yielding Fund
 The highest-yielding fund among those with assets over $100 million continued to be the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 5.22 percent, down from 5.37 percent.
Among funds investing in individual state securities in New York State, Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market continued to head the list, with the highest seven-day compounded yield of 4.95 percent, down from 5.05 percent a week ago.
In Connecticut, Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market Series again led with a 4.67 percent yield, down from 5.32 percent.
In New Jersey, the leader again was Calvert, N.J., Tax-Free Reserves, which reported a seven-day compounded yield of 4.89 percent, down from 5.16 percent,
Among the taxable funds, Mr. Frank said, the average seven-day compounded yield dropped to 5.21 percent, down 8 basis points from 5.29 percent. The simple yield also dropped b 8 basis points, to 5.08 percent from 5.16 percent,
The 30-day compounded yield dropped by 6 basis points, to 5.29 percent, down from 5.35 percent, and the 30-day simple yield fell to 5.16 percent from 5.21 percent.
Assets of the taxable funds rose by $9.2 billion, a larger increase than the $4.1 billion rise the previous week. Of the $9.2 billion increase, Mr. Frank said that $6.7 billion came from institutional investors, which means the public participation was up by $2.5 billion. Assets now total $461.2 billion, versus $452.0 billion last week.
Average maturities of portfolio holdings of the taxable funds moved up by a day, from 61 to 62 days.
The taxable fund with the best return was Riverside Capital Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 6.32 percent.
In comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 5.00 percent, from 5.02 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Expecting More Losses

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it expeceted to report losses for the rest of the year.
In a prospectus for a $750 million issue of preferred stock, Ford said it anticipated a third-quarter loss bigger than the second-quarter loss of $323.5 million. Ford lost $1.2 billion in the first half of this year. 
 "Because the pace of the economic recovery in the United States has been slower than had been anticipated, Ford also would expect to report a loss for the fourth quarter," said the prospectus.
The prospectus gave no indication of what the anticipated loss would be. Wall Street analysts had forecast that the General Motors Corporation, Ford and the Chrysler Corporation would break even or show a modest profit in the fourth quarter after five straight quarters of losses.
Collectively, the Big Three lost $3.2 billion in the first half of this year and they appear heading to their worst financial year in history, victims of a profound slump in car and truck purchases. In 1980, during the depths of a deep recession, the three companies lost a combined $4.5 billion.
Ford's disclosure of a probable fourth-quarter 1991 loss suggested that the other auto makers would probably report similar results.
"I don't anticipate that Ford will be alone in reporting a loss," Steven Girsky, an auto analyst at Paine Webber Inc., said today. "I think G.M. will be close by."
Ford's stock lost 75 cents a share today, closing at $29.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
