HEADLINE: Tempus Fugit, but You Can Buy It

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
After a decade when Americans struggled to find more time for work to increase their earnings, what people now seem to want even more than money is time off -- time away from jobs and chores, to do whatever strikes their fancy.
As a result, many people who can afford it are trading their hard-earned dollars for services that offer hassle-free leisure time. Sensing that shift, travel and service companies are coming up with new ways to package time, wrap it as neatly as a Big Mac and sell it to the public. 
 The American Express Company, for example, is selling a packaged Thanksgiving Day in New York, with brunch, a window on Broadway overlooking the Macy's parade and dinner at the Rainbow Room. The tab is $175 for each adult and $100 for each child.
The McDonald's Corporation has just opened the first in what may become a chain of large indoor play centers that are not attached to McDonald's restaurants. The center, near Chicago, is designed to give parents burdened with chores at home a place to spend time with their children. McDonald's is wagering that parents will pay $4.95 for a place where their children can play safely while they can watch from a quiet room.
"People are now saying they are willing to give up current income for leisure time, and that is a big change," said Dr. Juliet Schor, an associate professor of economics at Harvard University. "A shift in materialist values is taking place even as economic pressure on people to work longer hours is increasing."
In the last 10 years, as incomes stagnated, many Americans worked longer hours to maintain their life styles, researchers say, and women entered the work force in unprecedented numbers.
Now, the growing demand for unharried leisure time is particularly acute among families with two working parents. Close behind are white-collar employees who no longer believe that working long and hard for money and success necessarily means they are going to live better.
A survey of 1,010 adults in January by the Hilton Hotels Corporation found that 67 percent of those responding said they would be willing to forgo one or two days' pay, or 20 to 40 percent of the their income, for a day or two of free time each week.
Asked what seemed the most important use of their time in the 1990's, by contrast to the way they spent time in the 1980's, 77 percent said they would spend more time with family and friends; 72 percent said they would use the time for self-improvement, and 66 percent would just do whatever they pleased. Only 61 percent said they would use the time to make more money. The Hilton study was done in conjunction with Prof. John P. Robinson of the University of Maryland.
People have always dreamed about having more free time. And there have been periods like the 60's when sizable numbers wanted to drop out of society altogether.
What distinguishes the current demand for leisure time, researchers say, is that it comes as most workers' incomes have stagnated. And even among white-collar workers whose incomes rose in the 1980's, the desire appears to grow not out of abundance but out of exhaustion and frustration as husband and wife both work at top speed.
 
'A Decline in the Belief in Work'
 "For white-collar workers the restructuring and downsizing of industry did something fundamental to people's thinking about where they get satisfaction in their lives," said Bickley Townsend, a vice president of the Roper Organization, a New York survey research company. "There is a decline in the belief in work as a source of satisfaction."
Professor Schor of Harvard said the average amount of time worked each year grew by 149 hours between 1969 and 1989. About half that increase took place in the last decade.
Some researchers, like Professor Robinson, have challendged Professor Schor's estimates, but most agree that the frustration about lack of time has hit working mothers hardest. Another Roper study, conducted in 1990, found that a majority of working women with children under 13 years old said they would prefer to stay home rather than to hold a paying job, by 51 percent to 42 percent. That finding represented a major reversal from 1985, when more women chose employment over homemaking by 51 percent to 45 percent.
With an ear to such sentiments, American Express announced last month that it would start selling "experiences" in sports, politics, food, literature, music and other fields -- like the Thanksgiving Day parade -- to people holding its expensive Platinum Card. The idea, the company said, is to plan all the details of a perfect evening or day off and, at a cost of $75 to several hundred dollars, spare people the trouble of making plans themselves.
"To Platinum Card members, leisure time has become a precious commodity," said John Williams, an American Express vice president for marketing. "As card members tell us about their individual interests, we will shape once-in-a-lifetime experiences to match."
 
Offering 'Quality' Leisure Time
 On a more modest level, McDonald's last month opened its first Leaps and Bounds children's center, where the product is not fast food but "quality" leisure time for parents with children.
Situated in the Chicago suburb of Naperville, Ill., the center gives adults a choice of romping with their children in an 11,000-square-foot play area or sitting in a glass-enclosed "plenty quiet" room. There they can watch their children on television monitors, read or do nothing at all.
"If it were physically possible to not require sleep, that would help out immensely," said Susan Oberling, 32, a manager at a health care company who sat peacefully, as her 7-year-old son, Michael, played outside.
"To have time together as a family is always a challenge," Ms. Oberling said, adding that she and her husband worked a total of 100 hours a week. "In the evening," she continued, "by the time my husband and I are finished working, it's time to eat dinner, do homework with my son, and then it's bedtime."
 
Successful Hilton Campaign
 Hilton Hotels discovered a successful marketing campaign over the last two years with its discount "Bounceback Weekend" at $65 to $150 a night. The chain advertised the weekend as an escape from the mounting pressures of weekends at home and awarded its weekend customers planning kits to help them schedule their weeks more efficiently.
Weekend reservations at its 260 hotels have more than doubled, Hilton says, turning Saturday night from the least popular to the most heavily booked night of the week. Other large hotel chains have mounted similar marketing efforts.
Companies that provide services that eliminate hassle or planning to free up leisure time also say they have discovered a fast-growing market. They include "drop off" day-care centers, which allow parents to leave children at almost any hour without making reservations in advance, and services that shop on behalf of busy adults. And around the nation, milk delivery is making a comeback.
 
Supermarket Shopping by Phone
 Shoppers Express, based in Bethesda, Md., allows a customer to order groceries from the supermarket by phone or facsimile machine, then delivers the order. In the last 10 weeks, it has added service in 11 metropolitan areas, for a total of 32, and now serves some of the largest supermarket chains in the nation.
"Our customers don't want to give up two hours of free time to shop," said Kevin Sheehan, a vice president at Shoppers Express. "They are the two-income families with kids. We have done two years of research and development, and we think that as we enter the 1990's these people are going to place more emphasis on time."
Other food delivery services also report steady growth in demand. Room Service, a Chicago company, permits customers to select different courses from the menus of more than 15 restaurants. Brian Keil, one of the company's founders, said deliveries in Chicago had doubled in the last year, to more than 700 a week.
 
Child-Care Centers' Tactic
 In Minneapolis, four chains of child-care centers are competing for the patronage of parents who decide to take a spontaneous day off or night out and need child care, right away. One company, Clubkid, even lends beepers to parents so they can be contacted immediately if problems develop.
Lynn Taylor, a vice president at Robert Half International, a large recruiter of accountants, financial employees and data processing personnel, said that since 1989 a growing number of companies have lured employees not with higher salaries, but with promises of shorter hours or more flexible time off.
"Many people have been through the 70-hour workweek and they are asking themselves, 'Why do I want that?' " Ms. Taylor said. "People are stepping back a bit to smell the roses."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Is Set to Open New Center

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 9

 BODY:
While other auto makers are busy promoting their 1992 car and truck models, the Chrysler Corporation is also showing off a building that will consolidate engineers, designers and scientists under one huge roof in hopes of speeding the development of new models.
Four teams assigned to develop four future vehicle "platforms," or wheelbases, each the basis for a family of similar-size models, will occupy one entire floor at a new four-story technology center that officially opens next week in Auburn Hills, Mich., about 30 miles north of Detroit. Two years ago, Chrysler reorganized its engineering departments into platforms, in line with the structure of most Japanese auto makers. 
 Historically, American auto makers developed cars by having separate departments for each part of the same car. In recent years, more and more auto makers have developed a team approach for each family of models.
"It's extremely difficult to communicate in technical depth when people are spread out as they are," in about 40 locations in the Detroit area, said Richard Torigian, a Chrysler executive engineer. In addition to the traditional testing equipment, the center will include five laboratories that Chrysler currently does not operate, like a laboratory to test the electromagnetic interference between a vehicle's electronic components and airplanes and microwave towers.
Chrysler also hopes the technology center will promote confidence in the No. 3 auto maker's future. In a prepared statement, Lee A. Iacocca , Chrysler's chairman, called the Chrysler Technology Center the place where "the world's best vehicles will be born" and "a commitment to long-term thinking."
The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and Chrysler all are trying to organize engineers into platform teams. All three continue to keep some engineers assigned to departments as specialists, as do the Japanese auto makers.
G.M.'s Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac group adopted the team approach earlier so a bigger proportion of its engineers work on platform teams. Ford executives have said they are about halfway toward complete platform-team organization. And a Chrysler spokesman said virtually all engineering was organized in that manner.
 
Aging Operations
 To stay competitive, Chrysler had very little choice but to modernize its operations that are used for developing new products. Those operations are centered in Highland Park, Mich, a poor community on Detroit's north side, which has a high crime rate. Chrysler believes it will be better able to recruit young scientists and engineers to work in suburban Auburn Hills.
The expenditure, however, comes at a time when the No. 3 auto maker is having financial difficulties and vehicle sales are weak.
To pay for the building, Chrysler sold $1.1 billion worth of bonds last year, with an interest rate pegged to the auto maker's credit rating. The interest payments to holders of the Auburn Hills Trust bonds will be covered by Chrysler's lease payments on the building. Interest payments on the bonds started at about $136.1 million annually and have risen to $174.6 million at the current interest rate.
Since the sale of the bonds, however, Chrysler's credit rating has fallen to below investment grade, causing interest on the notes to rise to 15 7/8 percent from 12 1/8 percent.
The auto maker's precarious financial position began two years ago as the economy began to weaken. Chrysler lost market share and has been losing money this year.
Chrysler broke ground for the technology center in 1986. It does not expect to finish construction until 1994. At that time, the auto maker expects 7,000 people to be working there. So far, 1,200 workers have moved there. The auto maker has said it will keep its headquarters and nontechnical white-collar workers in Highland Park.

HEADLINE: Allied Plans Broad Cuts; Stock Jumps

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Allied-Signal Inc., whose spending has far outstripped the cash it has been taking in, took strong action yesterday to do something about it, including plans to reduce managerial ranks by 14 percent. In response, its stock price jumped 12 percent.
The measures reflected the determination of Lawrence A. Bossidy, the chief executive since Aug. 1, to move quickly to make Allied more competitive and cut costs. 
 The company said it also planned to cut capital spending and the stock dividend, sell 8 small businesses, and close 10 small manufacturing plants. The reorganization will lead to an $880 million charge against earnings in the current quarter.
The earnings write-off includes $200 million for potential environmental liabilities, bringing Allied's total environmental reserves to $500 million.
 
Stock No. 4 on Active List
 Many of the measures, including the dividend cut, were expected on Wall Street. Still, the extent of the reorganization pleased investors nearly as much as July's announcement that the highly regarded Mr. Bossidy had been recruited from the General Electric Company to take over from Edward L. Hennessy Jr. Allied's shares, which jumped $3.75, to $33.125, when Mr. Bossidy's appointment was announced, rose $4.25 yesterday, to $40.375. With 2.8 million shares changing owners, it was No. 4 on the New York Stock Exchange active list.
The dividend will be cut almost in half, to $1 from $1.80.
Allied, based in Morris Township, N.J., said the $880 million writeoff would result in a substantial loss for the year. The company had net income of $142 million from regular operations on sales of $5.95 billion in the first half of 1991.
 
Cut in Operating Costs
 Mr. Bossidy told analysts gathered at a midtown Manhattan hotel and listening by telephone from around the country that the various changes would reduce operating costs by $225 million, or $1 a share, next year and $350 million, or $1.55 a share, by 1994. Analysts were especially impressed by projections that the company would start taking in more cash than it was spending next year.
"It eliminates the uncertainty they have had for a long time of never having enough money to operate the business without borrowing," said Anthony Ludovici, who follows the company for Tucker Anthony.
Mr. Bossidy said the 5,000 managerial layoffs would be spread fairly evenly throughout Allied's aerospace, automotive and engineering materials businesses. The automotive sector, where 1,580 jobs, or 17 percent of the salaried work force, will be eliminated, will be the hardest hit. Allied will also close heavy vehicle component manufacturing operations in Reno and in Salisbury, N.C., and eight other auto component plants that were not named yesterday.
The plant closings and other consolidations will also eliminate 3,300 hourly jobs. Allied's total worldwide work force is about 100,000.
 
Salaried Worker Reductions
 About 700 of the job reductions in salaried workers will stem from centralizing financial, purchasing and human resource jobs. In some cases, just one of the company's three business sectors will perform work for the whole company. The aerospace group, for example, will take over all payroll operations.
"We will do work in the most economical place," Mr. Bossidy said. "There will be no stand-alone sectors." Allied also said that 10 data centers would be consolidated into one large center in Arizona and the 4 separate telecommunications systems would be consolidated into one system.
The reorganization plan also sharply reduced capital spending for 1992 from a requested $927 million to about $700 million. A substantial part of the reduction reflected the company's decision to reduce its investment in anti-lock braking systems and fluorine products. Although Allied is the leading manufacturer in the world of vehicle braking systems, it is a distant third to Bosch of Germany and the Teves subsidiary of ITT. in the sophisticated anti-lock systems segment. Mr. Bossidy said the company hopes that its newest anti-lock system, which will be tested this winter, turns out to be "a breakthrough product" but that the company will reconsider its involvement in the business if it is not.
One key element in Mr. Bossidy's plan to halt the outflow of cash is a drive to raise productivity and reduce the time it takes to make products.
One area that Allied did not cut, to the surprise of some analysts, was research and development spending. Mr. Bossidy said that when the sums devoted to engineering or provided by customers were removed from Allied's reported totals, the $430 million projected for this year represented an average commitment for the industries Allied is in.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Rich Icing For Turner Broadcasting

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AS the Atlanta Braves stormed from well back of the Los Angeles Dodgers this summer, the stock market took notice. The team's owner, the Turner Broadcasting Company, perhaps better known for such operations as Cable News Network and Turner Network Television, followed right along.
Shares in Turner Broadcasting, which were languishing below $14 in late July, when the Braves were in third place and seemingly headed nowhere, have moved up to nearly $18 as the Braves captured the Western division title in the National League. Last night they lost the opening game of the playoffs to the Pittsburgh Pirates. Wall Street analysts say it has been the fate of the Braves that seems to have drawn investors. 
 It is a bit absurd that the fortunes of the Braves would have a big effect on the shares of Turner Broadcasting. Last year, the revenues from Turner's sports operations -- including the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association as well as the Braves -- were $34.7 million, or less than 3 percent of the company's $1.4 billion.
That figure is, to be sure, understated, since it does not include advertising revenues from broadcasting Braves games, but the fact remains that Turner's fortunes are much more dependent on trends in cable television advertising than they are on any sports activities.
But the investor enthusiasm does reflect that when given a chance, sports fans have often been willing to show their loyalty by investing in stocks representing their favorite teams. The only publicly traded team now, the Boston Celtics of the N.B.A., went public in 1986 at $18.50 a share, a price that seemed high at the time based on such things as earnings, but that reflected fan enthusiasm. The price of the shares is now $17.
The last two public offerings of shares in big league baseball teams were in 1917, when the St. Louis Cardinals went public, and in 1936, when the hapless St. Louis Browns did so. In both cases, according to an article in the Summer issue of the Friends of Financial History, the shares eventually were bought cheaply from public holders. Jason Zweig, the editor of the journal, said it appeared that public investors in the Cardinals lost money, but that investors in the Browns may have fared better than the team did.
Now the only other major league teams in which public holders have a stake are the Cardinals, owned by Anheuser-Busch, and the Chicago Cubs, owned by the Tribune Company. In each case, the baseball operations provide a minor share of revenues.
For Turner Broadcasting, the revival in the stock certainly cannot be justified by the increased profits that will come from the Braves' successes on the field. Jeff Russell and John Reidy, who follow the stock at Smith Barney, said the success may help Turner get more for ads for next year's Braves games, and probably was a modest positive for third-quarter results.
But they noted that the field success will not help the company in the current quarter. A lot of money will be spent advertising on the Braves' playoff and, if all goes well, World Series, games. But that money will go to CBS, which has the television rights.
Still, it is arguable that Turner's rise in the stock market is a belated recognition of the company's revival, which followed a 1989 reorganization that resulted in cable operators, principally Time Warner and Tele-Communications, owning a large stake in the company. Together, they now own 44 percent of the company's stock, adjusted for conversions of preferred stock. Ted Turner, the company's founder and chairman, controls 32 percent, but has voting control because the company has two classes of common, one -- class A -- with extra voting rights but inferior dividend rights, if dividends are ever paid.
Yesterday, Turner class A shares fell 12.5 cents, to $17.625, while the more widely held class B shares rose 25 cents, to $17.75, in American Stock Exchange trading.
The company has reported losses for years, but reported a profit of $4.6 million for 1990. That was not nearly enough to cover preferred dividends, but this year the company has reduced its preferred stock substantially, by exchanging it for common, and for the first six months of 1991 it reported profits of $19.1 million, or 8 cents a common share.
For all of 1991, the Smith Barney analysts think the company will earn 20 cents a share, rising to 65 cents next year.
Still, the most important fact for the company is likely to be trends in advertising, which have done surprisingly well during the recession, reflecting the success of CNN, and what happens to the current talks about Turner's acquisition of the rights to the Hanna-Barbera cartoons from Great American Communications.
But just as those factors seem to have been relatively unimportant in the rise of the Turner stock, perhaps they will also be unimportant in its trading over the next few weeks. That could depend on whether Atlanta manages to pull off still more upsets and go on to win the World Series.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines by 17.44 in Heavy Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday in heavy trading, dragged down by concern over corporate earnings, a weak bond market and fading expectations of any imminent interest-rate cut by the Fed.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 17.44 points, to 2,946.33, as Big Board volume reached 186.7 million shares, up from 170.1 million on Tuesday. Decliners outpaced gaining issues by a ratio of slightly less than 2 to 1. 
 Ricky Harrington, director of investment policy for Marion Bass Securities in Charlotte, N.C., called yesterday's market and the previous session a technical rally that ended about noon as bonds came under pressure. "While the broad market was considerably weaker," he said, the Dow did not fall lower because of a strong gain in one Dow stock, Allied-Signal.
For most of yesterday's session trading was mostly in the lower end of a tight range, with blue chips little changed. There is some individual buying, but on the most part investors find there is not much to motivate them ahead of a watershed of corporate earnings expected.
"A couple of significnt Dow support levels in this market have already been broken, 3,000 and 2,970," Mr. Harrington said. "How far will this market fall? Well, you now have some support at the 2,900 to 2,920 levels and a low end at 2,850 from which the market can mount a rally."
 
Vulnerability of the Market
 The market will continue to be vulnerable over the near-term for a number of reasons, one of them the bond market, he said. When the bond market rallied for several weeks, the stock market failed to match it, but now that bonds have come under pressure, stocks are following suit. Another, is the back drop of institutional investors who have some what less cash than they did a year ago.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 3.87, to 376.80, while New York Stock Exchange composite was off 1.84, to 207.95. The American Stock Exchange composite slipped 0.68, to 368.51.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite fell 3.44, to 513.81.
Millipore, a diversified manufacturer, fell 2 points, to 33 5/8, after the company, citing soft economic condition domestically and Europe, said its sales were weaker than expected for the third-quarter and nine-month period. Analysts wasted no time in lowering their own estimates.
Nordstrom fell 8 1/2, to 33 3/4, after the specialty retailer projected sharply lower-than-expected third-quarter sales and earnings results. In hectic trading more than 2.5 million shares were traded in the first hour, with 6.2 million shares changing hands for the day. Nordstrom rang the bell for other retailers, Dayton Hudson fell 2 7/8, to 66 3/4; Dillard Department Stores dropped 2 points to close at 122 1/4; May Department Stores was down 1 1/4, to 50 1/2; Sears, Roebuck, off 7/8, to 36 3/4, and J. C. Penney was down 1 1/2, to 48 1/4.
Digital Microwave, a manufacturer of telecommunications equipment rose 3/4, to 9. The company expects a second-quarter loss, but sees new order activity beginning to materialize.
Allied-Signal rang up a 4 1/4-point gain, to 40 3/8, after the announced restructuring, which was taken as a bullish move by the company.
Bristol-Myers Squibb was up 5/8, to 82 3/8, as the Food and Drug Administration approved the company's Dideoxyinosine, a drug for treating patients at advanced stages of infection with the AIDS virus.
Biogen, which reported third-quarter profits on Tuesday, rose 1 1/8 yesterday, to 34 3/8.

HEADLINE: With No Chicken in the Pot, Cubans' Faith in Castro's Revolution Is Waning

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
In this city of crumbling beauty and pressing hardship, many Cubans say that only the still-intimidating police apparatus prevents them from openly expressing the hope that their three-decade-long experience with a Communist system is drawing to an end.
Even as the international network of cold war alliances that supported him has dissolved, President Fidel Castro, the country's leader for 32 years, has warned his people that come what may, Cuba will not veer from the Communist path. 
 But in a weeklong visit on tourist's visa, which allowed more open exchanges with strangers and frank discussions with Cuban acquaintances, almost all expressed the hope or belief that with the island's economy stumbling badly and faith in the leadership thinning, Cuba was now heading toward change.
 
Bold Conversations
 "We have got to change," said one ticket agent, boldly striking up a conversation with a rare American customer. "You can't imagine what it feels like when you are on the margins while the whole world is moving forward."
"We all feel this way now," the agent said. "Change is coming. It has to. Let's hope it comes soon."
A tourist guide, among the most carefully chosen and privileged workers in the country because of their frequent contacts with foreigners and dollars, expressed similar sentiments.
Asked which of the national tourist outfits she worked for, the young woman said with a sneer: "Don't you know everything here is for the state? It's all the same. This is a really terrible system. We are a little luckier than others, but even for us, life has become rotten here."
 
Closed Communist Congress
 In the midst of what the leadership acknowledges is its worst crisis since Mr. Castro deposed the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista on Jan. 1, 1959, the ruling Cuban Communist Party has scheduled a closed congress for Oct. 10 to try to formulate a message of hope while preserving the foundations of its one-party system. Many Cubans, however, say they view the meeting as simply a bid to hold onto power rather than to move the country forward.
"How do you expect me to have faith when they lock themselves up behind closed doors?" asked one university student in a typical remark. Another man said, "If they knew how to make the economy function do you think they would wait for a congress to announce it?"
Nothing has so eroded support for the government as the recent, rampant spread of shortages of foods and consumer goods, caused in large part by the collapse of Cuba's trade with its former allies in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The shortages have come well before the full impact of the Soviet Union's recently announced disengagement from the island could be felt. And while there has never been abundance under the revolution, the new scarcities alarm many Cubans who had lived comfortable lives compared to many in Latin America.
In the living room of the cramped apartment where he lives with his wife and two children, a Cuban writer described the dispiriting dietary regimen that is now more or less standard.
 
Few Chickens
 "We get one chicken for four people every nine days, theoretically," said the writer, who like most Cubans expressed fear over having his name appear in a foreign newspaper. Referring to the small ration book that tightly governs the monthly consumption of every household, he added: "Often it doesn't work out the way the libretta suggests, though. Sometimes we only get a chicken every 15 days.
"We get five eggs a week per person," the writer continued over a glass of white wine brewed at home from green beans in a flash of the sort of creative improvisation that has flourished here in the absence of many ordinary goods. "We are given fish maybe once a month, and the condensed milk we just bought was our allotment for July."
At the mention of pork, a Cuban favorite, one woman mocked: "Is that Spanish you are speaking? Here we have forgotten what that word means."
Others tell of using Chinese toothpaste, which can still be readily found, to wash their clothes in the long and frequent absences of laundry detergent. Soap and shampoo have become just as rare, forcing most people to revert to cold water baths. The recipes that Cuban women swap these days as often as not are for homemade products for the care of their hair.
 
No Shortage of Police
 The growing candor of ordinary Cubans is more remarkable since Cuba still maintains a vast force of police officers and soldiers, both uniformed and plainclothesmen, who pervade the country's society. These police officers peer stone faced from kiosks outside foreign embassies, noting passport numbers of all who enter, unsubtly mingle in hotel lobbies monitoring foreigners' movements and keeping out Cubans, and trail visitors and eavesdrop on telephone conversations.
Human rights advocates have long faced attacks by security agents posing as offended citizens whenever they have tried to mount demonstrations or hold public meetings. Recently, the government announced the formation of "rapid response teams" to be based in neighborhoods and workplaces so they can quickly put down any discontent before it spreads.
During an earlier visit this summer, a brief and non-political conversation between an American and a group of young Cubans in Havana's Central Park, police officers quickly surrounded the young Cubans and herded them off to a side street, where they were frisked and questioned aggressively.
One question that is on everyone's minds concerns the intentions of the United States.
From thin Cuban newspapers, which for lack of paper have become increasingly hard to find, Cubans are still fed negative images of the United States.
Granma, the Communist Party daily, still devotes about a half a page to reporting every rise in American unemployment, bankruptcy or drug abuse. Murders and other crime stories from New York City are an especially favored staple.
"Are the Americans going to invade us again?" several people asked an American visitor, as if they feared some new imminent military action had already been prepared.
If Cuban news on the United States has long been skewed and sketchy, recent information about the Soviet Union, the country's closest ally for over 30 years, has become equally selective after the failed attempt by Communist Party hardliners to overthrow President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
For over a year, Mr. Castro has given ominous warnings about the consequences for Cuba should the Soviet Union somehow disintegrate. For a time, he spoke of a "zero option," or a painful if temporary shift to austere horse- and oxen-powered autarky in order to save socialism.
Hundreds of Cubans, frightened by the apocalyptic-sounding scenario spelled out by their leader and given flesh by the growing shortages, have fled the island -- by boats and rafts in most cases, or by defecting abroad, as many of the more privileged children of the revolution have recently done.
The number of Cuban boat and raft refugees rescued by the United States Coast Guard has increased more than fourfold already this year. The most recent figures show that 1,907 refugees have been taken in so far this year compared with 467 for all of 1990.
Since Mr. Castro's warnings on the Soviet Union have mostly come true, discussion in the media of the consequences for Cuba have been minimal.
"I heard they were pulling out their soldiers but that all of the commercial agreements would be maintained," said one Cuban intellectual, who like most of his countrymen seemed unaware of the extent to which Soviet subsidies have already been cut.
A street-level appraisal of Cuba's circumstances came from a taxi driver who saw the replacement of the fleet of Soviet-made Lada cabs with shiny new Nissans as a more blunt expression of the new economic realities.
"The days of great friendship are over and the Russians are asking for dollars like everyone else now," the taxi driver said. "I'll be glad when I get a Japanese car, because the Ladas were never really any good anyway."

HEADLINE: 7 Arab Houses Are Seized in Raid By Jewish Settlers in Jerusalem

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 9

 BODY:
A group of Jewish nationalistic settlers evaded the police and took over seven Arab houses today in an effort to re-establish a Jewish neighborhood at the former site of the ancient city of King David. Most were soon evicted by the police.
The incident occurred a few days before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, is to arrive here for what many hope will be the decisive round of negotiations before the convening of a Middle East peace regional conference at the end of the month. 
 Opposition-party politicians called the action a deliberate provocation, given that Mr. Baker was confronted with new settlements in the occupied territories on several previous visits. Government officials also saw possible diplomatic effects.
Science Minister Yuval Neeman, who is a member of the far-right-wing Tehiya party, joined the settlers early this morning.
"If one result of this will be that it will be harder to convene the peace conference, I certainly wouldn't be sorry about that," he said.
The seizing of the houses before dawn set off stone throwing in an already tense city. The police here are braced for possible Palestinian demonstrations or attacks to commemorate the killing a year ago of at least 17 Palestinians near Al Aksa Mosque at Haram al-Sharif, or the noble sanctuary. Jews call the area the Temple Mount.
The Israeli police used force to oust the 50 armed settlers from all the houses except one, where four rightist members of Parliament and one family were allowed to remain, a police spokesman said.
"We knew of the moves in advance and in large measure prevented it," said Anat Granit, a police spokeswoman. "We were prepared for them."
Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, an opponent of the planned Mideast conference, was asked if he supported the predawn takeover. "Jews have a right to settle anywhere in the city," he replied.
 
'Only the Street Is Left'
 Similar moves by Jewish settlers have occurred in the last year inside the Old City and in various parts of Arab East Jerusalem. A municipal spokeswoman said that such "brazen actions" only cause tension and friction among the city's 150,000 Arabs and 350,000 Jews.
One of the Arabs evicted, Jamil Ahmed Abasi, 45 years old, returned home this morning from visiting relatives and found the settlers rearranging his home and refusing him entry.
"Of course I was shocked," he said. "Where else am I supposed to go? Only the street is left."
Mr. Abasi, who has five children, is currently unemployed.
Mohammed al-Abasi, the mukhtar, or leader, of the 30,000 Arab residents of the area, Silwan, said 17 families received eviction notices from a Government body in charge of absentee properties six months ago and had appealed. A hearing is scheduled on Oct. 20, he said.
The new Jewish group, called El Ad, which means To There, supports Mr. Sharon's ideas. It said it had bought half the approximately 12 acres of land that make up the former City of David, including the houses. A spokesman, Yigal Canaan, said that an appeal against their ouster by the police would be filed with the High Court.

HEADLINE: Between Worlds: New York's Bangladeshis

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
When Maksouda Bhuiyan, an announcer on a Bangladeshi cable television program in New York City, answered a knock at her front door recently, a Bangladeshi man, his wife and their 5-month-old child were standing outside. The family, who had arrived in the United States only hours earlier on a flight from Bangladesh, carried a picture of Mrs. Bhuiyan that they had clipped from a magazine.
The couple, who knew no one in the city when they arrived about three weeks ago, needed a place to stay. Mrs. Bhuiyan allowed the family to move in with her. She did not have the heart to refuse them. She continues to feed them, and they live with the Bangladeshi family next door. 
 For many Bangladeshi immigrants, that scene has been played out often in New York City. Newly arrived immigrants who know no one in the United States search out any Bangladeshi they can find to ask for help, which is often given in the tradition of their country.
But when one of those newly arrived immigrants was arrested in April in the slaying of a woman whose family had hired him as a houseboy, Bangladeshis who had been in New York City for years began to realize the need for better services and programs to support those immigrants.
"They think they come here and everything is ready for them," said Rehana Hasan, who owns a pharmacy in Queens, and is a friend of Mrs. Bhuiyan. "The reality smashes them. It breaks them completely."
Many of the new immigrants have come to New York after winning visas in a lottery that the State Department began two years ago and that will be closed this year in an effort to increase the ethnic diversity of those entering the United States. Most Bangladeshis have settled in Jackson Heights, Astoria and Corona in Queens and work in restaurants, delicatessens and as taxicab drivers. Some move to Brooklyn, where many work on construction jobs.
Because the more than 6,500 lottery winners may bring their immediate family with them, about 20,000 Bangladeshis have come to New York in the last couple of years, said Sayed Ullah, editor of Probashi, one of the three Bengali-language newspapers in the city.
But when they arrive after leaving a land cursed by recurrent and massive natural disasters and beset by extreme poverty and unemployment, they find a community that is without many job skills or access to job training and second-language programs and that is plagued by a high unemployment rate, Mr. Ullah said. Their dreams of economic prosperity quickly dissolve into a nightmare of economic, social and cultural deprivation, he said.
The result has been a strain on New York's insular Bangladeshi community, whose 50,000 members have been struggling to find links between their native culture and their new country. The community has eight mosques in addition to the Bengali-language newspapers.
 
Frequent Arguments
 Bangladeshis point to the life of Abu Ahmed, whose wife was killed by an immigrant whom the family hired as a house boy and who has hired about 10 of the immigrants to work in the family's three Manhattan restaurants.
The Ahmeds hired Mohammad Lokman Uddin as the housekeeper at their home in Little Neck, Queens. Mr. Uddin, a 21-year-old welder from Bangladesh who spoke no English and could barely read and write in his own language when he arrived in America less than a year ago, lived with the Ahmeds and was paid $200 for a six-day week.
But he argued constantly with Noor Ahmed, who was 31 years old, adding to the strain in a household where the marriage was already troubled, friends and relatives of Mrs. Ahmed said. The police said that in a fit of rage after hearing that he would be dismissed by the Ahmeds, Mr. Uddin strangled Mrs. Ahmed and then dumped her body in her car. The police said he confessed through an interpreter to the murder.
The slaying has has led many women in the community to question their role as Bangladeshi women in the United States.
 
Contrasting Roles
 Many of the women work as doctors, dentists, social workers and in other professions, but signs of independence and assertiveness welcomed at work are frowned upon in their homes.
The community faced with the realization that a woman's place in the Bangladeshi community in New York City, while often better than that of women back home, is ruled by centuries of Muslim and Hindu tradition. Because of that tradition, Mrs. Ahmed's family and friends say, Mrs. Ahmed felt trapped in a marriage that she wanted to leave. But to leave meant being ostracized by her family and the entire community.
 
Family Influence
 "In our society, it is very difficult for a man to see a woman independent," said Syeda Khalique, a third-year law student and mother of four who runs three small businesses, an unusual accomplishment for anyone and especially for a Bangladeshi woman. "Marriage is a contract, a social duty. In our society if a woman divorces, the blame is always with the woman. The whole society feels pity for the man."
Shama Mubdi is a case manager for the New York City Human Resources Administration who has lived in America for 16 years. "We are here in America," he said, but the men "still have the old-country mentality."
And Mrs. Khalique said: "You may work and earn a living, but if you come in front of men to talk, you are shameless. Aggressiveness means you have no moral character. It is like a master-servant relationship."
Friends and relatives of Mrs. Ahmed say that Mr. Uddin, who often watched pornographic movies against her wishes, never respected her and rarely followed her instructions. Mr. Uddin, for his part, says that Mrs. Ahmed treated him "like a slave."
"I did not want to come," Mr. Uddin, who was born in Sylhet in northern Bangladesh, said in an interview at Rikers Island. "Bush gave me the lottery, and I said, 'Why not make some money.' So I came."
Members of Mrs. Ahmed's family say they are angry with themselves and with Mr. Ahmed, saying that they could have made her life happier. Mrs. Ahmed's mother, Suretunessa Laskar, said that her daughter had been deeply unhappy and had wanted a divorce, but that her family and Mr. Ahmed had forbidden it out of tradition.
"I told my sister -- you are a woman; he is a man," Sabir Laskar said. "You have to tolerate him. You can't get divorced because who will marry your daughter?"
Bangladeshi women say such an attitude is prominent in all their lives. Some women in the community, troubled by their friend's death, have begun to re-evaluate that view. They have begun to meet and discuss the complexities of their lives, their role in the Bangladeshi community and their relationships with their husbands.
But amid their discussions, they think about Mrs. Ahmed.
"I feel so much that her soul is not at rest," Mrs. Khalique said. "She used to ask me how can you be so free and I would tell her it must come from inside. I hope she is free now."

HEADLINE: Bush Said to Order China Import-Barrier Inquiry

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
President Bush has ordered a wide-ranging investigation into Chinese import barriers that could lead to punitive duties on imports from China, Administration officials said today.
Scheduled for announcement on Thursday, the President's decision reflected a broad consensus among Federal agencies that China is discriminating against American products and shows no willingness to change its policies, they said. 
 But the decision reflects not only international trade strategy but also domestic political maneuvering.
The Administration waged a fierce political battle this summer to win the renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status. Part of the price it paid for the support of seven Democratic senators from farm states was a commitment to start an investigation if China did not change its policies soon.
The investigation ordered today would look at four ways in which Administration officials believe that China unfairly restricts imports. They are import quotas and outright bans on some products; complex import licensing requirements; highly specific technical standards that only match domestically produced goods; and a refusal to publish rules so that American businessmen can avoid legal pitfalls.
Administration officials contend that these import barriers are a major reason why China will accumulate an estimated $12 billion trade surplus with the United States this year, exporting more than $3 worth of goods to the United States for every dollar worth of imports. Chinese exports to the United States have soared while American exports to China fell slightly last year.
The Chinese Ambassador, Zhu Qizhen, said at a news conference this summer that weak Chinese imports of American goods reflected a slowdown in the Chinese economy, and not discrimination against American exports.
China is one of the largest foreign markets for American grain and agricultural pesticides, and senators from states producing these products were under pressure from constituents to vote against legislation this summer that either would have canceled the preferential trade status immediately or made any renewal next year subject to a wide range of conditions, such as an improved human rights record.
China threatened to retaliate against American exports if either measure passed, and Administration officials said President Bush would veto any legislation that did not call for an unconditional renewal.
The Senate voted 55 to 45 to impose conditions, failing to reach the two-thirds majority required to override a veto. The House passed similar legislation by slightly more than a two-thirds margin. Neither house has moved to iron out differences between the bills.
A resolution to cancel the trade status entirely passed the House by a narrow margin and was never put to a vote in the Senate.
In a letter on July 19 to Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, one of the seven farm state Senators who supported the Administration on this issue, President Bush wrote that if talks with Chinese officials in mid-August "fail to produce Chinese commitments to take substantial measures to improve market access," the Administration would take action.
The talks in August made no progress, but American trade officials gave China until the end of September to outline a new negotiating stance.
The delay infuriated Mr. Baucus, and he threatened last month to withdraw his support of Mr. Bush's position.
China gave the American Embassy in Beijing a response on Sept. 30, but Administration officials concluded that it represented no change.
Senators who voted in favor of the Administration's position in July have been put in an awkward position by a Customs Service order last Friday impounding shipments of wrenches and steel pipes from China, pending an investigation into whether they were made by prison labor.
The order followed testimony to a Congressional panel on Sept. 23 by Harry Wu, a former Chinese prisoner who said he returned to China this summer with false credentials and signed deals with prisons to ship these and other products to the United States.

HEADLINE: States' Public Workers Face New Round of Layoffs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Just as state and local governments complete an agonizing round of large-scale layoffs of public employees, many budget directors are predicting that with the economy still faltering and revenue declining, a whole new wave of layoffs may be necessary.
"I think it's going to be a really tough year," said Marcia A. Howard, research director of the National Association of State Budget Directors. "Most state budgets were based on the premise that a recovery would be well under way by now, and if it is, it certainly hasn't helped state revenues yet." 
 State and local employment has declined by 84,000 workers since July, the start of the fiscal year for nearly all states, the United State Bureau of Labor Statistics reported in early October. It was the first time in 10 years that state and local employment decreased for three months in a row.
The drumroll of layoffs is constant:
Connecticut laid off 2,500 workers last month and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is threatening to lay off another 7,500 unless unions provide more concessions. Massachusetts is laying off 4,000; Ohio is laying off 1,000 and Maine 200. New York State, completing a 12-month work-force reduction of 18,000 through layoffs and attrition, is laying off 1,300 this year. New Jersey has laid off 5,000 and is considering laying off another 5,000 while California plans to lay off 3,000 in January.
 
Nation's Capital Cuts Back
 Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon of Washington has sent termination notices to 126 middle-management employees, as part of her campaign promise to sharply reduce the district's 48,000 employees.
Gina Douglas, a communications specialist in Washington's Office of Personnel, said she could not answer questions about the layoffs because she herself was being laid off from her $48,500-a-year job.
"I'm just a little bit depressed today, I'm fighting back the tears," said Mrs. Douglas, 33 years old, who is married and has two children. "We have a whole host of bills associated with a car, house and two kids. It's frightening."
The continuing layoffs not only erode the traditional sense of job security associated with government work, but put a drag on the economic recovery, forcing thousands of families to tighten their belts.
Layoffs of public employees have profound social impact, too, bringing in their wake larger class sizes in schools, shorter library hours, fewer hospital beds and less protection from fire and crime.
 
Maryland Revenue Problems
 No one is certain where the cuts will end, as Maryland's experience has made painfully clear. Last year, the state laid off 3,000 employees when, for the first time in state history, tax revenue did not exceed the previous year's.
But this fiscal year, which began July 1, is looking even worse. Since then, Maryland has dropped its revenue estimates for this fiscal year by $260 million, to $5.8 billion.
So, Gov. William Donald Schaefer recently announced the layoff of 1,766 more state workers and the elimination of 420 positions that are currently vacant. The layoffs effectively eliminate rehabilitation programs for all 20,000 state prisoners and several mental health programs, close 1,000 beds in substance abuse programs, shut four state parks, two state police barracks and two medical evacuation helicopter stations.
The state also eliminated subsistence grants and health benefits for 24,000 indigent and disabled people who are ineligible for Federal welfare programs.
Things are expected to worsen in Maryland before they improve.
"Fiscal 1993, which starts next July, looks like another $600 million to $800 million deficit," said Frederick W. Puddester, deputy secretary of the State Departent of Budget and Fiscal Planning. "We're looking at more cuts and layoffs."
 
Medicaid a Big Factor
 The most serious problem in Maryland, as in other states, is the skyrocketing cost of health care in the Medicaid program for the poor.
"In the last two years, we've seen a double-digit increases in health costs and a 25 percent increase in enrollment, from 340,000 to 420,000 people." Mr. Puddester said.
The striking three-month decline in state and local government employment -- an 84,000-worker drop to 15,401,000 -- was still smaller than the 153,000 decline in state and local employment in the single month of July 1982, the start of the fiscal year after the last recession. Some experts expect the current decline to be just as steep, but take place over a longer period.
At the state level, the decline in employment was steepest in July, when the work force shrank by 21,000 workers. It declined another 6,000 in both August and September.
According to the new Bureau of Labor Statistics figures, local governments are laying off workers even faster that state governments, with the decline in local employment doubling in each of the last three months. The number of local government workers dropped by 7,000 in July, 15,000 in August, and 29,000 in September.
New York City, which has about 240,000 workers, has laid off 3,000 employees since July and may lay off up to 3,000 more, depending on union negotiations. Nassau County officials are also preparing to lay off up to 2,000 employees after labor negotiations collapsed two weeks ago.
 
Public Safety Hurt
 Cities in Massachusetts, for the third year in a row, laid off thousands of workers, including 2,500 teachers and 365 firefighters.
"We can't comfortably provide public safety at the levels of firefighters we have now," said Robert B. McCarthy, president of the Professional Firefighters of Massachusetts, a union.
Many small municipalities, he said, are making do by relying on mutual aid agreements with their neighbors.
Stephen K. Wollmer, a spokesman for the Massachusets Teachers Association, the union for the state's 68,000 teachers, said that as a result of the cuts "class size in virutally every district is mushrooming, and in some cities and towns, it is not unusual to have class sizes over 40."
Part-time government workers are especially vulnerable. The National League of Cities reports that full-time employment in large cities was stable over all last year, but that these cities reduced part-time employment by 15.2 percent. Federal employment, amounting to nearly 3 million workers, actually increased by 10,000 in the last three months, recovering some of its losses earlier in the year.
 
Decline in Tax Income
 Budget officials in 19 states, surveyed by the budget officers' association in August, said they were planning or considering layoffs this year. Since the survey, sales and income tax revenue has declined below projections in as many as half the states, the association estimated. The association expects the number of layoffs nationwide to increase sharply later this year and next as states come to grips with revenue estimates that are turning out to be overly optimistic.
Midyear tax increases are also likely in some states, according to the association. But tax increases are less of an option for most states, since they already raised taxes this year by at least $15 billion.
"States are likely to have a succession of difficult budget years," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at RockefellerInstitute. "There will be more layoffs, and I think public employment will have slower growth in the 1990's than at any time in the whole post-war period."

HEADLINE: Singapore Journal;
Back to Somerset Maugham and Life's Seamy Side

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
Discovering too late that much of its colonial history was being smothered beneath antiseptic towers of steel and tinted glass, Singapore is trying to restore what remains of its past, both the dignity and the debauchery.
The dignity is embodied in Raffles, the big wedding cake of a hotel once described as having stood "for all the fables of the Exotic East." Raffles reopened in September after a $90 million, two-year renovation intended to return the hotel to the tropical glory that attracted the likes of Somerset Maugham and Rudyard Kipling. 
 The debauchery is Bugis Street, which was once the Singaporean equivalent of Bourbon Street in New Orleans or Place Pigalle in Paris and which was largely bulldozed over in the early 1980's to make way for a new subway station.
The transvestites of Bugis Street have been quietly told that they can soon return to what had for decades been their dusk-to-dawn home. Bugis Street (pronounced BOO-gees) is being recreated.
"Darling, it's going to be show time again in Singapore," said a 34-year-old transvestite and former denizen of Bugis Street who goes by the "stage name" of Tammy Tan.
 
Losing Touch With the Past
 The restoration of Raffles and Bugis Street is the result of a larger realization among Singaporeans that, in turning a fetid, malarial port into one of the most modern, ruthlessly well-scrubbed nations on earth, Singapore was losing touch with its past.
A place that still conjures up images of opium dens, bawdyhouses and brawling, peg-legged pirates, Singapore is now better known among its Southeast Asian neighbors for Japanese-style efficiency and for hygienic standards second to none. In Singapore, you can drink the water.
In recent years, historic neighborhoods of ramshackle row houses and small shops have fallen to the wrecker's ball to make way for the futuristic office towers that now dominate the city-state's skyline.
The economic miracle of modern Singapore is the vision of the nation's first and, until last year, only Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, whose leadership involved a strong element of puritanism. It took his successor, Goh Chok Tong, to lift a national ban on jukeboxes and R-rated movies.
But this nation's 2.7 million residents are nothing if not astute business men and women, and it has occurred to many here that Singapore's sterile, oblivious-to-its-history reputation, deserved or not, could be scaring the tourists away.
Among visitors to Singapore, Japanese are the biggest spenders, and a 1989 survey found that while 47 percent of Japanese tourists were attracted to Singapore for its lush greenery and its cleanliness, only one percent said they were brought here principally by the opportunity for sightseeing.
"Singapore has a lot to offer, but I think it's true that we don't have much of what would collectively be known as historic sightseeing areas," said Jennie Chua, the general manager of Raffles. The resurrected Raffles, she said, will serve two purposes: luxury hotel and premiere tourist attraction.
Opened in 1887 and named for the colony's founder, Sir Stamford Raffles, the hotel early on developed a reputation as the home away from home for men of letters. Its guest list has included Kipling, who advised travelers to "feed at Raffles when visiting Singapore," and Maugham, who paid his first visit to Raffles in 1921 and who was said to sit beneath a fragrant frangipani tree in the hotel's Palm Court and craft short stories from tidbits of gossip overheard while supping among Singapore's gentry.
The hotel is woven into Singapore's history. In 1942, on the eve of the Japanese invasion, British colonialists made their "last stand" at Raffles, gathering to sing "There'll Always be an England."
Yet unlike the other Grand Dame hostelries of Southeast Asia, Raffles was allowed to deteriorate, a victim of Singapore's worship of the new, and by the late 1980's there were reports that the hotel, faded and a bit dowdy and therefore very un-Singaporean, was preparing to close for good.
The rescue began in 1987, when Raffles was designated a national landmark. It closed two years later for a complete rehabilitation.
The conversion has turned Raffles into a palatial all-suites hotel; each of the 104 suites is now complete with teakwood floors, 14-foot ceilings, overhead fan and handmade carpets. It will be the most expensive hotel in Singapore, with prices beginning at $350 a night.
The famed Long Bar -- where in 1903 the bartender Ngian Tong Boon created the Singapore Sling, a slow-acting concoction of gin, cherry brandy, lemon juice and soda -- has been moved to what will be a shopping-and-dining complex adjoining the hotel.
 
'A Partying Place'
 Only a few blocks north of Raffles, the rehabilitation of Bugis Street is intended to appeal to those searching for something very different -- a taste of the island's raucous, disreputable past.
Bugis Street may have had its heyday during the Vietnam War, when sailors descended by the boatful on the its open-air restaurants and hawker stalls to drink and carouse. Bugis Street accommodated them, remaining open 24 hours a day.
In a second-floor office on the recreated Bugis Street, Ronnie Chia, the developer who is overseeing the restoration, displays photographs of the street carnival that was the old Bugis Street.
"It's going to be a fun place, a partying place," Mr. Chia said of the new Bugis Street, which, like the old, will feature buildings with old terra cotta-tiled roofs and Venetian windows. "We want to create the original flavor of Bugis Street," he said. "Good food, 24 hours of fun."
"I have no objections about these ladies coming back, so long as they don't get in trouble with the law," Mr. Chia said of the Bugis Street transvestites. "This is Singapore. They will have to behave themselves."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Restores Africa Trip But With Revised Financing

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Stung by the collapse of his ambitious plans for taking a chartered airplane to South Africa with a large delegation of city officials and business executives, Mayor David N. Dinkins now plans a scaled-down trip on commercial flights, with many members of his entourage paying their own way.
The Mayor postponed the trip last month because, he said, a top aide was too busy working to calm the racial violence in Crown Heights to raise the necessary $500,000 in private funds for the flight for him and several dozen officials, aides and friends. The fund-raising effort had drawn questions from some civic groups. 
 It is not yet clear how many people will go, but the overall cost appears likely to be less than half that for the earlier plan.
 
Tentatively Rescheduled
 The trip has been tentatively rescheduled for Nov. 10 to 17, the aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, said yesterday. Privately raised money will still pay the way for Mr. Dinkins, his wife Joyce, Mr. Lynch and their support staff of press aides and advance team. But others, including the half-dozen city commissioners who had been invited, will be asked to pay their own $4,500 transportation and hotel costs -- about $1,500 less per person than the charter air fare and ground transport alone were to have cost, officials said.
Mr. Dinkins had focused much attention on the trip, planning to take about three dozen people, not including his immediate aides, and the effort grew unwieldy amid the city's other problems. Its sudden collapse embarrassed him and it echoed other organizational failures that have plagued his administration.
But his aides said the Mayor believed his goals for the trip -- to lend support to the African National Congress and forge cultural and economic ties between New York and any post-apartheid regime -- were badly misunderstood and unfairly criticized. Tomorrow, he is to address the City Club of New York in an effort to explain his rationale and build support for the trip.
Asked why the trip had been switched to commercial flights and the itinerary scaled down, Mr. Lynch said, "Cost, lower cost." He and Mr. Dinkins had said all along that they planned a charter flight to save time and that the large delegation was intended to make the trip more than a ceremonial visit. The Mayor had repeatedly said that he and a handful of aides could have simply made the trip but that he had higher aspirations for it than that.
Yesterday, several city officials, including Douglas H. White, the city's Personnel Director; H. Carl McCall, the president of the Board of Education, and Dr. Margaret Hamburg, the acting Health Commissioner, said they still planned to go.
"He still intends to go," said a spokesman for Mr. White, Denise Collins. "He very much wants to. He understands that he has to pay his own way."
Spokesmen for some others, including the Human Resources Administrator, Barbara J. Sabol, and the head of the Housing Authority, Laura Blackburne, said they did not yet know their bosses' plans.
The city, as it always does on mayoral trips, will pay the way for the Mayor's police bodyguards, though it will not say how many are going, citing security.
 
Money Still Being Raised
 Mr. Lynch said money for the trip was still being raised by the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, a city-controlled nonprofit group that has raised money for other events, including the ticker-tape parade for veterans of the Persian Gulf war. He said the names of the contributors would be made public eventually, but so far the administration has not released them.
After the last trip was postponed, Mr. Lynch said he would establish a citizens committee to raise funds for the trip to avoid any conflicts of interest in having him, the Mayor's chief political aide, solicit contributions from corporations and individuals. He said yesterday that the committee did not have a formal head but that some people, including Lee Dunham, head of the Harlem McDonald's Group, had been working informally to raise money.
Mr. Lynch said Mr. Dunham and other business people going on the trip had always been scheduled to pay their own way, and would now.
Under the earlier plan, the charter plane would have cost a fixed price, no matter how many people went, though the per-person cost would have been lower if more people went. Now the cost will be directly tied to the size of the party.
 
No Stop in Lagos
 The current plan would abandon a stop in Lagos, Nigeria, but still calls for a stopover in Rome in hopes of gaining a papal audience on the way to Africa.
In South Africa, the group would meet with government and opposition political figures and labor and church leaders in Johannesburg and Cape Town, and the black township of Soweto. But a planned visit to the city of Durban will probably be scrapped, Mr. Lynch said.
Mr. Lynch said City Hall was surprised that the prior plans and the postponement had caused such a stir.
"We were confused by why it caused that reaction," he said. "I thought we had laid out clearly why we were going and why it was important from an economic development standpoint. It was not just taking an entourage."

HEADLINE: The Search for Romance In the Shadow of AIDS

 BODY:
Last spring, George K., a 43-year-old family therapist from Brooklyn, placed a personal ad, describing himself as heterosexual, white, professional, spiritual, healthy and infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS.
"If you love warm sandy beaches, pure white snow and fireplaces, let's connect," the ad read. 
 A 34-year-old woman from Connecticut, also infected with the virus, was one of six to respond. "I view HIV as a challenge, and not as the end of my life," she wrote.
They met in April, and plan to be married next year.
 
The Need for Love
 George and his fiancee have found romance in the age of AIDS. They are among the one million Americans, gay and heterosexual, estimated to carry the deadly virus usually transmitted by sex. They live surrounded by fear and stigma, but life, with the need for love, goes on -- goes on longer than ever, as early testing becomes more widespread and treatment improves.
And as they learn to live with the virus, many of the infected are striving for companionship, sexual intimacy and even marriage.
Still, many people suffer rejection, struggle in vain to keep marriages together or withdraw into the loneliness more commonly experienced in old age or widowhood, say psychotherapists and organizers of support groups for people infected with HIV. Yet there are relationships that survive, couples that become closer and people who fall in love, sometimes with uninfected partners.
"Many people are very concerned about not ever wanting to transmit this to anyone else," said Alison M. Deming, a psychotherapist in Syracuse who works with an HIV-positive support group. "Yet the need for a relationship and someone to care about is so important. It's basic."
 
Telling, or Not
 A key question for HIV-positive people -- most of whom are between the ages of 25 and 44 -- is when and how to disclose their infection to someone in whom they are romantically interested. For some the decision is even harder, because they are also forced to disclose intravenous drug use or bisexuality.
Some say they tell straightaway. But others say that as long as they keep the risk of transmission to a minimum -- by using condoms and avoiding any exchange of blood or semen, as health experts advise -- they think that they pose little threat and feel they can withhold the information.
There are HIV-positive people who engage in sex without revealing their infection or taking precautions. Four states have passed laws that make failure to inform a sexual partner of HIV-infection before sex a crime, and 15 others have made it a crime to knowingly expose a partner to the virus.
But experts say that most people with the virus feel compelled to tell, or at least to practice preventive measures. George K.'s fiancee said she previously had a simple rule -- she would keep quiet unless there was the possibility of a long-term relationship. (Most HIV-positive people interviewed for this article either declined to be identified or allowed only a partial identification, out of concerns for their privacy, their insurance or their jobs.)
"I felt no HIV-negative man would want to sleep with me if he knew," said the woman, a physical therapist who tested positive in 1989. "My feeling was that if I was going to practice safe sex, why should I put myself on the line while there are people who do not know they are infected and are not practicing safe sex?"
Don A., a 43-year-old New York City school teacher who is gay and who tested positive five years ago, said he does not tell the men he has sex with about his infection until after their third date, although he always takes precautions.
By then, he said, he trusts the person and feels he should tell; before then, his infection is nobody's business.
"In this day and age you have to assume that everybody is positive," he said. "If you feel a condom could break, then you shouldn't be putting yourself at risk."
 
'I Wonder If It Will Make You Scared'
 But waiting until a bond has been established does not make telling any easier. Steven G., a 25-year-old gay man from Brooklyn, said it took him eight months to inform his uninfected companion of his HIV infection because he feared losing him and because "I just didn't know how to tell him." He told him in a letter.
"I keep wondering how you will take this," he wrote. "I wonder if you will be angry, disappointed or what. I wonder if it will make you scared of me."
But it did not. The two remain together, and the boyfriend still tests HIV-negative, nearly four years later.
The boyfriend, Mark A., a 29-year-old communications coordinator for an AIDS service organization, said it never occurred to him to leave. He was in love, he said, and "I don't feel I'd be any safer without Steven.
"For a gay man, there's no escaping," he said. "You either protect yourself or you're going to get it."
For Steven, an account executive for a marketing consulting firm, telling Mark was as difficult as coming out of the closet had been -- and as cathartic. Afterwards, he said, he was willing to consult a doctor and start on antiviral drugs for the first time.
But not all couples cope as well. Gail B., a 28-year-old Camden, N.J., resident, and her husband took the HIV blood test after applying for life insurance. Last year, only weeks after their first wedding anniversary, they learned that he was negative and she was positive.
"My husband has really backed away," said Gail B., who traces her infection to a previous relationship with a drug user. "Every time I don't feel well, he withdraws from me. Once he said he thinks he might be afraid to get close to me because he doesn't know how long I'll be around."
But even couples that have adjusted well and enjoy satisfying relationships are troubled by other issues. Many fear becoming a financial and emotional burden. Those who are parents ponder their children's future in their absence. Sometimes the child is also infected. Often, a couple keeps the infection a secret from family and friends, which can leave them feeling isolated.
Many people with the virus find it easier to be with someone who is also HIV-infected. Many AIDS organizations arrange social gatherings for HIV-positive people to meet, and workshops on dating and sex.
 
'We Live Now. We Don't Wait.'
 George K., who found his fiancee in the personal ads of The Body Positive, a magazine for people with the virus published by a group of the same name, said the couple share both fears and a desire to enjoy each day. A former intravenous drug user, he learned of his infection in 1988.
"We live now. We don't wait," he said. "The new car next year is not as important as what we can do now."
The only disadvantage in their relationship, they said, is a temptation not to practice protected sex since both are HIV-positive, despite the possibility that they could reinfect each other with different strains of the virus and further weaken their immune systems.
"For us," his fiancee said, "part of it is denial and that we can pretend for a short time that we're like regular people."
But sharing the virus is no guarantee of a better relationship. Debra Chabrier, 35, of the South Bronx, said she and her husband, both former intravenous drug users, went in different directions after both tested positive six years ago. She overcame her heroin addiction, had a son three years ago despite the urgings of doctors and relatives and now goes to school. The boy, Isaac, is free from HIV.
Her husband, who used to work as a security guard, now is unemployed, stays home and recently began using crack.
But she stays with him, she said, because she feels sorry for him, out of gratitude for the care he gives when she is sick and out of fear of being alone. They are no longer lovers. "He sleeps. He doesn't go anywhere. He has no friends," she said. "He watches cartoons all day and night. He says that's his therapy."
Many HIV-infected people choose celibacy. Victoria Gonzalez, a 42-year-old grandmother who tested positive for the virus last December, a month after her husband died of AIDS, said she will not go out with men, mostly because she feels "marked."
"When you say, 'I'm HIV-positive,' you're saying 'I'm a walking infection,' " she said. "I don't want to share this with anybody."
Marcie L., a 22-year-old business student in Manhattan, broke off her engagement and ruled out any future love relationship when she learned three years ago from a routine blood donation that she was infected.
She said she does not want to deal with the risk of passing on the virus, even with safeguards like condoms.
"It's frustrating sometimes," she said of her decision to give up the idea of marriage or a family. "I didn't care much about life until I realized life is so limited. It hurts."
Still, she dates, just for fun, she said. But when a man gets too interested, she lies and tells him she is seeing someone else.
Lee G., a 41-year-old health professional in Manhattan, said she made one attempt at dating after she found out she had the virus in 1989. But she said that after several outings, her date kept pressing her to go to bed.
When he hinted that there could be something wrong with her, she told him she was HIV-positive. "He cried," she said. "He said, 'I'm sorry I asked you.' "
The two stayed friends.
Although the need for companionship is central, some HIV-positive people say that a love relationship also gives them a sense of security.
Steven G. said he feels under extreme pressure to make his relationship work. "I feel it's my last long-term relationship," he said, but also because he cannot afford to lose his boyfriend.
"If I get sick, he'd take care of me," he said. "It's a very selfish thing to feel but knowing that he's negative is a big safety net for me."
George K. does not count on his HIV-positive fiancee to see him through his illness. Her own health might falter first, he said, or she might not be able to handle the stress.
All he wants, he said, is to enjoy a rewarding relationship, even in the shadow of AIDS. "It's all attitude," he said. "You have to be thankful for what you have.
"I have a career. I have health. I have a wonderful woman in my life.
"I'm alive."
