HEADLINE: Cuomo Details His Medicaid Plan, And Reviews Are Less Than Raves

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today filled in the framework of his plan to overhaul the state's Medicaid system with cold numbers that were ridiculed by Republican legislators, rejected by hospital officials and viewed warily at City Hall in New York.
Two weeks ago Mr. Cuomo proposed that the state assume by the end of the century the full share of Medicaid costs paid by local governments, now totaling $2.8 billion. In exchange, localities would give up a share of their taxing authority to the state. 
 Today, detailing his plan publicly for the first time, Mr. Cuomo revealed that New York City would be asked to give the state all of its personal income tax revenue by the year 2000 if the state is to assume Medicaid costs now paid by the city.
 
For Suburbs, Sales Taxes
 Under the plan, counties outside the city would sacrifice the revenues generated by up to 1 percentage point of their sales taxes. State law allows counties to levy local sales taxes of up to 4 1/4 percent.
Although Mr. Cuomo has proposed that the city sacrifice all of its personal income tax revenues, he said today that the city would still reap a windfall from the takeover, an amount that would grow to $1.2 billion by the city's 1999-2000 fiscal year, he said.
But city officials were wary, saying they would have to study the economic underpinnings of the Governor's proposal to be sure that the city would not lose more than it gains.
"One of the things that needs to be reviewed carefully is what happens if the personal income tax grows more quickly than Medicaid," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who called the plan "a point of departure."
But state officials said guarantees would be written into the plan to insure that the city and other local governments could not lose money.
Mr. Cuomo also revealed that his plan is based on assumptions that local tax collections would grow by an average of 5 percent a year and that Medicaid costs would grow by 12 to 13 percent a year through the end of the century. That led the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., to call the plan "a house of cards built on overly optimistic forecasts."
The Senate Republicans, who have their political base upstate and on Long Island, have expressed reservations about the plan because of a perception that their counties would benefit far less than New York City, which has most of the state's Medicaid recipients.
State officials say the plan released today would produce net savings of $1.6 billion for all local governments, including $1 billion for New York City, in the state's 1999-2000 fiscal year. But the city would receive only a fraction of that amount in the immediate next three years. That has prompted city officials to complain that the plan does not do enough to help them avoid large deficits in the next three years.
"If you're going to say this is a 20th century idea, why wait until the 21st century to see it fully implemented?" an aide to Mayor David N. Dinkins said today.
 
Immediate Gains Projected
 City officials have projected budget shortfalls of at least $1.5 billion in each of the next three years. The city budget this year is $28.5 billion. Mr. Cuomo's plan projects that the city would see a net gain of $78 million in the city's 1992-93 fiscal year, $169 million in 1993-94 and $273 million in 1994-95.
By the city's 1999-2000 fiscal year, which differs from the state's, the city would save $1.2 billion, the plan projects. The savings would result from the city's giving up $5.3 billion in Medicaid costs while giving up only $4.1 billion in income tax revenues.
What remained unclear today was how Mr. Cuomo would bring the cost of the $12 billion Medicaid program down to a more manageable level. He and his aides have said that cost containment would be the fiscal and political key to enacting the Medicaid proposal. The Republicans, who control the State Senate, have said that they would not consider the plan unless serious efforts were made to reduce costs.
"It's the price of admission," said Patrick J. Bulgaro, the state budget director.
 
Sharing Burdens
 Under Mr. Cuomo's plan, local governments would save $150 million from cost containment in the state's 1993-94 fiscal year. But the plan did not specify how the savings would be produced. His aides said only that the Governor would take "a balanced approach" by trying to place equivalent burdens on both Medicaid recipients and health care providers when proposing next year's budget.
But the fact that the proposal relies so heavily in its early years on cost containment has already generated opposition from hospital officials.
Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said yesterday, "We're not on board on the takeover at this point because the takeover looks like nothing more than a cost-shifting to the already financially strapped hospital community and its patients."

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
The King Has No Time for Bush

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton

 BODY:
President Bush, or anyone else, ought not be upset with Michael Jordan for failing to attend a White House reception last week with the Chicago Bulls. Why should Jordan have traveled all the way to Washington so the President could enjoy such a rare and important photo opportunity?
It seems only fair that Bush visit Michael, a busy man with domestic and global responsibilities, at Michael's house. 
 As a habit, Jordan does not favor political alignments, but it is unlikely that he would refuse to open his home to the President, especially if Bush contacted Jordan's agent, David Falk of ProServ, to make an appointment. (White House staff should be aware that Jordan is currently engaged in rigorous two-a-day practices with the Bulls and prefers a relaxing round of golf during the middle of the day.)
It's not as if the President is dying in the polls, but an election year is coming, the economy remains weak, the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court can't be helping, and who in this country currently has a higher approval rating than Michael Jordan?
Following his and the Bulls' ascension to the National Basketball Association championship last spring, Jordan has made the final leap from adroitly marketed basketball phenomenon to indisputable American icon. He's everywhere -- cereal boxes, fast-food joints, soft-drink bottles, basketball shoes, in the hearts and minds of millions -- except the White House. Maybe some day he'll run.
NBC, realizing the consumer-friendly benefits of Jordan on the air, has recently become the Michael Jordan Channel. First there was a prime-time tribute to Jordan, with the comedian Billy Crystal as host. Then there was the hourlong show to announce the 1992 U.S. of N.B.A. Olympic team, climaxing with a live studio presentation of Jordan as the primary defender of that American birthright, the basketball gold medal. Next came a week's work as the host of "Saturday Night Live."
Between television gigs, Jordan slipped down to his home state, North Carolina, to have a stretch of highway named after him. Which will be the first American city to take the next obvious step and rename the airport?
One day last summer, sitting in his Roslyn, Va., office, Falk revealed that organizers of the Emmy Awards were after Jordan to appear on their show. "I'd love for him to do it," Falk said. "But I know what he's going to say when I bring it up to him. That's another day gone, when he'd rather be with his family or out on the golf course. I don't even know if I'm going to mention it to him.
"You wouldn't believe all the requests that Michael gets. He gets asked to do so many charitable and community activities, more than one a day. If he did them it would be a full-time job. Beyond basketball and the community, he has his business obligations, and like all normal human beings, he wants to have enough time for himself."
When Jordan opted not to appear at the White House with the Bulls, his decision created a controversy in Chicago as the Bulls opened their training camp. It was suggested in print and even by some of the Bulls, most notably Horace Grant, that Jordan should not be allowed to place himself above the team.
The Bulls' coach, Phil Jackson, was asked to comment, and looked amused. He was likely thinking: Where does everyone think Jordan has been all these years?
Larry Bird and Magic Johnson carried the N.B.A. out of its sickbed in the early 1980's and taught it to walk, tall and proud. Jordan is helping it fly. Doing roughly $15 million annually in endorsements, he is Star Trek, the Next Generation, where no athlete has commercially gone before.
It apparently took stiffing the President for Chicago to notice that there are different rules for Michael Jordan, and have been since he took that city by storm in 1984. Jordan is no saint. He probably kept Isiah Thomas off the Olympic team. He has been manipulative within the Bulls' organization relating to personnel, just as the much-maligned Thomas has been in Detroit. He has hardly used his power to address prevalent black issues. But here, finally, is a black American athlete so successful in the art of overcoming racial stereotypes and marketing to mythical proportions that he can get away with telling the White House, sorry, he's busy.
Maybe next year.

HEADLINE: Hilton Net Drops 14.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 10

 BODY:
The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its third-quarter net income fell 14.2 percent from the third quarter of 1990, when the company reported a large gain from a property sale.
Despite problems in the hotel division, Hilton's operating income rose 18 percent during the July-September quarter, reflecting better results from Nevada gambling operations. 
 The hotel and casino operator earned $18.8 million, or 39 cents a share, in the latest quarter. That compared with $21.9 million, or 45 cents a share, a year ago. The earlier figure included $6.5 million, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of a half-interest in the Hotel Conrad Hong Kong.
Revenue rose 5.5 percent in the quarter, from $260.1 million to $275.1 million.
"All of our Nevada gaming properties recorded improvements in operating income from a difficult third quarter last year," Barron Hilton, the company's chairman and president, said in a statement.
"However, the soft U.S. economy, and generally overbuilt conditions in many markets, continue to adversely affect our hotel division."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bowater Buys Great Northern

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that it was selling 80 percent of its Great Northern Paper Inc. operation to Bowater Inc. for $300 million in cash.
The Great Northern acquisition will increase the mill capacity of Bowater, based in Darien, Conn., by about 40 percent and more than double its timberland holdings. 
 The major bond ratings agencies expressed concern that the deal might increase Bowater's financial risk. The company's senior debt and preferred stock, currently rated A, were placed on creditwatch yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, with negative implications. Moody's Investors Service Inc. also mentioned a possible downgrade.
The sale reduces Georgia- Pacific's holdings in Maine just 18 months after its merger with Great Northern Nekoosa Inc., the largest merger ever in the forest products industry.
Bowater will manage Great Northern Paper and will have the option to purchase the rest of the company from Georgia- Pacific after June 30 for another $22 million.
Bowater will acquire Georgia-Pacific's mills in Millinocket and East Millinocket, Me.; hydroelectric assets that power the mills; an Ashland, Me., lumber company and about 2.1 million acres of timberland.
Georgia-Pacific, a $13 billion forest products company, has been hurt by the recession and the subsequent housing downturn.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Higher on Concern Over Yeltsin's Whereabouts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher in volatile trading yesterday as a result of rumors that the Russian President was missing.
Gold prices declined after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped 70 cents to settle at $358.80. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid price of $358.30, off 70 cents an ounce from Wednesday. 
 The dollar opened lower in domestic trading but soon reversed course when rumors hit the market that the Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, was missing. He was vacationing on the Black Sea.
The rumor "created a flight-to-quality buying of dollars," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank P.L.C. The dollar is considered a safe haven in times of world turmoil.
A second bout of dollar-buying was prompted when President Yeltsin's deputy was reportedly unable to reach him. Reports of Mr. Yeltsin's disappearance were denied, but not before the dollar had broken through key technical levels.
"There was no hard economic data to trade off of," Mr. Hatcher was, explaining why the rumors had such a strong impact on trading.
Today, the Government is scheduled to release producer prices and retail sales reports for September. While many expect the data to reflect controlled inflation and a sluggish economy. Mr. Hatcher said the market had probably already taken that into account and the reports may have little influence on trading if they come in as expected.
Japanese markets were closed for the Sports Day holiday. In European trading, the dollar slipped to 130.30 yen, from 130.40 yen in Tokyo on Wednesday. In New York the dollar settled at 130.35 yen, up from 129.80 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7150, compared with $1.7175 on Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.7145 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7195.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6960 German marks, up from 1.6890; 1.4845 Swiss francs, up from 1.4785; 5.7780 French francs, up from 5.7515; 1,268.25 Italian lire, up from 1,262.25, and 1.1293 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1308.

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs 30.19; Program Trading Cited

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose strongly yesterday, despite growing investor concern about the prospect of lower corporate earnings. After a lackluster morning and early afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average surged to close at 2,976.52, up 30.19 points.
Analysts said the increase was largely a result of program trading. Indeed, Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said computer-driven trading accounted for about 87 percent of the Dow's ascent. 
 The Dow slipped below its opening level twice yesterday before turning upward. Birinyi Associates said that there were three buy programs in the afternoon, with the most significant occuring at 3:43 P.M., and continuing until the end of trading. Program trading accounted for about an hour of trading, nearly twice the average of recent months, Birinyi said.
The Nasdaq composite index was up 2.13 points, to 515.94. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose less than one-tenth of 1 percent, to 368.59. The Standard & Poor's 500 stocks were up 3.75 points, to 380.55. And the New York Stock Exchange index was up 1.60 points, to 209.55.
"Even though the Dow rose, there are still some concerns about corporate earnings," said Edward J. Shopkorn, managing director of institutional equities with the Mabon Securities Corporation. "And people are waiting to see what the Federal Reserve will do about interest rates. So it seems that today's action doesn't mean anything." He added that the market could well fall further.
 
Big Movers on the Dow
 Two big movers on the Dow yesterday were I.B.M. and J.P. Morgan, which were each up 2 3/8. I.B.M. rose to 99 3/4. J. P. Morgan rose to 63 3/8 after the company reported better-than-expected earnings. Also, General Electric was up 1 7/8, to 67 1/4. Minnesota Mining rose 1 3/4, to 90 5/8. Procter & Gamble rose 1 3/8, to 83 1/4. Those five stocks accounted for 57 percent of the Dow's movement.
The Dow Transport stocks showed particular strength, rising 23.54 points, to 1,206.46, a gain of nearly 2 percent. Setting the pace for thatgain was American President, an operator of container ships. The company's stock was up 4, to 39 1/2. American President earnings were up sharply and the company's chairman said that the upward trend will continue into next year because of improving conditions in the shipping industry.
On the New York Stock Exchange, the most active issue yesterday was the Limited, which was down 1 3/8, to 21 3/4. Analysts said that the stock fell because of retailers posting weak sales in September.
On a percentage basis, the biggest gainer on the big board yesterday was General Datacomm, a maker of data communications networking equipment. The company's stock rose 3/8, to 3, a gain of 14.3 percent.
In over-the-counter trading, the most active issue was Scitex, an imaging and computer graphics company. The company's shares were down 2, to 34 1/2, with 5.3 million shares changing hands. The Israel-based company's shares slipped because of new shares being on the market stemming from a secondary offering, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Seven Troubled Banks Shut in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday closed a group of seven New Hamphire banks owned by five diffferent banking companies, and said the banks would open today under new ownership.
The failed banks, which account for about a quarter of the New Hampshire market, were closed and sold as a group rather than individually, to limit disruption of the local economy, L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C. said. Officials at the agency have said they may consider similar treatment of other clusters of weak banks. 
 Deposits of all the banks continue to be insured by the F.D.I.C. for up to $100,000 for each account, and all customer accounts will be transferred to the new owners. While the five banking companies had total assets of about $5.2 billion, the F.D.I.C. estimated the cost to the Government of the failures at $966 million. The unusually large loss, compared with the size of the banks, is an indication of the severity of the banks' problems with bad real estate loans.
 
4 Go to First NH Bank
 A group of four commercial banks with total deposits of $1.8 billion -- BankEast of Manchester, Amoskeag Bank of Manchester, Bank Meridian of Hampton and the Nashua Trust Company -- will reopen as branches of the First NH Banks Inc. of Manchester, a subsidiary of the Bank of Ireland, with $1.3 billion in deposits. Nashua Trust, Bank Meridian and Amoskeag were all part of Amoskeag Bank Shares Inc., once the largest banking company in the state.
First NH, which the Irish bank acquired in late 1988 for $370 million, is the state's largest banking company, with $3 billion in assets and 57 branches in all 10 counties of the state. Since the purchase, losses at First NH have caused the Irish bank to inject an additional $145 million in capital to keep the bank strong enough to make acquisitions.
 
3 to New Dartmouth Bank
 A group of three savings banks with total deposits of $2.2 billion -- the New Hamphsire Savings Bank of Concord, Dartmouth Bank of Hooksett and Numerica Savings Bank of Manchester -- will open as branches of the New Dartmouth Bank of Manchester, a newly created bank owned by a group of private investors.
The investor group, which was assembled by Kidder, Peabody & Company, is led by William F. Craig, a former vice chairman of the Shawmut Bank, Boston, and Robert P. Keller, the chief operating officer of Dartmouth Bank.

HEADLINE: Corporate Economists Urge Further Easing by the Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 10

 BODY:
A panel of economists from a score of the nation's biggest corporations recommended today that the Federal Reserve cut interest rates further to keep the recovery from stalling.
"Some further reduction in interest rates would be a prudent policy step to help assure that adequate growth does in fact occur," the economists said. "Preventive action now is preferable to waiting until new weakness becomes apparent." 
 The Business Council's prediction of a 2.4 percent rate of growth in the gross national product for the quarter ended Sept. 30 and of a 2.5 to 3 percent growth rate through the end of 1992 differed little from the forecast it made in May at the earlier of its semiannual meetings at the Homestead Resort in southwest Virginia.
But the undertone of the report and the forceful recommendation for an additional easing of monetary policy reflected less confidence that the recovery can be sustained.
The group, which met on Oct. 1 to assemble the latest forecast, said the prediction was subject to "considerable downside risk" from sources like interest rates, job losses, stress in the financial system and an actual decline in the aggregate net worth of consumers, which fell in 1990 for the first time since 1962.
A separate panel of top corporate executives who constitute the membership of the Business Council was generally even less optimistic than the economists, with at least two of them urging a big easing by the Fed.
"We're in a very, very slow growth situation," said James D. Robinson 3d, chairman, chief executive and president of American Express. "We think a bold step should be taken." When asked how much the Fed should ease rates, Mr. Robinson suggested a full percentage point from levels that are already among the lowest in at least a decade.
John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of General Electric, said the risks of bold action would be minimal because of the greatly diminished upper pressure on prices.
When asked about the possibility of a so-called double-dip recession, Mr. Welch said the question implied that the economy was already recovering. "We are not seeing any 'out' yet," he said, disagreeing with the consensus among economists -- as opposed to company executives -- that a recovery started in the spring.
John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, said he saw the economy exhibiting "limited signs of life," with consumers and lenders remaining cautious. He said 50 percent of credit card customers were now paying off balances monthly, well above the usual 30 percent.
With inflation "gone as an immediate issue," Mr. Reed added, there is "tons of room" for the Fed to further ease monetary policy.
And while John G. Smale, chairman of the executive committee of Procter & Gamble, said his company began to see some rebound in its business in May, the chairman and chief executive of another consumer products company, H. Brewster Atwater Jr. of General Mills, was far less optimistic.
"It is a slow and dragging recovery," with consumer spending down twice as much as disposable income, Mr. Atwater observed. "There is an opportunity for the Fed to loosen up a little further."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Selloff Continues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The selloff in the Treasury bond market continued yesterday, as inflation worries prompted speculators and retail accounts alike to sell long-term securities. Traders feared that the economic recovery sought by the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve Board may push up inflation.
The rise in bond yields, which continued to move toward 8 percent, came on a day when the nation's leading retail chains reported that sales were weak in September. 
 "The fundamentals for the economy are not any different, but expectations about the future are different," one government bond trader said.
"People are somewhat concerned that the Administration and the Fed will do almost anything to get us out of recession. That concern has created uncertainty about whether or not the Fed is abandoning efforts to contain inflation."
Concern about reports scheduled to be released today, including producer price numbers and retail sales for September, may have also touched off some selling, analysts said.
And comments by Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, may have heightened the notion that the recovery is gathering steam.
Mr. Parry told a conference at California State University yesterday that the economy emerged from recession in the third quarter. He added that a number of current factors, including recent declines in interest rates and growth in industrial output, should help sustain the momentum in months ahead. Mr. Parry spoke before the Fed issued its weekly report on money growth.
Sluggish growth in the monetary aggregates, especially M-2, the money measure the Fed tracks most closely, has been a source of mounting concern at the central bank. The figures released yesterday did little to allay those worries.
The Fed reported that the two largest monetary aggregates, M-2 and M-3, posted big declines in the week ended Sept. 30. The narrowest measure, M-1, rose by $4.6 billion.
The $3.2 billion decline in M-2 pushed growth in that aggregate down to 2.2 percent, from the fourth quarter of 1990. That level is below the 2.5 percent rate that is the lower end of the Fed's target range for the year.
Moreover, the Fed announced that in the third quarter M-2 growth fell by three-tenths of 1 percent. It is the first quarterly decline in the aggregate since 1959, when the Fed began tracking M-2.
 
Treasury Prices Recovered
 Treasury prices recovered somewhat after the money numbers were released. Analysts said the weakness increases the chances that the Fed will ease monetary policy soon, especially if today's reports reflect a moribund economy accompanied by modest inflation.
The retail sales report "will either confirm or refute the pervasive anecdotal evidence that retailing is still in the tank," said David H. Restler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "If the numbers are weak, then I think the Fed will probably have to act."
The Fed prefers to have its easing moves follow a decline in market interest rates. As a consequence, the rise in bond yields this week cannot be viewed as a favorable development.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 29/32, down 17/32, to yield 7.95 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Wednesday. So far this week, yields on the benchmark issue have risen by nearly 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year securities were offered at 102 5/32, down 14/32, to yield 7.55 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes dipped by 2/32, to 100 10/32, to yield 5.95 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.00 percent, up one basis point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged on the day, at a late offered rate of 5.04 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.08 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the NCNB Corporation offered $300 million of 10-year subordinated notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 9 1/8 percent notes, which mature Oct. 15, 2001, were priced at $99.56, to yield 9.193 percent, 1.65 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues fell by about 1/8 point. Trading activity, which has been sluggish lately, picked up yesterday, market participants said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by about 1/8 point, according to traders.

HEADLINE: J. P. Morgan Posts Record Earnings

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday announced a record quarterly profit, largely as the result of increased earnings in a wide range of trading activities.
Among other banking companies to report earnings, the Bank of New York Company announced lower profits as it charged off a loss on more bad loans. But the company said its holdings of troubled loans fell for the second consecutive quarter. 
 The Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., reported slightly improved earnings.
At a time when profits at many banks have been weighed down by record-high loan losses and weak demand for new loans, Morgan has prospered by shunning the riskiest borrowers and building its trading businesses. Its low loan losses have helped Morgan maintain top-notch credit ratings, which in turn have helped its trading business by attracting corporate treasurers who prefer to arrange their currency and interest-rate swaps with the strongest banks.
 
Morgan
 In the three months ended Sept. 30, Morgan earned $373 million, or $1.89 a share, up 79.3 percent from $208 million, or $1.08 a share, a year earlier. Third-quarter profits were raised $32 million, or 17 cents a share, by a one-time gain from the early retirement of a bond issue.
Morgan's profits were better than some analysts expected, and helped the company's stock climb $2.50, to $63.375, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Moves by the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term interest rates also helped Morgan, as well as many other banks, analysts said. As rates have fallen, the difference between the interest rates banks pay for deposits and the rates they charge on loans has grown. At the same time, banks that trade securities have benefited from the lower cost of borrowing needed to finance their inventories, and in many cases from price gains in their securities holdings.
Norman Jaffe, a banking analyst at Fox-Pitt, Kelton Inc., a securities firm, said that Morgan's low loan losses were not typical among other large banks, which he expects will report higher-than-normal loan losses and continued increases in delinquent loans.
Analysts at Merrill Lynch & Company noted in a recent report that the increases in troubled loans this quarter will generally be smaller than previous quarters, except for some banks in the West. They said that bank profits would also be hurt by weak loan demand. Earnings for regional banks, they concluded, "are recovering, but ever so gradually."
 
Bank of New York
 At the Bank of New York, a sharp rise in losses from bad loans pushed its third-quarter profit down 16.9 percent, to $59 million, or 72 cents a share, from $71 million, or 90 cents a share, a year earlier.
The bank said it charged off $252 million in loan losses, up from $148 million a year earlier. At the same time, however, the bank said its holdings of nonperforming loans had fallen by $280 million since midyear to $1.57 billion. Much of the increase in charge-offs was the result of the sale of loans for commercial real estate projects and loans to highly indebted companies that had previously been listed as nonperfoming.
Analysts said the decline in nonperforming loans -- those that are badly delinquent or so troubled that the bank does not expect full payment -- helped raise Bank of New York stock $2.50, to $30.75, in Big Board trading yesterday.
Bank of New York also announced that it had decided not to sell its subsidiary BNY Financial because of the unit's strong performance and because the parent company's capital strength had improved without the sale.
BNY Financial, which specializes in making business loans secured by receivables, is the third-largest lender of its type, with about $800 million in assets and annual volume of over $6 billion.
 
Wachovia
 Among other regional banking companies, the Wachovia Corporation announced third-quarter profits of $80.6 million or $1.12 a share, up 6.9 percent from 75.4 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier.
Wachovia has long been one of the country's most profitable banking companies with a good record for avoiding bad loans. Its chairman, John Medlin, attributed the meager increase in profit to weak loan demand and increased loan losses caused by the weak economy.
Wachovia's shares fell 12.5 cents each yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $55.125.

HEADLINE: Potamkin, Cadillac Maven, Is Back

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Cadillac executives never questioned Victor Potamkin's ability to sell cars during his 15 years as a Cadillac dealer. But his flashy, low-price pitches to New Yorkers did not always square with the auto maker's high-style marketing approach.
Now, after Mr Potamkin sat it out for four years while Cadillac floundered with a more refined approach, Cadillac officials have decided that the 80-year-old Mr. Potamkin knows New Yorkers. Potamkin Cadillac-Buick-Chevrolet is scheduled to open Tuesday at the same stand where Mr. Potamkin sold Cadillacs from 1972 to 1987. 
 In each of those years, Mr. Potamkin said he was the national sales leader by far for Cadillac, averaging 6,000 cars a year. By comparison, today's top-selling Cadillac retailer averages about 1,600 cars a year.
"We missed him," said Peter R. Gerosa, Cadillac's general sales and service manager, who is confident that Mr. Potamkin will regain the title of national Cadillac sales champ. "I'm sure he's going to do it with Cadillac style, but maybe with a little Potamkin style thrown in. We want him to sell cars."
Mr. Potamkin's return comes not a moment too soon for beleaguered Cadillac, whose sales nationwide are off 20 percent from last year's level as of September, and have been in a slump for the last two years thanks to insurgent brands like Lexus and Infiniti. In Manhattan, Cadillac is eager to fill a troubling void because it has been without a dealer for its new cars since Roger Penske closed his dealership in May.
Mr. Penske, who runs a transportation conglomerate with interests that range from truck rentals to diesel engine-making to Indianapolis 500 racing, closed Penske Cadillac-Buick-Chevrolet after struggling for four years with dismal sales.
When Mr. Potamkin bowed out of the business, General Motors took the occasion to dress up the dealership and tried to sell cars with a more refined approach. The lighting was more subdued, Italian ceramic floors were installed and stainless steel cabinets were moved into the repair area. The idea was to offer New Yorkers white-glove treatment more in keeping with Cadillac's self-styled image.
 
Not As Many Ads
 Mr. Penske did not advertise as much as Mr. Potamkin, and he did not discount his cars as deeply. As a result, Mr. Potamkin, who watched the proceeding closely, doubts that Mr. Penske sold in a year what Mr. Potamkin moved every two months.
After Mr. Penske closed the dealership, Mr. Potamkin said he called General Motors this summer to suggest that he could get the dealership humming again. A sometimes critic of Cadillac's previous products like the ill-fated engine that ran alternatively on four, six and eight cylinders, Mr. Potamkin says he loves Cadillac's new offerings, especially the sporty Seville STS and Eldorado models which were dramatically redesigned for 1992.
"New York City is a General Motors town," he said, and the luxury car maker should have representation there.
Mr. Potamkin gave up the dealership in 1987 because he wanted to devote more time to raise money to fight Alzheimer's disease, which afflicts his wife, Luba. He said he would continue with his work to help fight the disease. He and his sons, Robert and Alan, will be the principal investors in the dealership, along with James Goldfein, a longtime Potamkin lieutenant, who will be the dealership's general manager. The Potamkins own about 50 dealerships in five states on the East Coast, including a Cadillac dealership in Atlanta. Sales in 1990 totaled nearly $800 million.
 
A Gloomier Market
 Mr. Potamkin will be operating in a gloomier market for selling Cadillacs than he left four years ago. He signed over his busy dealership to Mr. Penske just three days before the stock market crashed on Oct. 19, 1987, and the New York economy has been crippled ever since.
Even in a strong economy, selling cars in Manhattan is difficult and expensive. Overhead costs are about 35 to 40 percent higher than a comparable dealership in an outlying suburb, Mr. Gerosa said. Just arranging test drives on crowded Manhattan streets is a challenge.
But Mr. Potamkin, who first went into business in 1946, is undaunted. "We've seen this market before," he said, adding that New York drivers consider their luxury cars a necessity.
Mr. Potamkin declined to predict sales for the dealership, but said the key to succeeding in the expensive New York market was sales volume. As a dealer, he sold an average of 500 Cadillacs a month. His best month was May 1982, when he sold 968 Cadillacs. The current Cadillac retail sales leader, which does not include sales to corporate fleets, is Don Massey Cadillac in Plymouth, Mich., which sells about 135 cars a month.
Mr. Potamkin said he would use promises of low prices and customer satisfaction in his advertisements, and also key the ads to leasing. Leasing is important to Cadillac because lease customers are typically 10 years younger than Cadillac buyers, who average 65 years of age. Cadillac needs to woo younger drivers to insure its future; with its new Seville and Eldorados it hopes to attract buyers as young as age 35.
The opening of the Potamkin dealership was delayed partly by contract negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union, which represents many of the service workers. A clause in Mr. Penske's contract with the U.A.W. required his successor to honor the contract. But Potamkin officials balked at some of its terms, including high wages negotiated with Mr. Penske. Severance packages also had to be negotiated for some workers who would not be needed at the new Potamkin dealership.
Cadillac officials contributed an undisclosed amount of financial support to bridge differences, according to a person involved in the labor negotiations who insisted on anonymity.
Cadillac is also paying for minor renovations to the two showrooms. The larger showroom is at 11th Avenue and West 56th Street. A smaller showroom, expected to open in January, will be at 1133 York Avenue at 61st Street, Mr. Goldfein said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Victor Potamkin, once the national sales champ for Cadillac, at his old showroom on the upper West Side of Manhattan, which he will re-open Tuesday and go for the title again. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Army of Veterans Will Need Jobs

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WITH the end of the cold war, hundreds of thousands of men and women attached to the United States armed forces will be looking for jobs in the private economy.
Before President Bush took the initiative for sharp reductions in tactical nuclear forces, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney had laid out a plan for reducing the armed forces by more than half a million from its present level of about two million. Of that total, the Army would cut military personnel by 245,000, the Navy by 77,000, the Marine Corps by 28,000 and the Air Force by 170,000. 
 In addition, the plan called for reducing the reserves by 245,000 and eliminating the jobs of 193,000 civilians employed directly or indirectly by the Defense Department. In all, the Cheney plan proposed to cut total jobs over the next five years by nearly one million from the present level of about four million.
It now seems likely, however, that the military cuts will be even deeper. During a conference this week of business leaders and military officers at Fort Myer, Va., sponsored by the Army and the Committee for Economic Development, Secretary Cheney called the failed coup against the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a "watershed event" -- and one that cleared the way for a new United States strategy.
But he warned against letting "our euphoria blind us to the tasks that lie ahead." The central authority of the Soviet union, or what remains of it, has not yet been clearly defined. New threats could arise within or between individual republics. "Independence," Mr. Cheney said, "is not the same as democracy." And new "regional threats" could arise, as in the Middle East.
Nevertheless, he said a new strategy could assume that in the future there would be "more warning time" to respond to threats. That would mean fewer weapons on ready alert and fewer troops in Germany. The task now, he said, is "to reduce forces without reducing security."
That will involve decisions on what weapons to keep and what to take away. Superior technology is required to make future crises manageable. That is the military's first principle for a new strategy, reinforced by the Persian Gulf war, where, Mr. Cheney said, "technology produced tremendous results."
The second principle, he said, is the importance of rigorous training. He reported talking with soldiers who told him that their experiences at the Army's National Training Center in California "were tougher than anything we encountered in Iraq."
The third principle is maintaining the quality of the people -- "a professional force of men and women." The Army at latest report was 88.8 percent male and 11.2 percent female. Its racial compositon was 62.6 percent white (not including Hispanic), 28.6 percent black and 8.8 percent other minorities. Secretary Cheney asserted that with an all-volunteer force and high standards for recruitment, the quality of the military "is higher than it has ever been."
A former Secretary of Defense, who requested anonymity, said he thought the result of the strategic changes prompted by the success in the Persian Gulf and by the collapse of the Soviet Union would be deeper cuts in military personnel -- possibly by as much as 40 percent rather than the 25 percent envisioned in the earlier plan.
Facing the job of "massive deployment" from military to civilian jobs, Secretary of the Army Michael P. W. Stone said the Army was undertaking a broad-based program to insure that the people it will be releasing find jobs in the private sector.
Prof. Paul Andrisoni of Temple University's School of Business and Management told the Fort Myer conference about evidence he has found of discrimination against blacks and other minorities when they are discharged from the military. The Army prides itself on the job it has done in the integration, training and promotion of blacks, other minorities and women. Indeed, some of the businessmen at the conference said business could learn from the Army about equal treatment of people from different backgrounds.
But in so sluggish an economy, will the jobs be there? When asked what he thought about the capacity of the private sector to absorb so many into new jobs, Secretary Cheney restated his view that "we have a plan, we will follow it and we think this presents a great opportunity for the private sector." However, the task of absorbing veterans and the already unemployed into civilan jobs is not only managerial and educational but macroeconomic.
The cardinal issue facing the Bush Administration is whether it yet has an overall budget and fiscal plan, as well as an educational policy, that will strengthen the nation's economic growth, with lasting benefits to the nation's social structure, financial stability and global competitiveness.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Are Up Again

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
New applications for unemployment insurance benefits rose again in late September, the Labor Department said today, as the economy's recovery from recession remained too weak to encourage hopes of employment.
Claims for jobless pay rose to a seasonally adjusted 435,000 in the week ended Sept. 28, an increase of 5,000 from the previous week. 
 Economists had actually expected a drop in claims to 427,000. The increase underlined the concern that has become apparent even at the White House over the thinness of the recovery.
The department said the seasonally adjusted number of claims over the four-week period was 427,000, compared with 423,000 in the previous four-week period.
The number of people receiving benefits under state programs rose to 3,343,000 in the week ended Sept. 21, the latest period for which the figure was available. That was a rise of 17,000 in a week.

Markets

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
Syria partially withdrew from talks crafted by America to promote peace in the Middle East, in a move that U.S. officials fear may induce other Arab countries to remain on the sidelines and make the negotiations less appealing for Israel. Page A1

HEADLINE: Embargo Starts to Worry Haitian Business People

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 10

 BODY:
On Rue Pavee, the sweltering commercial street whose traffic has long been a barometer of Haiti's economic life, the chaotic return today of newspaper hawkers, whiskey vendors and Crazy Glue salesmen nearly two weeks after a violent coup belies the deep worries of business people working in air-conditioned offices.
After their euphoria at seeing Haiti's first elected president, the leftist priest Jean-Bertrand Aristide, forced out of office by soldiers, many in this poor country's small commercial community are awakening to the realization that the outside world is likely to exact a high price for bucking the hemispheric trend toward democracy. 
 Defying efforts by other nations in the hemisphere to win the reinstatement of Father Aristide to office, the Haitian legislature on Tuesday named a provisional president, Joseph Nerette, to replace him. Almost immediately, the Organization of American States announced stringent economic sanctions that many merchants now fear will quickly ruin them.
[Ambassador Alvin Adams said the United States may freeze the foreign assets of Haitian business people involved in blocking the return of deposed President, the Associated Press reported.]
Many in the business elite said they felt caught between a brutal and undisciplined army that refuses to consider allowing Father Aristide's return and a violence-prone population that could make the country ungovernable if he remains in exile.
Moreover, with much of the country's economy based on exports of simple assembled goods, many business people say that a strict embargo of Haiti would almost immediately spell doom for them and even greater hardship for their employees.
"Right now I feel like I would be very happy in Beirut," said one Rue Pavee entrepreneur who was busily canvassing the city for dollars so that he could make a new start in Miami if the worst should arrive.
"For most of us up until now this has been a political thing, but suddenly it is economic," the businessman said. "There is no clean way out of this situation."
"I know I don't want him to come back," he said, referring to Father Aristide, "but what we have now scares me too."
In Haiti's industrial zone there was similar anguish and confusion.
"Two days of an embargo and 40,000 jobs will go out the window just like that," said one Haitian industrialist. "In the meantime, we have a lot of very determined army people out there who are not looking at the economics. They are going to ride this thing regardless of the consequences."
With only enough oil and cash on hand to keep the country running for about six weeks, the businessman said he had little doubt that "the most stubborn forces" would be brought to their knees, but wondered "if the rest of the world is willing to pick up what is left of Haiti afterwards."
When business people contemplate the return of Father Aristide, many say they fear that after international attention dies down, the populist leader who has described Haiti as a mother who gives "sweet milk to the rich and sour milk to the poor" will unleash the masses on a spree of vengeance.
The affluent often cite statements like one in which the President urged the teaching of the words Pere Lebrun, the local term for lynchings with burning tires, in the national literacy program as proof that his return would endanger them.
With words like these still ringing in their ears, many of the relatively affluent here say that they are looking for ways out of the country.
Others, however, say that rather than fearing Father Aristide, who they found provocative, but not lethal, they worry more about an nervous army that is thought to be responsible for 300 or more killings since the coup began.
After five years of coups, plots and purges of senior officers, said one Haitian military analyst, the command structure has broken down to the point where "if you are sitting up in the palace, the only thing you command basically is your orderly and maybe your driver."

HEADLINE: SECOND GOVERNOR RESIGNS IN MEXICO

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10

 BODY:
A second Mexican state governor has resigned after allegations of election fraud, underlining the growing power of opposition protests as President Carlos Salinas de Gortari seeks to improve the image of his country's political system.
 Fausto Zapata, governor of the central state of San Luis Potosi, announced Wednesday night that he was resigning only two weeks after being sworn in "to pave the way to a political solution to the problems our state is facing." 
 Mr. Zapata, a member of Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has faced opposition protests since official figures showed that he won the Aug. 18 election.
 Groups of protesters prevented him from entering his offices, and his opponent, Salvador Nava, has been leading a protest march to the Mexican capital.
 
 
Interim Governor Named
 The San Luis Potosi Congress appointed Gonzalo Martinez Corbala of the Institutional Revolutionary Party as interim governor until new elections are held in 14 to 18 months.
 Opposition forces have also accused the governing party of fraud in elections in the neighboring state of Guanajuato, prompting the PRI candidate, Ramon Aguirre, to step down in August only hours after being declared the winner of the gubernatorial elections.
 The mid-term election was the first held under a reformed electoral code ordered by Mr. Salinas to counter persistent allegations of vote-rigging by the governing party. The Institutional Revolutionary Party has ruled Mexico for more than 60 years.
 The party's landslide victory across Mexico was viewed as a vote of confidence in Mr. Salinas's attempts to remold his party and seek closer economic relations with the United States.
 
 
Embarrassment to Salinas
 But Mr. Salinas evidently saw the protests in Guanajuato and San Luis Potosi as an embarrassment that could hinder his major foreign policy objective of signing a free trade agreement with the United States and Canada.
 Mr. Salinas's hand was evident in both resignations. Mexican newspapers reported that Mr. Zapata was called to the President's office here on Wednesday to be told of his fate.
 As was the case in Guanajuato state, Mr. Zapata's resignation angered backers of the Institutional Revolutionary Party in San Luis Potosi.

HEADLINE: Majority in Poll Fault Focus by Bush On Global Policy but Back New Order

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
A sizable majority of Americans say President Bush has been spending too much time on foreign policy and should pay more attention to domestic matters, especially the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
A major reason for those beliefs may well be a widespread conviction that many key foreign-policy problems have been solved. Among respondents in the poll, which was conducted by telephone from Saturday to Monday, 70 percent said nuclear war is unlikely in the next decade, 50 percent said the cold war has ended and 44 percent said no country posed a serious military threat to the the United States. 
 But the 1,280 people questioned in the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, sharply rejected a turn to isolationism in this country like the one that followed World War I.
The poll was taken not long after President Bush's ground-breaking speech announcing the withdrawal of all American land-based and sea-based tactical nuclear weapons from Europe and Asia, and just as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union was promising to make similar arms reductions.
 
Pattern of Political Strength
 Americans responded very favorably to Mr. Bush's initiative, with 59 percent praising the President's withdrawal of the short-range weapons and two-thirds of the 35 percent who did not approve saying they would approve if the Soviets in fact followed suit.
Mr. Bush's success on the arms-reduction front was part of a continuing pattern of electoral strength as the 1992 campaign approaches. Over all, a strong 64 percent of those interviewed said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job, even though that is down six percentage points from September, and essentially the same proportion (63 percent) said they approved of his performance on foreign policy. His rating on his handling of the economy was weak, at 30 percent, but the other figures suggest that for the moment at least the public judges him primarily in foreign-policy terms.
Still, the pervasive dissatisfaction with the President's performance as manager of the economy could prove damaging, as Democratic Presidential hopefuls have already begun suggesting. Mr. Bush's current economic rating, down from August, when it stood at 38 percent, ties his lowest point (one year ago) since he took office, and it comes as economic forecasters within the Government and in private industry are suggesting anew that the current recovery may prove to be weak or transitory.
The new poll indicates the depth of public concern about the economy in several ways. Asked to name the most important problems facing the country, 20 percent named unemployment and 17 percent mentioned the economy in general -- far more than chose any other issue and more than have mentioned economic problems in previous New York Times/CBS News polls during the Bush Administration.
 
Peace Dividend
 About three of five respondents, 59 percent, said President Bush had been neglecting the home front and about four of five, 78 percent, said he should concentrate more on the economy. Asked what should be done with any peace dividend, three of five said it should be spent on education, the environment, health care or other domestic needs rather than on reducing the deficit or cutting taxes.
Obviously, the voters give the President credit for successfully negotiating the turmoil in Europe and the Middle East during the last three years.
Respondents to the poll agreed, for example, with most of President Bush's contentions in his dealings with Israel, which form a key element in his attempt to convene a Middle East peace conference.
A majority back the Administration in its opposition to new Israeli settlements in the West Bank and favor withholding loan gurantees until Jerusalem yields ground on the issue. And a plurality says Israel has too much influence in Washington -- just like the President, who complained about Israeli lobbyists on Capitol Hill.
Some of the afterglow of the Persian Gulf war continues, with 74 percent still arguing, as in other recent polls, that getting involved was not a mistake, whatever the critics think, and 61 percent saying the cost was "worth it."
Nor is the public in any mood to challenge Mr. Bush on China. It is split down the middle, the poll indicates, with 40 percent saying criticism should be avoided to maintain relations and 44 percent insisting that it is important to call attention to the way that China suppresses human rights. With such a wide division on an issue of secondary importance to most voters, the President has a relatively free hand.
One area of potential peril for the President and for American policy is Japan. In the next century, Japan will be the No. 1 economic power in the world, according to 58 percent of those who talked with survey interviewers; only 25 percent thought the United States would be. American voters are not likely, if the past is a guide, to accept such a development without protest.
Japan's economic might and Americans' fears about their own economy is reflected in two other findings of the new Times/CBS News Poll. After the gulf war, there was a surge of optimism in the polls, but now the prewar tenor of opinion has reasserted itself; 52 percent of respondents said life for the next generation of Americans will be worse than for the present one, and a strong minority, 44 percent, saw the United States as a power in decline.
 
End of the Cold War
 The survey left no doubt that Americans see a vastly changed world, if not yet a new world order of the kind that Mr. Bush has so often discussed, and they strongly favor a strong continued United States role in that world.
Fully two-thirds of the respondents rejected the following statement: "Since the United States is the most powerful nation in the world, we should go our own way in international matters, not worrying too much about whether other countries agree with us or not." Likewise, two-thirds rejected the idea that the United States should behave less assertively on the world stage.
For the first time in a Times/CBS News Poll, a majority says the cold war is over, a surprising finding, perhaps, given the answer to another question. Asked whether the changes in relations between East and West were permanent, a majority, 52 percent, said no, that they would probably revert to their old pattern before long.
In addition, the bulk of the respondents said it was still important for the United States to keep strong military defenses, to maintain the North Atlantic Treaty Organization partnership with Europe and to keep American troop strength in Western Europe at about the same levels.
When asked whether any country in the world poses a serious threat to the United States, 44 percent said no, 43 percent said yes. Among that fearful minority, predictably, the potential foes were seen as Russia and Iraq.
But some Americans, at least, see an opportunity for the United States to let its guard down a little.
For example, 46 percent said spending on intelligence agencies like the C.I.A. should be decreased, with 46 percent saying financing should stay the same and only 5 percent calling for an increase. About a third (36 percent) said that overall Federal spending on the military should come down.
And if there is a residual distrust of the nation that has formed the focus of American apprehensions for four decades, feelings in this country toward the Soviet Union have warmed substantially as it has struggled to redefine its relations with the world, and, indeed, to redefine its own character.
Reflecting a steady improvement over the last five or six years, as arms-control agreements have gone into effect, 50 percent of the electorate says that the Soviets can be trusted to keep their word on nuclear weapons.
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday to Monday with 1,280 adults across the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for the group who say they follow news about world affairs and foreign policy issues "very closely" it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion might introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Medicaid Plan: No Free Lunch

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The beauty of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's ambitious plan to restructure the state's insatiable Medicaid system, at least according to the Governor and his aides, is that every county in the state would come out a winner.
"This is a plan that's very good for local governments," Mr. Cuomo said today. "You've got to come out at least even and probably make money." 
 But what is already dampening the plan's political prospects is the fundamental truth that there still is no free lunch in state government. If the state, which cannot print $100 bills, ends up assuming a Medicaid burden estimated at $1.6 billion a year, the money has to come from somewhere.
In the two weeks since Mr. Cuomo unveiled his plan, which calls for the state to take a share of local taxing authority in exchange for picking up local Medicaid costs, the legislative debate has increasingly focused on who the losers might be.
 
Savings and Cost
 "It will save localities $1.6 billion, but who's going to pay for that?" asked one state official, who requested anonymity. "Is it the taxpayers, is it the hospitals, is it the recipients? There is a savings for all counties, but for every savings there is a cost."
Predictably, representatives of upstate and suburban counties complain that the plan asks the rest of the state to subsidize a New York City bailout.
In New York City, officials at City Hall suspect that the Governor, by calling for the city to sacrifice all of its personal income tax revenues by the turn of the century, is asking them to give up more than they will get back.
Republican state senators question the economic assumptions that form the foundation of the Governor's plan, particularly his assertion that Medicaid costs will grow at 12 percent or less in coming years. Citing statistics released by the State Comptroller's office but questioned by the Governor's staff, they predict that Medicaid spending is far above that level and far above budget in the current fiscal year.
That has heightened fears that by taking over local Medicaid costs the state would assume an uncontrollable burden. That burden, the Republicans maintain, eventually may drive the state to raise taxes or to cut cherished programs, like aid to schools.
And virtually everyone in the Legislature is cynical about the potential for significantly cutting the Medicaid program's cost, which Mr. Cuomo has made a prerequisite for a takeover.
There are few mechanisms left for reducing Medicaid costs these days without either cutting the services provided by the program and the eligibility levels of its recipients, or reducing reimbursement rates for the state's financially strapped hospitals.
The state has already imposed $600 million in cost-containment measures in the last year, and the Governor's call for an additional $375 million in the next two years -- $225 million in savings for the state and $150 million in savings for localities -- has generated nervousness among both health-care providers and Medicaid recipients.
Mr. Cuomo has not yet said where the savings should come from, hoping instead that a private consensus emerges from administration experts and the Legislature. But it is clear that the traditional politics that have blocked past cost-containment efforts may be difficult to overcome.
 
A Power Base
 The Democrats who control the Assembly can be expected to resist cuts in the level of Medicaid services and eligibility that would harm the poor. The Assembly Democrats' power base is New York City, where two-thirds of the state's Medicaid recipients live.
The Republicans who control the State Senate have already criticized Mr. Cuomo for not proposing enough Medicaid cost containment. But they can be expected to resist cuts in reimbursement rates to hospitals and nursing homes, which they traditionally have protected.
Many Medicaid analysts believe that hospitals, nursing homes and long-term care centers are the only places where significant savings can be found. They account for about 65 percent of all Medicaid payments. Some legislators are also concerned that many cost-containment measures will simply shift the burden of indigent health care to other government agencies.
If the state eliminates Medicaid coverage for services like podiatry and dentistry, untended ailments may worsen until treatment is demanded in public hospital emergency rooms.
Mr. Cuomo argues that in the next legislative session, when Medicaid is certain to be the hottest of topics, the Legislature will have little choice but to consider cost-containment measures it has rejected before.
With the state slow in emerging from the recession, with little help coming from the Federal Government and with legislators unlikely to raise taxes in an election year, "they have no options," Mr. Cuomo said.
"If you're the Legislature and you know you're not going to have the money and that you will have the needs, what are you going to do?" he asked.

HEADLINE: Governor Offers Plan to Preserve Wilderness Site

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today formally unveiled his decidedly moderated plan for preserving the Adirondack Park Wilderness. The proposal has drawn less enthusiasm from environmentalists but also less rancor from local officials than the far more aggressive preservation blueprint advanced last year by the Governor's Commission on the Adirondacks.
Mr. Cuomo's plan focuses on state-financed tax breaks and other incentives to keep back-country forest tracts out of development. It amounts to the most significant gubernatorial package of legislation affecting the Adirondacks since the early 1970's.
 
A Better Chance of Passage
 The Governor, speaking to a meeting here of the Adirondack North Country Association, a local citizens group, staunchly defended his recommendation as having a much better chance of passing the Republican-controlled State Senate than his commission's package. 
 His plan was laced with programs to revive the struggling economies of many of the park's hamlets, including tax credits to attract businesses and the creation of an Adirondack North Country Authority to help improve housing and water treatment systems.
The Governor's proposals came nearly three years after a series of land sales to developers were attacked by environmentalists as threatening the wilderness character of the 6-million-acre park.
Mr. Cuomo estimated today that the cost of his plan, primarily the tax incentives, would be about $5 million a year. The incentives, he said, would have to come from an environmental trust fund that has yet to be approved by the State Legislature. Estimates of the cost of the commission's proposals ranged upward of several hundred million dollars.
The Governor's plan is generally given a better chance in the Legislature than the commission's package. "This is a horse that can cross the finish line," said Neil Woodworth, conservation director of the Adirondack Mountain Club.
The tax incentives proposed by the Governor would be largely intended for forest products companies and other large landholders that might consider selling their land to developers. Such landowners would get breaks on their tax bills ranging from 35 percent for making a 10-year commitment to preserve the land as open space to 80 percent for giving the state rights to buy the property in the future or allowing public recreation on it. The commission called for zoning that would have forbidden almost any new construction of homes or condominiums in the back country.
 
Zoning Laws Proposed
 The Governor did embrace some new zoning laws for many now-undeveloped lakefronts in the park. But as contrasted with his commission's proposals, the laws would reduce, but not eliminate, multi-home developments in these lakefronts by designating shorelines as "critical environmental areas" and demanding expanded lot sizes.
In general, individuals who currently hold land with plans for building a single dwelling on it would be unaffected by the new laws, although there would be new requirements for upgraded septic systems any time a new house is built or an old house changes hands.
"I think there's an interesting philosophy here, not just a land grab," said Jim Frenette, a member of the Franklin County Legislature.
Environmental groups generally had positive if somewhat lukewarm reactions to the Governor's package. The National Audubon Society, whose president, Peter A. A. Berle, served as chairman of the Governor's Adirondack Commission, praised many aspects of Mr. Cuomo's proposals but said they "fall short in several significant ways" of an overall preservation plan.

HEADLINE: Tashkent Journal;
A Dream of One Central Asia Under Islam's Banner

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TASHKENT, U.S.S.R.

 BODY:
The young mullah bowed one more time on his knees, finished praying, sat on the edge of the mosque's expansive prayer mats and began talking in a hushed voice, his eyes often scanning the faces of those who passed through the hand-carved gates to the place of worship.
"We want an Islamic state," he said, his rarely tried English carrying him slowly through his ideas. "Every person in their heart wants this. They want Islam in their homes. We want to live in a Muslim way." 
 The mullah, who insisted on anonymity, came to worship in the mosque, not to preach there. He said he felt safe preaching only in the homes of believers, where the risk of secret police surveillance is reduced.
Here in Soviet Central Asia, the mullah's sentiments are increasingly heard, in the mosques, in homes, on the streets and, for a time, on the airwaves of the region's republics.
 
Dream of Grand Turkestan
 Left in the foam of glasnost's and perestroika's wave here are a rush of passions, a longing for a return to the region's religious roots, a deep-seated hatred of the Communist Party and, for the first time, talk of returning to a vast Central Asian state, a revival of the old idea of a grand Turkestan.
These ideas, these dreams even, are not necessarily compatible, are not shared with equal fervor in each Central Asian republic. But the collapse of the monolithic Soviet Union and the rush toward independence by individual republics, real or not, has created fertile ground for aspirations that once seemed the stuff of fairy tales or history.
"Maybe this is the history of a new country," said Goga A. Khidoyatov, a professor of modern history at Tashkent University. "The country we call the Soviet Union is gone. I dream to live in a time that we will form a United States of Asia."
He went on to say that the new mufti of Bishkek -- the capital of Soviet Kirghizia, formerly called Frunze after a Soviet revolutionary, regained its historical name in February -- had spoken of this. "I think we will create this new Turkestan," he said. "It is the wish of all the people."
 
Balkanization by Stalin
 Uniting Central Asia's republics -- Kirghizia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenia -- may be easier said than done. Already, the leaders of the republics are plotting their own courses toward a post-Soviet future, some intent on a rapid restructuring of their economies and political order, others, like President Islam A. Karimov of Uzbekistan, determined to preserve the Stalinist political system.
Professor Khidoyatov said the current fragmentation of the republics stems from Stalin's deliberate Balkanization of the area. "The Turkestan republic was very strong, and very dangerous for Stalin," he said. "That is why he split it into many parts. In language, for example, they liquidated our alphabet. Now we are restoring it, because we want to restore this republic."
By law, the local languages are the official languages of the republic. But here in Uzbekistan, where the two-thirds of the population who are Uzbek speak the local language, their newspapers still use the Cyrillic alphabet imposed on them instead of the original Arabic script. And Russian remains the lingua franca of government and economic life.
At the core of pan-Turkestan sentiment remains the enduring cultural and slowly reviving religious tug of Islam. But the young mullah in the mosque said it was important that the region's religious leaders not deceive themselves into believing that the token allegiance to Islam expressed by the majority of the people would bring down Communism and replace it with a religious state.
"Here there is a Stalinist regime stronger than in Russia," he said, tugging on his beard. "So you see, there are Muslims in word and Muslims in deed. Our people's minds were oppressed by the Stalinist system."
"But there is a difference between a Russian way of life and an Asian way of life. We cannot live without religion. Because every ceremony, every birth of a child, every circumcision, every wedding, all these ceremonies are made by mullahs."
 
'Every Day a New Mosque'
 "Every day a new mosque is born," said Abdulla Ismail, the head of the international department of the Central Muslim Board. "We have many Muslim schools. As to whether we will become like Saudi Arabia, or Iran, it will depend on the people's desires."
In the last year, a political movement has begun in the region grouped under the banner of the Party of Islamic Renaissance. It is rapidly attracting adherents, though it is illegal since the constitutions of every Central Asian republic bans religious-based political parties.
The young mullah at the mosque here said: "There are two kinds of mullahs. There are the official, the approved mullahs. And there are the underground mullahs like myself. We don't preach in the mosques. We preach in people's homes. Now, there are many more fundamentalists than official mullahs."
How long, he was asked, did he think it would be before his dream of an Islamic state would be realized? He looked down at his hands. "I am 30 now," he said. "It will take 30 or 50 years. When I am an old man."
