HEADLINE: 4 Slain in 2 New Jersey Attacks And Former Postal Clerk Is Held

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 10

 BODY:
A former postal clerk, apparently seeking revenge for his dismissal, killed his former supervisor and her boyfriend and then invaded the post office here early today with a small arsenal and killed two mail handlers, the authorities said.
Before setting out from his Paterson apartment dressed in black military fatigues, black combat boots and a black silk Ninja-style hood, the man left a handwritten two-page letter there complaining about postal authorities and vowing revenge, officials said. 
 "It generally expresses his dissatisfaction with the Postal Service," the Passaic County Prosecutor, Ronald Fava, said of the note found in the home of 35-year-old Joseph M. Harris. "He felt he was treated unfairly. It basically indicated that these people are going to pay. He was doing this as an act of revenge."
 The Ridgewood Police Chief, Frank C. Milliken, said, "The firing just brewed and churned and churned for 18 months."
 
Note Refers to Slaughter
 Without offering specifics, Mr. Fava said the note referred to the massacre at an Oklahoma post office in August 1986. In that case, an employee who was facing dismissal pulled guns from his mailbag, killing 14 people and injuring 6 others before killing himself.
Mr. Harris emerged from a basement locker at the post office building and surrendered to members of the Bergen County SWAT team shortly before 7 A.M. He was wearing a gas mask and bulletproof vest and armed with a 9-millimeter Uzi handgun, a .22-caliber machine gun with silencer, a samurai sword, three hand grenades and some homemade bombs.
"I think Mr. Harris came prepared to die," said Joel Trella, chief of the Bergen County Police Department. "He was armed quite heavily -- more heavily than I"ve ever seen in my career."
But he surrendered quietly after about a half hour of negotiations.
Among his victims was Carol Ott, a 30-year-old supervisor of mail clerks who work the overnight shift, sorting mail for carriers. She was stabbed to death in the home she shared with her boyfriend in Wayne, about 10 miles west of here.
Mr. Fava said the wounds were large and gaping, including a deep slash on her left shoulder consistent with a slash by a sword. Ms. Ott was clad only in a T-shirt when she was killed. Mr. Fava said there was no sign she had been sexually assaulted.
Besides Ms. Ott, the victims were her boyfriend, identified as Cornelius Kasten Jr., who was shot behind the right ear as he sat watching television in a basement recreation room, Mr. Fava said. The two mail handlers were Joseph M. VanderPaauw, 59, of Prospect Park, N.J., and Donald McNaught, 63, of Pompton Lakes, N.J.
Ms. Ott was Mr. Harris's immediate boss in his final months of his employment with the post office here and was instrumental in getting him discharged 18 months ago, officials said.
Two months before Mr. Harris's dismissal, Ms. Ott filed a report with the Ridgewood police department, accusing Mr. Harris of harassing her on the job. Chief Frank C. Milliken said today that Ms. Ott never specified the type of harassment although he said it was not of a sexual nature. She declined an invitation by the police department to file a formal criminal complaint against Mr. Harris.
Chief Milliken said Ms. Ott told officials she wanted to consult a lawyer before filing a formal charge. "She said, 'I don't want to do that,' and she never came back," he said.
Former co-workers today described Mr. Harris as a quiet, tense and often sullen, ill-tempered man who said little while working and did not respond well to authority and directions. None, however, could recall any particular incident that prompted Ms. Ott to go to the Ridgewood police.
But some remembered friction between the two.
"They were like oil and water -- they just didn't mix," said one ex-clerk who sorted mail on the overnight shift and asked to remain anonymous. "He just had something against her."
Several postal workers remembered that Mr. Harris had told Ms. Ott sometime in early 1990 that he was going to "get" her. But apparently the two had no further contact until Ms. Ott was slain last night.
"I asked her a couple of months ago if she was having any problems with him and she smiled and said no," said Philip Torchio, a letter carrier.
Shortly after Ms. Ott went to the Ridgewood police in February 1990, she started the procedure that led to Mr. Harris's dismissal, according to postal authorities. She asked that he submit to a "fitness for duty exam," a Postal Service procedure under which an employee is sent to a doctor to determine if he is able to work. The exam can involve both physical and psychological evaluations.
 
'No Further Contact'
 Mr. Harris refused to take the test and was dismissed outright, said Thomas F. Johnson, chief inspector for the Postal Service in New Jersey.
"When he declined to go for the 'fitness for duty,' he was removed and there was no further contact with him," Mr. Johnson said at a news conference here.
Mr. Johnson said he was unaware of the particulars of the problems between Mr. Harris and Ms. Ott.
The Ridgewood Postmaster, Earl Alston, also signed the forms seeking the exam, officials said. He was unavailable for comment today. Postal workers who attended a private mid-morning briefing with the police said they were told that Mr. Alston was also a target of Mr. Harris today.
 
'Very, Very Quiet'
 It was not immediately clear late today whether Mr. Harris had ever filed any grievances over his dismissal with the union representing postal clerks, the American Postal Workers Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O.
The police said today that they knew little of Mr. Harris's background. He has apparently been unemployed since his dismissal and living alone in a small second-floor apartment in a six-bedroom house on Derrom Avenue on the east side of Paterson.
The owner of the home, Carmen Johnson, who said she was Mr. Harris's half-sister, said he had lived in her house for about 14 years and was "very, very quiet."
He was born in Trenton in March 1956, and served in the Navy from 1974 to 1977, specializing in repair of mechanical and electrical equipment, officials said. Mr. Harris, who is 6 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 175 pounds, began working for the Postal Service in 1981 and spent most of his nine-year career as a clerk sorting mail on the overnight shift here, officials said.
 
Little Contact With Family
 In 1984, he was reprimanded by postal officials for harassing co-workers, law-enforcement officials said. They said they had no details of this incident. Mr. Johnson, the chief postal inspector, said he did not have the information about it.
Kim Ward, Mr. Harris's sister, said in an interview last night outside his house in Paterson , that he was the second oldest of 10 children.
After he was discharged from the Navy, Mrs. Ward said Mr. Harris had only sporadic contact with his family, including his mother, who also lives in Paterson. Mrs. Ward said that she has not spoken to him in several years.
Otto Harris, a 36-year-old cousin in Paterson, said: "He was always fascinated with martial arts. He was always fascinated with explosives. He always liked guns, but he never hurt anyone before."
He recalled seeing Mr. Harris late Wednesday night near his home, and said, "He seemed calm."
Before leaving his apartment, however, Mr. Harris rigged a homemade bomb of explosives and an ether-based can of auto-starting fluid to his front door, officials said.
He apparently first drove to Ms. Ott's beige split-level house.
At 2:15 A.M., Marcello Collado, a truck driver from Paterson, pulled up to the rear loading dock of the post office with a truck load of mail. Unlike on most nights, the bay doors were closed and the building was dark. He went to the basement of the building and encoutered a gunman wearing agas mask. A shot was fired, and Mr. Collado fled to the police station about half a mile away.
Sgt. Robert Kay and Officer Peter Tuchol were sent to the post office building about 2:20 A.M. They, too, came upon the masked gunman in the basement. He hurled an explosive device at them and they retreated and called for assistance.
Within minutes, the building was surrounded and officers began stopping mail handlers and sorting clerks as they arrived for work.
From about 3:15 until shortly after 6 A.M., police officials attempted to call Mr. Harris by telephone inside the building, officials said. But the calls were unanswered. The negotiators with the Bergen County SWAT team entered the building through a side door at 6:26 and emerged with Mr. Harris at about 6:50.
Until mid-afternoon, the police feared that both the post office and Ms. Ott's home in Wayne were booby-trapped. Both were cordoned off. But no explosives were found at either place.
At about 7 A.M., the police found the device Mr. Harris had rigged to his apartment door. They had gone to the home earlier, at about 3 A.M., but Mrs. Johnson, the owner, refused to give them the key to Mr. Harris's apartment without a search warrant.
"If I did what the police asked me to do and I gave them the key, we would all be dead now," Mrs. Johnson said this afternoon.

HEADLINE: White House Defends Delay on Health-Care Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Top officials of the Bush Administration defended themselves today against criticism that the White House was ignoring the nation's health care problems by failing to propose a comprehensive overhaul of the system.
"We will have our comprehensive plan in due course," the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, told members of the House Ways and Means Committee. 
 He said that he hoped the Administration would propose a plan before the 1992 election, but that in any event, "I suspect we'll all be at a signing ceremony in the second Bush Administration term."
Mr. Darman said the incremental changes the Administration has proposed would not be enough to adequately put the brakes on soaring health care costs. But he said these measures, including malpractice changes, were a start.
 
Several Plans Dismissed
 Administration officials have already dismissed several plans to deal with the health-care crisis, including national health insurance that would cover everyone under a Federal system, and have also dismissed "pay or play" plans that would make employers either offer health insurance to workers or pay into state funds to insure workers. Officials are leaning toward programs that involve changes in the tax system, either incentives for business or changes in personal income tax to help make health insurance affordable.
Health care costs have been rising at more than twice the rate of general inflation, a pace Mr. Darman calls "unsustainable," and will exceed $650 billion this year. Health-care spending currently accounts for about 12 percent of the gross national product, yet an estimated 34 million Americans have no health insurance and lack access to routine health care.
The Health and Human Services Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, said he, too, would like to propose a comprehensive plan before the election, "but that is going to be the President's decision."
Dr. Sullivan and Mr. Darman pointed out that about 30 different health-care reform plans were circulating on Capitol Hill, and that Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said in a speech on Wednesday that "attempting to legislate now would be a terrible mistake."
But committee members said Mr. Rostenkowski had at least entered the debate actively by proposing his own plan, which would require employers to provide health-insurance coverage to employees or pay a tax to support a public benefit plan for those who do not have workplace coverage.
Dr. Sullivan has criticized this "play or pay" proposal and others like it. He said the plan would not contain health-care inflation, would smother competition and would lead to rationing and waiting lists for health-care services.

HEADLINE: Silver-Lining Deal Has Publisher Staying

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
After considering a move out of New York City, a major publishing concern, the Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Division, has decided to relocate from Third Avenue to Union Square, long ago the hub of the nation's publishing industry.
The publisher, which has some 400 employees, is close to signing a lease for about one-third of the commercial base of Zeckendorf Towers, at 10 Union Square East, between 14th and 15th Streets. The agreement may be the salvation of the office portion of the condominium building, whose sole tenant, Integrated Resources, filed for bankruptcy last year. 
 In deciding to stay in New York, the publisher dramatized the silver lining for tenants -- and the city -- when developers are forced to strike generous deals.
Should the division take the full 120,000 square feet in which it is interested, the value of the lease over its 10-year life would be $34 million, said Tom A. Javits, vice president of the Zeckendorf Company.
 
'Made Them Feel Really Welcomed'
 City officials believed Macmillan/McGraw-Hill was seriously considering a move to Connecticut or New Jersey. They arranged a meeting last month with local executives, community leaders, police and transit officials and others to discuss the publisher's worries, including security.
"We made them feel really welcomed in their new neighborhood without committing city dollars," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the deputy mayor for finance and economic development. Mayor David N. Dinkins said it proved that "there are more than financial incentives to our economic development approach."
The president and chief executive of the division, James P. Levy, confirmed that the publisher had considered other sites. Now, he said, "We look forward to being part of the redevelopment of this important artery in the lifeline of New York City."
The division is part of the Macmillan/ McGraw-Hill School Publishing Company, a joint venture. It operates out of the Maxwell Macmillan Building, 866 Third Avenue at 52d Street. Mr. Levy said it was the largest publisher of educational material for children through the eighth grade.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said, "It is clearly a great day for New York as the center for the printed word."
And Jonathan F. Fanton, the president of the New School for Social Research and co-chairman of the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation, said, "The Macmillan decision is a real vote of confidence in the vitality of Union Square."
It would also seem to be a vote of confidence in the commercial portion of the Zeckendorf development, above which four residential towers rise.
"I think, with the emergence of such a strong user as Macmillan/McGraw, that it will really become a publishing building -- books, magazines, things of that type," said the developer, William Zeckendorf Jr. His partners in the project include Elie Hirschfeld and KG Land, a subsidiary of the Kumagai Gumi Company of Tokyo.
Financing came from the Equitable Life Assurance Society, the holder of $67 million in Industrial Development Agency bonds.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
The Mayor's Trip: Who's Paying?

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins of New York City has scaled down his proposed trip to South Africa. Instead of traveling by chartered plane Mr. Dinkins will travel commercially, and many in the entourage will pay their own way. These moves make good sense. But disquieting questions still remain about who's footing the rest of the bill.
Mr. Dinkins isn't the first mayor to venture abroad, and it's hard to quarrel with his effort to forge cultural and economic ties between New York and any post-apartheid regime. But the administration still delays in disclosing the list of donors. 
 The money is being raised by the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, the same city-controlled nonprofit group that raised funds for the parade for veterans of the Persian Gulf war. Responding to criticism that it was inappropriate for the Mayor's chief political adviser, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, to solicit corporations and individuals doing business with the city, Mr. Lynch formed a citizens' committee to do the job.
The committee still doesn't have a head, suggesting that Mr. Lynch is still involved. He promises that the list of contributors will be made public when the fund-raising is completed. But further delay merely heightens concern about conflicts of interest.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

Sandro's
 In his leaner days, Sandro Fioriti might have been a soccer goalie, thrashing his towering frame in front of the net while deflecting leather cannonballs. Today his goal is less perilous but equally challenging: endearing New Yorkers to the multifaceted cuisine of his native region around Rome. Sandro's cadre of regular patrons offers proof that to some extent he is succeeding.
Six-year-old Sandro's is not the kind of place you stumble upon. It is well concealed in the lobby of a high-rise apartment building on far East 59th Street, hard under the rumbling 59th Street Bridge. The big, casual dining room has a terra-cotta floor, palm trees and walls covered with framed posters of Italian food products. In such a neighborhood setting, captains in black tie seem incongruous.
Upon being seated, you are presented a basket of terrific rosemary bread and "dare you to eat just one" sage-and-rosemary breadsticks. You will find that the wine list is strongest among Italian reds and whites, with a smattering of American labels, all on the moderate to high side. As we were discussing the wine and other matters, a captain barged in -- a common and annoying occurrence -- and recited his daily specials. When we wanted him, though, he was nowhere to be found. Another captain took the wine order and, a mere 20 minutes later, returned with it. Service in general was maladroit. The amiable Mr. Fioriti, though, was a most cordial host, stopping by every table to ask how the food turned out.
We had no complaints about the ravioli filled with spinach and ricotta afloat in a beautifully balanced tomato-cream sauce, nor with the crisply fried artichokes, their dark golden leaves as brittle as puff pastry. The most compelling pasta dish was ravioli filled with sea urchin roe in a subtle tomato sauce studded with minced baby scallops. The oceanic sea urchin flavor burst through with every bite, and the light tomato sauce allowed it to shine.
Quality pancetta and pecorino cheese were the foundation of a dish recommended by our captain, but the sauce was not integrated and the pasta was unevenly sauced. Spaghetti with clams on the half shell, a touch of tomato and herbs had a lusty shellfish flavor. Penne tossed with mild Italian sausage and cream was too timorous and lacking pepper for my taste.
Among nonpasta starters, tender sauteed baby calamari with radicchio and tomato had everything going for it but flavor. Garlic or hot pepper would have helped. Ice cold carpaccio with olive oil and slices of Parmesan was hard to judge until it warmed on the plate. Then it was pleasing.
Main courses here could sustain a pair of soccer players for the day. The roast suckling pig, a special, has a wonderful burnished skin concealing a thin layer of fat that adds moisture to the succulent meat. Equally good, if not better, was roasted baby lamb with a blackened crust and aroma of rosemary. One of the house favorites seems to be straccetti, grilled slices of beef that had been coated in olive oil, garlic and lemon. The vibrantly flavored meat is exceptionally tender. Fennel sausages with bitter broccoli were a fine combination, too. Butterflied Cornish hen, though, which can be savory when grilled, is fried here, which leaves it a bit heavy and bland.
Among the seafood, salt cod cooked with potatoes, onions and tomatoes is firm and flavorful, reminiscent of traditional Portuguese recipes. Grilled swordfish, a special, was lustrous in a pool of white wine sauce scented with lemon and basil. It came with grilled endive. Only grouper braised with artichokes in a lemony wine sauce came out flat and one-dimensional.
Another one of Mr. Fioriti's regional dishes is the polenta pudding with raspberry sauce. Surprisingly, the pudding was ultra-smooth with no grain detected. We later learned that a fine grade of polenta, almost flourlike, is used. Chocolate mousse cake is relatively light and intense with good bittersweet chocolate. And chocolate-dusted tartuffo is a special treat, as is granita of expresso (although granita of lemon is watered down).
The first time we visited the restaurant, we were victims of Mr. Fioriti's puckish sense of humor. Toward the end of our main courses, he came by and insisted we try a platter of his favorite pasta. We groaned. As we finished our desserts, he came over holding a platter over his head. "Pasta, Pasta!" he announced as we all cringed. He then placed in front of us a platter of warm sugar cookies. Then came a selection of his homemade fruit grappas. Peach was our favorite.
Sandro Fioriti is the type of host who makes sure you never leave hungry. And if you order wisely, you'll leave happy, too.
 
Pamir
 Afghan food, which not long ago was as obscure as it was exotic, has moved into the dining mainstream in major cities. In New York City, for example, diners can choose from more than a half-dozen serious Afghan restaurants and many more living-room-size family cafes. Pamir, a congenial spot on Second Avenue in Manhattan, has always been one of my favorites.
Afghan food is a melange of Middle Eastern cuisine with some spicy Indian accents tossed in. Lamb, chicken, rice and vegetables are the primary ingredients. Exotic herbs and spices give the food its allure.
Pamir's dining room is a long, shadowy expanse with a bar at one end. Oriental rugs, assorted wall hangings and soft Eastern music contribute to its mysterious feeling. Candlelit tables are tightly arranged to accommodate the enthusiastic nightly crowds. Over the course of three visits, I found that service is not as sharp as it used to be. Orders are occasionally confused and servers are not always as diligent about getting drinks, bread, water and the like.
The menu rarely changes, so it takes only one visit to become familiar with the specialties. Starters include sambosa goushti, triangles of greaseless fried pastry stuffed with a mixture of ground beef and chickpeas redolent of cinnamon and cumin; bulanee gandana, thin, blistered turnovers filled with scallions and herbs that are eaten with a tart yogurt sauce; bulanee kachalou, another turnover, stuffed with mashed potatoes, onions and spices, and aushak, crisp flat scallion-filled raviolis under a lovely yogurt sauce with ground meat and mint. All of the turnovers go well with some fiery cumin and coriander sauce.
Beer is probably the most suitable beverage with this tangy food, although certain full-bodied red wines from the perfunctory list might stand up to the spices. Oddly enough, Pamir has a menu of tropical cocktails. The barman makes a mean margarita, although I wouldn't try it with a spicy yogurt sauce.
Two popular main-course dishes are badenjan chalaw, a spicy mixture of cubed lamb, eggplant, tomatoes and onions, and sabsi-chalaw, lamb in a mellow spinach sauce flavored with onions and garlic. A daily special was a winner, too: zardak chalaw, stewed lamb with carrots, onions, garlic and ginger.
One of my favorites has always been a colorful creation called norange palaw, a circular mound of saffron rice laced with almonds, pistachios and thin strips of orange zest. Beneath the rice is an aromatic lamb stew that, when mixed with the rice, can yield a complex and subtle melange of flavors and textures. A recent sampling, however, was woefully unbalanced. The rice was overloaded with sweet orange zest and cloying with rosewater. Quabilli palaw, a similar lamb dish made with brown rice, almonds, pistachios, raisins and carrot strips instead of orange, was better balanced, but some of the lamb was mushy from overmarination.
Among meat entrees, there is only one escape from lamb. Kabab-e-murgh features skewered marinated chicken cubes with vegetables. On two samplings, the chicken was dryish, ameliorated somewhat by the coriander dipping sauce.
Side dishes to consider are sabsi, a puree of spinach with onions and assorted spices (ours arrived at room temperature); buranee kadu, sauteed chunks of pumpkin topped with yogurt and ground beef, and buranee badenjan, delicious sauteed eggplant with a garnish of the same yogurt meat sauce.
Desserts take some getting used to. Firnee is a firm, semisweet pudding studded with almonds and pistachios. Baghlawa is a form of baklava, made with brittle layers of pastry and sweetened walnuts. Gosh-e-feel is the most exotic, a pizza-size piece of fried dough dusted with cardamon, pistachios and confectioners' sugar.
While Pamir still has exotic (and economic) appeal, the lapses in service and food merit a reduction from two stars, which it received in 1987, to one star.

HEADLINE: Palestinians Should Accept Israeli Settlers;
Private-Sector Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The disagreement over the loan guarantees to Israel can be resolved by extending the guarantees to private-sector investments in Israel, rather than to the Israeli Government. The loan guarantees to the private sector will facilitate raising capital to build the infrastructure and plants, and to buy the equipment needed to provide employment to the incoming immigrants. 
 Many Israelis would prefer it if less resources were extended to the Government, which is not known for its frugality or efficiency in investments. The Israeli Government controls too much of the economy and giving it more resources will further increase its economic and political power relative to the private sector.
The extension of United States-sponsored loans to the private sector, rather than to governments, has been suggested by the United States as the policy of the European Bank towards Eastern European countries. Also, the United States Export-Import Bank routinely lends money to private foreign companies that import from the United States.
If this proposal is implemented, the Israeli Government would have to raise the additional funds it needs to build new settlements by raising taxes. This will make explicit to the Israeli public the economic burden that the settlement activity entails. If this burden seems too high for the Israelis to bear, they could pressure the Government to freeze the settlements. Such internal political pressure would be more potent than an outside pressure.
 
YAKOV AMIHUD
Professor of Finance
New York University
New York, Sept. 24, 1991

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Pulling Together

 BODY:
At a recent meeting, the state governments of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut agreed with New York City to find ways to press economic development as a regional unit. Although separate efforts to attract business will continue, competition will henceforth be downplayed while joint efforts to attract jobs and tourism will be stressed. It's an excellent strategy, especially in these difficult economic times.
No one expects that all competition will stop. But the rival governments seem finally to have acknowledged that bringing new employment to the New York metropolitan region is far better for the region as a whole than having the same development take place a thousand miles away. 
 The cooperating jurisdictions will no longer publicly criticize each other. And there was general agreement that unbridled rivalry sometimes encourages cities to make such huge concessions, in taxes and other benefits, that the winner often ends up losing more money than it can possibly recoup.
The various governments have now built a constructive foundation for further cooperation. The introductory meeting should now be followed by some specific steps to raise the region's banner.

HEADLINE: SYRIA TO BOYCOTT REGIONAL SEGMENT OF MIDEAST TALKS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Syria has informed the United States that it does not intend to participate in one of the three phases of the American-crafted Middle East peace talks, a move that American officials fear may induce other Arab countries to remain on the sidelines and make the negotiations less appealing for Israel.
According to Middle Eastern diplomats and American officials, the Syrians told Washington that they do not plan to take part in the negotiations involving Israel and other countries about regional problems -- like water rights, economic development and arms control. The United States had envisioned these discussons as an important accompaniment to the direct, one-to-one negotiations between Jerusalem and Damascus. 
 The Syrian move, which was conveyed to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d by Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa during a heated meeting in New York on Sept. 26, could have a dampening effect on the proposed peace conference, if other Arab countries follow suit. This is because the United States has promised Israel that the wider-based talks would include Arab countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, with whom Israel has never had diplomatic contact, and would signal that Israel might one day win recognition and acceptance in the whole Arab world.
 
Carrot and Concession
 The Syrians have decided, though, that such talks, which Washington viewed as a carrot to induce Israel to join in the process, constituted a concession, one they were not willing to make until and unless Israel commits itself to returning the Golan Heights, the diplomats said. Israel captured the region in the 1967 war and virtually annexed it.
Administration officials have gone out of their way not to disclose the Syrian move, as Mr. Baker continues to try, through private channels, to persuade Damascus to change its mind.
The negotiations the Syrians are balking at attending are one of three integrated stages in the peace talks that Mr. Baker has been trying to organize. The first stage is a purely ceremonial opening session to be held somewhere in Europe later this month. The Arabs, and particularly the Syrians, insisted on this opening to give the talks an international cover.
The second stage is to be separate, direct talks between Israel and Syria, Israel and Lebanon, and Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. The Syrians are still agreeing to engage in these two-way talks with Israel, but there is no agreement as to where or how they will be conducted.
Two weeks after these talks begin, Mr. Baker promised that the broad negotiations would take place over regional problems. The purpose is to draw into the negotiations the Arab states that do not have territorial disputes with Israel -- particularly Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other Persian Gulf nations -- in order to signal Israel that there really has been a radical change in Arab attitudes that opens a path to various new relationships.
The American logic underlying these broad-based talks was that the way to persuade Israel to make concessions to the Palestinians was by creating a regional environment that signaled that reconciliation of Israel and its Arab neighbors was possible.
The Syrians told Mr. Baker, the diplomats said, that all they have to discuss with Israel now is exchanging land for secure and recognized boundaries, under their interpretation of United Nations Security Council Resolution 242.
Until Israel commits itself to giving up territory, Syria is not ready to participate in a broad-based conference about other issues. The Syrians told Mr. Baker this is because they fear that the Israelis will pocket whatever concessions come at the regionaltalks, particularly the tacit recognition Israel would derive from sitting down with the Saudis and other Arabs -- and not give Syria what it wants on the Golan Heights.
 
Baker Armed With Compromise
 This also explains why Syria refused to attend a conference in Ankara scheduled for Nov. 3 to discuss regional water problems. The Syrians said they would not come if the Israelis did. When other countries heard that Syria was not coming, they pulled out and the conference was postponed.
American officials say they have compromise proposals they plan to present to President Hafez al-Assad when Mr. Baker meets with him in Damascus next Tuesday. He will try then to persuade him to send a delegation to the regional session.
When asked about Syria's move, an Administration official said: "There is good news and bad news. The bad news is that they say they don't want to come. We're still working on that. The good news, though, is that it is a sign that they know this thing is real and is going to happen, and that is what is making them so nervous. The important thing is that they are not raising any questions about the bilateral talks."
Nevertheless, a senior Israeli official said, if Syria is not going to attend the regional talks, "it would certainly send a very negative signal to the Israeli public about this whole process."
 
Cementing a Delegation
 On another front, Mr. Baker met today with four Palestinian leaders to try to prod them into forming their joint delegation with Jordan.
Mr. Baker told the Palestinian representatives -- Hanan Ashrawi, Faisal al-Husseini, Sari Nusseibeh and Zakaria al-Agha -- that their delay in assembling a joint delegation could hold up the whole conference -- which is to start by Oct. 31.
Mr. Baker, an American official said, told the Palestinians that it was important that they, or their colleagues from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, go immediately to Amman and set up the joint delegation "in the right way." That means that the delegation include only Palestinians that the Israelis approve of -- that is Palestinians from the occupied territories, without any direct links with the Palestine Liberation Organization or without any clear-cut connection with East Jerusalem.
It also means that the delegation must be visibly assembled by people from the West Bank and Gaza, with Jordan's King Hussein, and not by the P.L.O. and Jordan, since that could drive Israel away from the talks.
 
Assurances Still Sought
 The Palestinians, for their part, emphasized to Mr. Baker that while they want to come, they still want to be assured that the question of a freeze on Israeli settlements will be addressed as soon as the conference opens. They want to know that the future status of Jerusalem will be on the agenda, and they still insist that a Palestinian with some links to East Jerusalem be allowed to be participate. They have also been seeking a clearer American commitment about their political rights.
Mr. Baker, speaking to reporters before his talks with the Palestinians, said: "President Bush and President Gorbachev made it clear at the Moscow summit that they would like to convene a conference in October, and I simply would point to the fact that this is the 10th of October. So we've got to see some decisions taken here and we've got to see some decisions taken across the board, across the region."
Without being specific, he warned that hard-line elements in the region were intent on disrupting the talks.
"As we get closer and closer to the end of October," he said, "I think you will see a tendency on the part of rejectionists and extremists across the region to take actions designed to disrupt the possibilities for peace."

HEADLINE: Major Aid to Soviets Tops Agenda At Economic Meeting in Bangkok

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The seven major industrial nations, impressed by the worsening financial condition of the Soviet Union and in particular its growing foreign debt, are expected to discuss the granting of substantial foreign aid at a meeting of their finance ministers and central bank chiefs that will begin here Friday.
American officials, traveling to Thailand after an overnight stop in Tokyo, said the agenda at the meeting would be almost completely devoted to the prospect of a Soviet debt crisis and how to solve it before it undermines the country's ability to trade with the West, a critical need. 
 "There is a rough consensus that some alleviation of the short-term debt problem is going to have to take place," said a senior United States official, who spoke on condition of anonymity .
 The major industrial nations, commonly called the Group of Seven, are the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada. Senior American officials said today that they have decided they will have to formulate an urgent program to ease the Soviet debt burden, which is now estimated at $70 billion.
A Soviet delegation is expected at the meeting on Saturday.
 
Debts May Be Postponed
 The senior American official declined to discuss specifics, but there have been suggestions that some debt payments to foreign banks and governments might be postponed or that short-term loans might be offered.
A $70 billion debt is not considered onerous, given the Soviet Union's vast resources and its potential for earning hard currency from exports.
But the nation's economy has deteriorated so rapidly in recent months that there have been disruptions in exports and in the flow of hard currency into the country.
Although figures are sketchy, the Soviets have suggested that they may be unable to make about $5 billion -- and perhaps as much as $8 billion -- in debt payments due in the next three months.
Such a default, in addition to drastically reducing Moscow's ability to trade with the West, would presumably halt any further foreign loans to the Soviet Union.
 
Minimizing the Problem
 Nonetheless, some officials sought to minimize the acuteness of the problem and the importance of the meetings here. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve Board, told reporters today, "I wouldn't look at this particular meeting as a watershed, but as an ongoing, continuous, intensive exploration of the economic evolution of the Soviet Union and the types of problems that are emerging."
Another senior American official preferred calling the pending problem a temporary "liquidity crisis" rather than a longer-term "financial crisis."
"There is a hump they need to get over, and then it will be easier for them to service their debt," the official said.
Those who consider the Soviet situation acute say that if Moscow loses its credit-worthiness with the West, the ability of governments to help save the country from great economic disorder may be severely limited.
Long-term aid is not now being considered because of concerns whether the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would be able to use it effectively.
The Soviet Union has received special associate status in the International Monetary Fund, which is also meeting here. The Soviets are already getting technical advice on how to transform their deteriorating central system into a market economy.
And, according to the senior American Government official, the matter of humanitarian aid has been resolved in recent days "in terms of philosophy."
The United States has offered $2.5 billion worth of credits to provide food and other goods to the Soviet Union. The European Community offered a similar-sized package, and Japan, which for years resisted providing help because of a longstanding territorial squabble with Moscow over disputed northern islands, offered a package of credits and loan guarantees as diplomatic progress was made on the islands issue.
There has been some criticism of the aid offered by Japan and the Europeans, on the basis that their assistance was in a form not always immediately available.
In comments to reporters today, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said that economic help to Moscow should be substantial and forthright. "It's hard money, and it's going right this minute," Mr. Brady said of the American commitment. "I don't want to criticize anyone else. What I do know is the United States is there with $2.5 billion in food credits."
 
First, Two Hurdles
 Officials emphasized that two major hurdles must be cleared before the Soviet Union's debt problems can be eased: the lack of clear information on the extent of the problem, and uncertainty over the relationship between the central Government and the Soviet republics.
So the Soviet delegation is being awaited here with keen anticipation.
"The most important thing that they could bring would be clarity in the responsibilities of the center and the republics, starting with debt obligations," the senior American official said.
Mr. Greenspan said that, despite the difficulties caused by the lack of solid information, the Soviets had made substantial progress in collecting and providing the industrial nations with previously secret economic data.
"They're telling us things I never expected them to tell us," he said. "We're learning increasingly how the system works with the type of detail that basically enables us to diagnose what's happening."

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
An article and a picture caption in Business Day on Wednesday about the effects of recession on Presidential elections referred incorrectly to the voting of 1876, during a recession. The incumbent party was re-elected: Rutherford B. Hayes, a Republican, received the most electoral votes and succeeded Ulysses S. Grant. But Samuel J. Tilden, a Democrat, received more popular votes, fitting the pattern in which challengers receive more votes during recessions.

HEADLINE: Bad Times at the A-Bomb Factory

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
When the Savannah River Plant, the nation's main installation for the manufacture of nuclear bombs, was built in the 1950's near Aiken, S. C., it was like "gold rush days," recalls a local resident in Mark Mori and Susan Robinson's frightening documentary, "Building Bombs." 
 Almost overnight, the population of the area grew from 13,000 to 55,000. Aiken became a thriving company town run by the Du Pont Company, which built and operated the plant until the 1980's, when it was taken over by Westinghouse. 
 Those rosy days are long gone. None of the plant's five reactors are operating today. It is a nuclear waste site and storage facility whose cleanup costs have been estimated at more than $30 billion. 
 The 54-minute film, which opened yesterday at the Angelika Film Center on a bill with three shorter films dealing with nuclear issues, offers an understated history of the plant, which is shown to be aging badly, contaminating the local ground water and threatening one of the country's largest aquifers. One of the most disturbing disclosures is that between 1955 and 1983 low-level nuclear waste from the plant was disposed of in cardboard boxes, dumped in shallow trenches and shoveled over. 
 Among those who tell their stories are Art Dexter, a retired Du Pont physicist who suffered a crisis of conscience after being shown a vault containing enough tritium to power 30,000 of the bombs dropped on Nagasaki, and William Lawless, a former engineer for nuclear waste management for the plant. While employed by the plant, Mr. Lawless filed a report on the dangers of ground water contamination from the cardboard boxes that Du Pont rejected and eventually had killed. George Couch, a maintenance mechanic at the plant for 22 years, who is now suffering from a rare blood disease, recalls the plant's lax safety procedures. 
 The plant's biggest defender, who cites its economic benefits to the region (14,000 jobs), is James Edwards, a former United States Secretary of Energy and a former Governor of South Carolina.
 "Building Bombs" is an effective muckraking film because it doesn't scream hysterically. Its scenes covering the 1950's have a deceptively cozy, upbeat atmosphere. The recollections of former plant employees are clear and reasonable, and the narration by Jane Alexander is almost dispassionate in its coolness.
 "Deadly Deception: General Electric, Nuclear Weapons and Our Environment," a half-hour video that is also on the bill, interweaves saccharine television advertisements for General Electric consumer products with inflammatory material about the company's operation of the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State and the Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory in upstate New York. 
 The company ran the Hanford reservation for two decades into the mid-1960's, a period in which the film alleges that those living downwind from the reservation suffered from serious radiation-induced ills. The video was produced by Infact, an organization that is pressing General Electric to get out of the nuclear weapons business, and does not present General Electric's views. 
 Rounding out the program are two clever, strongly polemical antinuclear cartoons. In Jonathan Amitay's "Nukie Takes a Valium," a mocking male mushroom cloud puts on drag to offer a seductive modest proposal for nuclear annihilation. Hal Rucker's "Manic Denial" is a vignette about a psychiatrist awakened to nuclear peril by the discovery of a missile weapon silo near her uncle's farm.

BUILDING BOMBS
Directed and produced by Susan Robinson and Mark Mori; written by Ms. Robinson, Mr. Mori and William Suchy; edited by Philip Obrecht; music by Steve Hulse; narrated by Jane Alexander. Running time: 54 minutes.

DEADLY DECEPTION
Directed and produced by Debra Chasnoff. Running time: 27 minutes.

NUKIE TAKES A VALIUM
Directed by Jonathan Amitay. Running time: 5 minutes.

MANIC DENIAL
Directed by Hal Rucker. Running time: 11 minutes.

At the Angelika Film Center, Houston and Mercer Streets. These films are unrated.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Time to Review Benefits Is Now

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With employers increasingly adopting flexible, or cafeteria-style, benefit plans, many of which require re-enrollment in the fourth quarter, millions of Americans face important choices about their financial security. Even for people in traditional benefit plans, it is useful to review whether there are gaps in coverage they ought to supplement.
Some flexible plans offer more choices than others. But the basic idea is that employees are given a menu to select how much health, life and disability insurance they want and an opportunity to put away money on a nontaxable basis for dependent care and unreimbursed medical expenses. 
 Generally, the employee is given a certain amount of benefit credits to use for the benefits chosen, and the option of supplementing the credits with salary, if desired. The plans allow employers to shift part of the cost to employees, but at the same time allow employees to tailor their coverage to their personal or family needs. Working couples, for example, may be able to coordinate their coverage. Making the best use of a flexible plan can be equivalent to getting a raise.
"Employer-provided benefits are becoming more significant but precious, so an employee has to evaluate carefully how he is going to spend his employer's money and how much he wants to contribute of his own," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company in New York, who specializes in pensions and benefits. He and several other experts discussed criteria for employees to use in making choices.
"Health and medical is the most important because it's an ongoing major expense for both an individual and a family," Mr. Neumark said. "Everybody should be covered." Whether to choose regular health insurance or a health maintenance organization is a partly a life-style choice and partly an economic one, he said.
Regular insurance reimburses patients for care provided by their own physicians, typically at 80 percent or 100 percent of the usual and customary charges for a procedure, which may be less than a particular doctor charges. Generally, patients must pay several hundred dollars before insurance kicks in. H.M.O. coverage is far more complete, but doctor choice may be limited.
"If you have a family with young kids, you may have to go with the bread-and-butter plans with low deductibles," Mr. Neumark said. Optical and dental coverage are extra. With several children in a family, the benefits collected could well exceed the premium cost. A healthy young single worker might well find that paying for optical and dental care as needed costs less than the insurance premiums.
Disability insurance, which partly replaces salary in case of illness or accidents that prevent working, is the next consideration. William J. Goldberg of Houston, national director of personal financial services for KPMG Peat Marwick, said, "If you need your earnings to support yourself, you need disability insurance." Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Clarfeld & Company, New York, and director of personal financial planning, advised people to build a six months' cash reserve to take care of short-term needs because short-term disability insurance is relatively expensive. But he advised supplements with the purchase of good long-term coverage, which is less expensive. "The main thing you want to protect against is catastrophe," he said.
Mr. Goldberg noted that the coverage provided by many corporations had not kept pace with inflation, so he often advises executives to buy supplemental disability coverage. Also, many traditional plans do not provide long-term disability insurance, so employees need to buy it on their own.
Life insurance needs vary greatly, with the number of dependents, age and other family financial resources. Mr. Isaacson said someone who is the sole support of a family might want to buy private insurance to supplement what is available at work, which is often limited to two or three times annual salary. But a single person with no dependents probably needs very little.
Tim Kochis, partner in Kochis & Fitz, San Francisco, said a healthy, young worker who does need life insurance might well find that private coverage costs less than group insurance, "where he is subsidizing older workers."
Flexible spending accounts that allow the use of pretax dollars for payment of unreimbursed medical expenses like well-baby care or psychotherapy or for dependent care offer big opportunities for tax savings. Mr. Isaacson noted that one client-couple who put $5,000 into such an account for child care would have had to earn an additional $2,375 had they paid for child care with earned income after Federal, state and city income taxes and Social Security.
But, Mr. Ray cautioned, flexible spending accounts are "use it or lose it." Anyone who has put money into such accounts this year should be sure to spend it before the end of the year or the money will be lost, he said. "There is a lot of paperwork, but it's worth the paperwork," he added.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Broad Decline On Low U.S. Inflation Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled broadly lower on world currency markets yesterday after a better-than-expected report on United States inflation raised the possibility that interest rates might decline.
Gold prices advanced after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $359.90 an ounce, up $1.10 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $359.50, up $1.20. 
 The dollar was driven down in choppy trading largely by a Labor Department report showing prices at the producer level rose a slight one-tenth of 1 percent in September. The rise in the Producer Price Index was smaller than expected and was the latest in a series of data showing mild inflation at that level.
With inflation moderating, the climate is more conducive for the Federal Reserve to trim interest rates to stimulate the economy. Lower interest rates generally are bearish for the dollar because they lessen the value of dollar-denominated investments.
A separate report showed that excluding the volatile auto category, retail sales inched up only one-tenth of 1 percent in September.
"The dollar was driven down considerably in an immediate knee-jerk reaction," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "There is no reason for the Fed not to ease at this phase."
Later in the day, the dollar seesawed amid heavy corporate buying, rallying higher and then declining again to settle lower.
Mr. Donney suggested that political turmoil in the Soviet Union had helped underpin the dollar, with investors making safe-haven purchases.
"But the fundamentals -- weaker interest rates, a weak economy in the U.S. -- is still the dominant factor," he said.
In Tokyo, where markets reopened after a holiday on Thursday, the dollar fell to close at 129.85 Japanese yen from 130.30 yen at Thursday's close in London. Later in London, it fell to 130.00 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.58 yen, down from 130.35 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7195, from $1.7150 late Thursday. In New York a pound cost $1.7235, up from $1.7145 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6895 German marks, down from 1.6960; 1.4793 Swiss francs, down from 1.4845; 5.7575 French francs, down from 5.7780; 1,264.00 Italian lire, down from 1,268.25, and 1.1285 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1293.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
United Technologies to Cut Corporate Staff

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The United Technologies Corporation said today that it would cut about 25 percent of its 1,000-member corporate staff, becoming the third major industrial company in a week to announce job cuts because of the poor economy.
United Technologies said the cuts, part of a $1 billion company wide belt-tightening announced this summer, would be followed by other, unspecified reductions. 
 "Increasing pressures from the continued poor economy, a decreasing defense budget and more aggressive competition worldwide will undoubtedly require further reductions that will result in a substantially smaller, restructured corporate office," Robert Daniell, the company's chairman, said in a statement.
The sluggish economy has forced more companies to tighten operations as sales have slumped and profits have been squeezed by the lingering effects of the recession.
On Wednesday, Allied-Signal Inc., the aerospace, automotive products and materials company, announced it was cutting 5,000 jobs, and on Monday the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would lay off 4,000 employees.
United Technologies said its cuts would take place over the next few months. About 670 people on the corporate staff work at headquarters in Hartford, while the rest are at other locations in the United States and overseas.
In addition to producing electronic defense systems for the military, United Technologies' businesses include Pratt & Whitney jet engines, Carrier air-conditioners, Otis elevators and Sikorsky helicopters. It had sales last year of $21.8 billion.
In the latest quarterly report, released in July, the company said profits fell 79 percent in the second quarter to $43.4 million from $207.5 million the previous year. The stock of United Technologies rose 37.5 cents today, to $43 a share, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Edged Up 0.1% Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level rose a slim one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the Labor Department said today, suggesting that inflation remained under control.
A drop in food prices, the fourth straight monthly fall, helped keep a lid on prices. Energy prices rose, however. 
 The September gain in the Producer Price Index followed a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in August and a decline of two-tenths in July.
 
Hopes for Rate Cuts
 Economists said the report gave the Federal Reserve more leeway to cut interest rates to stimulate the sluggish economic recovery, if it wanted to do so.
The White House, which has been putting pressure on the central bank to lower interest rates, called the report "extraordinarily good news," saying it provided "plenty of room for interest rates to be low and stay low and get low.
"It's an ideal foundation for stimulating growth in the economy when you've got inflation low and under control," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, told reporters.
So far this year the Producer Price Index, which measures prices charged by producers of finished goods, has fallen at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent. That is the best performance since 1986.
Excluding volatile food and energy prices, the so-called core rate of inflation was unchanged, after edging up two-tenths of 1 percent in August.
 
Lack of Demand Cited

"There just aren't inflation pressures out there," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc. "There's just not the demand to create them.".
"If demand were good and producers could raise prices, you bet your bottom dollar they would," she added.
Responding to tame inflation, economic weakness and sluggish growth in the money supply, the Fed pushed down interest rates on Sept. 13 to their lowest levels since the 1970's.
Banks soon followed by cutting their prime lending rate a half-point, to 8 percent, a move that reduced borrowing costs for small businesses and people with home-equity loans.
Facing Presidential elections next year, the White House wants the Fed to cut interest rates more to insure that the recovery remains on track. But the Fed is standing pat for now, apparently awaiting more data.
Today's report on producer prices showed that food prices continued to slide, dropping five-tenths of 1 percent last month, after falling four-tenths the previous month.
 
Drop in Food Costs

The department's food index tumbled at an annual rate of 6.6 percent from June to September, the quickest decline for any quarter since the third quarter of 1976.
The September decline was led by meats, fresh fruits and vegetables, as well as potato and corn chips, fats and oils, and eggs.
Energy prices, by contrast, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, but this was less than the 1.8 percent climb the previous month. The relative slowdown was primarily attributed to gasoline prices, which rose just one-tenth of 1 percent. Home heating oil prices jumped 3.7 percent.
Prices of new passenger cars rose six-tenths of 1 percent, after a 1.1 percent climb in August.
In September, the overall index stood at 121.3, meaning that a basket of finished goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $121.30 last month.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Surge on Inflation Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An exceptionally favorable report on inflation prompted a sharp rally in the credit markets yesterday, pushing interest rates down as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose.
The rise in prices wiped out much of the steep declines registered earlier in the week, but long-term bond yields were still higher at the close of trading yesterday than they were a week ago. 
 The inflation report showed that prices at the producer level rose by just one-tenth of a percent last month and were unchanged when food and energy prices were excluded. That was much better than most Wall Street economists had anticipated.
 
Exceeding Expectations
 "The inflation numbers were as good as you could hope for, and were considerably better than people had thought," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
For market participants, the good inflation news was bolstered by a report on retail sales, which rose by an anemic one-tenth of 1 percent during September, once automobile purchases were excluded.
The data renewed speculation that the Federal Reserve Board would move quickly to lower short-term interest rates another notch. But the Fed chose not to initiate that move yesterday.
"Greenspan is out of the country," one government securities trader said. "And I don't ever remember the Fed easing when the chairman is out of the country."
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is in Bangkok, Thailand, for a meeting this weekend of monetary officials from the Group of Seven industrial nations.
Prices of Treasury securities began moving higher during overnight trading in Asia and later in Europe, but spurted after the reports on producer prices and retail sales were released.
 
A Shortened Session
 Much of the United States activity was telescoped into the morning hours, since the government securities market closed at 2 P.M., Eastern daylight time, providing an early start to a three-day Columbus Day weekend. Futures markets will be open on Monday, but the cash market in government securities will be closed.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 25/32 late yesterday, up 30/32, to yield 7.88 percent, compared with 7.95 percent late Thursday.
Despite the decline, by the end of the week yields on the benchmark issue were well above the 7.77 percent at the close of trading the previous Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year securities were offered at 102 27/32, up 22/32, to yield 7.45 percent. The 7 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, up 3/8, to yield 6.81 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes rose by 1/8 point, to a late offered price of 100 14/ 32, to yield 5.88 percent.
 
Bill Rates Decline
 Short-term Treasury bill rates fell in anticipation of an easing move by the Fed.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 4.94 percent, down 6 basis points, or six one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.99 percent.
Because of the truncated session in the government securities market, activity in the markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was slow.
Corporate traders said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 point to 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Balancing Act in Quest for Quiet Skies

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
In the battle for quieter skies, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey finds itself caught between the airlines that pay the bills at its three airports and the politicians who represent the airports' angry neighbors.
In starting to draft "aggressive" local rules that would reduce such noise faster than new Federal rules, the Port Authority is throwing in its lot with its neighbors, at least for now. 
But in addition to the airlines, the Federal Aviation Administration may well also oppose the move.
Top officials at the Port Authority promised yesterday to seek a compromise that everyone can accept, even if reluctantly. But it is hard to see how the Port Authority can satisfy these conflicting interests.
Richard C. Leone, the head of the Port Authority, said that while he expects an eventual compromise, he will respond first to instructions from local political leaders. He added that he simply does not agree that the Federal Government is the ultimate arbiter of noise policy from coast to coast.
 
Too Passive? Too Aggressive?
 And David Z. Plavin, the authority's director of aviation, said: "I am assuming there is no way to do this that will satisfy most of the people. Some will say we have been too aggressive and others not aggressive enough. But I think there is a way of reaching agreement. We have no choice but to do that."
The authority's objective, Mr. Plavin said, is to cut down on the actual number of noisy flights to and from the local airports. The Port Authority is not persuaded that new Federal rules announced last month, which set deadlines for airlines to phase out noisy planes from their nationwide fleets over about 10 years, will make much difference to New York and New Jersey, which have a disproportionately high number of noisy flights.
"We see no relief in terms of the specific fleet that serves our airports," Mr. Plavin said of the Federal rules.
There are at least two ways the authority might go about devising local rules, although the agency doesn't plan to make its decisions for at least a month, after a round of consultations with airlines, politicians and citizens groups.
One approach would be to adopt the Federal compliance schedules on a local basis. A few years from now, when an airline is required by the Federal rule to have eliminated half the noisy jets from its fleet nationwide, it would also promise to schedule quieter jets for half its flights in the New York area.
 
New Rules in Los Angeles
 An alternate approach would be to count the number of local flights by an airline using the noiser jets in 1991, and to reduce them steadily -- for example, to cut them by 10 percent each year until they all ceased in 10 years.
But the airlines are sure to object to either approach, and neither would be welcomed by the F.A.A. The airlines want, in effect, to be let alone by the Port Authority, since in any event virtually all the noisy jets will be gone nationwide in 10 years' time under the Federal rule.
New York is not the only locality eager to impose strict local noise rules. A recent attempt to do so in Los Angeles led to intense negotiations between the city and the Federal Aviation Administration in the months before the final Federal rules were published.
Although an agreement has not yet been completed, the negotiations have led to an understanding that Los Angeles may set tight limits on individual airlines operating noisy planes at its airports.
But Federal officials have said that the Los Angeles plan cannot be construed as a pattern to be followed elsewhere. They reached agreement with the city in large measure to head off its strategy of setting strict local rules before the Federal rules took effect.
 
Reluctant to Wait
 The pressure for stricter local rules originates with the people who live near airports or within earshot of arriving and departing planes. They are reluctant to wait for years as the planes are replaced with quieter models. Although they have the support of powerful lawmakers at the local, state and Federal levels, there is little hope that the residents can dictate the outcome of the battle, say lawyers familiar with noise regulations. The best they can do is argue that the new law specifically allows local airports to set local noise rules, a disputed point that can only be settled in court.
The Federal Aviation Administration, for its part, has two options to thwart local rules it does not like. One is to go to court claiming that Federal law pre-empts the local airport authorities. A second is to withhold grants and revenues from the Port Authority unless its noise regulations comply with the new Federal rules.
Finally, although they cannot tell the authority what to do, the airlines have profound economic power as the authority's customers and tenants and Kennedy, Newark and La Guardia airports. By bringing business there they fuel the authority's economic engine, and they claim that local noise regulations could cost them so much money that they would have to cut flights into the area.
Mr. Plavin said the agency will be careful to meet the technical requirements of the new Federal noise law, which dictates the process by which local airport authorities set their local noise rules.
The local rules have to be based on economic and environmental analyses showing what alternatives were considered and whether the costs imposed on the airlines are worth the benefits to be gained by the localities. When the rules are proposed, there must follow a comment period of at least 180 days before final adoption.

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS NOMINATION;
Americans Riveted By Lesson in Civics

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS

 BODY:
In cities and towns far and wide, Americans took time out from their workaday lives yesterday to tune into an extraordinary civics lesson: the riveting collision before the Senate Judiciary Committee between Judge Clarence Thomas, the Supreme Court nominee, and Anita F. Hill, the Oklahoma law professor who said she was sexually harassed by him.
For a nearly a week now, since the charges became public, they have been topic No. 1 in offices and universities, in restaurants and on street corners, with many women celebrating the sudden public discussion of a heretofore private subject and many men wondering about their own conduct, present, past and future. 
 "The old rules are going out," said Steve Traub, a student at the StanfordMedical School in Palo Alto, Calif., who gathered with a group of friends to watch the proceedings. "We don't really have new rules in place yet. But at least now we're talking about it."
There's plenty of disagreement among people watching and listening to the hearings about who was telling the truth and who was not, plenty of debate about whether the confusing set of facts and allegations ought to disqualify Judge Thomas from service on the High Court, plenty of speculating and ruminating about why Professor Hill was there telling her story and whether the Senate had handled her situation properly.
 
Anguish and Fury
 The vivid details of Professor Hill's account and the raw anguish of Judge Thomas's defense at times left spectators gasping.
Who could have imagined just a few days ago that a quiet Baptist woman would be in the Senate chamber and on national television describing conversations about pubic hair or penis size? Who could have imagined a Supreme Court nominee alternately on the edge of tears and trembling with fury as he described the anguish he and his family have suffered?
Was it possible, television viewers asked each other, that Judge Thomas could have done or said even half the things that Professor Hill accused him of without understanding that he crossed some boundary between repartee and abuse? Or alternatively, was it possible that she could have some political agenda or emotional disturbance that would lead to such carefully crafted lies?
"It's still his word against hers," said Floyd Stevenson, a barber at the Hyde Park Hair Salon in Chicago. "But I'd say Judge Thomas has a problem because of the graphic detail she is providing."

 
 
Which One to Believe?
 Many people watching the hearings were struck by the impossible task of knowing for sure whom to believe when two unshakable witnesses tell diametrically opposed stories, which is often the case with sexual harassment claims.
"That's what's so problematic about this stuff," said Karen Seal, a medical student at Stanford, where the campus was rocked a few months back by the resignation and subsequent return of a prominent female neurosurgeon who charged she had endured 25 years of subtle and not-so-subtle sexism. "Each person sounds so believable. How do human beings judge?"
Many viewers were saddened by the belief that Professor Hill and Judge Thomas, both individuals of good reputation and credentials, would emerge scarred from these hearings, whatever the resolution.
"It's incredibly sad," said Jill Kasle, a professor of public administration at George Washington University in the nation's capital, where people were so preoccupied by the hearings that lunch dates were forgotten and the streets were almost deserted at midday. "Everybody is in an impossible position."
 
'It's Unfortunate for Both'
 The same sentiment was heard at a YMCA in Greenwich, Conn., where a television just off the lobby acted like a magnet for employees and patrons alike. "I think it's unfortunate for both sides," said Beth Finger, a YMCA trustee. "They're both very sympathetic and tragic figures."
Many people said that the ragged and ruthless process of confirming Supreme Court nominees, or electing presidents, for that matter, was to blame for incalculable suffering.
"None of us could pass the scrutiny they go through," said Bill Jenkins, an engineer on the Stanford campus, who completed his tasks yesterday with radio headphones firmly on his head. "This dirty linen stuff -- that's one of the reasons I would not want to go into politics."
The process could get even dicier now, some people said. In recent years, candidates for appointed or elective posts have been pilloried for sexual liaisons and drug use and now, conceivably, another moral litmus test has been added to a growing list.
"Sexual harassment is so pervasive, but nobody asked about that before," said Whitney Carrico, another Stanford medical student. "Many people could be held accountable for this. Who's going to be the next appointment? He could be accused of the same thing."
 
Captivating Audiences
 From Clarence Thomas's hometown of Pin Point, Ga., to Morris, Okla., where Anita Hill's family still lives on the farm where she grew up, and even to the Supreme Court itself, televisions tuned to the hearings captivated audiences. The Justices of the Supreme Court, who attended their regular closed-door Friday morning conference, missed the opening hours of the Senate hearing, but the sounds of the hearing were audible in the corridors behind their conference room, emanating from the television sets and radios of their law clerks and secretaries.
Certain viewers had special agendas as they watched the hearings. Women, who seemed to feel they had the most at stake, said that listening to Professor Hill's account of unwanted advances and offensive conversation stirred memories of their own unpleasant experiences in the workplace. And, by and large, they had no trouble understanding her decision not to confront Judge Thomas when he was her supervisor a decade ago.
"It was simple economic viability," said Rae Amey, the director of development for a nonprofit organization in Santa Monica, Calif. "You can't make men understand. They just don't grasp the issue."
Men, for their part, talked of their confusion and concern trying to figure out how to behave in a shifting social climate. "I'm scared to say anything," said Luke Fichthorn, a college student who was interviewed by The Associated Press in a New York City bar.
"You make lewd comments now and then; everybody does," Mr. Fichthorn continued, noting that a lot of male-female repartee could be misconstrued if taken out of context. "I feel sorry for Judge Thomas. I know, in his position, he should be very careful. But nobody's perfect."
Many viewers asked themselves and their friends if workplace relationships between men and women will ever be the same.
 
Smelling a Conspiracy
 For some black Americans, the charges against Judge Thomas, even though leveled by a black women, smelled like a conspiracy, perhaps by Democrats and perhaps by Republicans, to keep a black man off the Supreme Court.
"Anita Hill shouldn't make a mistake and the women's groups shouldn't make a mistake," said Tracey Boykin, a Chicago social worker who was getting her hair done and watching television at the Hyde Park Hair Salon. "This is about politics. The big boys in power don't give a damn. They're just using her."
The owner of the salon, John T. Tolbert, had another theory: President Bush had somehow set up his own nominee for disgrace. "I think Bush could be having a change of heart about having a black man in such an important position," Mr. Tolbert said. "This was a great opportunity to back out of the deal and still look good."
In addition to specific concerns, confusions and questions about Judge Thomas, Professor Hill and a messy political process, many people yesterday looked forward to the rewards that might come from a frank, public discussion of sexism in the workplace.
At the Stanford Medical School, that discussion was joined last June when Dr. Frances K. Conley resigned her post after condemning the way men treated women in the hierarchical world of academic medicine.
Dr. Conley has since rejoined the faculty, citing progress by the school's administration in addessing issues of sexism. And students said yesterday said that their professors, jolted by the reaction on campus and across the nation, have changed their behavior in ways great and small.
Typical is one faculty member notorious for using offensive slides in his lectures, without understanding the distress among female students. The slides are gone now, and his door is open to female students.
"Now we can talk on a humane level," said Whitney Carrico, the medical student. "And that has happened with somebody we thought was recalcitrant."
