HEADLINE: Angry Dinkins Defends Travel To South Africa

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
In an impassioned and often angry speech yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins painstakingly detailed his reasons for going to South Africa, saying he hoped to forge an economic partnership with leaders he believes will lead the country after apartheid falls.
"I'm going in November," the Mayor declared at a meeting of the City Club, a civic group. "I'm going in a rowboat if I have to. I'm going to South Africa. No doubt about it." 
 In often prickly tones, the Mayor chided critics who have questioned the need for the trip and the size of the delegation. He asserted that his detractors were ignorant of both the potential economic benefits New York City could reap and the influence the city could have in helping end the racist system.
"Under a democratic South African Government, an enormous amount of business will flow through New York," the Mayor said. "And, as Nelson Mandela said during his visit here to New York City last year, the A.N.C. will remember those who stood by them." The A.N.C. is the African National Congress, the leading opposition group led by Mr. Mandela.
 
Like a Schoolteacher's Scolding
 Mayoral aides said Mr. Dinkins has been extremely annoyed by the attention reporters focused on the scuttled trip and the criticism of his administration's way of doing business. Yesterday's speech was a clear attempt to counter that criticism and outline what Mr. Dinkins said he believes are the important reasons for going.
The Mayor was embarrassed last month by the collapse of his initial ambitious plan to charter a jet to South Africa and take more than three dozen city officials, business leaders and friends. That trip was postponed and eventually scaled back because his top aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, was too busy working to calm racial violence in Crown Heights to raise $500,000 in private money for the trip.
Since then, the fund raising -- done by the same city-controlled nonprofit organization that has raised money for events like the parade in June honoring Persian Gulf war veterans -- has drawn fire from some civic groups that questioned whether the contributors might have done business with the city.
At times using the scolding tones of a schoolteacher, the Mayor spoke angrily of the deprivation in black townships and the laws that continue to discriminate against blacks.
 
'Isn't It Sad?'
 He said New Yorkers were uninformed about conditions in the country, and pointed to an article in The New York Times Travel section that, he said, "actually suggested that the biggest obstacle confronting an American tourist visiting South Africa today is not the terrible truths that have resulted from apartheid, but the high cost of a ticket to get there."
The Mayor then broke from his prepared text, saying: "I know that if the whales were endangered tomorrow, that the world would be organized in righteous protest, and perhaps properly so. Isn't it sad that these kinds of conditions can go on and on for so long -- and yet here we are perhaps on the eve of the ability to recognize a breakthrough -- and too few people seem to understand?"
Underlying the speech, mayoral aides said, was Mr. Dinkins's frustration at his seeming inability to communicate to the public that the trip would be more than ceremonial and that he was deeply committed to doing what he could to end apartheid.
"He feels this trip has not been understood," Mr. Lynch. "People got the impression this was a kind of junket. And it's not."
 
'A Double Standard?'
 The Mayor's aides said he has felt unfairly singled out by critics. Some prominent blacks have gone so far as to say publicly that Mr. Dinkins's trip is being scrutinized more harshly because he is black.
"There is room to point to a double standard," said the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church. "In my memory they have not been as critical of others who have gone to other places."
Yesterday Mr. Dinkins took pains to point out that his trip was no different from those made by other politicians that drew less criticism. He mentioned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's trip to Italy in 1984, trips by Mayors Edward I. Koch and Abraham D. Beame to Israel and even a trip Mayor John V. Lindsay took to Britain.
"It is also a personal voyage for me," he said. "I will be returning to the continent of my ancestors for the first time. And to travel back to one's homeland and offer support to people who suffer personal misery is, I believe, a profound singular experience and one that is uniquely American."

HEADLINE: Organizing for Visas: Irish, Lottery and Luck

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
In the shadow world of the more than 30,000 Irish living illegally in New York City, this weekend has become a symbol of their hopes and dreams.
It is the culmination of a maddening but strangely coordinated frenzy of millions of mailings, their one chance to leap overnight from a barely visible realm into an established world, part of the largest legal migration of the Irish since 1965. 
 Only 16,000 citizens of the Republic of Ireland can win a coveted residence visa this year. But over the last couple of weeks, Irish people living illegally in New York -- nearly a third of the 100,000 Irish thought to be living illegally in the United States -- have come out of their gray world, gathering in pubs and organized seminars to study every possible angle to reduce the random nature of the Government lottery. In fact, the Irish have organized so extensively that they have also become the leading experts for many of the citizens of the 34 other countries that are participating in the lottery.
For most, the permanent residence visa, which allows immigrants to work and live in this country legally, will lift them out of a world ruled by fear of deportation, paranoia and insecurity.
"This is the opportunity of a lifetime," said Moira Philbin, 26, who has been working illegally under an assumed name, jumping from job to job, for the last three years. She has worked without health insurance and any other benefits. "I want to get on with my life, go to school, get a good job. I'm so, so hopeful. If I don't get it, I'll be a basket case." If she does not win, she said, she is not sure if she will have the courage to apply again in next year's lottery.
For the Irish, one of the largest groups of illegal immigrants in the city, this fight for legitimacy has taken on added significance. "There has been terrific networking, and it has given them a new sense of security," said Adrian Flannelly, who is the host of an Irish radio program and has helped organize the preparation campaign.
On Monday beginning at 12:01 A.M. the people who mailed the first 40,000 letters deposited by postal workers in a cage in a post office in Merrifield, Va., will qualify to become permanent resident aliens. Any letters deposited before 12:01 A.M. Monday will be discarded. As many as 5 million pieces of mail are expected to arrive at the post office in suburban Washington between 12:01 A.M. and the Oct. 19 deadline for receiving such letters.
Among the factors expected to determine which of the 5 million pieces will be among the prized first 40,000 is pure luck. For example, a postal truck delivering these letters may run a few minutes late or a mail sorter may pause in his work. To increase their chances of winning, applicants are mailing hundreds of applications each.
An additional 10,000 envelopes will be picked and held as a reserve in case some of the first 40,000 are disqualified because of things like having a criminal record, carrying the AIDS virus, having syphilis or active tuberculosis.
This unusual lottery system for obtaining permanent resident visas is being conducted by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service and is a result of a 1990 law that gives preference to European countries to compensate for the preference given Latin Americans and Asians in the last 26 years. It guarantees the Irish at least 40 percent of the places. Most of the Irish who will win the lottery are already in the United States, Irish-Americans say.
 
Fear of Deportation
 In this new visa program, the Irish are guaranteed 48,000 resident alien permits over the next three years and the lottery will become a permanent annual feature.
Although critics describe the lottery as a disguised amnesty for the illegal immigrants from the Republic of Ireland, its supporters say that it is merely addressing years of discrimination against Irish immigrants and that its main goal is to legalize the Irish already in the United States.
"The impact is unbelievable," said Sean Benson, director of the Emerald Isle Immigration Center in Woodside, Queens. "Many have been invisible for four or five years. It's a real coming-out session."
And it has also pulled the community together. While in the past the new Irish rarely even admitted to their friends that they were illegally working, the new social pastime at the hundreds of Irish pubs throughout the city has been licking scores of envelopes and stamps for the applications. Lottery announcements have been plastered on the doors of Irish pubs and delicatessens.
Since their first wave of immigration more than 200 years ago, the Irish have consistently flowed into America. The large Irish communities in the city are in Woodside and Sunnyside in Queens and around Bainbridge Avenue in the north Bronx. Most of the illegal community here in the city came after 1965, when immigration laws became much stricter, and they reflect a very different Ireland. The two communities -- the one with the brogue and the one without -- while supportive of each other, are also separated by a cultural and generational gap.
"The younger Irish think the older ones have an antiquated view of Ireland," Ms. Philbin said. "They idealize Ireland in a way we don't."
While the older generation is much more nationalistic, the younger arrivals view themselves as part of an integrated European community. The majority of the new Irish are young and single, escaping a collapsing economy in Ireland with 20 percent unemployment.
 
Careers and Visits
 A survey taken by the Irish Immigration Reform Movement shows that the new arrivals come from all parts of Ireland, many from rural backgrounds and that most have completed a high school education. They enter the country on tourist or student visas and then never leave, taking tough jobs for which they are frequently overqualified and over-educated, often as nannies, maids, bar and restaurant employees and construction workers. For most of the women, legality has come to symbolize career advancement. For the men, it meant finally being able to go back home for visits.
Despite their differences, there has always been a tremendous wave of sympathy and support among the established Irish here for their younger counterparts. Under the premise that the key to winning is sending in an application letter that will be part of the first batch to be selected, local Irish newspapers, radio stations, immigration centers as well as the Catholic Archdiocese have set up more than 18 seminars in the city to discuss how, when and where to mail application letters as well as how to prepare for the I.N.S. interview that will follow the winning of the lottery.
To increase their chances, most people are mailing 500 to 1,000 application letters each, staggering the mailing over several days and mailing in different areas of New York as well as taking letters directly to Virginia. A three-day mail strike in Ireland has increased the chances for those already in the United States. The Irish Voice, Adrian Flannelly and scores of other organizations are trucking down hundreds of thousands of letters to Virginia.
On a recent evening in Manhattan, more than 400 people gathered at a seminar sponsored by The Irish Voice. The majority were Irish, but there were English and Dutch and Poles and Italians as well. For all, a resident alien permit was the unattainable dream finally at their fingertips. Even if legalization meant a stricter payment of taxes -- that was fine, too, they said.
It was a room full of hope.
One woman who has been working here on a student visa for more than a year, would identify herself only Susan McK., 24 years old, from Dublin. Winning, she said, for her meant an end to exploitation. As a waitress, she has survived without a salary, merely on tips for more than eight months. "My other choices are nannying and I'm not really into child care," she said. "I want to continue my postgraduate work in art here."
Ms. Philbin is counting the hours for the letter that will tell her she won. "I feel like my 300 letters will be lost among the 5 million. I want it so badly. I'll be the first person greeting the postman every morning."

HEADLINE: Bush Vetoes Extended Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
President Bush today vetoed a $6.5 billion bill that would have provided as many as 20 additional weeks of unemployment benefits for 3 million people who have been out of work more than half a year. The President said the measure would damage the economic recovery by abandoning budget discipline.
 Mr. Bush's 23d veto was accompanied by a message intended to blunt the political issue the Democrats have made out of his opposition to this bill and a similar measure that he killed in August. He said his Administration was "deeply concerned about the needs of the unemployed and their families." Mr. Bush added that if a "responsible" bill were passed that did not violate last year's budget agreement, he would sign it immediately. 
 But he did not seek to draw attention to his action today. The veto, which was threatened before Congress passed the bill last week, was announced while much of the nation's attention was concentrated on televised hearings concerning Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court. The President had until Oct. 19 to act.
 
Little Hope for Override
 None of Mr. Bush's vetoes haves been overridden. The Democrats who pushed this bill are not optimistic about overriding this one, for they would have to persuade two of the 35 Senate Republicans who opposed it last week to change their votes to do so. The 65-to-35 vote there was short of the two-thirds majority required under the Constitution to override, although the 300-to-118 margin in the House exceeded it comfortably.
 The Senate will take an override vote next week, said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, who complained that with the veto, "President Bush has once again demonstrated that he is more willing to assist those abroad than Americans here at home." As evidence of that attitude, he cited Mr. Bush's willingness to issue emergency declarations under last year's budget act in order to help Kurds, Turks and Israelis.
 This measure would be financed by declaring an emergency and increasing the deficit by its cost. Mr. Bush was able to kill a similar measure in August without a veto because it was drafted in a way that allowed him to sign it first and then refuse to declare the emergency. The bill he vetoed today already included a declaration of emergency, so he had to veto it to kill it.
 The Democrats' interest in making a political issue out of unemployment was reflected not only in Mr. Mitchell's language, but also in the announcement by Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, that his organization was running radio and television advertisements in the districts of House Republicans who opposed the bill. Mr. Fazio said it was cynical for the veto to be issued during the Thomas hearing.
 But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, said the veto would force the Democrats to choose between real extended benefits for the jobless "or just political benefits at the expense of unemployed Americans."
 He said the Democrats could choose between two cheaper measures, with shorter periods of extended benefits, which Mr. Bush would sign. One is his own and the other is offered by Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota. Both would be paid for by extending a tax law procedure for using the Internal Revenue Service to collect defaulted student loans and by auctioning off unused radio frequencies.
 
Costs of 2 Alternatives
 The Durenberger bill would cost $3.9 billion and provide as many as 15 weeks of extended benefits for workers whose regular 26 weeks have run out. The Dole bill would cost $3.3 billion and provide as many as 10 weeks of benefits in the states with the highest levels of unemployment plus special provisions to be made by the Secretary of Labor in pockets of very high unemployment.
 Democrats in both houses have been reluctant to move ahead with the plan of auctioning the radio frequencies, and some broadcasters have opposed the idea.
 In complaining about the veto today, Mr. Mitchell and other Democrats said there was about $8 billion in a Federal trust fund set up to pay extended benefits of as many as 13 weeks. But, although national unemployment was 6.7 percent in September and about 300,000 workers exhaust their benefits each month, the rules for paying benefits out of this fund are drawn so tightly that workers in no state are now eligible.
 The bill vetoed today by Mr. Bush would provide 20 weeks of additional benefits in states where the total unemployment rate over the previous six months averaged 8 percent or more, 13 weeks in states where the rate is 7 percent or more, and 7 weeks in all other states.
 The President complained about several elements of the Democratic bill today. He complained that its three tiers of extended benefit levels amounted to "a complex, cumbersome system." He said it "could slow reemployment and would result in benefit delays, payment inaccuracies and escalating administrative costs."
 He also complained that the Democratic bill, unlike existing law or the Dole or Durenberger measures, used a state's total unemployment as a standard. Current law and the Republican bills use the rate of unemployment among insured workers, who are about half of those employed.
 The Administration contends that the rate based on the insured is more accurately calculated and thus a more precise tool. The Democrats maintain that it does not reflect real conditions in a recession labor market, when a large number is unemployed, insured or not, makes it hard to find a job.
 But Mr. Bush's heaviest emphasis was on the budget argument. He said that enacting the bill "would signal the failure of budget discipline, which would have a negative effect on financial markets that could threaten economic recovery and lead to increased unemployment."

HEADLINE: March of the Mayors

BYLINE: By Osborn Elliott; Osborn Elliott, chairman of the Citizens Committee for New York City, is organizing a march on Washington in April.

 BODY:
Suddenly last summer, while no one was looking -- not even the press -- the mayors of America got mad.
Meeting at Hyannis, Mass., in August, leaders of the U.S. Conference of Mayors -- representing 1,000 cities -- voted to mount what they hope will be history's greatest march on Washington. It will be part protest against a Government the mayors think has betrayed them, and part celebration of the immeasurable contributions the cities make to our society. 
 Today there will be a trial run, as Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore leads his city in its own march on Washington. Mayor Schmoke hopes to rally more than 10,000 people, including a number who will actually walk the 40 miles from Baltimore to Washington.
The date chosen for the main march, April 11, 1992, is a Saturday in the middle of the Presidential primary season. The mayors plan to gather hundreds of thousands of people, in Washington and in cities around the country. Citing multiple crises in housing, health care, jobs and schools, they will be marching under the slogan, "Save Our Cities! Save Our Children!"
They are targeting those people and institutions they hold responsible for more than a decade of brutal cutbacks in Federal financing: a Democratic Congress, a Republican White House, an uncaring bureaucracy. The mayors want the march to be nonpartisan: in their view, both political parties have been responsible for the cuts in Federal aid.
It is not hard to understand why American mayors have become so angry.
Since the late 1970's, the portion of state and local budgets picked up by Washington has plummeted by one- third. For New York City, that has meant the loss of almost $25 billion in Federal money and $3 billion in the current fiscal year alone. That is about the size of the budget gap the city has painfully had to close.
Everywhere the cutbacks have had devastating effects. They extend to surrounding areas, to the suburbs, even to rural America -- all those places that suffer from crime, drugs, poverty and unemployment.
That's why the mayors expect their march to draw people from all segments of society. They are calling for civic groups to join the protest. They look for teachers and students and mothers and fathers to join hands, demanding delivery on all those promises of a better education. They expect church and labor leaders, bankers and businessmen, doctors and lawyers, artists and merchants, farmers and pharmacists -- in short, everyone who has a stake in the well-being of our cities -- to join the march.
For years, our leaders have shown their disregard for the cities. They seem to be saying that's not where the votes are. But the mayors argue against this. They point to polls suggesting that Americans think of the cities as the engines of our society. Indeed, a survey by Louis Harris last summer showed that 77 percent of Americans believe this country cannot survive unless the problems of its cities are solved.
That gives the mayors reason to hope that their protests, today's and the march scheduled for April, will be instrumental in focusing the nation's attention on its pressing domestic problems once again.

HEADLINE: Miyazawa Gets Party Approval to Lead Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Kiichi Miyazawa, a stalwart of Japan's governing party and one of the architects of the country's postwar economic ascent, was virtually assured election as the next Japanese prime minister tonight, ending a bruising weeklong scramble for the leadership.
Mr. Miyazawa, an urbane 72-year-old politician who has held virtually every key political post in Japan except prime minister, was endorsed this evening by the largest and wealthiest faction in the Liberal Democratic Party, controlled by former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita. 
 At a news conference earlier in the day, Mr. Miyazawa said he expected no significant changes in Japan's relations with Washington, where he has been a well-known and influential player in Japanese-American relations for more than two decades.
 
'The Same Values'
 "We have the same values," he said of Japan and the United States. "If we have something to complain about to each other, we should do so frankly."
It was the Takeshita faction that withdrew its support from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu a week ago, forcing him to abandon his hopes of seeking a second term. Political analysts said they expected Mr. Miyazawa, a far more senior member of the party and a leader of a major faction, to hold somewhat more independent sway over the conduct of the Government than did Mr. Kaifu, who was widely viewed as a weak leader entirely dependent on the good graces of Mr. Takeshita and his aging ally in the governing party, Shin Kanemaru.
For Mr. Miyazawa, known as one of the party's keenest minds and one of its most fluent English speakers, the endorsement today completes a stunning political turnaround. Less than three years ago, he was forced to step down as Finance Minister when he was implicated in the Recruit scandal, a stock-and-influence peddling scheme that later also led to the resignation of Mr. Takeshita.
It was the Recruit scandal that brought Mr. Kaifu to office, with his promise of political reforms that would rid Japan of "money politics" and the perpetual struggle among party factions that emphasize power relationships over ideas or ideology.
But the political reform bill on which Mr. Kaifu staked his premiership failed, precipitating the swift end of his tenure. The events of the last week, in which a small cadre of behind-the-scenes players have chosen a new prime minister, suggest that the scandal ultimately brought about little lasting change.
Technically, the position for which Mr. Miyazawa was endorsed is president of the Ruling Liberal Democratic party. But ever since the party took control of the nation more than three decades ago, its president has automatically become the prime minister.
 
Rival Assails Process
 One of Mr. Miyazawa's two main rivals for the party presidency, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, criticized the secretive selection process.
"Some people may think that the presidential election is now over, but others wonder how the party's 1.75 million rank and file members feel," Mr. Mitsuzuka said. "A public election should be held so that we can seek the support of the people in competitive balloting. I am ready for the election. I will not budge."
Mr. Miyazawa's other key rival for the job, Michio Watanabe, also said he would stay in the race, though neither man has much chance of winning.
Overall, there has been little public criticism of the fact that Japan's new leader is once again being chosen behind closed doors, amid the promises of the jobs and patronage that have always cemented temporary alliances among the five main factions.
In fact, the Japanese public seemed in a curious way to enjoy the drama of the last week, with plots and maneuvering that rivaled anything performed in kabuki theater. With almost no differences in philosophy or national policy at stake, many Japanese say, a Western-style nationwide vote or greater public participation in the process would accomplish little.
If all goes as the party expects, Mr. Miyazawa will take office when Mr. Kaifu's term ends on Oct. 30. Mr. Miyazawa comes to power at a moment of considerable challenge for Japan, which is struggling to resolve a territorial dispute with the Soviet Union that has blocked full relations, contain a ballooning trade deficit with the United States and define its role in Asia, where it is often courted as an investor but mistrusted as a neighbor.
Mr. Miyazawa will also have to navigate two of the most delicate international decisions facing Japan in the next few months: how to contribute to United Nations peacekeeping forces and whether to open up its highly protected rice market to imports.
"I am very humbled," he told his supporters tonight, using the modest words expected of winners in Japanese society. "I do not believe I am worthy of the honor."
The endorsement of Mr. Miyazawa seems to reflect the party's sense that, with the passage of time, the principals in the Recruit scandal have been rehabilitated and can once again openly share in the Government's top posts. But Mr. Miyazawa was careful to say that his top priority would be passage of a political reform bill, exactly what Mr. Kaifu failed to accomplish.
The endorsement capped several days of frantic politicking within the governing party as Mr. Miyazawa, Mr. Watanabe and Mr. Mitsuzuka, scrambled to seek support.
Mr. Watanabe, a tough political infighter, is believed to have been passed over in part because of derogatory comments he made several years ago about American blacks. Mr. Mitsuzuka has only narrow support in the party, where he has taken over the leadership of the faction formerly headed by Shintaro Abe, who died this year.
American and European diplomats seemed pleased by the choice of Mr. Miyazawa. "He's been in touch with American leadership for 20 years, and he is well-known and respected," a senior American diplomat here said. "And he is a very engaging man."
Mr. Miyazawa joined Japan's Ministry of Finance during the war. After Japan's defeat, he used his English skills to negotiate with the occupation forces. In 1949 he became the political secretary to Hayato Ikeda, later a Prime Minister.
He ran later for Parliament and began serving in the 1960's in a succession of top jobs. As Minister of International Trade and Industry, one of Japan's most sensitive posts, he tacked the textile trade disputes with the United States, the forerunner to a series of economic clashes that would grow more heated every year. From 1974 to 1976 he served as Foreign Minister.

HEADLINE: What's Wrong With Tolls on East River Bridges? Plenty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tolls on New York City's East River bridges, a bad idea when first proposed decades ago, hasn't improved with age ("What's Fair Is a Fare," Op-Ed, Sept. 28). 
 When the idea was last floated, studies showed it would only cut discretionary traffic to Manhattan, basically shopping and entertainment trips, while the other side of the bridges would have an increase in air pollution of as much as 400 percent. This could doom development of downtown Brooklyn's new backoffice complex.
New technology might reduce the backups, but there will always be a need for several tollbooths for each bridge for drivers who do not regularly travel to Manhattan and lack the high-tech panacea on which toll proponents now rely.
Tolling the East River bridges is also bad public policy.
Tolls would shift the maintenance cost of the city's 877 bridges to the users of only a dozen routes and at the same time divide the city, sending a message that Manhattan is accessible only to the affluent.
The tolls proposal is an admission that the city has lacked the political will to maintain its infrastructure, even in years of budget surpluses.
New York can devote sufficient resources to its transportation infrastructure without tolls. Instead of supporting this ill-conceived notion, I urge a commitment by the city's leaders to our long-term maintenance needs.
 
KENNETH K. FISHER
Member of City Council, 29th Dist., Brooklyn
Brooklyn, Oct. 1, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy 
Retail sales rose 0.7 percent last month, the Commerce Dept. reported. Those sales include everything from groceries and gas to autos and appliances. The rise was more than most economists had expected, but the report did not portray a strong or sustained pickup in spending. [Page 41.]
 The banking overhaul legislation in Congress has bogged down in a tussle of powerful egos among House Democrats. Personalities and politicking may overtake any substantive airing of the issues. News analysis. [42.]
 Prices at the producer level rose a slim 0.1 percent in September, the Labor Dept. said, suggesting that inflation remained under control. A drop in food prices helped keep a lid on prices. [42.]
 Bush vetoed a bill that would have provided up to 20 weeks of unemployment benefits. [6.]
 
Companies
 An investment partnership headed by William E. Simon said it had sold HonFed Bank, Hawaii's largest savings institution, to BankAmerica. [41.]
 I.B.M. says it will not meet its end-of-the-year goal for shipping a new version of its personal computer operating system. [41.]
 The bidding for Executive Life closed out with a sweetened offer from a French consortium and seven other proposals. [41.]
 Forstmann Little and Whittle Communications discontinued talks on a deal in which Forstmann would have invested $350 million in Whittle in exchange for a one-third stake. [41.]
 Young & Rubicam New York lost its Camel cigarette account, with an estimated $30 million in annual advertising spending, to an agency being started by two former employees. [43.]
 United Technologies said it would cut about 25 percent of its 1,000-member corporate staff, becoming the third top industrial company in a week to announce job cuts. [43.]
 
International
 To try to head off phone disruptions worldwide, a group of the largest telephone companies agreed at a meeting on a procedure to issue alerts to keep problems with new, sophisticated equipment that can break down in a split second from spreading beyond national boundaries. [45.]
 Russia and most Soviet republics announced their commitment to forming a new economic community devoted to free-market resuscitation of the nation. [1.]
 Kiichi Miyazawa, one of the architects of Japan's postwar economic ascent, was virtually assured election as the next prime minister. [1.]
 Since Communism fell, Poland has become a haven for the piracy of cassette tapes, and industry experts say it is now a leading worldwide producer of counterfeit tapes. [41.]
 
Markets
 Stock prices rose modestly, but trading was light as many investors held back, concerned with corporate results. The Dow closed at 2,983.68, up 7.16 for the day and 21.92 for the week. [44.]
 Credit markets rallied sharply, prompted by a favorable report on inflation, pushing interest rates down. [44.]
 Soybean futures prices were battered as the market adjusted to prospects of a huge crop in the fields. [49.] The dollar settled broadly lower. [49.]

 With employers increasingly adopting flexible benefit plans, many of which require re-enrollment in the fourth quarter, millions of Americans face important choices. Your Money. [42.]
 Two new ways to use fiber optics to make security systems that can spot intruders, sniff smoke or detect dangerous chemicals have been patented by a small California company. Patents. [42.]

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Cuomo Utters a 'Maybe' But Hastens to Add 'Not'

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told a group of supporters at a private meeting yesterday that he was thinking about running for President, and then spent the rest of the day insisting that he had not said anything that anyone should be interested in.
 Thus Mr. Cuomo set off another round of the now familiar guessing game, "Will he or won't he?" Mr. Cuomo, who has steadfastly insisted that he has no plans to run for President and no plans to make plans, was now raising the possibility that he was planning to make some. 
The confusion began at breakfast.
 Cuomo supporters who attended a morning meeting with him in Manhattan say he told them that he was considering running for President.
 But at a news conference later in the day, after word of his ruminations had leaked out to The Associated Press, Mr. Cuomo insisted that he had made the remarks only to placate contributors who were pressing him on the subject.
 "They said, 'Will you think about it?' " he said. "I said, 'Sure, I'll think about it. I'm always thinking about it.' I said I'd have to be mindless not to think about it. I don't talk about it, but I think about it. Of course I do."
 The events of the day were reminiscent of the Governor's long flirtation with a presidential candidacy four years ago, when he often seemed to be encouraging speculation only to express irritation later with those who did speculate.
 But it was unclear yesterday whether the Governor was simply trying to reinvigorate his national image or whether he had truly shifted his public position and was seriously considering the 1992 campaign.
 
Starting to Believe Him
 With five candidates already vying for the Democratic nomination, and with the first primary just four months away, even many of the Governor's supporters had finally started to believe his protestations that he had no plans to run.
 Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee and a friend of the Governor's, told reporters at a breakfast meeting on Thursday that he did not know whether Mr. Cuomo would run.
 But he added, "I take him at his word ---- that he has no plans to run and no plans to plan."
 In the last few weeks, as interest has shifted to the declared candidates, Mr. Cuomo has complained that news organizations have ignored his message about the economy and the state of the country because they are interested in him only as a potential presidential contender.
 Apparently to regain press attention, the Governor's aides have sent out mixed signals about Mr. Cuomo's intentions, much to the dismay of candidates already in the race. At a meeting in Los Angeles last month, John Marino, the chairman of New York's Democratic Party and a close associate of the Governor, told members of the Democratic National Committee that Mr. Cuomo had until November to get into the race. That remark set off a spate of rumors that Mr. Cuomo would run.
 Any hint that Mr. Cuomo may run is likely to make it more difficult for the declared candidates to muster money and supporters. Yesterday, some Democrats expressed irritation at Mr. Cuomo's shifting signals.
George Bruno, a Democratic National Committee member from New Hampshire who supports the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, said this afternoon: "You can't be the reluctant maiden for year after year and then expect to jump into the process in midstream. The time is really past when candidates should be thinking about whether to get in. The time is at hand to either do it or not do it."
 
'Wholly Different Attitude'
 Mr. Cuomo has been toying for so long with the idea of running for President that many of his supporters are inured to his circumlocutions on the subject. But several people who attended the breakfast at the Regency hotel, at Park Avenue and 61st Street, said they had been struck by the forcefulness with which Mr. Cuomo discussed his plans to explore a Presidential race.
 They said that the Governor had brought up the topic himself, and had said that it was time for him to make a decision about the 1992 race.
 "It was a wholly different attitude about running for the presidency," said Peter Tufo, chairman of the State Thruway Authority and a guest at the breakfast. "What really struck you, it sounded as though he was giving it serious consideration."
 Howard Rubenstein, a public relations executive who has been a major contributor to Mr. Cuomo's campaigns, said: "He said he would think over the next few weeks about what he would do concerning running for President. He also said he was leaning in the direction of not running, although listening to him you could get the sense that he was running."
 Word of the Governor's remarks at the breakfast, which was closed to the press, reached reporters almost immediately, and a flock of television cameras greeted Mr. Cuomo when he arrived at a midtown Manhattan event to promote volunteerism.
 The Governor maintained that he was shocked to learn that his remarks had created such a stir. He insisted that he had discussed the Presidential race only in response to questions at the breakfast -- an account contradicted by several people who were there -- and that he had said he would think about a race only to avoid disappointing his supporters.
 The question that remained was, just what was the point to all this? Some politicians speculated that Mr. Cuomo, irked by a perception that his profile had diminished, was trying to attract national attention and deflect attention from the problems at home in New York.
 But others suggested that the Governor remarks meant he was genuinely considering a race. The reason he did not want to say this publicly, they speculated, was that if he eventually chose not to run, he would then have to explain why publicly.
 "This is not just dithering," one adviser to the Governor said. "He's really torn."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I don't talk about it, but I think about it," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, with his wife, Matilda, responding to questions yesterday about running for President. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Consumer Sales Post Rise of 0.7%

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
After holding back in August, consumers spent a bit more freely in September but not enough to change the sluggish economic outlook.
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales -- which include everything from groceries and gas to autos and appliances -- rose last month by a total of seven-tenths of 1 percent. 
That was more than most economists had expected. Still, the report did not portray a strong or sustained pickup in spending, and, as such, did little to calm fears that the economic recovery could fade this fall.
 
Lack of Enthusiasm
 "These are status quo consumption numbers," said Gail Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board.
 The September gain, which was largely accomplished by a jump in auto sales, merely made up for a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in August. And, outside of cars, spending was practically flat, up only one-tenth of 1 percent. That reflected a mix of more spending on household furnishings, food and gas, and less on clothes and drugstore items.
 Coming in tandem with a report that showed weak prices at the wholesale level, the retail sales report did lift hopes that the Federal Reserve would soon push short-term interest rates lower. "This leaves the door wide open," said Ed McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. [Page 42.]
 The bond market welcomed yesterday's economic news, driving long-term rates down. [Page 44.]
 
Hints in Advance
 Yesterday's report had already been foreshadowed by earlier reports of disappointing sales at department stores and some improvement in car sales, in part because of stepped-up auto purchases by businesses.
 All in all, economists interpreted the latest sales reports as evidence that consumer spending had risen fairly solidly in the summer, but, at best, would rise much more modestly this fall.
 "The report doesn't end the drama: Will they spend or won't they?" said Ed Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence
 The first official look at the economy's overall performance in the third quarter will be reported on Oct. 29. Based on the last three months of retail sales data, most economists estimate that consumer spending rose at an annual rate of 3 percent to 4 percent in the summer quarter, compared with a 2.5 percent rate in the second quarter.
 In light of that, and given that consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the economy, these economists also estimate that the gross national product grew at a 2 to 3 percent rate in the third quarter. To be sure, inventories, which appeared to decline at a slower pace than in the spring, are a wild card in the G.N.P. estimate.
 Taking the July, August and September data together, retail sales were about 2 percent higher than the average for the second quarter. And spending on services, like rent and medical care, has been climbing at around a 3 percent annual rate, said Kurt Karl, an economist at the WEFA Group. Services account for about half of household budgets.
 
An Early Rebound Fades
 The trouble is that all of the third quarter's strength came at the beginning of the period and subsequently faded. Car and light-truck sales, for instance, which had dropped to a 10.7 million annual rate in the depths of the recession, had climbed back to around a 12.9 million rate by July, but improved only slightly in September. That left sales no higher than in July.
 "The consumer did come out of the closet in the spring," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at the Connecticut National Bank. "The problem is that they ran straight into a jobless recovery."
 The economy has generated just 224,000 jobs since April. Many large companies as well as state and local governments continue to announce cost-cutting measures that include layoffs, and few executives expect the kind of rip-roaring job growth that followed the deep 1981-82 recession.
 "The growth in the economy has come mostly from rising productivity, not new jobs," Mr. Perna said.
 That has kept consumers who have held on to their jobs feeling anxious. Confidence surged in March after the Persian Gulf war ended but "has been moving sideways ever since," said Richard Curtin, director of the Consumer Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan.
 
Lacking the Cash
 And incomes, which have been inching up, have not recovered from the recession yet. On average, each American consumer lost about $450 in after-tax income in the recession and has recouped just $100 of that loss, according to David Kelly, an economist at Data Resources Inc. "The glass is just one-quarter full," he said.
 So far, consumers have been squeezing their savings, freeing up ready money by paying off debt, and benefiting from lower inflation. But spending cannot continue to climb much faster than income for long. So with job growth likely to stay anemic, Mr. Kelly said he expected consumer spending to rise at just a 2 percent rate in the fall.
 Yesterday's report from the Commerce Department is based on a survey of 3,000 retailers, compared with the 12,000 retailers who will be included in a final September sales report to be released a month from now. Revisions in monthly retail sales data, a senior official said, have averaged four-tenths of a percentage point during the last 12 months.

HEADLINE: ART;
From Quirky Little Gallery to Behemoth

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
To the art world, the name Getty usually means the acquisitive J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., whose high-profile purchases -- from ancient Greek sculptures to Van Gogh's "Irises" -- have made front-page headlines.
 But the museum is only one component -- albeit the most important one -- of the mighty J. Paul Getty Trust. Last year this $3.5 billion private foundation spent $149 million -- almost the entire budget of the National Endowment for the Arts -- on the museum and seven other programs, some of them hotly debated in their fields. 
 For all its ambitious reach, the nine-year-old trust has kept out of the public eye, its offices discreetly tucked away in anonymous-looking buildings around Los Angeles. But it will achieve a dramatic new presence in 1996 with the opening of the Getty Center, Richard Meier's cloisterlike campus in Brentwood, for which the model was unveiled last week.
 Though the trust still seems shadowy and remote compared to its glamorous offspring, its involvement with collecting, scholarship, education and conservation reflects the ideological wars of the art world, from multiculturalism to the split between curator-connoisseurs who view art in strictly esthetic terms and academics who see it in social and political contexts.
 Like any other spending colossus, the trust has provoked at least as many detractors as supplicants. Some complain of its Eurocentric bias and elitism, evidenced by the decision to disengage from heavily ethnic Los Angeles and place the new complex on an "acropolis" in the rarefied precincts of Brentwood. Others say that its largesse is still controlled by corporate standards of "success." And there are those, mainly in the museum field, who think that the Getty money should be funneled entirely to the museum, which could expand to take on all the programs.
 The Getty Center, the lavish architectural statement commissioned by the trust to bring the programs together, is obviously designed to give all of them -- including the museum -- equal prominence. But many people in the museum world feel that the programs are undeserving of the same monumental treatment accorded the museum, and have usurped space and money that should go to it.
 The key question is how well the trust is using its massive resources, a question that intensifies as the trust gains visibility.
 Harold M. Williams, president and chief executive officer of the trust, says the Getty's money frees it to undertake "creative, innovative projects," and to support ventures beyond the reach of most public and private institutions. Driven by these aims, the trust has created an arts-humanities study center, a conservation institute, a center for art education, a computerized battery of historical information, an art-on-film collaboration with the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a museum management institute. A grant program finances projects not initiated by the trust.
 The grant program, in fact, along with the conservation institute, are two of the Getty's best programs. The grant program is admired for its wide range and its skill at finding worthy projects, the conservation institute for its gung-ho attitude toward tough jobs and its willingness to take on new ones.
 The education program and the Center for the History of Art and the Humanities, on the other hand, are both in the thick of battles about the nature of art and how it should be taught. The center's critics accuse it of encouraging a babble of trendy ideas without establishing a clear direction. The education program has been attacked as being in thrall to a single formula that excludes other approaches.
 The trust that has hatched the programs is the only major foundation devoted entirely to the arts. Its enormous budget and its work force of 600 make it the behemoth of the country's 2,000 private foundations. Its spending habits are dictated by tax laws requiring that it use a minimum of 4.25 percent of its endowment for programs, with an additional three-quarter percent for outside grants.
 Such is the trust's power in the art world that it is almost impossible to escape its gravitational pull. "The difficulty in talking about the trust," said one museum official, who asked not to be named, "is that almost everyone has served on the Getty advisory committees or been a consultant -- a recipient of plane tickets, hotel suites, parties and so forth. In a way, we've all been bought."
 Such power was undreamed of -- as was the trust -- when J. Paul Getty died in 1976 and left an estate worth more than $1 billion to the quirky little gallery he had established in Malibu in 1953. Removed, shortly before his death, to a lavish reconstruction of a Herculaneum villa that he had built nearby, the gallery was still a rich man's treasury that was a long way from ripening into a public collection. But besides the museum, Getty's will mentioned a "library for the diffusion of artistic and general knowledge."
 Stunned by the fiscal Niagara, the trustees felt that it would swamp the small museum. Seizing on Getty's words, they approved a plan for a broader organization that would support scholarship, a library and other endeavors to enhance intellectual opportunities on the West Coast. It was the basis for the trust.
 
The Corporate Touch
 In 1981, the board named as head of the trust Mr. Williams, a brainy lawyer whose robust corporate career took a nonprofit turn when he became dean of the graduate school of management at U.C.L.A. and then chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He is credited with the agile engineering of the sale of the museum's stock in the Getty Oil Company, eventually to Texaco, that more than tripled the original $1.1 billion endowment.
 "When I came to the trust, I told my skeleton staff, 'I'm not interested in what you or I think should be done," said Mr. Williams during a recent interview in his sumptuously understated office in West Los Angeles. "Get out there and get a sense of the field. What can we do that might not otherwise happen?" Based partly on the answers he got, Mr. Williams developed the trust's programs.
 Some critics feel that his corporate background has shaped the way the trust functions. George Marcus, a cultural anthropologist teaching at Rice University who was a visiting scholar at the trust in 1988, wrote in the magazine Cultural Anthropology: "There is an obsession with evaluation and assessment, a constant judging of the operation. Elaborate consultation occurs before any move or decision is made." In an interview, he added, "There is a sense of Harold Williams as a manager rather than a leader with a farsighted vision."
 Mr. Williams replies: "This is a complex organization, and you can't have each of the programs going off on its own. Also, I do believe in holding people accountable, just as I hold myself accountable. It is not true at all that we think quantifiably; everything we do has to be judged qualitatively by what it is and what it does. If we're spending $149 million, we have to work hard at whether we're spending it in the best way."
 But the trust's effectiveness can only be measured in terms of how well its programs succeed, and predictably, the reviews are mixed.
 One program that is counted a success is the conservation institute. Now headed by Miguel Angel Corzo, an educator and a former official of the Mexican Government, the institute employs 84 people and last year had an operating budget of around $10 million. In and out of its laboratories, 20 scientists pursue some 30 research projects, including the problem of bacterial growth in Egyptian royal mummies; the weathering process of adobe, the effects of indoor pollution in museums, and the damage wrought by earthquakes.
 
A Taste for Showy Third-World Projects?
 The institute also sends its people to work on such immovable properties as the Great Sphinx at Giza, on whose back Getty scientists have installed a monitoring station to register environmental effects. As the largest private body with such a heroic agenda, the Getty conservation institute is unique in the field. Even this program has its naysayers, however, who complain that the Getty emphasizes research over practice and pursues showy third-world projects.
 "We are in the business of research and training, not a conservation service organization," said Mr. Corzo. "We work with others to help arrive at solutions. And to the extent we take on these so-called showy third-world projects, we do it because no one else does anything about them."
 Dealing in the less tangible realm of ideas is the Center for the History of Art and the Humanities, headed by Kurt Forster, a provocative Swiss-born architectural historian who believes that "a work of art is too important to be left to art historians.
 "We should do everything we can to bring as many diverse perspectives as possible," he said. To that end, the center invites up to 12 scholars for an academic year of residence, joined for shorter periods by visiting scholars. Their work covers many fields besides art history: musicology, cultural anthropology, film history, comparative literature, psychology. In 1990-91, topics ranged from contemporary European feminist art and film to the architectural theory of Quatremere de Quincy, the 18th-century French archeologist and critic. A library of more than 600,000 books and a photo archive of two million images are available, along with a vast collection of unpublished letters, manuscripts and the like.
 The center, more imbued with its director's personality than the other Getty programs, is a hotbed of theory, ideology and clashing views, which Dr. Forster sees as giving it "some of the quality and vitality of a genuine university setting." But some scholars say that of all the trust programs, the center is the most unfocused and incoherent, interested more in the turnover than the content of ideas.
 
Contradictory Agendas
 "The center doesn't quite know what it is yet," said James Marrow, an art historian at Princeton University, who has been on Getty committees and has worked at the art and humanities center. "Part of its problem is that it's trying to serve a lot of agendas -- not only traditional ones but those of the intellectual left wing of art history. There is a problem of establishing a clear-cut identity."
 Dr. Forster responds: "That we haven't established a clear-cut identity may be one of our greatest virtues. Instead of a monolith, the center is a marketplace of many ideas and views. We make every effort to kick open as many doors as possible."
 
Nitty-Gritty Accounting
 Some staff members and visiting scholars resent what they see as rigid economies and nitty-gritty accounting procedures at the center. "I felt very controlled the whole year I was there, yet there was an atmosphere of excess," said Mr. Marcus. "They don't understand what scholars do. They think we're parasitic, and inclined to take the organization for a ride, so we have to be watched." Yet, he added, "after all is said and done, no one else provides this kind of help and support for scholars, not even Princeton or Stanford."
 The Center for Education in the Arts finances the teaching of art to elementary-school children through a demanding approach called discipline-based art education. The method, which integrates the making of art in the classroom with art history, criticism and esthetics, has children in Getty-guided courses around the country discussing such things as positive and negative space in Picasso and Matisse. In making their own art, they are guided by historical and critical concepts.
 
'Reading' Works of Art
 "Discipline-based art education is providing an important alternative in teaching art to children," said Leilani Lattin Duke, director of the Getty's education program. "Change in education takes a long time, and we're amazed at how quickly it's captured the public imagination and teacher willingness to implement it."
 By entertaining other viewpoints, the center has begun to defuse criticism that the discipline-based method is too rigid and puts too much emphasis on "reading" works of art rather than allowing children to follow their own creative impulses.
 "Once you put critics, history and esthetics on an equal footing with art production, you make it into a verbal discipline," said Howard Gardner, professor of education at Harvard and co-director of Project Zero, an art education research center in Cambridge.
 "To support different approaches would be a more farsighted and flexible use of the funding than to endorse a method about which many have reservations." He said, however, that in the last few years, the Getty had made "good faith efforts to be more ecumenical."
 The important thing, as Mr. Williams sees it, is that the center has focused attention on the content of art education and raised the level of discussion and argument in the field. "That's at least half the battle," he said.
 
Competing Empires
 While still in its infancy, the trust has come a long way from the small museum that spawned it. For Harold Williams, getting the most for the Getty's money meant branching out into programs. "Part of the yeast of this place," he said, "is that it represents diverse points of view. There's a freedom in each of our activities that's very different from what it would be under the umbrella of the museum."
 But there are still those who say that the trust is dissipating its resources by not putting all its eggs -- its ambitious constellation of programs -- in one big basket, the museum. They point out that the great museums of this country -- the Metropolitan, the National Gallery, the Cleveland Museum of Art and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston -- carry on all or most of the programs that the trust has set up as separate entities. By absorbing them, the Getty itself could become a truly great museum, they say.
 "The trust's whole assumption about the role of the museum is that it is a sleepy cupboard," said Edmund P. Pillsbury, director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, who in the early 1980's turned down an offer to become director of the Getty. "But it can be a major research institution involved with a study center, publications, conservation and so forth. By creating independent agencies, the trust has made a whole series of competing empires, with problems of overlap, communication and different priorities. Their existence -- some with very outspoken points of view -- lowers the importance and role of the museum and gives the impression of a lack of effective leadership."
 But Mr. Williams counters: ""We'll continue to work toward building an outstanding museum, but given the magnitude of our resources, our responsibility was to do something more. Frankly, the trustees' feeling that we needed to go beyond a museum was what attracted me."
 As he envisioned the trust's new prominence in its grandiose quarters, Mr. Williams reflected on the Getty phenomenon: "We've grown faster than I expected and accomplished more. One of the real challenges we face is maintaining the ability to be self-critical."
 As government support for the arts dwindles, the Getty will be called upon to improve the art of spending its millions. There will no shortage of advice on how to do it.
 
 
 
FROM NEFERTARI TO DATABASES
 Besides the museum, the Getty Trust sponsors seven other programs. They are:
* The Grant Program. Designed to foster works of "exceptional merit" in the visual arts and humanities. Last year it supported projects ranging from a catalogue for a show of Chicano art to the conservation of Romanesque sculptures in a Hungarian cathedral.
* The Conservation Institute. Conducts art conservation projects around the world. A current project, in tandem with the Egyptian Government, is restoring wall paintings in the ancient tomb of Queen Nefertari.
* The Center for the History of Art and the Humanities. Furthers advanced research in the history of art through a scholar-in-residence program that emphasizes a cross-disciplinary approach intended to "rescue" art from art historians.
* The Center for Education in the Arts. Supports the teaching of art to children through a method known as discipline-based art education. In addition to making art, the children learn art history, criticism and esthetics.
* The Art History Information Program. Creates databases -- like a bilingual index of literature about Western art -- that give researchers computer access to a vast array of historical information.
* The Program for Art on Film. Attempts to improve the quality of film, video and television productions about art. A joint venture with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, it has set up a computerized inventory of information on art films and videotapes, and in 1989 and 1990 sponsored a production laboratory for innovative film and video projects.
* The Museum Management Institute. Provides a four-week course at the University of California at Berkeley to train museum professionals in leadership, management and business skills.
 
 
HIDDEN COSTS?
 The price of translating the long-planned Getty Center into brick and mortar, which officials now estimate at $360 million in "direct construction costs," has been a hot topic among Getty watchers. Speculation places the cost at between $500 million and $1 billion, which Getty officials dismiss as exaggeration. Not included in the $360 million estimate are costs for land acquisition, bonds, architectural fees and site preparation.
The crumbly hill that holds the center's 124-acre site has required extensive -- and expensive -- preparation. Even the freeway adjacent to the museum's parking garage has had to be buttressed with concrete.
To pay for the center, said Franklin D. Murphy, an influential Getty board member, a portion of the Getty's endowment was set aside several years ago and invested in high-yield securities. Earnings were plowed back into that segregated portion, which Mr. Murphy said has "grown substantially."
Mr. Murphy balked when figures higher than $500 million for the total cost were broached. "Those are beyond my ken," he said.
Asked if the Getty Trust's programs, including the museum's acquisitions budget, had been cut back to accommodate the building project, Mr. Murphy conceded that budgets had been "tightened up a bit," although he insisted that it was not because of the building program. The Getty had been spending too freely, he said. "We were shoveling the money out. The curators feel squeezed, but the museum's acquisitions budget is in excess of any other in the world. I've never seen a major picture come along that the Getty didn't go after."

HEADLINE: Private Schools Turn to Reconstruction

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
AFTER two years of living like academic nomads, the students and teachers of Nightingale-Bamford, a private girls' school on Manhattan's Upper East Side, are home again.
When the 1991-92 school year began last month, they returned to their 62-year-old, Georgian-styled schoolhouse at 20 East 92d Street after a $22 million expansion and renovation of the building. While the work was going on they held classes and ate lunch in 17 neighboring schools, churches, synagogues and community centers. 
 "We were trying to meet educational needs of the 20th and 21st century with a building from the 1920's and having a harder and harder time doing it," said Ann McChord, director of administration for the school, which has 475 students from kindergarten through grade 12. "To make the kinds of improvements we wanted, we had to leave the building. The work could not go on around us."
Nightingale-Bamford is not alone in its decision to put students and staff through the agonies of a reconstruction. By a rough count, New York City's private, or independent schools, as they prefer to be called, are spending more than $75 million on ongoing and recently completed improvement projects.
The Spence School, at 22 East 91st Street, spent $7.2 million on its expansion and upgrading and the Chapin School, at 100 East End Avenue, at 84th Street, spent $8 million. The Dalton School, which owns several buildings on the Upper East Side, this month began a campaign to raise $27 million for a new gymnasium and other capital improvements.
On the West Side, the Calhoun School three years ago bought a building at 160 West 74th Street from the defunct Baldwin League School and then put $7 million into renovating the building for its preschool, kindergarten and first grade.
In the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the Berkeley Carroll School expects to complete in January a $5 million renovation and expansion of its upper and middle school building on Lincoln Place.
All this construction activity has put the schools in the improbable role of real estate developers. Administrators, trustees and parent volunteers have found themselves struggling with zoning and planning issues, pleading their cases before community boards and working with architects, contractors and construction companies to see the projects through to completion. With a few exceptions the schools are not creating new space to expand enrollment, nor are they anticipating a rush of applicants. Rather, they are upgrading to meet the changing needs of their students and putting money into more sophisticated science laboratories, expanded room for computer studies, new gymnasiums, larger cafeterias and libraries and more spacious and comfortable work areas for teachers.
Competition for students plays a major role in the decision to modernize.
"The main point, of course," said Dr. Gardner Dunnan, headmaster of the Dalton School, "is to improve educational programs. But schools also want to be sure that their science, math and computer programs are up to the other institutions." He said that in analyzing its strengths and weaknesses, Dalton had found it was not as strong in math and science as in the humanities.
Mildred Berendsen, headmistress of the Chapin School, said that the improvements in the girls schools are one way that they can reaffirm their commitment to science, math and physical education studies for young women.
"They have always been important," she said, "but they demand special spaces. When you create those spaces you are making a statement about the content of the education you provide and the environment for students and teachers."
In the last few years, several independent schools in New York City have closed or merged. This unsettling trend has even prestigious and generously endowed schools looking over their shoulders.
"We are not anticipating a major expansion of the applicant pool," said Frederick Calder, director of the New York State Association of Independent Schools, half of whose 138 member schools are in New York City.
"New York City will hold its own," he said. "But we are not looking for the kind of growth we saw in the 60's and 70's, largely because the students are not there."
Brooklyn is an exception, Mr. Calder said. In that borough, independent school enrollment is still increasing.
What makes these ambitious rebuilding plans all the more challenging is that the money to pay for them must come, for the most part, from parents and alumni. Moreover, they are being undertaken at a time when the schools are coping with not only a shrinking pool of potential applicants but also rising operating costs and a faltering national and local economy that is straining the budgets of some parents. Annual tuition ranges from about $9,000 to $11,000.
Still, many schools have no other choice.
By the time construction started at Nightingale-Bamford, space was so tight that hallways had been pressed into service for computer study and for book storage from an overflowing library. Lunch was starting at 10:30 A.M. so that everyone in the school could be fed, and the auditorium was doing double duty as a gymnasium.
Nightingale-Bamford students and teachers returned last month to find a schoolhouse twice as big as it had been -- almost 100,000 square feet, instead of 50,000. Now air-conditioned, the building has new science labs, a new skylit cafeteria, a new auditorium with foldaway seating for 300 people and a two-story library with homey touches like cushioned window seats.
"We built a completely new building inside the old skin," said Jack L. Gordon, who served as the project's architect. "It was one of the most complicated projects ever attempted in a landmark district."
EXPANSION included a 22-foot addition to the west of the existing building. The new space was added on an adjacent site that held two row houses the school had bought in 1978 in anticipation of the construction project. Another component of the reconstruction was the excavation beyond the depth of the original basement for the addition of the auditorium.
From planning to completion, the Nightingale-Bamford project spanned more than a decade. Part of the time was eaten up as the school sought, but was ultimately denied, a zoning variance that would have let it add four stories to the original structure. In a compromise move, only two stories were added.
"It was quite a struggle,' said Joan McMenamin, the school's headmistress since 1971. "But it was more than worth it. We found that our parents were tireless in their efforts to see this project through, and the generosity of our neighboring institutions was remarkable."
While the schoolhouse was rebuilt, lower-school classes were held in the Park Avenue Synagogue and the middle- and upper-school students studied at Temple Emanu-el. The Spence and Browning schools opened their cafeterias to Nightingale-Bamford students and Chapin offered the use of its labs for chemistry and biology classes.
Some students took physical education classes at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church or the Murphy Center for Sports and Arts while others used the gymnasium at the 92d Street Y.M.H.A.
Although admissions officials at Nightingale-Bamford had no school to show off to prospective parents for more than two years, Mrs. McChord, the director of administration, said applications did not drop.
IN the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, work is nearing completion on a $5 million renovation and expansion of the Berkeley Carroll middle and upper school at 181 Lincoln Place. Its lower school is in two buildings on Carroll Street -- the pre-school and kindergarten -- at 712 the elementary school across the street at 701.
Dr. Bongsoon Zubay, headmistress of the co-educational school, said Berkeley Carroll has seen a steady increase in enrollment, from 487 in 1982 to 647 in the current academic year.
Two years ago portions of the main building and a one-story wing were remodeled and upgraded. But most of the capital improvement budget is evident in the 17,500-square-foot, five-story red brick addition.
It is being built in the courtyard between the main building, which dates to the 1890's, and the free-standing gymnasium, built in 1936.
"The main purpose of the new building," said Bruce Fowle, a partner in Fox & Fowle, the architectural firm that designed the new building, "is to provide more space. But a side benefit is that the addition will hide a rather unattractive one-story structure that had to be built rather quickly in the late 70's. It gave the school urgently needed expansion space but did nothing to enhance the campus or neighborhood."
The addition, which will be connected on all floors to the existing schoolhouse, follows its neo-classic brick and limestone design.
Primarily for the upper school students, it will have classrooms, art studios, administrative offices and a basement commons where lockers, now squeezed into corridors, will be put.
Once the building has been opened, further work will include expansion of the library and learning center in the main building.
Most of the city's independent schools are in old buildings, some of them in renovated town houses or mansions. Many are in residential neighborhoods where there is virtually no space for expansion and zoning and landmark laws limit the size and design of new construction. A particularly complicated fit for these schools are the new physical education facilities that figure prominently in most of the improvement plans.
The Dalton School made its way to much larger gymnasium space by teaming up with a private developer. The school is taking four floors in a new residential building now under construction on East 87th Street and Third Avenue. Dalton is currently negotiating to buy its space in the new building.
The new 22-story condominium where Dalton's 30,000-square-foot physical education facility will be is three and a half blocks from its 89th Street building. The school's enrolment of 1,255 pupils makes it one of the largest independent schools in the city. Some students have physical education classes in a gymnasium in the 89th Street building and others travel by bus to a gym on 94th Street.
Dalton's new gymnasium was made possible in part because Norman H. Segal, the developer of the residential building, agreed to major design changes. The school facilities, designed by Fox & Fowle, will have two gymnasiums -- one with a 570-seat mezzanine -- a wrestling room, a training room with sports therapy equipment and a multi-purpose room with video projection equipment and movable partitions.
John Ciardullo, a Manhattan architect, designed the condominium building.
The new facility will free almost 8,000 square feet in the Dalton building on 89th Street. Dr. Dunnan said that classrooms and laboratory space have been planned.
LAST year, Dalton bought 63 East 91st Street, a town house adjacent to its lower school building. For the time being it will be used for office and conference space. But David Helpern, an architect, is working on a new interior design in anticipation of its conversion for classroom use.
The hurdles the independent schools have faced on their way to better buildings have been financial as well as logistical.
"The independent school that embarks on an improvement program has to be scrupulous in its financial planning," said Dr. Dunnan, who also is president of the New York State Association of Independent Schools. "You don't want to be stuck in a plan that will have to depend on tuition increases or for which you have not budgeted the extra costs for operating the added space."
In a pioneering move, Nightingale-Bamford became the first independent school in the city to take advantage of tax-exempt bond financing to cover its construction costs. A 1986 change in the state law provided an avenue for non-profit civic organizations and institutions to use this type of lower-cost financing. The bonds, arranged through the New York City Industrial Development Agency, gave the school a loan with an interest rate of 6.75 percent plus 1.25 points for its letter of credit to National Westminister Bank. The 30-year term will allow the school to repay the loan through fund-raising campaigns, not tuition increases.
The Calhoun School on the West side, and the Day School, which has buildings on East 90th Street, as well as West 88th and 89th Streets, have followed Nightingale-Bamford's lead. Both schools closed bond financing deals with the Industrial Development Agency recently. Dr. Zubay, headmistress of Berkeley Carroll, said the school's board is considering applying for the tax-exempt bond program.
But other schools, like Dalton, Chapin and Spence, have avoided taking on debt by raising money before construction starts. The $8 million spent to expand and renovate at Chapin was raised from parents and alumnae. The work, completed in 1990 and designed by the architectural firm of Buttrick White Burtis, of New York, gave the school a new gymnasium, six new science labs, a new dance studio, new faculty workrooms and a lounge and improved computer space.
