HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Zuccotti Role;
Looking Beyond Downtown's Downturn

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A MAN who builds a reputation on both the public and private sides of the fence does not spend his time sitting on it. John E. Zuccotti is no fence-sitter.
"The principal problem doing business in New York City is cost -- taxes and other costs," says the 54-year-old former First Deputy Mayor and City Planning Commission chairman, who became president of Olympia & York (U.S.A.) in January 1990. 
 "And transportation," he puts in as an afterthought. "I don't hear complaints about the availability of housing."
Mr. Zuccotti has a new platform for these observations, the chairmanship of a public-private planning venture known as the Lower Manhattan Project. It is an offshoot of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, which he also chairs. With staff support from the Department of City Planning and a director paid by the association -- Con Howe, who was the planning agency's executive director until he left in February -- the Lower Manhattan Project intends to recommend long-term improvements for Manhattan south of Chambers Street.
The recommendations will presumably dovetail with the thoughts of the department itself, which intends to come forth in a year with the first comprehensive plan for Lower Manhattan since the McHarg report of 1966. That consultant study was big on the need for housing downtown, and much has come. But "how much and where" are still issues, says Richard L. Schaffer, the chairman.
Mr. Zuccotti was central to the planning and taxation policies that helped lift New York City from the real-estate slump that accompanied the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's. Are similar policies appropriate now?
At the depth of that recession, Mr. Zuccotti pushed for the steep tax abatement for the Commodore Hotel next to Grand Central Terminal that set the stage for its reconstruction by Donald Trump and Hyatt Hotels Corporation as the Grand Hyatt Hotel. In real-estate circles this was considered the beginning of the turnaround in the hard-hit east midtown office market.
He also supported the use of the J-51 tax abatement program to recycle unmarketable loft buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn into housing. When the market later improved, that program was cut back.
Now "we are in the almost dead center of a major down-cycle in commercial and residential markets," he says. "The frailty of city and state finances and the condition of the major financial institutions exacerbate the real estate cycle."
FOR the so-called Class C office buildings downtown, Mr. Zuccotti says, a comeback as competitive office space will be difficult. It should be possible in selected areas to make their conversion into housing possible by offering the tax abatements that would ease the way to financing for the expensive reconstructions required. That would help shrink the office vacancy rate and give the buildings a better chance for constructive use, he thinks.
Also needed, Mr. Zuccotti says, is something similar to the five-year cap on real-estate taxes brought into effect in 1975, which paved the way for the real-estate comeback of 1979. It takes three or four years to work, he says, and it should focus on existing tenants. For major tenants renewing a lease, there should be a way of providing significant tax abatements, so that New York City can stay competitive in the region. The object is to help dissuade major tenants from moving out of New York.
When John Zuccotti left city government in 1977 he was ending two years as First Deputy Mayor to Abraham D. Beame. Mr. Beame was considering running for another term as Mayor at the time. Mr. Zuccotti, widely considered a possible candidate himself, would not oppose him. "I was not prepared to run for Mayor against a man I greatly respect and admire," he said.
He joined Peter Tufo, a law-school roommate, in law practice and came to represent many of the most active developers in New York City. To the firm -- later merged into Brown & Wood -- came many developer-initiated zoning actions or requests for special permits, and no small number of lawyers who had served in government.
NOW when he walks the streets of the city, "I have more continuity in my head," he says, adding: "I'm a walking history, 1970 to 1991. Every building is a memory -- a chuckle or a pain."
The general remark comes more easily than the specific recollection. But what arouses the greatest sense of frustration and failure, he said, has been the city's inability to get construction started on a new West Side highway. The planning for it began in 1969 and was pursued through three mayoral administrations.
He might chuckle with satisfaction over the success of the World Financial Center, Olympia & York's six-million-square-foot venture at Battery Park City. He represented the Toronto-based company in obtaining all the land-use approvals it needed for the project. The office development galvanized the previously languishing residential component of Battery Park City.
Olympia & York entered the New York scene in 1977 with the purchase of the Manhattan office buildings developed by Percy and Harold Uris. Now the company owns 15 million square feet in Lower Manhattan, part of the 26 million square feet it controls across the country. Its downtown properties are experiencing a 9.8 percent vacancy rate, Mr. Zuccotti said. The figure includes two-thirds of the space at 60 Broad Street, which Drexel Burnham once occupied.
The total Lower Manhattan inventory of primary office space is 108 million square feet, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the leasing firm, and 17.1 percent of it is available for leasing. The inventory of secondary space is 28.8 million square feet and 23.7 percent of it is available, the firm says.
FOR comfort, New Yorkers can look at Los Angeles. "Los Angeles will experience a real-estate recession far worse than New York's," Mr. Zuccotti said. He himself, when looking west, concentrates on San Francisco. There Olympia & York is developing the office component of the large-scale mixed-use Yerba Buena project. And in New York the company hopes to start reconstructing 320 Park Avenue, the former ITT building, at 50th Street across the avenue from St. Bartholomew's Church, late next spring.
The transportation-improvements side of the Zuccotti prescription was addressed by Mr. Howe. He sees opportunities to improve the subway entrances south of Chambers Street (there are 108 of them) and to constructively reuse the deteroriated city-owned East River waterfront properties from the South Street Seaport to the heliport at the foot of Wall Street.
Mr. Howe, like Mr. Schaffer of the Planning Commission, thinks New York should do more for tourists downtown and can improve its parks and public spaces. He also says the Staten Island ferry terminal needs to be rebuilt as an important civic space. That was to happen as part of a mixed-use development planned by William Zeckendorf and partners. The weak market unhorsed it, but then a devastating fire at the existing terminal last month made reconstruction planning an immediate necessity.
The planners are also keen on increasing the residential population south of Chambers Street. It already numbers 15,000, including the 7,000 people at Battery Park City. The residential clusters are typically near parks or the water. The structures that lend themselves best to residential conversion are slim and tall, without the excessive unlit inside space found on broad floors, Mr. Howe says.
The co-op owners who have already arrived are likely to be a new voice in conversion policy. Richard Landman, president of the Lower Manhattan Homeowners Association, with a membership of 60 co-ops, noted that conversions and state law had worked together to saddle owners of J-51 co-ops with extraordinary property taxes once the benefits ran out.
"Sponsors put the tax savings in their pockets and got a big mortgage and the city dumped a high assessment on the building," he said.
As Mr. Zuccotti sees it, the current downturn is part of the cyclical pattern of change that Lower Manhattan has experienced since World War II.
"There is still an opportunity for growth by the foreign financial institutions," he says. "In the eyes of Europeans, New York City is still the capital." But an upturn in jobs, no one denies, is the best curative medicine.

HEADLINE: Private Schools Wrestling With Diversity and Identities

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
THE most recent entries on the valedictorian plaque at the Pingry School in Martinsville would probably surprise John Francis Pingry, a Presbyterian minister who founded the school in 1861 for the sons of wealthy Elizabeth business leaders. The names Schmulewitz, Cheng, Friedland and Sachs have a distinctly different ring from the patrician surnames of those who attended his school back then.
The changes in Pingry's student body are not only reflected in academic achievement: This year's school president is Korean, as were the co-captains of last year's football team. There is the Afro-American Scholars' Society and the Asian Awareness Society. The halls are filled with students from different racial, ethnic, religious and economic backgrounds. 
 Motivated not only by survival instincts, but also by the belief that diversity strengthens education, Pingry and other New Jersey independent schools are enrolling students from different backgrounds in record numbers. Once perceived as homogeneous citadels for the priviledged, they are promoting their multiculturalism and aggressively courting new students to broaden their cultural composition. Along the way, they are reshaping curriculums, rethinking decadelong traditions and trying to balance diversity with preserving their identities.
"It's a very tricky situation," said Arlene Gibson, head of the Kent Place School, a girls' day school in Summit. "You don't want to toss out the traditions that bring tears to alumni's eyes. At the same time you need to be sensitive of who is here."
The transition has not always been smooth. When Jewish students wanted to light a menorah next to the yule candle at Pingry's annual Christmas concert last year, which coincided with a night of Hanukkah, school officials decided to remove the menorah and yule candle at the last minute and substitue a peace candle.. Kent Place convened meetings last year to work out racial tension among black and white seniors. At Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood, students are divided along economic lines, school officials say.
The problems these three schools are confronting are ones that many school officials say they have seen. Next month, 200 New Jersey private school administrators, trustees and parents are to attend a symposium sponsored by the Parents Association of New Jersey Independent Schools at the Peck School in Morristown to pool perspectives on a number of issues regarding cultural diversity. One of the topics to be discussed is how to recruit minority faculty members and trustees, a pursuit the schools have found particularly frustrating.
Just how much New Jersey independent schools have changed is unclear. New Jersey and New York independent schools had a minority enrollment of 17.4 percent last year, up from 12.8 percent in 1981-82, according to the National Association of Independent Schools.
While New Jersey independent school admissions directors say they recently have seen a great change in the makeup of their enrollments, many acknowledge they do not know the best way to measure exactly how diverse they are.
"Our school is struggling to define diversity," said Peter Davies, director of admissions at Dwight-Englewood, which is often cited as a model multicultural school. "If someone is of mixed parentage or has lived here for some time, how do you classify him? We're trying to do a much more accurate assessment of who we are so we can celebrate that, design our curriculum and just know who we are."
Dwight-Englewood estimates its minority population has jumped to 30 percent from 18 percent 6 years ago, largely because of an increase in Korean students and, to a lesser extent, Indians and Pakistanis. The school promotes its diversity as one of its greatest assets and has restructured its curriculum to emphasize that.
For a week each spring, students can attend more than 20 presentations highlighting various cultures. The school's ninth-grade medieval history course was recently dropped for one that focuses on the early civilizations of India, China and Japan. This year 15 teachers from different disciplines are taking time off to integrate the study of Islam into the curriculum.
"We really broadcast quite loudly that this is a diverse place," Mr. Davies said. "It's so diverse, I don't think any one group can say they're in the majority."
 
Designer vs. Denim Jeans
 While there is general harmony among different cultural groups at Dwight-Englewood, school officials concede that students are often divided along economic lines. A dress code dropped in 1985 that allowed designer jeans but barred less expensive blue denims became a symbol of economic favoritism. Now students can wear whatever they want as long as it is "clean, neat and not offensive," said Gene Wojtyla, a spokeswoman for the school.
"That has helped a lot in terms of making kids feel comfortable economically on campus," she said. "But there is still a feeling between the haves and the have nots, like who gets a parking space on campus, what you drive and where you go on vacation."
To heal that rift, Dwight-Englewood, which has been working to shake its reputation as the school on the hill for rich kids, has begun requiring an ethics course and community service. The scholarship fund has also been increased, but because individual grants have been increased, there are fewer students on scholarship than four years ago.
For years, many schools had unstated admissions practices that excluded certain religious groups, especially Jews, a practice that has all but been abandoned today. Still, religious tensions remain. At Pingry, where chapel was a part of school life until the 1970's, a student committee is weighing the possibility of making the school's annual Christmas concert, with its heavy Christian emphasis, more inclusive.
"The music is overly religious, I feel, to the point that it makes me feel uncomfortable from a Jewish perspective," said Emily Goldberg, a senior on the committee who has sung in the concert for four years. "I don't know how people from other religions feel, but I assume it is probably equally uncomfortable for them."
John Hanly, headmaster of Pingry, said the decision to remove the menorah and yule candle at last year's concernt stemmed from "discussions about the nature of religious symbols" that occurred shortly before the concert was to begin.
"Because we were under the gun in terms of time, rather than create a situation that would be offensive to anyone, we decided to replace the yule candle and the menorah was a single white peace candle," he said.
After anti-Semitic graffiti was scrawled over the face of a Jewish student in a class photograph last year and several other incidents pointing to strained relations among various student factions, Pingry's Awareness Society, a student club that brings issues it deems important to students' attention, decided to devote itself to the subject of intolerance this year.Earlier this month, the society's president, Andrew Goldstein, began a series of assemblies and workshops that had been planned on the subject with a speech that received a standing ovation.
"There is intolerance at Pingry," he said. "Thgere is racism, there is prejudice, there are majorities who feel included and there are minorities who feel left out. And it is the responsibility of all of us to end this intolerance, to make the Pingry community a true community."
Some schools got off to a rocky start in the fall when they scheduled their first day of classes on the second day of Rosh ha-Shanah. At Gill-St. Bernard's School in Gladstone, which closed for one day of Rosh ha-Shanah but remained open on Yom Kippur, administrators have decided to close for both holidays in the future. Roughly 35 percent of the students were absent this year.
"It was fairly clear to us that attendance was low enough on the day we were open that we weren't getting much accomplished anyway," said Christine Cox, headmistress of the school.
More schools have been closing for major Jewish holidays in the past few years, said Dr. Daniel Kahn, executive director of the 59-member New Jersey Association of Independent Schools, but he added that that might not have to do with any significant demographic shift.
"I don't think there are more Jewish students," he said. "I think there is more vocalization. Jewish families have been in independent schools for a while now, and they may be more comfortable in articulating their needs."
Allan Strand, headmaster of the Newark Academy in Livingston, found he angered many people several years ago when he tried to make the annual holiday concert more secular after receiving criticism about the religious music and decorations. The school then tried a different approach.
"We decided that instead of trying to sanitize everything, we would be very open, thorough and forthcoming about the Jewish and Christian traditions," he said. "I told all our parents and kids that it's part of learning about each other's traditions. It's been wonderful since then."
 
The Role of Financial Aid
 Dr. Strand said the most dramatic change at the academy since his arrival in 1979 has been the increase in Asian students.
"Five years ago, the Asian population became larger than the black and it seems to get larger each year," he said, noting that the school is now 26 percent minority, including 8 percent Asian.
Dr. Strand said that while demographics have had a lot do with the makeup of his school, scholarships and financial aid have also played a large role in maintaining diversity. William E. Simon, an alumnus, recently pledged $2 million for a minority scholarship program that is to support up to 25 students a year by 1994. The academy also provides free bus transportation for students from Newark, operates a Saturday program for high-achieving inner-city students and opens its doors to gifted minority students during the summer.
Students and administrators at Newark Academy say that blacks and whites mingle easily. When only two students signed up for the Black Awareness Club this year, the club was informally disbanded.
"I like that, because that's my sense of the way the kids connect here," Dr. Strand said. "It's not Eden, but it's a very comfortable environment for different types of kids."
The transition for black students has been a bit bumpier at Kent Place, where the minority enrollment jumped from 6 percent three years ago to 14 percent now, mostly because of the enrollment of more black students. Last year, the senior class was divided over whether a minor argument between a black student and a white student over whether personal property should be left in the lounge was racially motivated.
"We looked at the dynamic that was going on there -- that two kids of different races couldn't have an argument without everyone jumping in and taking sides -- and decided there was something to be learned from this," said Mrs. Gibson of Kent Place.
In meetings and an overnight stay at the school, the class raised questions about race and ethnicity that Mrs. Gibson said "should have been dealt with a long time ago."
The school then began a major study of its curriculum to examine how it handles issues of ethnicity, religion, sex and class, and made some changes.
"If you define racial tension as being that which allows people to grow and address issues, then there has been some racial tension," Mrs. Gibson said, "but it's been a very positive force."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Biology class at the Dwight-Englewood School, often cited as a model multicultural school (pg. 1); Students on the campus of the Dwight-Englewood School. School officials say their minority population has jumped to 30 percent from 18 percent six years ago. (pg. 12) (Frank Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Singapore, a Search for a Second Act

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
Koh Boon Hwee is the kind of young executive Singapore would love to clone. Still a teen-ager when this island city-state was cast off from neighboring Malaysia, which distrusted its ethnic Chinese elite, he was educated in England and the United States and ran the Hewlett-Packard Company's giant manufacturing operations here upon his return, persuading the computer maker to develop new products for Asia using a potent mix of Singaporean engineers and American technology.
He cultivated Singapore's strong-willed leadership and its legions of industrial planners, who have left nothing to chance in building one of Asia's most incredible economic success stories. In the 1980's, he learned to cut deals with the Japanese, who with lightening speed have supplanted Americans as the region's most important investors. And a year-and-a-half ago, Mr. Koh fullfilled his Government's dreams, returning to the fold as head of Singapore Telecom, the state-owned and surprisingly dynamic telecommunications company. 
 If Singapore has a major problem today, its leaders say, it is that native talent like Mr. Koh, who is 41 years old, is scarce, as are the engineers and programmers, the corporate strategists and budding industrialists who will fulfill the country's goal of becoming the highest-tech nation in Southeast Asia. Twenty-six years after the country declared its independence, the fiber-optic cables are all laid, the skyscrapers are built, the computers are buzzing. But the days of hyperactive growth are over. The country's brilliant but autocratic Prime Minister of 31 years, Lee Kuan Yew, stepped aside a year ago, clearing the way for a new Singapore generation. The question now is whether that new generation can come up with a second act.
Having relied on cheap labor and some of the world's most finely honed economic incentives to shape itself into an island of other nations' multinational corporations, Singapore is now struggling to become an economic power in its own right. Its Western-trained planners, people like Mr. Koh who run the nation's cadre of state-owned enterprises, have embarked on an ambitious program to invest not only in Singapore, but also in technologies abroad. They are spreading Singapore's management techniques through Asia, funding venture start-ups in everything from chip-making to biotechnology, and prowling the world for good ideas to bring home.
 
An Asian 'Growth Triangle'
 With halting success, they are also turning to their quickly developing neighbors, Malaysia and Indonesia, to create a "growth triangle." Indonesia and Malaysia would supply labor and raw materials to this multi-lingual manufacturing hub while the people of Singapore contributed the brains and the organization, and kept the most profitable manufacturing processes on their island. Every morning, Malaysian workers pour over the causeway that connects Johor state to Singapore, while boats loaded with circuit boards ply the waters between Indonesia's nearby islands and Singapore's huge port.
Still, it is far from clear whether this nation, which has always prospered by its wits, will be able to muster the critical mass and the depth of talent to become the engine of Southeast Asia. Wages have soared, making the island less attractive than some of its neighbors. And multinational corporations, the bedrock of Singapore's success, are increasingly turning to up-and-coming economies for their next round of investments. Some have already moved operations out of Singapore. And Japanese money, important in an era when American companies seem to be disappearing from the Asian scene, is also headed elsewhere.
"It is not a popular view, but I do not think Singapore is ready to go out on its own," said Mr. Koh, one of the growing ranks of Singapore's business leaders willing at times to differ from the Government's perpetually rosy outlook. "The days of plentiful, reasonably priced labor here is a thing of the past. To upgrade our level of technology, and our command of technological processes, we need far more talent than we have available. We still have to learn how to develop products on our own. And to market them. I don't know how ready we are for that transition."
For its part, the Government clearly worries that its population may simply be too small and underskilled. The country now has a very Singaporean "procreation incentive," a tax break on second and third children intended largely for the well-educated Chinese majority, who make up 70 percent of the population. The new Prime Minister, Goh Chok Tong, talks of a more "refined and compassionate" society that allows "people to behave more as adults," part of an effort to lure overseas Singaporeans back home. Starting a few months ago, it was even possible to see "R"-rated movies here -- or at least films the Government determines aren't too racy.
That Singapore should be experiencing growing pains at all seems remarkable, given the speed at which the country has overtaken its neighbors. Since 1965, its economy has averaged 9 percent growth a year. Per capita domestic income has soared tenfold, to more than $9,000 a year. Malaysia's, by comparison, still hovers at around $1,800. For years Singapore has been the world's largest producer of disk drives for small computers and has been such a key "swing" refiner that for a few months during the war in the Persian Gulf, Saudi Arabia was actually importing gasoline from here.
But many fear the magic is beginning to wear off. Growth is slowing rapidly, as is manufacturing investment, partly because wage rates have risen by double digits for three years running.
"There is a limit," says Friedrich Wu, the head of economic research at the Development Bank of Singapore, which is taking the lead in the strategy to invest internationally by financing many of the acquisitions. "The country has only so much ability to absorb new manufacturers and provide the labor and the land. Only 6 percent of the population is university educated. So there are a lot of questions to be resolved."
 
Emulating Japan
 Singapore is hardly alone in facing these problems. They echo throughout the "Four Dragons," the name attached to the world's fastest-growing economies in the 1980's: Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan. The four were lumped together as the region's "newly industrialized economies" amid a lot of loose talk that they would soon replicate the success of postwar Japan, a goal that always seemed a bit overambitious. Now, none of the four is so new anymore, and growth rates, while still impressive, are not likely to see the pace of the 1980's return.
Each of the nations faces its own distinctive economic problems. South Korea is trying to contain burgeoning inflation, periodic labor strikes and growing trade friction with the United States, which is no longer willing to overlook its closed markets. Taiwan has been in a crisis of confidence since its market plunged, and it is uncertain how quickly it can capitalize on the reopening of economic ties with the People's Republic.
And then there is Hong Kong, convulsed in successive waves of optimism and terror over the prospect of China's takeover of the British colony in 1997. Hong Kong's crisis, in fact, is Singapore's opportunity: It is already wooing banks, investment houses and manufacturers to move their Pacific headquarters here, and it is waiving its usual sharp limits on immigration for Hong Kong professionals.
Whatever their unique problems, the dragons are all paying the price of quick wealth and quick growth: Workers have learned to expect an ever-increasing standard of living and steady demands for much higher wages have wiped out the chief advantage against Japan. And while each of the four talk about taking the next step -- toward achieving Japanese levels of automation and productivity -- few have the capital or the skilled work force to make that transition quickly.
Japan is not making it any easier. The dragons, once seen by Tokyo as struggling cousins, are now regarded as headlong competitors. The Japanese were never generous with technology, but have begun to cut off the flow, many Asians complain. "The Japanese are very, very reluctant these days to license anything of real value," Lee Hun Jo, a top executive of the Goldstar Corporation, the giant Korean consumer electronics company, said this spring. "Sometimes we feel like they are choking us."
Of the four dragons Singapore is the smallest. But it is also the most carefully planned, the most centrally controlled, the most politically stable, and the most adept at dealing with the Western multinationals, which have accounted for 90 percent of its manufacturing investment. As a result, the way it navigates its economic problems over the next few years will get more than its share of attention in Asia. "We are under a microscope," Lee Kuan Yew's son, Lee Hsien Loong, who is now Deputy Prime Minister, said early this year. "So we try not to make too many mistakes."
 
Colonial Heritage
 From the time it was founded in 1819, Singapore was born to commerce. Its location at the tip of peninsular Malaysia made it a natural port, and the days of rubber, tin and spices live on in the vivid literature about the lives of the colonial administrators and the "planters," British managers shipped out to Malaysia to keep the plantations running, who tried to create a Western oasis in the Asian jungle.
But modern Singapore was built largely by men like Lee Kuan Yew who spent their youth in the anti-colonialist movement, and who so dominated the political scene that they had a free hand to turn the country into the ultimate bureaucratic state, but one virtually devoid of corruption and dissent. Mr. Lee rebuilt the country, replacing the old row houses down by the piers with giant office towers and building one of Asia's largest petroleum refineries just off shore and, in the 1980's, an eerily accurate replica of Silicon Valley minutes from downtown. The gleeming airport, now vastly expanded, is widely agreed to be one of the world's most efficient.
At once charismatic and fiercely argumentative, Mr. Lee offered foreign investors a degree of freedom over their own operations that would have made the Japanese, the Koreans and the Taiwanese bristle, fearing that their own industries would be stifled. American companies loved it: Exxon and DuPont, Mobil and Hewlett-Packard all moved in.
"You have to remember that in the 1960's we were a trading nation with high employment and the prospect of more unemployment," said Lee Suan Hiang, the director of industry development at Singapore's powerful Economic Development Board. "Given the choice between developing local indigenous industry and going international, the choice was clear: go for the ready market and the ready technology."
But for foreigners, Singapore is no longer the manufacturing heaven it was in the 70's and 80's. In its relentless drive to become higher-tech, the Government has withdrawn the economic incentives to perform labor-intensive, low-technology manufacturing, rewarding automation, product development and engineering instead. To get a tax break and a spot in an industrial park today, companies must prove they are bringing in technology Singapore needs.
Some companies have changed with Singapore: General Electric moved from making radios to making aviation equipment. But because the Government has not solved the problem of the chronic shortage of well-trained talent, many other companies are balking at the thought of big capital expenditures in new plants. A recent survey of American firms showed that some are voting with their feet: disk drive makers are moving subassembly work to Malaysia and Thailand. Even the Japanese, who began outinvesting the United States in Singapore in 1986, have begun to turn elsewhere, pouring money into industrial parks outside Bangkok and factories in Indonesia.
And they have company: the Government of Singapore.
Much of the savings Singaporeans have been forced to set aside are invested in equity markets overseas, giving the country foreign reserves of about $28 billion. And over the last three years or so, the Singapore Government has led a direct-investment campaign abroad, putting at least $1.5 billion so far into foreign business ventures that promise a return of technology as well as profits.
Like everything in Singapore, it is precisely focused: Information technology, automation and biotechnology, three growth areas that Singapore's planners think can flourish on the island. Earlier this year the Government disclosed that it invested nearly $500 million in a New Zealand conglomerate, Brierly Investments. At Singapore Telecom, Mr. Koh has taken a $27 million stake in a Thai computer company and it is building a nationwide paging and data communications system for the country. The biggest single Singapore investment in the United States belongs to Singapore Airlines, which took a small equity stake in Delta Air Lines as part of a deal in which the two are linking routes.
 
A Legacy of Mistrust
 One of the many benefits sought from the overseas investments, Singaporeans say, is to avoid overdependence on the one power that looms over the Pacific: Japan. Few here forget that this winter will not only be the 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor, but the 50th anniversary of Japan's invasion of Malaysia, which culminated in a brutal sweep into Singapore. Those who were not massacred were imprisoned at the site of the current airport.
Singapore still woos Japanese investors, but Mr. Lee has made no secret of his distrust for the Japanese state. And so many Singaporeans, Mr. Koh included, worry about what they see as the flight of American capital from the region.
"In all of the countries in Southeast Asia the Japanese are by far the biggest investors, outstripping everyone," he says. "It is not something these countries have a choice in. If the choice is slower economic growth or more Japanese investment, they will go for the investment. And they will deal with the political cost later."
The Government says the next challenge is to establish a research and development base. There are efforts to start up more university programs, but it is with a very pragmatic air. "It doesn't matter if you have inventions galore," says Lee Suan Hiang of the Economic Development Board. "We have to pick carefully, because we can't afford to get carried away with blue sky, basic research. But then again, this has always been a very practical country."
 
 
CONTROLLING THE AUTO IN SINGAPORE FASHION
 Singapore has a nightmare, and it is Bangkok.
In the Thai capital, industrialization has proceeded at such a frenzied pace that the downtown streets are terminally gridlocked. Business executives decline to make more than two or three appointments a day. Police wear masks to protect themselves from auto exhaust. For the meeting of the Finance Ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized nations this week, Thailand declared a holiday so the ministers can move around the city without choking.
Clearly, such chaos and carbon monoxide would not do in pristine Singapore, the city made for business. So the Government has attacked congestion as it does most problems: with economic incentives and disincentives so severe that no one can ignore them. That is why Singapore is one of the world's most expensive places to buy a car.
Buying a car in Singapore is not just a simple matter of visiting the city's auto dealers. Starting a year ago, potential owners were required to enter a lottery to win a chance to buy one. The buying rights are not cheap, running upwards of $7,000 or $8,000 a car. Because so many applicants fail to win, a black market in buying rights has developed.
But that is just the beginning. The registration tax is 150 percent of the purchase price. The import duty is an additional 45 percent. So a $50,000 Mercedes-Benz -- this is, after all, a city of image-conscious entrepreneurs -- can cost as much as $110,000 or more.
And car owners may not be able to drive downtown. During rush hour, they must buy a pass to enter the "Restricted Zone." Parking tickets are severe, although not as severe as in Tokyo, where illegal overnight parking can cost $1,400.
Then again, Singapore isn't that big -- about 250 square miles -- and the subway is bright, shiny, automated and cheap.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
At the S.E.C., Another Move For Secrecy

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Globalization is the new Holy Grail at the Securities and Exchange Commission. As a result, 58 years after the Securities Act of 1933 made disclosure the cornerstone of American securities regulation, it is gradually being undone by the body charged with enforcing it.
The latest assault on the public's right to know what is happening in the securities markets came last week as the commission made it possible to trade stocks on Nasdaq from 3:30 A.M. to 9 A.M., New York time. That is prime trading time in Europe. 
 If it were only a matter of time, there would be no objections here. But to compete with London's secretive system, the S.E.C. agreed that there would be no disclosure of trading information during the session, and very limited information afterward. Information about actual trades, the S.E.C. says, is none of your business.
The S.E.C. also sanctions secrecy in the so-called Rule 144A market, in which institutions trade securities issued by companies that find it too bothersome to comply with America's normal financial disclosure rules. Once again, the justification is that if this country does not seek out the lowest possible common denominator, it might lose business to foreign markets.
It is odd to see the S.E.C. choosing this moment to allow shades to be pulled down over what goes on in markets. The Treasury bond trading scandal might not have happened, and certainly would have been easier to detect and police, had that market not been so opaque. Now the reformers are looking for ways to open it up.
The winners of such a closed system are, inevitably, the brokers with superior knowledge about what is really happening. The losers, just as surely, are brokers who are not members of the inner circle -- and the customers. Those customers may take their business elsewhere, but their options are limited. They must trade where the liquidity -- that is, the other trading -- already is, and that is likely to be the place favored by the brokers.
The desire for globalization does correspond to a trend among investors. They are not hostile to most American securities, but last week the bond market rally looked shaky, and evidence of economic recovery is mixed. In that atmosphere, overseas opportunities seem more attractive. Banks are rushing to make unsecured loans to Kuwait, and individual investors are pouring money into the new Argentina Fund.
It is conceivable that the S.E.C.'s efforts will bring in a bit more business for American brokers and trading systems, even as investors lose needed information. Some trading will be siphoned from other, more open, American markets, and perhaps they will demand to be allowed to keep secrets to stay competitive. In the current S.E.C. atmosphere, a meek assent is likely.
Eventually, the S.E.C. may regret the steps it is now taking. It is to be hoped that the markets will not have been irreparably harmed in the meantime.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Putting the Best Face on Nordstrom's Problems

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc., the fast-growing retailer best known for its high standards of customer service, pushes its sales force always to be bright and cheery. So it was not surprising when James Nordstrom, one of the four co-chairmen of the Seattle-based company, was upbeat last week even after the chain shocked Wall Street with the news that it expects flat profits and a decline in sales for the quarter ending Oct. 31.
"I feel we are running our company today as well as we ever have," Mr. Nordstrom told an industry conference in Vancouver. "We are still making money. But our customers don't feel good right now and it's having an effect on our business. It's just something we will have to work our way through." 
 Wall Street was not feeling quite so sanguine. Nordstrom's shares fell $8.50, to $33.75, in over-the-counter trading on Wednesday, the day after the earnings estimate was released. Several analysts had been predicting that the chain would post a gain for the quarter, building on growth in the second quarter. During that period, same-store sales increased 3.5 percent, paced by a strong July. The stock closed Friday at $37, compared to its 52-week high of $53.
The weak outlook for Nordstrom dragged down other retail stocks as well, as analysts and investors concluded that consumers remain wary about the economy and their personal finances.
Indeed, concerns about a weak Christmas selling season grew late last week with reports from many of the nation's largest retailers that business in September was even weaker than predicted.
The poor results were spread throughout the industry, from discount chains like K Mart to upscale merchants like Nordstrom. Two exceptions: Wal-Mart, the nation's biggest retailer, posted a sales gain of 32 percent, and sales at the Gap were up 41 percent. Overall, though, September sales rose only 1 percent compared with September 1990, as measured by an index of 22 leading retailers prepared by Merrill Lynch.
The downturn at Nordstrom poses a challenge to the four members of the family who run the company as a group: James Nordstrom; his brother, John; their cousin Bruce Nordstrom, and John A. McMillan, a Nordstrom brother-in-law. The company has been expanding rapidly from its base on the West Coast into the Middle West and the East, including New Jersey. It will open its 67th store later this month, in Maryland outside Washington.
The company plans to open three stores next year, down from four this year.
James Nordstrom said the chain had frozen salaries of senior managers earlier this year. But he said the company would not slash prices to bring shoppers in, and he pledged not to allow any erosion in customer-service standards.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 6-11

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A New Market for the Baby Bells 

Last week Judge Harold H. Greene, at the prodding of a Federal appeals court, overturned the ban barring local telephone companies from selling information electronically. The ruling was contested by publishers afraid that the companies would raise phone rates to subsidize their information business. To blunt the ruling, Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, introduced a bill allowing the companies to sell information only where there is competition. Not to worry, the Baby Bells say. The Federal Communications Commission forbids them to sell information unless they set up separate companies. But the main obstacle to their dominating the information market may come from the companies themselves. "These guys come out of a heavily regulated environment," said Joel D. Gross, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The don't really know what consumers are willing to pay for."
 
A Rash of Scandals Spreads . . .
 
Perhaps it is sunspots, which are at a seven-year high. Or maybe it's just human nature. But scandals in the financial community continue to proliferate. Last week, the American Express Company said it was investigating whether its executives falsified records to conceal defaults on the company's Optima credit card. News of the investigation comes a week after Amex said it was setting aside $265 million in reserves and write-offs on its credit card operations. "There were clearly instances where internal credit policies weren't followed properly, and we are conducting an extensive review," the company said in a statement last week. The firm said $24 million in defaults had been improperly reported for three quarters because of accounting problems.

. . . and Spreads Some More
 
Merrill Lynch & Company has rarely been accused of anything worse than extravagance. Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission said it was investigating whether Merrill had engaged in trades that helped a Florida Insurance firm, Transmark USA Inc., disguise its deteriorating financial condition. The S.E.C. is investigating trades from 1984 to 1988 between Merrill and one of Transmark's subsidiaries. In the transactions, Merrill sold hundreds of millions of dollars of Government securities to the subsidiary. Almost at the same time, Merrill bought junk bonds of equal an amount from the insurer. This asset swap could have made Transmark's books look better than they should have looked. For Merrill, the deal may have allowed it to conceal which securities it owned. Merrill denies any wrongdoing.

Forget Pearl Harbor?
 
A lot of advertising agencies would rather forget Dec. 7, 1941. At least the ones that hawk Japanese goods. This year -- the 50th anniversay of the bombing of Pearl Harbor -- the television networks and many magazines are planning special coverage of the event. That has the agencies pacing the halls. Last week, an internal memo from one agency -- Bozell Inc. -- hit the streets. It regarded Bozell's Minolta account. "It is imperative for Minolta not to advertise in any issue containing editorials related to this event," the memo read. "I'm sure you understand the gravity of this matter." Other agencies are doing the same.
 
A New AIDS Treatment
 
It was a small victory in a long fight. Last week, the Federal Health and Human Services Department announced it would approve a new drug, called dideoxyinosine, for the treatment of AIDS. DDI, as the drug is called, is the first anti-viral medication approved since AZT won approval in 1986. Though it helps AIDS patients, DDI is not a cure. So far, 106,000 have died of AIDS; 182,000 Americans have the disease, and about 1 million have tested positive for the HIV virus. The dismal statistics sadly point out that DDI, which is made by the Brisol-Myers Squibb, is poised for strong sales. According to Samuel D. Isaly of Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Research, DDI should bring in revenues of about $100 million a year for its maker.

The Unsinkable Potamkin
 
For decades, Victor Potamkin was Cadillac's top salesman -- his dealership in Manhattan sold 6,000 cars a year -- but he did not have, well, Cadillac style. He was a brash discounter. When he sold out to Roger Penske, Cadillac was pleased. Mr. Penske brought potted plants into the showroom. But Mr. Penske closed down in May. Last week, Cadillac said it was bringing back the 80-year-old Mr. Potamkin to run the dealership. With Cadillac's sales 20 percent behind last year's, substance matters more than style.
 
A Deal Between Apple and Sony?
 
A week after Apple Computer and the International Business Machines Corporation signed a deal, John Sculley, Apple's chairman, turned up in Tokyo for talks with Norio Ohga, president of the Sony Corporation. The whispers in the corridors were that the two men were cooking up a deal. After all, Sony already makes many of the components Apple uses in its computers. Is that the case? "I can't talk about it." Mr. Sculley said.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japanese Aid for the Soviets
 
Japan has been reluctant to grant aid to the Soviet Union, or what is left of it. But last week the government changed its mind and announced a complicated $2.5 billion aid package designed to get Japanese products into Soviet hands. The aid consists of $1.8 billion to ensure that the Soviet Union pays for its Japanese imports, along with $200 million in credits it can use to buy Japanese products. The remaining $500 million is for food and medical goods. The package is another triumph for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has kept money flowing into the Soviet Union despite objections from the donors that it still has no credible reform plan.
 
Easy Credit Terms for Kuwait
 
To raise money to rebuild the country, Kuwait said last week it would borrow $5 billion over a five-year period in the private capital markets -- the largest loan ever requested by a country. Kuwait's Ministry of Finance appoointed J.P. Morgan & Company to stitch together a deal involving dozens of banks from around the world. Analysts think Kuwait, which has plenty of oil, will get good terms. It will be able to borrow at half a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate, now 6 percent. The loan will be unsecured. But considering the way Kuwait's friends came to its aid once before, the banks don't think that is a problem.

Tokyo Bares Its Teeth at Nomura
 
At first it looked as if Japan's Ministry of Finance would let Nomura Securities Company off easy. Nomura admitted to a number of misdeeds, including manipulating stock prices in a deal with the late Susumu Ishii, a top Japanese gangster. But last week the Ministry bared its teeth, ordering Nomura to close more than half of its domestic branches for a month and shut down several other key departments. The Ministry's show of strength comes days before American officials go to Tokyo to discussopening up Japan's financial markets to more American firms.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Baby Steps To Spur the Economy
 
President Bush seems to be honoring history. Americans are pocketbook voters, and incumbents -- even popular ones -- lose during recessions. So last week, with bank lending down 8 percent from last year and growth creeping along, Mr. Bush tried to tackle the economy. He announced steps that he said would curb the credit crunch and ensure that banks lend. The proposals allow banks to value real estate more liberally and give them a way to complain about the auditors. But these proposals are no Desert Storm. "Banks have slowed down lending in response to sluggishness; they did not cause the sluggishness," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York. The proposals "really won't do anything," he said.

Retail's Disappointing Rebound
 
In this economy, consumers are the motivating force. If they spend, the economy will toot along. But according to the Commerce Department, September's 0.7 rise in retail sales was due to fleet-autombiles sales, and the rest of the sector was weak. Merrill Lynch & Company's index of retailers showed a 1 percent gain from last year, when the recession began. "Disappointing and below expectations," said Jeffery Feiner an analyst at the firm.
 
Growth Is Low, But So Are Prices
 
Optimistic economists see at least one benefit from an economy that bounces along at a sub-par rate of growth. If companies cannot sell goods, they usually do not raise prices. Last week, according to the Labor Department, that rule proved true. Producer prices for September rose barely at all -- a slim 0.1 percent. Producer prices have fallen this year by a seasonally adjusted 0.9 percent annual rate. That is the best showing since 1986 -- but for all the wrong reasons.

A Cash-and-Carry Bailout Bill
 
Congress relishes tussling with the Bush Administration over money. So last week, when the Administration asked the House Banking subcommittee for $80 billion more for the savings and loan industry, it got a yes, but with one large string attached. Congress added a pay-as-you-go amendment to the funding bill. Rather than allow the Government to borrow the money as it has in the past, the amendment would force the Administration to pay for the bailout by either raising taxes or slicing spending. While borrowing defers the pain, taxing people hurts immediately. So the Administration would rather put the bailout on its tab. Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, who took the case to Congress, said he was "deeply disappointed by the actions of the committee and wants to get it corrected." If the bill reaches the President's desk with the amendment attached, Mr. Robson will recommend a veto.

HEADLINE: All About/Car Engines;
A New Consumer Passion for What's Under the Hood

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
As the new model year begins, auto makers are touting their engines as never before to consumers, who are increasingly savvy about power plants. Car buyers are concerned not only about horsepower and cylinder displacement, but also about fuel economy, emissions, technology and performance. They know their engines.
"It's really amazing how many people do their homework," said Frank Ward, president of MOR-PACE, a consumer research firm in Farmington Hills, Mich. 
 But different drivers also want different technologies. Some customers want gas-stingy three-cylinder engines, like the 1.0-liter engine in the Geo Metro. Others long for the power of a 5.7-liter V-8 in the new Cheverolet Corvette. "We want the right engine for the right product at the right price," said Donald L. Miles, chief engineer for the General Motors Corporation's 3300 and 3800 V-6 engines.
Car makers compete hard to win bragging rights to technological firsts. But missteps can be costly. Developing a new engine and the factory in which to build it can cost $750 million or more, according to the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, a Detroit-based trade group. G.M., for example, is investing the time of 400 engineers to develop and refine its family of automobile engines.
But new technology comes with trade-offs. As a result, auto makers are proceeding more carefully than ever before to develop new products.
 
The Auto Holy Grail
A Car That 'Torques' And 'Twists' Well
 Most car engines on the road today can be divided into two categories: "torquers" and "twisters." The terms, coined by Mr. Miles, describe the feel and performance of two different, widely used types of engines. Each engine has its advantages and limitations.
Torquers are engines that use pushrods to open and close the engine's intake and exhaust valves. This engine design provides maximum power, acceleration and torque at lower engine speeds.
But because pushrod engines have just two valves to control the flow of fuel and air through each of the engine's cylinders, they have trouble maintaining power and efficiency at higher engine speeds.
By comparison, twisters generally use more complex technology with four valves per cylinder and an overhead camshaft. This configuration enables engines to breathe more fully and maintain their power at higher engine speeds. But twisters do not have as much power at low engine speeds as torquers. They are slower than torquers from a standing start and more expensive to make.
Auto makers say drivers now want engines to have the attributes of both types of power plant. "If you can do the best of those, you've really got a winner for the customer," said Mr. Miles.
Car makers are rushing to develop that winner. Cadillac will introduce a new four-valve V-8 engine, called the Northstar, in next year's Allante, Eldorado and Seville models. The Northstar will have four valvesper cylinder, like a twister. But its sheer size -- probably in the 5-liter range -- will give it a lot of low-end power, like a torquer.
Other auto makers are also adding torque to their four-valve twisters. Mazda achieves the effect by changing the speed of the air moving into the six cylinders of the 1.8 liter engine in its new MX-3 coupe. At low revolutions, air is drawn through gates to create a fast-moving, pulsating stream. When mixed with fuel, the air fires more fully and provides more power and torque at low revolutions. At higher revolutions, the engine works so quickly that the air needs less massaging for peak efficiency.
 
More for Less
Taming Emissions For Fuel Efficiency

Besides increasing power at all engine speeds, auto makers are pursuing goals of fuel efficiency and cost-effective design.
Fuel-efficient engine technology has won recognition for Japanese auto makers such as the Honda Motor Company. The car maker recently unveiled a VTEC-E engine for its new Civic that uses a complicated system of valves to adjust the mixture of air and fuel going into the cylinder. More gas is added at lower speeds to boost power, but is reduced as the car reaches cruising speeds. This "lean-burn" engine, which analysts say improves efficiency by 10 to 25 percent, is not without its problems. Increased nitrogen oxide emissions prohibit Honda from offering the engine in California.
Engineers are also pursuing efficiency in production. Ford has invested $700 million to retool a former tractor factory in Romeo, Mich., to build different versions of the same basic engine on one assembly line. By using more common parts, the company can make different "modular" engines with two or four valves per cylinder, with various displacements and from blocks of iron or aluminum.
 
Refining the Basics
Different Strokes For Different Folks
 Engine designers tinker mostly with refinements to the traditional engine invented in 1876 by the German engineer Nikolaus Otto. It is powered with explosions created by sparking a mixture of gasoline and air which moves through the combustion chamber in each cylinder. The basic engine is called a four-stroke engine because each piston must move up and down twice to complete a cycle. A cycle includes the intake of fuel, an explosion and the expulsion of the exhaust gases. But engineers are researching changes to some of those basic engine ingredients.
If the technology could be perfected, lightweight two-stroke engines have the potential to transform the auto industry. The benefits of a two-stroke engine are power on every piston stroke, lighter weight and fewer parts. "The incentives of achieving it are so dramatic that everyone is working on it like crazy," said David E. Cole, director of the University of Michigan's automotive transportation program. But questions remain for the technology, including its long-term reliability, fuel efficiency and ability to pass emissions tests. Still, many auto makers have purchased development licenses from Orbital Engine Corporation, an Australian company that developed a two-stroke engine.
Car companies are also changing the fuel itself, are testing a host of different fuels, including methanol, propane, ethanol, natural gas and hydrogen. Experts predict that variety of fuels will be used in about 5 to 7 percent of vehicles by the year 2000.
By the end of the decade, many cars will not be using internal combustion engines at all. California law requires that 2 percent of new cars sold in 1998 have no emissions.
Many car makers are stepping up to the challenge of developing a workable, cost-effective battery system for cars. G.M. intends to put its electric car, the Impact, into production in the mid-90's. Nissan announced this summer that it had developed an electric car that can be fully recharged in 15 minutes. It must still clear many technical hurdles. Nissan and other auto makers say they are committed to finding solutions to avoid being shut out of the California car market.
 
THE ESTHETICS OF THE ENGINE
 Like car bodies, engines are designed to appeal to visual tastes. "Every engineer knows that this is one demand," said Thomas Gubitz, a spokesman for BMW, which highlights its engines in many of its advertisements for its new models.
Audi changes the designs of its engines for different customers. Its new V-6 was designed to be "esthetically pleasing but not intimidating" with a gaggle of lines or high-profile manifolds, said an Audi spokesman. Its V-8, on the other hand, is built to appeal to a more performance-minded customer, and its shape is more dramatic.
Auto makers also have worked to clean up the engine compartment itself. As engines grew more complex in the early 80's, creating a busier look under the hood, executives at the General Motors Corporation handed down a directive to clean up the engine's layout. The company rerouted wires and hoses and shifted components.
But David E. Cole, director of the University of Michigan's Automotive Transportation Program, said consumers should not be deceived by the simple look of some engines when they open the hood, as much of the wiring has been hidden from view.
"If you look under the engine, it looks like a bowl of spaghetti," he said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Alternates as the C.D.'s Go Sour

SERIES: First of two articles on yields.

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
More than $150 billion invested in certificates of deposit are coming due this month, and many holders of these certificates are looking for new homes for their money. The reason: yields on C.D.'s and other short-term investments like money market funds have dropped.
As of Oct. 1, one-year C.D.'s were yielding just 5.66 percent on average, according to Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla. 
 The interest rates that banks could pay were deregulated in October 1983, and because C.D.'s are sold mostly in six-month and full-year units, October remains the biggest month for C.D. rollovers. Rates are now at their lowest level since deregulation, and a recent survey by Gallup and Fidelity Investments found that fewer than one-third of the investors with certificates coming due were committed to reinvesting in C.D.'s.
One easy alternative to C.D.'s is money market funds, but their yields are even lower. The seven-day compound yield for taxable money funds was 5.29 percent as of Oct. 1, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report in Holliston, Mass.
New Yorkers and investors in other high-tax states can do better with United States Treasury money market funds, where earnings are exempt from state and local taxes. The Dreyfus 100 Percent U.S. Treasury Money Market Fund was yielding 5.80 percent before taxes. This generally produces an after-tax yield of 6.39 percent for California investors and 6.61 percent for New York City investors.
Anything else involves more risk than C.D. or money fund investors are accustomed to. "To get more yield, you have to take more risk," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund research group in Chicago.
Investors can minimize credit risk -- the risk that issuers will not repay interest or principal -- by staying with high-quality bond funds. Even so, going longer than the 90-day maximum permitted for money funds exposes investors to interest rate risk. Investors in foreign bond funds also assume currency rate risk.
One way to minimize the overall level of portfolio risk is to mix the various types of risk, Mr. Phillips suggested. That said, what are investors' choices among high-yielding mutual funds? The following are suggestions, with discussions of the risk each entails.
* Short- and intermediate-term bond funds. Unlike C.D.'s or money market funds, bond funds can lose value if interest rates rise. So while the yield looks good, the total return -- yield plus changes in principal -- may not. In the long term, it is total return that counts.
To decrease risk, choose funds with shorter maturities. Short-term bond funds invest in securities maturing in one to five years. Among short-term government funds, Mr. Phillips recommends 20th Century U.S. Government, with a yield of 6.95 percent and a total return of 10.89 percent in 1991 through Sept. 30. On the corporate side, he likes T. Rowe Price Short-Term Bond Fund (yield, 7.17; total return, 10.05 percent).
Intermediate-term funds invest in securities maturing in five to 10 years, so yields are slightly higher. Mr. Phillips likes the Benham Treasury Note Fund (yield, 7.07 percent; total return, 12.97 percent) and the Fidelity Intermediate Bond Fund (yield, 7.64 percent; total return 13.29 percent).
* Mortgage funds. There are two basic types: adjustable-rate mortgage funds and Ginnie Mae funds. The adjustable-rate funds were developed to compensate for the volatility of the fixed-rate Ginnie Mae funds, whose prices move around to compensate for shifts in market interest rates.
The tradeoff: monthly dividends fluctuate more than they would with a standard Ginnie Mae fund. And the funds' yields drop when interest rates fall, as the borrowers' rates are adjusted downward. When rates rise, the funds lag because rates on the underlying mortgages are not adjusted immediately.
In both adjustable-rate and Ginnie Mae funds, when mortgages are prepaid the money is reinvested at lower rates, cutting the funds' yields. Mr. Phillips recommends the Franklin Adjustable U.S. Government Securities Fund (yield, 8.63 percent; total return, 9.59 percent) and the Vanguard G.N.M.A. Portfolio Fund (yield, 8.26 percent; total return, 16.67 percent.)
* Short-term global income funds. These funds take advantage of foreign interest rates that are higher than United States rates. To minimize credit risk, they hold government securities and high-quality short-term corporate paper. To control currency risk, they rely on sophisticated hedging techniques. For investors who want to go this route, Alliance Short-Term Multi-Market Trust class A (yield 9.95 percent; total return 10.64 percent) is Mr. Phillips's choice.
Next week: High-yielding stock funds.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
The Ginnie Mae Rate Puzzle

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Today's falling interest rates are good news for bondholders because lower rates mean higher bond prices. For investors in Ginnie Mae funds, which hold issues of the Government National Mortgage Association, the story is more complicated.
Lower interest rates prompt homeowners to refinance their mortgages. When mortgages are prepaid, the money flows to the funds to be reinvested, but the rates now in effect pull down the fund's yield. 
 For most investors, the real story is total return -- yield plus principal changes. By this measure, G.N.M.A. funds have outpaced Treasury bond funds in each of the past seven years except 1986, when interest rates were also falling. But for investors who rely on yields to cover living expenses, lower dividends may be a high price to pay for an increase in their G.N.M.A. fund shares, said Stephen A. Schoepke, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services.

HEADLINE: Managing;
The Parables of Corporate Culture

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
STEWART J. LEONARD JR., president of Stew Leonard's, the Norwalk, Conn., food store known for its customer service, loves to tell employees the tuna fish story. It goes something like this:
"I unwrap one of our tuna sandwiches, and this package of mayonnaise rolls out. I figure, the sandwich has enough mayo already. So I call Bill Hollis, my deli manager, and tell him, get rid of the extra mayo, it's expensive. 
 "So next week, I open a sandwich, the Hellman's pops out again. I call Bill again, and he says, you gotta talk to Mary Ekstrand, she makes the sandwiches. I call Mary, who says, 'Sorry, Stew, the customers want the extra mayo, so I'm packing it again.' You know my reaction? Bravo, Mary!"
No one is likely to option that story's movie rights. But it sure serves Mr. Leonard's purposes. It shows him as an involved manager who tests products, questions procedures and cares about costs, but cares about satisfying customers and empowering workers even more. And it praises Bill and Mary for recognizing those priorities.
"Making employees giggle with a story is a better way to teach them something than reciting a list of rules," Mr. Leonard said.
Storytelling, an art generally associated with parents, standup comics and anthropologists, is emerging as a hot management tool. Numerous business professors and consultants, including fad master Tom Peters, are touting it in classes and workshops. The Journal of Organizational Change Management devoted its entire summer issue to storytelling as a way of diagnosing an existing culture or promulgating a new one.
"The best way to pass on a company's cultural themes is by telling stories," said David M. Boje, editor of the journal and an associate professor of management at Loyola Marymount University.
Added C. Warren Neel, dean of the University of Tennessee's College of Business: "A good company uses its oral legacy to embellish its history and focus its aspirations."
That certainly describes how David Armstrong, vice president of Armstrong International Inc., uses stories. The industrial equipment manufacturer, based in Stuart, Fla., doesn't even have a policy manual. But it has stories galore -- bound in books, hanging on bulletin boards, framed on office walls. Each is one page long, each was told by an employee to Mr. Armstrong, who wrote them up.
There's the one about the man who had bypass surgery and alerted the company to hospital overcharges. There's the one about how road congestion problems dating back 20 years led to a policy of letting office workers break for lunch five minutes ahead of factory workers. There's the one about how the controller of a new division came up with travel expense rules that let employees mirror their at-home life styles on the road.
"People remember stories and their morals a lot better than they remember written policies," said Mr. Armstrong, whose book, "Managing by Storying Around," is slated to appear in bookstores in March.
At the Saturn Corporation, the General Motors subsidiary in Spring Hill, Tenn., the assumption is that people remember what they see even better than what they hear or read. Saturn's communications people regularly videotape employees telling stories about customer service, teamwork and the like. They compile the tapes into a news show format and circulate them throughout the company every week.
Recent stories included tales of an engineer who helped an irate customer, of an employee's wife who helped teen-agers feel comfortable in new schools, of a dealer who handled a recall by inviting all his customers in for a barbecue while his mechanics fixed their cars.
"We use these stories to reinforce what we want Saturn to stand for," said Richard G. LeFauve, Saturn's president.
Since Saturn is only six years old, it is still in the culture-setting stage. At older companies, managers often elicit stories from their staffs to find out if their behavior is running afoul of their employee's expectations.
"If your people still talk about how you avoided layoffs in the last recession, you can bet they are unprepared for layoffs this time around," said Alan Wilkins, a business professor at Brigham Young University. "And if they talk about the abrasiveness of a dead plant manager as though he were still here, you've got an employee relations problem."
Of course, employee's stories need not presage problems; they can also solve them.
Frederick Nichols, a manager of organizational effectiveness at the Xerox Corporation, uses stories employees tell him about successful projects they worked on in the past to assign them to project teams.
"We like to match people who think success comes from all-nighters with those who relate it to technology," he said. "They'll bring different ideas to the project."
 
 
 
SHORT AND TO THE POINT
 Stories can be an excellent vehicle for comparing different cultures.
Robert F. Dennehy, a management professor at Pace University, has his students interview people from different countries and cultures, write up their stories -- complete with quotes -- and read them to the class. Lately, he's been asking them to compare and contrast corporate stories, too.
Here's one of his favorite story pairs:
"At I.B.M., people talk about the time legendary boss Thomas Watson Jr. forgot his name tag, was barred from the building by a security guard, and praised the man for his conscientiousness. Revlon people tell how Charles Revson fired a guard who did not recognize him without his identification.
"I.B.M.'s story shows a culture that respects rules; Revlon's story shows one that respects power."

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: William & Mary;
Rules Tightened In Effort to Limit Student Drinking

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

 BODY:
The College of William & Mary has tightened its regulations about alcohol consumption to stem what the college's administration, local hospital officials and national fraternity chapters have increasingly depicted as student drinking that is out of control.
Kegs and other large containers of alcohol are now banned from fraternity houses and other residence halls, except during large-scale events like homecomings. Fraternities and other campus organizations must provide separate drinking areas, called beer gardens, at all events where alcohol is served. 
 Last fall, officials at Williamsburg Community Hospital told the college the number of severely intoxicated students needing treatment for alcohol poisoning and accidents sustained while drunk was increasing, said Kenneth E. Smith, associate vice president for student affairs. The college concluded that underage students had too easy access to large amounts of alcohol, he said, and students and administrators on the alcohol policy review committee proposed the regulations. The college president, Paul Verkuil, approved the regulations over the summer.
"There were not many campuses with as liberal procedures as ours were," Mr. Smith said. "Most people kind of felt it was inevitable for this to come."
 
Targeting Fraternities
 He said that national fraternities have pressured individual chapters nationwide to limit access to alcohol. Insurance companies, which charge fraternities rates comparable to those for stunt men and race car drivers, have threatened to stop providing coverage because of the rising number of personal-injury suits involving alcohol-related incidents at fraternity parties.
The need to curb student alcohol use was underscored by the highly publicized drug arrests of students at the University of Virginia last spring and by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's formation of a substance abuse task force to examine problems at the state's colleges, Mr. Smith said.
The new policy has received mixed reviews from members of the 14 recognized fraternities at William & Mary. About 40 percent of the estimated 6,500 undergraduates at William & Mary are involved in the Greek-letter fraternity system. Unlike many other colleges and universities, most of the institution's fraternity parties are open to students who are not members.
Fraternity leaders have been charged with the primary responsibility for enforcing the new policy. Each house must designate its own drinking areas and check guests' identification, Mr. Smith said.
 
Some 'Negative Feelings'
 Stephen Welty, a senior who serves as president of Sigma Chi fraternity, said that many students resent having designated drinking areas and feel the college does not trust them to act responsibly. "The general student body was harboring negative feelings when this policy was set down," Mr. Welty, a senior economics major from San Diego, said. "They don't understand how the college thought this could work out."
W. Samuel Sadler, vice president for student affairs, said the policies are less Draconian than some of the ideas discussed by the Governor's task force over the summer, including making all Virginia campuses alcohol free.
"We have an obligation as a community to make certain people are engaging in safe practices," Mr. Sadler said. The ban on kegs, he said, is an important step in reducing the amount of alcohol students drink because, "When people have a keg, they drink until it's empty."
Fraternities now buy beer in cans, he said, which can be stored between social functions.
But John Marcoux, a senior in computer science from Rockville Centre, L.I., who serves as president of the Council for Fraternity Affairs, said the keg ban has created new problems. "Kegs did offer more control," Mr. Marcoux, a member of Sigma Alpha Epsilon, said. "The chances of liquor and flasks being brought in are now much greater."
Many students say they fear tighter regulations will move the college's social center out of the fraternities and off campus. "When it's off campus, more people will be drinking and driving," Mr. Marcoux said. "If anybody's going to throw a party, the fraternities are the ones best prepared to do it."
But he said fraternities and the students who frequent the parties need to accept the new regulations. National fraternities, he said, prefer the use of cans instead of kegs, and many are putting pressure on chapters to have parties that are "bring your own beer" or alcohol free.
"We need to cut down on liability," Mr. Marcoux said. But, he added, this semester's first parties have shown that even with stricter regulations, "as far as how much alcohol is consumed, there has been no difference."
