HEADLINE: Garden Q. & A.

BYLINE: By Linda Yang

 BODY:

Purple Turtles
Q. At a local nursery recently, I came across a beautiful purple flowering plant called turtlehead. What is it, and what does it need to grow well? -- Tracy Wilcox, Danbury, Conn. 
 A. The turtleheads (Chelone) are native American perennials with curved, tubular flowers that resemble turtles' heads. Very likely the plant you saw is Chelone obliqua, which has graceful, rosy purple flowers that bloom in late summer and linger through fall. This long-lasting bloomer can be a carefree addition to your garden if it is in moist, acid soil and gets partial shade.
 
Let There Be Light
 Q. I'd like to grow windowsill indoor plants, but I have no windowsill sun. What do I need to grow them under artificial light? Is this very expensive? -- Terry S. Rosenberg, Boston, Mass.
A. It is so easy to set up a small light garden that it's amazing more people don't do it. All you need are two fluorescent tubes and the reflector unit that holds them.
Although special bulbs have been touted as the last word in light-garden technology, they are relatively costly. Instead, many gardeners have found that the light spectrum that most plants need can be produced inexpensively by using a cool light or daylight fluorescent tube, together with a warm light tube, either 20 or 40 watts each.
Economical two-tube reflector units and bulbs can be found at hardware stores, but be sure to measure your window space so you know what size to buy.
Position the light unit so that the plants are no closer to the tube than about two inches, and no further away than about 10 inches. Since plants need both light and dark (day and night), it is wise to use an automatic timer to turn the lights on and off. A typical "day" for plants growing under lights is 14 to 16 hours, but there is no rule that this period must coincide with an actual day. You can reverse "day and night" to suit your decorating needs.
For a pamphlet titled "Learn to Grow Under Fluorescent Lights," by Pat Morrison, send $3 to M. T. Dieterich, 481 Great Road, Acton, Mass. 01720. It is published by the Indoor Gardening Society of America.
Although now out of print, two helpful books are "Fluorescent Light Garden," by Elaine C. Cherry (Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1965), and "The Indoor Light Gardening Book," by George Elbert (Crown Publishers, 1973).
 
Small-Space Composting
 Q. I have a rooftop terrace that is not large enough for the three-bin compost system recommended by most garden periodicals. But I would like to make compost. Can I? And if so, how? -- Jeffrey G. Donnell, New York, N.Y.
A. You can make compost in even the tiniest space using a large plastic garbage pail or a wooden barrel, placed outside.
First, line the bottom with an inch or so of twigs or rocks, and cover this with several thicknesses of newspaper. Then, heap in all the fallen leaves from plants that are free of diseases, along with small pieces of soft kitchen vegetable matter, if you wish.
Every few inches add a thin layer of soil, and some packaged cow manure from a nursery. (Fresh horse manure is actually better, but most gardeners are too embarrassed to roam bridle paths or follow mounted police with a plastic bag.)
Turn the compost heap weekly and continue adding leaves until frost. If there's no rain, water enough to moisten. Next spring, a rich and fragrant soil will be your reward.
You might also consider buying a polyethylene composting unit that keeps the ingredients together in a neat, unobtrusive container. Mail-order suppliers include the Gardener's Supply Company, 128 Intervale Road, Burlington, Vt. 05401 (802) 863-1700, and the Natural Gardening Company, 217 San Anselmo Avenue, San Anselmo, Calif. 94960 (415) 456-5060. Both offer free catalogues.
Address questions to Garden Q. & A., The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Those of general interest will be published. Unpublished questions cannot be answered individually.

HEADLINE: Budget Shell Game Hides Funds for Jobless

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "A Standoff Won't Help the Jobless" (editorial, Oct. 3), you paint a one-sided picture of extending unemployment benefits by advocating additional employer taxes to pay for any extension. You favor the extension but argue the provisions of the 1990 budget agreement must be met: If you want more domestic spending, find the money to pay for it.
What a charade! Consider: 
 * A dedicated fund for payment of extended benefits exists -- $8 billion collected from employers under the Federal Unemployment Tax Act. This money can be used only if the states meet certain criteria. But these criteria are so outdated that only Rhode Island and Puerto Rico meet them. Also, the prospects that other states will be able to pay extended benefits in the foreseeable future are dim.
The $8 billion sits in the Treasury.
* These supposedly dedicated funds (along with others like the huge Social Security trust funds) are in the Federal Treasury ostensibly to help balance the budget. They are used for every purpose in addition to those to which they are dedicated. In reality, this "unified budget" concept hides the true Federal deficit.
What chicanery!
Under the terms of the temporary bill passed in Congress with a July 1992 expiration date, it's not a sin to have used the $8 billion fund. It probably will be vetoed, unjustly, by President Bush.
These extended benefits paid to claimants are high-velocity dollars; they pay the butcher, the baker and (not the proverbial candlestick makers, but) the electric company.
Thus, the multiplier effect of these benefits would be powerful enough to give the economy a significant shot in the arm.
 
HAROLD KASPER
Albany, Oct. 4, 1991
 
The writer is retired statewide director of the Unemployment Insurance Division of the New York State Department of Labor.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Democrats Find A Campaign Voice, And It's Singing A Different Tune

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
OUT on the Democratic hustings, where a grim silence reigned for so many months, a Democratic message is emerging.
It is coming from a group of five candidates who, by and large, are looking for the synthesis that eluded their party in the 1980's. They seek a message to carry the country past Reaganism, back to a more active Federal Government, and back to a Democratic Party that is trusted by the middle class to use that Government to help them. 
 The candidates are trying to tap into the anxieties of voters who are worried about the economy, education, health care and other domestic problems but need to be persuaded that a White House held by the Democrats can do anything about them.
When Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas entered the race two weeks ago, he said that middle-class voters "think that most of the help goes to those at the top of the ladder, some goes to the bottom, and nobody stands up for them." He promised to "put government back on the side" of the "forgotten middle class" -- the sons and daughters of Franklin Roosevelt's "forgotten man," moved to the suburbs but still struggling.
These candidates deliver a stinging indictment of the 1980's as a source of many of the problems today, clearly believing that the Reagan magic has lost its hold on the American people. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa compares supply-side economics to Communism, arguing that both benefited only the privileged few and both belong on the "trash heap of history."
These candidates largely dismiss President Bush as a man with almost no domestic agenda and almost no feel for the nation's problems. But most of the candidates, in their announcement speeches, have had little to say about foreign policy. Perhaps understandably they have often avoided mention of the war in the Persian Gulf, which paralyzed the Democrats politically for so many months and left Mr. Bush with towering approval ratings; it is the Democrats' version of the dog that didn't bark. The real struggle in the world today, Democrats often argue, is an economic one and the nation, because of Republican domestic policies, is ill-equipped to wage it.
The five major candidates, four of whom have formally announced their candidacies only in the past month, will spend much of the next six months emphasizing where they disagree. But they look at many of the same polls, are trying to navigate the same political terrain and are striking some of the same themes.
 
Middle-Class Squeeze
 All of the candidates talk about middle-income families who see the basics of the American Dream -- a decent job, a house, college education for their children -- harder and harder to reach. The Democrats blame both general economic decline and tax policies that, they assert, have consistently favored the wealthy at a cost to everyone else.
Senator Harkin has adopted a classic populist campaign, arguing that "George Herbert Walker Bush and J. Danforth Quayle" have been looking after their "fat cat friends."
Gov. Douglas L. Wilder of Virginia says the middle class is suffering because some Washington elites in both parties have mismanaged the Federal budget. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska casts the problem in generational terms, appealing to the baby boomers' fear: "Unless we do things differently now," he says, the children of the baby boom will fall farther and farther behind.
Still, sympathizing with the middle class is one thing; persuading it that the Democrats can help is another.
So, an implied promise has surfaced as part of the Democratic message from most of these candidates. The Democrats will be different this time.
Indeed, there are some new tunes being sung. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts delivers a scathing attack on Democratic corporate-bashing, calling it "Twinkie economics" that feels good for the moment but lacks longterm nutritional value.
Mr. Clinton flatly promises to "reinvent government," saying it has to reflect American values, including the value of personal responsibility. He pushes for stronger child support enforcement, for example, and welfare programs that require recipients to work.
Mr. Wilder presents himself as a budget cutter and a staunch advocate of fiscal discipline, not a customary appeal in a Democratic primary season.
And Mr. Wilder, Mr. Clinton and others also call for some form of middle-class tax relief, an issue that many in the party see as a comer.
 
Familiar Strains
 The party, of course, has not abandoned its old-time religion: there are also calls for new "investments" (read spending) on schools, highways, all the resources needed to help the country compete economicially. Mr. Harkin, positioning himself as the voice of unashamed liberalism, has the most full-throated appeal on this front -- and the collapse of Communism, conveniently enough, gives Mr. Harkin a ready explanation of how he will pay for it all.
Mr. Harkin presents a zero sum game: Spending money to protect affluent Western Europe from a collapsing threat, or to help rebuild America's economy. "Are you ready for a President who will declare a peace dividend and turn Star Wars into Star Schools?" he asks.
The Republicans plan to assail the Democrats as naive isolationists. Even Mr. Kerrey fretted aloud recently: "We do have to bring the rewards of the cold war home to America and to make sure we build a stronger America, but I hope and pray that it's not an America that isolates itself against the rest fo the world."
In this campaign, most of the candidates are also striving to pay close attention to the nation's feelings and the nation's soul. It is a reaction perhaps to the campaign of 1988, when Democrats suffered from the managerial, dispassionate style of Michael S. Dukakis.
In doing so, the candidates often begin with a head-on attack on Mr. Bush's promise of a "kinder, gentler America." Mr. Harkin, for example, says the Republicans have delivered "a vision of America that says you're supposed to get what you can, get it in the shortest amount of time, don't ask how you get it, just get it and to hell with everybody else."
Most of the candidates talk about restoring a sense of community. Most of the candidates also regularly accuse Mr. Bush of dividing the country along racial lines, and they cite his campaign against the pending civil rights legislation as a "quota bill."
Still, polls show voters already tend to think of Democrats as a more caring party; the candidates are also spending considerable time on the traditional values of patriotism, thrift, hard work.
The Democrats also talk about ending the nation's sour political mood, which Mr. Kerrey calls a "season of cynicism."
The common strain, in fact, throughout much of the Democratic oratory these days is a call to belief -- in government, in the party, in the abilities of these five Democrats to do better than a popular President. The leap of faith they seek is broad: Are the voters who not so very long ago wanted the Government off their backs ready now to believe in it again, at a time of bouncing checks on Capitol Hill, ugly and bitter confirmation battles and a politics that rarely lifts the spirits?

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Beyond Manhattan, Some Islands Of Growth

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
"THERE is no argument necessary but this: Long Island City will be the greatest apartment and factory proposition around New York in five years," crowed New York City's leading real estate newsletter in 1906.
As far as Long Island City's future was concerned, it was right -- up to a point. 
 Since then, Northwest Queens, the South Bronx, central Brooklyn and many other New York City neighborhoods have seen their fortunes rise and fall. The cycle of growth and decay swings with the city's economy, growing outward from the Manhattan core in good times, as in the 1920's, the 1960's and the 1980's, and stallingwhen incomes and investments lag.
While New York is currently in a downturn, the pale green glass and steel Citicorp office tower stands across the East River from Manhattan amid the old factories and rail yards of Long Island City, a monument to the last boom and perhaps a sentinel for the next. Dozens of plans for future development have been shelved at a time when the city's fiscal problems have made it harder for city officials to argue for the special subsidies to encourage building in depressed areas.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo cut through some of this gloom late last month with a $7 billion blueprint to develop several large unused parcels of land in the city and improve rail and subway lines. Developers praised him for his optimism and plans, some of which were repackaged versions of proposals made years earlier, but cautioned that another burst of prosperity would be needed to transform his wish list into concrete and steel.
 
Lower Land Values
 Until prosperity returns, most plans must wait, including those for the 6,000 homes the Governor wants at Hunters Point, Queens, or the 7,500 houses for the Arverne section of Queens, or the Penn Yards site on the Upper West Side. Those plans, made when land prices were high, would have to be modified to reflect today's lower values, particularly where the price the city expects developers to pay for the land is concerned.
Bolstered by $110 million in city tax subsidies, considerable construction has already taken place in most of the areas beyond Manhattan that are expected to become the focus of the next big push. In Long Island City 3,000 Citicorp employees are at work in its building. At the Metrotech development in central Brooklyn, work is more than half way to completion on a 4-million-square-foot complex covering 10 blocks. On Staten Island, the Teleport Telecommunications Center has grown to five low-rise office buildings, four of them fully leased by tenants such as Merrill Lynch & Company, Dun & Bradstreet and Allstate Insurance. In Flushing, millions of dollars in private funds have been invested in the last three years, most of it from Asian immigrants.
Even with prosperity, it is difficult to predict where the next wave of growth will occur. When city economic development officials and their silent partners, the builders, look at a map of the city, they see not only streets, subways and rivers, but also zoning districts, special subsidy areas, protected environmental areas, and, increasingly, obstreperous local planning groups. Each factor is a force in directing growth and each is easy to get wrong. In the 1960's, for example, when the Regional Plan Association, a planning and research group, published its forecast for future commercial centers outside of Manhattan, it pointed to 149th Street in the Bronx; Jamaica, Queens, and downtown Brooklyn. It was right about Brooklyn, partly because millions of dollars in development subsidies were poured into the huge Metrotech center and other office and housing projects between Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues.
 
Boom in Flushing
 "With all the gloom about New York, there are still nuclei of growth that will radiate outward after the recession," said Louis Winnick, a widely respected urban analyst now with the Fund for the City of New York. "My supreme example is Flushing. Flushing has more private, non-subsidized construction going on than in any part of the city. It has a big new hotel, several office buildings, five or six banks and some very large apartment complexes, all because of the big immigrant population that is settling there."
The growth of Flushing, including the new 175-room Sheraton La Guardia East hotel at 39th Street and Main Street, came from overseas Asian investors. The area was underbuilt with single-family homes occupying lots zoned for four- or five-unit apartments. Now bootstrap investors have built multiple dwellings for big profits. Transportation is also an important factor; the Flushing subway line contributes to the area's development.
Mayor David N. Dinkins is committing to renewing former Mayor Edward I. Koch's "other boroughs" program of using tax subsidies and cut-rate utilities to encourage commercial development.
The incentive plan lured Citicorp to build in Long Island City in 1989 with approximately $90 million in tax breaks over the life of the abatement; also persuasive were the area's proximity to Manhattan and the convenience of four subway lines.
Little has followed this bold step. The Hunters Point project, where Governor Cuomo would like to see a $2 billion complex of 6,000 apartments and more than 2 million square feet of office space as the next major step in rebuilding Long Island City and a keystone of Governor Cuomo's building plan, is still awaiting someone with both cash and confidence in the city.
But economic development has always been a long-term proposition, and slow times, according to David Vandor, a Queens planning consultant, are just when officials and developers should be looking ahead. "The urgency of particular projects is a little way off," Mr. Vandor said, "and now is when we should be thinking about how to save jobs, separate the buildings, plan for parking and access to the river."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Eastern Europe's Reactors Don't Seem So Distant Now

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
PROTESTERS coined the motto "A nuclear accident anywhere is a nuclear accident everywhere," but lately it has been adopted by government regulators, looking nervously at the primitive reactors in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Meeting outside Paris last month, top regulators from the seven largest industrialized nations began laying plans for international safety standards. And in Brussels on Thursday, the European Community appropriated $60 million for assistance to the Soviet Union and discussed an aid program begun earlier this year for Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. Significantly, the aid is for improving the regulation of reactors. 
 "Before this summer, you didn't see one country tell another country what to do," said Michael B. Congdon, a foreign policy adviser at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, who recently returned from a tour of reactors in the Soviet Union and the former East Bloc. "The European Community is placing a lot of pressure on Eastern Europe to close these plants," he said. For years the plants seemed distant, across an iron curtain, but the curtain was only a figure of speech and Western Europe is not very far downwind. The point was driven home Saturday morning with the report of an electrical fire at one of the surviving reactors at Chernobyl. Just as the community sets policy on farm subsidies and food additives, it now wants to set policy on nuclear plants.
There is a weak precedent for intervention. In response to the Chernobyl accident, in the Ukraine in 1986, plant owners from around the world met in Moscow in 1989 to form a World Association of Nuclear Operators, with headquarters in London. But that is an advisory group; its organizers took pride in announcing, for example, that by this spring they had arranged for the manager or chief engineer of every nuclear plant in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe to visit a Western plant. But the continuing decline of Eastern Europe has emboldened the West to go further.
 
A Delicate Subject
 In Brussels, where questions of national sovereignty are an old thorn, officials put the issue delicately. "We are providing very significant technical assistance, and we are mandated to use part of this assistance to improve regulatory matters," said an official of the European Community's Directorate for the Environment, Nuclear Safety and Civil Protection. The official, who would not be named, said that a "byproduct" of improving the regulation would be to bring the plants up to international norms.
But Simon R. Carroll, a nuclear specialist in the Brussels office of Greenpeace, the environmental organization, called the standards a pre-requisite, not a byproduct. "One of the problems is convincing the Bulgarians," he said. "Because there was no accepted international criteria, it's been difficult."
Drawing standards is hard, however, because of the great variations in design. The oldest Soviet-built plants lack the concrete-and-steel containment buildings that would hold in radiation in an accident. They were also built without the pipes and pumps that would dump water into the cooling system in case of a leak.
American officials point out, however, that the Soviet-built plants have some design strengths. In an accident like the one at Three Mile Island, they would take far longer to overheat, because there is more water in their heat-exchangers. In addition, the cores are large compared with the heat they generate, so overheating would take longer.
Recent visitors to Eastern Europe, including Ivan Selin, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, were impressed in many cases that the operators were smart and well trained. But there were telling differences. Their years of experience are useless to them in an accident, he said, because nearly all they know is normal operation; they have no simulators to practice the "crash and burn" scenarios that American operators drill for regularly.
And there are short-term problems, like manuals at the Bulgarian plants written in Russian, even though most of the Russians have gone home. Mr. Selin speaks both languages, but he was just visiting.
Most of these problems would yield to an American engineering management technique: the continuous, heavy application of money. But that, say Western officials, is at the heart of the problem, because the Eastern European plants don't generate any money, and are not likely to under democratic regimes, with candidates promising lower prices for necessities.
"Unfortunately, every country that owns these plants is in shock," said Harold R. Denton, director of the N.R.C.'s Office of Governmental and Regulatory Affairs.
Getting too closely involved in Eastern Europe is also a hazard. Mr. Denton said that Americans risked "getting co-opted" by making suggestions or paying for safety improvements for a dangerous plant, when the better option would be to close it.
The nuclear official at the European Community, asked if his group had recommended closing the Bulgarian complex, replied, "Not officially," and said some of the community's aid was being used instead to find alternatives to nuclear generation, given the severe economic impact of a shutdown.
Antony P. Froggatt, a Greenpeace organizer in London, mentioned another reason for waffling. Western companies sent in to improve existing reactors are there in large part to gain a foothold in an area that may see new reactor orders, he said. But if they are too harsh in characterizing the existing reactors, said Mr. Froggatt, "people might not want them to build new ones."
"It's a fine line for them to say, these reactors are dangerous but not too dangerous," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reactors at the Kozlodui nuclear plant in Bulgaria, which Western experts say do not meet modern safety requirements. (Arnaud Adida/Gamma-Liaison)
 
Map/Graphic: "Eastern Europe's nuclear reactors"
Soviet-designed plants, like those of other nations, differ by age. The oldest, the model 230, and the second oldest, the model 213, lack emergency core cooling systems, which would provide water in case of a pipe break. They also lack containment buildings, which would hold in radioactive gasses and particles in case of accident, although the 213 has a "confinement" which is meant to retain some of this material. An exception is the Lovisa plant, which was built by the Finns with a containment supplied by Westinghouse. An American manufacturer, as well as electronic controls from Germany. The Model 1000 comes closer to Western standards. (Sources: U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission; U.S. Council for Energy Awareness; Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development)

HEADLINE: Group of Seven Edges Toward Soviet Debt Relief

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sunday, Oct. 13

 BODY:
After an evening of meetings here with Soviet economic officials, the financial leaders of the world's seven largest industrial nations appeared ready to consider an important step toward some sort of emergency program to prevent a Soviet debt crisis, officials said early today.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the Soviet Union's key economic planner, said there had been good progress toward providing what could amount to substantial financial assistance to his country. 
 Calling the discussions "very interesting and very deep," Mr. Yavlinksy said, that the finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Seven "will be more prepared to make some concrete steps in the direction" of financial assistance.
Mr. Yavlinsky added, "The goals which we jointly are trying to achieve are not far from us."
The discussions this morning followed seven hours of meetings among the Group of Seven leaders on Saturday and then a three-hour dinner with the Soviet officials focusing on ways to shore up the faltering Soviet economy.
The meetings were held in an atmosphere of growing drama, with the Group of Seven appearing to edge closer to some kind of major debt-relief program or other form of aid for the Soviet economy. The precise shape of any final package remains unclear, and is unlikely to be concluded in great detail here.
 
Postponing Payments
 Postponement of some debt payments or some emergency short-term loans have been mentioned as possibilities for an aid package. Beyond that, the delegations said they were avoiding public discussion of details because the meetings were still in a delicate stage.
But officials said there was a growing sense that if the industrial nations wanted to stave off serious economic chaos, they must act sooner rather than later. They said the meetings would possibly produce a solid commitment to forge a financial plan.
Until now the seven nations, which include the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy, have offered billions of dollars in humanitarian aid, like food and medical supplies. The agreement to meet at such a high level with Soviet officials to consider large-scale financial aid marked an important new stage in the West's efforts to help the Soviet economy through its crisis.
Soviet officials have told Group of Seven that they expect to be unable to meet about $5 billion of payments due on loans in the remainder of this year. They have also said that their gold reserves, an important cushion, are smaller than previously believed.
The fear is that if the Soviets default on their nearly $70 billion in borrowings from the West, that could disrupt the flow of foreign goods into the country and cause credit to the Soviet Union to dry up, aggravating already critical
"We got a very good presentation from Yavlinsky," said Theo Waigel, Germany's Finance Minister.
The United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, called the exchange "very useful." A senior Japanese official said there appeared to be a sense of teamwork in the Soviet delegation, which included representatives from three of the Soviet republics. Ten of the republics said Friday that they had agreed in principle to sign a new charter for an economic community. The officials meeting here took that as an encouraging sign that, economically, the Soviet Union might not be disintegrating.
After their first meeting this afternoon, the finance ministers and central bank governors emphasized that they needed more information from the Soviets before making any decisions. They indicated, though, that they had begun to agree that some action had to be taken.
 
'We Will Listen'
 "We've established the general line we will be taking," David C. Mulford, Undersecretary for International Affairs at the United States Treasury, said Saturday.
"The most important parameter agreed to this afternoon is that we will listen to what the Soviets have to say," Mr. Mulford added.
A two-page communique issued Saturday discussed other measures agreed upon by the senior economic officials, including greater steps towards reducing the debt burden of the poorest developing countries and the need for lower interest rates to encourage more rapid economic growth among the industrial countries.
The statement indicated that the group was satisfied with the recent sharp declines in the value of the dollar, particularly against the yen. A weaker dollar would help reduce America's large trade deficit and put downward pressure on Japan's trade surplus, which has expanded significantly recently after a four-year decline.
The group "concluded that the recent exchange market developments were broadly in line with continued adjustment of external imbalances," according to the communique.
It said that the group had agreed to make bigger concessions to reduce the indebtedness of the poorest countries, providing terms "that go well beyond the relief already granted." This is likely to mean debt forgiveness for some sub-Saharan nations and other very poor countries.
 
Weak Growth in the Big 7
 The officials noted that economic growth "has been weak" in general among the seven nations and said they had agreed to adopt policies that would permit lower interest rates to stimulate expansion.
"The ministers and governors emphasized the importance of fiscal and monetary policies which, while reflecting the differing situation in each country, provide the basis for lower real interest rates and sustained growth with price stability in a medium-term perspective," the communique said.
Although the Soviet situation merited just a single paragraph -- the last one -- in the communique, it dominated the discussions, officials said. Mr. Yavlinsky and Viktor Gerashchenko, head of the central bank, are leading the Soviet delegation that arrived here late Saturday.

HEADLINE: Jordanians Urged to Back Talks

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 12

 BODY:
King Hussein urged his people today to support Jordan's decision to attend a Mideast peace conference, saying peace was the key to "a brighter future we all seek."
"Peace is essential to us in leading a normal life," the King said in a nationally televised address before about 2,500 people representing a broad spectrum of Jordanian society. Jordan's economy has been hit hard by the Persian Gulf crisis and the return of about 250,000 Jordanians from Kuwait because of the war. 
 "Jordan is practically under siege" because of its difficult financial, social and economic conditions, he said, adding that the kingdom was finding it increasingly difficult to handle problems like unemployment, which is at about 30 percent.
"We will participate in order to protect ourselves and to safeguard our country and our people," he said of the peace conference that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is trying to convene before the end of the month. Mr. Baker was scheduled to arrive in Cairo on Sunday in his latest swing through the region to continue his efforts.
The King's support for the United States-led initiative has received strenuous opposition from Jordan's powerful Muslim fundamentalists, who oppose any negotiations or peace with Israel. But the King urged Jordanians, at least half of whom are Palestinian, to be realistic and seize the opportunity.
In the past, he said, "We have failed to deal with the events within the framework of what is possible and reasonable and have, consequently, lost one opportunity after another."
The King's speech outlined plans for the current peace process.

HEADLINE: Angolan Rebel Pleads for Help in Setting Election

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
After agreeing in the spring to end 16 years of civil war, the Angolan Government and the main rebel movement have brought their rivalries to this country, with both sides soliciting support from the United States Government, the American business community and the United Nations.
Jonas Savimbi, the United States-backed guerrilla leader of the civil war against the Soviet- and Cuban-backed Angolan Government, accused the Government in Luanda of seeking to delay a national election and has asked for American and U.N. support to insure a "free and fair" vote in September 1992. 
 In a weeklong visit scheduled to end this weekend, he also presented his plan for the structural rehabilitation of the devastated Angolan economy and urged foreign investment there.
Declaring that the cease-fire in Angola was holding up, except for "minor problems," Mr. Savimbi said on Thursday that contrary to a pledge to President Bush last month, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos had recently hinted to European leaders that elections planned for September might be switched to October or November or delayed 36 months. Mr. Savimbi added that Mr. dos Santos told the National Assembly in the Angolan capital, Luanda, this week that the date of elections was not important, and that what mattered was a stable economy.
Frank Da Cruz, spokesman for the Angolan mission to the United Nations, said that President dos Santos plans to announce a date for elections on Nov. 11, Angola's national day, which marks 16 years of independence from Portugal. He said he believed that the date would be sometime between September and November 1992, as stipulated in the peace agreement.
In meetings with Mr. Bush and Congressional leaders last month, President dos Santos pledged that Angola's commitment to democracy and a free-market economy was "irreversible" and asked for help with the electoral process. He met with American business leaders to discuss trade and other economic matters, according to the Angolan Mission to the United Nations.
 
'Firm Commitment' to Peace
 In talks with both Angolan leaders, Mr. Bush repeated his "firm commitment" to the peace process outlined in the peace accords signed in May, the White House said. After a meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Savimbi this week, the White House noted that Mr. Bush repeated that he would prefer September elections.
In a meeting with more than 100 American businessmen and bankers, held by the U.S.-Angola Chamber of Commerce in Washington, Mr. dos Santos detailed changes in the Angolan economy and encouraged American investments in his country.
Mr. Savimbi, in his meetings in Washington and with the Business Council for International Understanding in New York, questioned the Angolan Government's commitment to reform. He accused Mr. dos Santos of trying "to lure American capital" to improve his party's image and warned that without outside pressure, elections might not be held before 1993.
Calling for U.N. and American observers to be involved in the electoral process, and not only in the last two months of campaigning, Mr. Savimbi accused the ruling People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola of endangering the election with acts of intimidation, denying freedom of movement and limiting access to news media.
A highlight of Mr. Savimbi's visit was a meeting on Thursday with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Mr. Savimbi said he thanked the Security General for humanitarian aid to Angola and asked for his commitment to the peace process.
Mr. Savimbi expressed confidence that his organization, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, generally known by its Portuguese acronym Unita, could win a free and fair election because it was seen as "resisting Communist domination." Trying to deflect long-standing criticism for accepting military aid from South Africa, he said the aid was necessary because of the heavy Cuban support of the current Angolan Government.

HEADLINE: For Jews on West Bank, The Motive Is Economic

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARIEL, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, Oct. 11

 BODY:
It was hardly religious fervor that sent Erez Peer apartment-buying this week at a real-estate office here.
Nor was it an ideological imperative to expand Jewish settlement on largely Arab land in this part of the West Bank, which Israelis refer to by the biblical name Samaria, although he does not disagree that Israel has a right to populate territories captured in the 1967 Middle East War. 
 No, Mr. Peer said, he was driven to the beautiful, rugged, sometimes dangerous West Bank by the most prosaic, and most fundamental, of motives: Money. There is simply not enough of it from his job as a computer engineer for him and his wife, Feli, to build a family where they are now, in Yehud, near Tel Aviv.
"We don't have a lot of choices, frankly," the 26-year-old Mr. Peer said, talking about the new apartment in Ariel that he expects to be ready by December 1992. "Here, we get some financial aid. Here, we can get a mortgage for an apartment we can afford. Here, we can live."
 
Thousands of Couples
 Here, they have been joined by several thousand other couples, most of them young and at least 1,200 of them recent Soviet immigrants, who have left Israel proper for Ariel because, they say, they like its clean air, its new schools and its suburban American texture -- and its prices.
Thanks to Government incentives, there are income-tax breaks and generous mortgages. This means that a garden apartment with four rooms can be bought for $100,000. For that kind of money, one would be lucky to find two rooms in many sections of Tel Aviv, 25 miles to the west.
All of this has combined to make Ariel the fastest-growing Israeli town in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Its experience is echoed, if not fully matched, across the occupied territories, where the Jewish population has climbed to over 100,000 and the Israeli Government has stepped up its settlement activity to increase that number by 50,000 in the next two or three years.
Four years of a Palestinian uprising has not stopped people from coming, and neither have endless denunciations of Israel's settlement policy by domestic and external critics. If anything, the attacks are a badge of honor, some here say, making them feel a bit like old-time pioneers.
 
Population Has Doubled
 Despite the last four years of turbulence, Ariel has nearly doubled its population, to 11,000, and expects to double it again in two more years. Its leaders talk about reaching 100,000 some day.
Now that an American-brokered peace conference may soon begin, anti-settlement protests have intensified once more, along with warnings that Israel may have to trade territory for peace. The Bush Administration's opposition to settlements has been stated and restated.
In Israel as well, anti-Government critics accuse the Government of trying to block peace with settlements that they say are created to populate Arab territories with so many Jews that the Israeli occupation will be made irreversible. Amiram Goldblum, a Hebrew University professor active in a group called Peace Now, charges that financial incentives offered to people like Erez Peer amount to "a forced transfer of the population into the territories," and will lead to their "de facto annexation."
But no matter what the critics say, President Bush included, and no matter how many peace conferences may be convened, few here are prepared to budge.
"I don't think this will ever go back," said Becky Gil, an American-born Israeli who moved to Ariel three years ago. "I don't think we would have put so much work into this place if we thought we were living on borrowed time."
Their strength, people here say, comes not just from the Government's commitment to settlements but also from Mr. Peer and other newcomers. It is the ordinariness of his decision that sustains this town, they argue.
"It makes this place normal," said Deputy Mayor Yigal Rosental, who moved to Ariel in 1979, a year after it was founded. "We see our success first and foremost on this point. By sitting here and living here and working here, they convince themselves and others."
"If the land were held only by the dreamers and believers and religious people, our situation would be very different," he said.
There are, of course, members of ultra-nationalist groups who continue to plunk mobile homes on the hilltops in the West Bank and insist that they are obeying divine admonitions to populate all of the biblical Land of Israel.
A dozen towns alone account for well over half the Israelis in the territories. Nearly all the bigger communities -- Ariel, Maale Adumim, Karnei Shomron, Efrat -- hug the big cities of Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, creating metropolitan sprawls intended to help the Government fulfill its goal of effectively erasing pre-1967 boundaries between the territories and Israel proper.
"Bush has this notion that settlements can be stopped because he thinks they are tents or shacks," said Meron Benvenisti, a critic of the Government and former head of a research group called the West Bank Data Base Project. "The whole concept here is metropolitan. If he imposes sanctions on settlements, he will have to impose sanctions on all of Israel."
Ariel is a good example.
It may have started as a settlement 13 years ago when a few tents were dropped by helicopter onto a hillside. But its administrative jurisdiction now sprawls across nearly eight miles.
 
Tract Houses as Well as Villas
 It is an increasingly varied town, of cookie-cutter tract houses and individually designed villas. About 1,000 new houses are now being built -- by Arab laborers from nearby villages who are put through a daily security check on the one road leading into town -- and 1,500 more are to go up next year.
There are 33 kindergarten classes, 5 elementary schools, a high school and a College of Judea and Samaria that offers vocational training and pre-university courses to 2,000 students a day.
Many of them come from Tel Aviv and its suburbs, and so do at least 400 of the 2,500 workers in the expanding Ariel industrial zone. That, Deputy Mayor Rosental say, underlines how integrated his town is with Israel itself.
Mr. Rosental admits to worries about the new political climate and the pressures he expects Israel will face to give up territory.
Some here say they are prepared to give up their town, if it comes to that. "But it must be for real peace, not just to give the Arabs this or this or this, and then it never ends," said the owner of a souvenir shop who moved here from Tel Aviv last year.
To a newcomer like Erez Peer, though, talk of peace and territorial concessions seems as remote as an affordable house in Tel Aviv. "I look at this town," he said, "and it is hard to believe that one day this will go back."

HEADLINE: Europe's Hopes for Political Pact Shaken by Dispute on Sovereignty

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The European Community's hopes of defining its much-vaunted "political union" before a crucial meeting in early December have been thrown into doubt by sharp new disagreements over how much sovereignty different countries are willing to surrender.
The latest evidence of deep divisions among community members came Friday, when the Foreign Ministers of France, Germany and Spain met in Paris to challenge an initiative on future foreign and defense policy begun by Britain and Italy one week earlier. 
 As current holder of the rotating presidency of the community, the Netherlands, in turn, chastised France for calling the separate meeting. Its prestige as a mediator, though, was badly bruised two weeks ago when its own draft treaty on political union was rejected by 10 of the 12 members.
In theory, all member nations believe the community should have a stronger political profile to match its huge economic weight, but they remain at loggerheads over whether the Twelve should eventually become a federation of nations and over what new power the community should have.
 
'Political Union' Proposed
 Britain is the strongest opponent of a federal Western Europe, but even France, Germany and Spain, which favor accelerated political integration, disagree on many specifics. Several governments also share Britain's determination to maintain NATO as the main pillar of European defense.
The Twelve have set a deadline for agreement on political union and on economic and monetary union -- including a timetable for establishing a regional central bank and a common currency -- by the time European Community leaders meet in Maastricht, the Netherlands, Dec. 9 and 10.
But while the intergovernmental conference dealing with economic and monetary union has made considerable progress over the last nine months, a parallel conference handling political union has so far served to highlight points of disagreement.
First proposed last year by France and Germany, the vague objective of "political union" was initially welcomed by all community members except Britain as a logical complement to their decision to create a single trading market after 1992 and their goal of full economic union by the late 1990's.
 
Talks in Disarray
 A rapid succession of events -- the fall of the Berlin wall, the Persian Gulf war and the conflict in Yugoslavia -- further underlined the community's difficulty in speaking with one voice on world affairs until it had fixed the rules for defining a common foreign policy.
With the United States beginning to reduce its troop presence in Western Europe, some governments, notably France, also felt the community should develop its own military capability, perhaps by absorbing a long-moribund regional military group known as the Western European Union.
When political negotiations began early this year, the most ambitious proposal involved creating a single community structure handling not only its existing economic portfolio, but also foreign and security policy and judicial and police questions. By June, though, faced with a likely British veto, the Twelve agreed to deal separately with the three areas.
Then last month, the negotiations were thrown into disarray when the Netherlands abruptly proposed a new draft treaty that not only reiterated the community's "federal goal" but also brought the three areas under a single umbrella, with new power being transferred to the European Parliament and the community's executive commission.
 
Future Defense Posture
 After every member except Belgium found some reason to object to it, the Dutch draft was abandoned in favor of a less ambitious working paper, prompting the disappointed Dutch Foreign Minister, Hans van den Broek, to note that no political treaty might be preferable to an "extremely weak" accord.
Britain, traditionally seen as the "spoiler," now wants agreement in Maastricht not only because it is eager not to be blamed for the summit talks' failure but also because prolongation of political negotiations might turn Europe into a campaign issue in next year's British elections.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORS MAKING BUDAPEST UNEASY

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Oct. 12

 BODY:
With the civil war in Yugoslavia raging on its southern border, Slovak separatism rising on the northern side of the Danube in Czechoslovakia, and increased tensions to the east in Romania, Hungarians have reason to feel insecure.
"We feel increasingly threatened not because of anything that might happen in Hungary," said Gyula Kodolanyi, a foreign affairs adviser to the Hungarian Government "but if there is a conflict in Yugoslavia, tensions are high between Bohemia and Slovakia, and things are on the move again in Romania -- all in all, it is not very easy to feel happy and calm." 
 Hungary's geographic location puts it in the eye of the storms that are now roiling across Central Europe. As the most homogenous and prosperous country in the region, it has been spared the nationalist hostilities and some of the economic hardships that have beset its neighbors. But still it feels vulnerable, in particular out of concern for the three million ethnic Hungarians living in Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Romania and the Ukraine.
The fighting in neighboring Croatia, which has historic ties to Hungary, has already cut off Hungary's access to the Adriatic oil pipeline. Yugoslav fighter planes have crossed into Hungarian air space several times, and last month the Yugoslav Army accused the Hungarians of shooting down two planes, a charge vigorously denied by Budapest.
 
Stampede of Refugees
 One of Hungary's biggest fears is of being caught in a stampede of refugees, with those fleeing the war in Croatia colliding with those fleeing poverty in Romania and the Soviet Union. Last weekend, for the first time, Hungary turned back visitors at the Soviet and Romanian borders, requiring those entering Hungary to prove they have enough money to return home. As a result, about 3,000 people were denied entry at the Romanian border last Saturday, a Hungarian border guard said.
Hungary has accepted 72,000 refugees since 1988. About 2,000 Yugoslavs are now officially registered in refugee camps, and estimates on the number who have come across the border seeking temporary shelter from the fighting range as high as 35,000.
In Washington earlier this month and again at a meeting of top regional officials on Sunday in Cracow, Poland, Prime Minister Jozsef Antall of Hungary called on the West, in particular NATO and the United States, to help Eastern Europe's new democracies protect themselves.
"The point is NATO should assume responsibility for the security of the region lying between its borders and the Soviet border," Mr. Antall told the Foreign Policy Institute of George Washington University on Oct. 3. "The legal and organizational issues are of secondary importance."
Mr. Antall welcomed a U.S.-German proposal allowing for the participation of Eastern European countries in NATO councils, perhaps through a regional affiliate. He repeated Hungary's position that full membership in NATO would not be appropriate now.
 
New Hungarian-Soviet Treaty
 Since the withdrawal of Soviet troops in June and the defeat of Moscow's hard-liners in the failed coup in August, fears of Soviet dominance have ebbed here. A new treaty between Hungary and the Soviet Union is expected to be signed soon, after the Soviet Foreign Minister, Boris D. Pankin, removed a clause that would have blocked Hungary from joining any alliance the Soviet Union viewed as hostile.
Instead of the old Soviet threat, Hungary and other Eastern European countries are now confronted with a new and unpredictable situation as the Soviet republics sort out relations with one another, and their neighbors. They see the West's failure to cope with Yugoslavia's civil war as a bad omen for other possible conflicts.
"If it proves that the whole world is powerless, then Yugoslavia is a negative message for future crises," Mr. Antall said at a news conference after his meeting in Cracow with the Polish President, Lech Walesa, and the Czechoslovak President, Vaclav Havel. "You have to understand that it is not a problem of a small area, but a problem which concerns all of Europe."
In Washington, where he met with President Bush, Mr. Antall urged the United States to play a more active role in solving the Yugoslav crisis. "The United States cannot entrust the settlement of the Yugoslav crisis exclusively to Western Europe," he said.
 
History of Tangled Alliances
 Like much else in the region, Hungary's position on the conflict in Yugoslavia is dictated by a long history of tangled alliances, loyalties and suspicions. Before the breakup of the Austro-Hungarian Empire after World War I, Croatia was part of the Hungarian Kingdom. Those ties came up earlier this year, when Hungary was found to have been shipping arms to the breakaway Croatian republic.
After first denying the reports, Budapest was later forced to admit they were true. Faced with outrage from the Serbians and the federal Yugoslav government, Hungary declared a ban on all arms sales to Yugoslavia.
Since then, Hungary has tried to maintain a measured distance from the Yugoslav crisis, refusing to join in Germany's call for recognition of Slovenian and Croatian independence.
"We would not be accepted as mediators in the conflict," Mr. Kodolanyi, the Hungarian Government's foreign adviser, said in a recent interview. "That became clear very early on and has to do with deplorable reflexes, which are not shared on our part."

HEADLINE: Logging Regulation Bill Vetoed in California

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
In a move that could signal the renewal of a bitter conservation battle, Gov. Pete Wilson vetoed a logging-regulation bill on Friday that was meant as a compromise between enviromentalists and lumber companies.
Governor Wilson said the bill was too inflexible and would have imposed "unnecessary economic hardship on companies." But the Republican Governor immediately pledged to propose new legislation and asked the State Board of Forestry to begin implementing changes on its own. 
 Supporters of the legislation said they were outraged, and added that the veto could erode the good standing the Governor had cultivated with environmentalists. Conservation groups said that they were preparing a voter iniative, to be placed on next June's ballot, that would protect California's redwood forests and regulate logging more strictly than the vetoed bill.
"By vetoing a pragmatic, balanced solution to the timber wars, Governor Wilson has snatched defeat from the jaws of victory," said Dan Taylor, western regional representative for the National Audubon Society. Byron Sher, a Democratic Assemblyman from Palo Alto and sponsor of the legislation, said the Governor had "squandered an historic opportunity to resolve the timber wars through legislation."
The bill, meant to regulate logging on private timberlands, would have required lumber companies to cut trees only as fast as they grow new ones. The bill also banned clear cutting in old-growth forests and restricted clear cutting to 20-acre parcels in other areas, compared to 120 acres under the current law. Clear cutting refers to removing all the trees in a given area at once, leaving a swath of bare ground.
But the travails of the legislation, which might have been viewed as a model for the rest of the nation, suggests how difficult it will be to balance the demands of protecting forests and wildlife and protecting the livelihood of the forest products industry.
 
Attemept to Avoid Costly Battles
 The compromise was an attempt to avoid costly battles over voter initiatives, such as the one in 1990, when the conservationists and lumber companies spent millions backing rival proposals. The compromise was negotiated mainly by the Sierra Club and Sierra Pacific Industries, the state's largest timberland owner. It was supported by some environmental groups and a few lumber companies.
But several other large timber companies, such as Pacific Lumber and Louisiana-Pacific, opposed the bill as too restrictive, while many smaller environmental groups opposed it as too lax. For that reason, many environmentalists were happy the Governor vetoed the bill, though they were not happy with his reasons for doing so.
In the final days before the Legislature adjourned in September, Mr. Wilson proposed many changes in the bill that would have made it less onerous for the lumber companies. Most of those amendments were added, causing the Sierra Club to withdraw its support. But a few key proposals of the Governor were not added, including one that would have provided exemptions to some of the rules in counties with high unemployment.
Environmentalists say they believe the voter initiative they are preparing for June has a better chance of winning than the one that was narrowly defeated in 1990. That is because the new initiative lacks the provision for a huge bond issue to buy old-growth forests, a provision that is believed to have scared some voters last time.
Still, there was some hope held out that Governor Wilson could still avert a new eruption of the "timber wars." Environmentalists are especially heartened that some reform will be entrusted to Richard Wilson, the Governor's newly named Director of Forestry, who has long been active in efforts to save redwood forests.
Hal Arbit, a wealthy San Mateo investor who almost single-handedly financed the environmental voter initiative last year, said in a statement: "I know the Governor doesn't want this issue resolved at the ballot box. I only hope he will show us another alternative. If there was ever a need for statesmanship on this issue, it's now."
