HEADLINE: A Course in Capitalism For Soviet Enterprisers

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Chris Somers and Viktor Donyants have a lot to talk about as they ride back and forth to work each day: jobs and families, history and politics.
Mr. Donyants, 42 years old, is in the United States to learn new skills so he can expand his telecommunications company in Moscow. Mr. Somers, 30, is his American host; he sells phone systems for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. 
 A few miles away, in Emeryville, Calif., Sue Scott, a manufacturer of ornamental lights, is giving a crash course in sales and product development to Larisa Maslova so that her fledgling cooperative in St. Petersburg can break into the foreign trade market, exporting expensive mirrors and chandeliers to hotels and restaurants.
 
An Exchange of Visitors
 The Soviets and Americans were brought together by Sharon Tennison, a nurse who set out eight years ago to encourage links between private citizens because she was alarmed by the bellicose tone of politicians in Moscow and Washington.
Since then the Center for U.S.-U.S.S.R. Initiatives, founded here by Ms. Tennison, has brought Soviet visitors to 265 cities in the United States, where they spend three weeks living in American homes. And she has taken architects and educators, students and environmentalists, lawyers and doctors to the Soviet Union. The center also helped establish 47 Alcoholics Anonymous groups in 14 Soviet cities.
As Soviet leaders rush to end state control of industry, the center, which has a staff working to identify promising candidates in eight of the Soviet republics, finds itself out in front as the most experienced nongovernmental group prepared to help Soviet entrepreneurs. The distinction is both exhilarating and a little unsettling for an organization unaccustomed to such attention.
"We're moving quickly; no, we're racing," Ms. Tennison said recently. "We see Soviet citizens scrambling to build private businesses and to develop democratic institutions. They don't have the time for academic training. They must quickly grasp enough fundamentals to build their own businesses and create goods and services for their people."
 
Emphasis on Enterprise
 In May the center scaled back on most of its other activities to concentrate on its Enterprise Development Program, which has brought entrepreneurs like Mr. Donyants and Ms. Maslova here and has taken others like them to Missouri, Illinois, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.
This year 100 Soviet entrepreneurs were paired with their American counterparts. The number could increase, depending on the availability of qualified candidates, American sponsors and money. The center receives no government financing; it depends on a small but growing group of philanthropies and the willingness of companies like A.T.&T. to pay about $1,000, a modest share of the cost. The costs are low because company officials also provide housing and participants pay for their overseas travel.
So far the response has been enthusiastic from American hosts like Elliot Hoffman, founder and president of Just Desserts in San Francisco, who built his company from a home-kitchen operation into a multimillion-dollar enterprise.
Mr. Hoffman, a 44-year-old native of New York City, calls himself a child of the 60's. "I cut off my pony tail, shaved the beard but kept the ideals," he said with a grin. "I've always been attracted to causes."
Outside the rear door of the Just Desserts plant, paroled convicts tend tidy plots of berries, herbs and flowers, learning a skill and getting paid for their work. The strawberries will end up atop the company's cheesecake.
Yelena Kholina, one of the center's first Soviet entrepreneurs, spent a month at Just Desserts in January and was planning to start her own bakery in Moscow. But she lost her financial base when the ruble was devalued in February. Mr. Hoffman then promised to help with money and equipment. He also gave her 12 of his favorite receipes.
Sue Scott, like Mr. Hoffman, began modestly. She borrowed $25,000 and started turning out plastic lamps in the shape of lizards and fish. She has built her company, Primal Lite, into an enterprise that does business around the world, with annual sales of $3 million.
In addition to giving the center $1,000 for the program, she shares with Ms. Maslova her business plans, sales reports and bookkeeping records.
"I don't see myself as giving away trade secrets," Ms. Scott said. "I'm telling her what she needs to know to succeed. This has been one of the most exciting events of my life. I feel I am being part of history."
Ms. Scott, 37, said she was influenced by her grandparents, who traveled to Russia many years ago and brought home stories about the people there. "They wanted me to know the Russians were people like us, not monsters. They brought the world to me when I was young. But on a practical business level, I also believe we are a global economy and we cannot pretend otherwise."
A number of the center's participating companies are already moving toward joint ventures with Soviet businesses. Nevertheless, stimulating business between Soviet and American partners will not be a simple task, said Boris Khersonski, an entrepreneur from the Ukraine.
Mr. Khersonski, who has a degree in physics, came here earlier this year. He heads a cooperative that manufactures doors and windows, runs a private health service that offers porcelain dentistry, and manufactures metal badges.
After completing his internship under the center's training program, he returned to help write a series of manuals for prospective entrepreneurs in the Soviet Union.
Virtually all the placements made by the center appear to have been useful, Soviet participants said. The exception was one young woman who arrived, found romance and eloped.
Mr. Donyants, meanwhile, plans to pursue efforts to establish telecommunications services in Soviet airports with A.T.&T., a prospect that pleases company officials.
"Establishing relations with someone who is leading the way is very important to us," said Randall A. Shields, an A.T.&T. spokesman. "What a ripe market it is."
For Mr. Somers, Mr. Donyants's American host, the opportunity of doing business has a more personal prospect. "Viktor and I talk about how great it would be if one day his kids could play with my kids," he said. "At the very least, I've made a friend."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Goodbye, Skipper, Goodbye

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Either baseball owners and general managers are the greatest optimists since Pollyanna, or they are the greatest dopes since Goofy. They have had a long and gory history of firing their managers in order, of course, to hire new ones who, in almost every case, are fired, later if not sooner.
Not only does the brass think that the next guy in a dugout has to be better than the guy they've got, but then they also obviously can never figure out who the best next guy is. And he's told to pack his pajamas and hit the road, too. 
 During the regular work week last week, four managers were fired and a fifth, Jim Essian of the Cubs, understood that the end was near, after less than a full season as the captain of the ship, the lieutenant of the platoon, the head lemming. As it stood, 12 managers of the 26 teams have been dismissed since opening day for being ignoramuses, dolts, nincompoops. In other words, they didn't win any division championship lately.
One, Joe Morgan of the Red Sox, won two division titles in the previous three years. Another, Jim Lefebvre of Seattle, managed his team to its best record in club history, and also saw attendance records set in that dank and dismal cave known as the Kingdome. Both are unemployed, as of last week.
Never before have so many been dismissed in such a compact time frame. Why? Are the new owners -- often from the corporate world and rarely like some of the old-time bosses whose sole income was derived from baseball -- dumb about how to build a baseball team, seeking a quick fix, buckling to public pressure or simply trying to sell more luxury boxes?
Or does it matter? Is a baseball manager important in actual terms, or is the job overrated, and its significance just a figment of John McGraw's imagination?
"It must be pretty important," said Cito Gaston, the manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, who were down to the Minnesota Twins by a two-games-to-one margin in the American League playoff going into last night's game here. "Because are managers the ones who get the blame for not winning?"
"It's true that a manager can't hit or pitch or catch for his players," he added, "but maybe you can motivate them a little. You think, 'How would you like to be treated?' and treat them that way."
Anything else? "Let 'em play and get out of the way."
The other three managers in the playoffs -- Tom Kelly of the Twins, Bobby Cox of the Atlanta Braves and Jim Leyland of the Pittsburgh Pirates -- were asked the same question, "How important is a manager?"
Each paused and then said the same thing, "I don't know."
Each, though, went on to deplore the rash of recent firings. "If they fired Joe Morgan," Leyland said when he heard that news, "then none of us are safe."
Then each touched on what he believes is the most trenchant part of their jobs.
Leyland, whose spring-training confrontation with one of his stars, Barry Bonds, seemed to gain the respect of the players, said he actually tries not to be intrusive. "I keep one eye closed and one ear closed, and pull a pitcher once in a while, and turn 'em loose," he said.
While some managers have been fired for being too tough, some have been fired for being too easy. "Like now," said Leyland, "the players are in the clubhouse playing cards and playing a dunk basketball game. Should I tell them to cut it out and read Ted Williams's hitting book?"
Cox said: "I establish the rules. Try to be honest with 'em, and then say, 'Go get 'em.' "
Are these managers being overmodest, or oversimplistic? What about strategy? Aren't they supposed to be the Einsteins, the Napoleons, the Solomons of the diamond? How, for example, did the Twins jump from last place to first in just one season? "Better pitching," said Kelly.
Was he responsible for the better pitching? "Well, the ownership showed patience with the younger pitchers, and that helped me," he said. He added that the acquisitions of Jack Morris, Carl Willis and Steve Bedrosian also improved his mind.
"Otherwise," he said, "I just ask them to be prepared, help them a little with it, and tell them to run out everything and play hard. No half speed."
Certainly, as in other occupations, some baseball managers are better suited for the job than others. And dealing with people (including the press) appears today to be an even more vital requirement than knowing when to hit-and-run. After all, the players will take care of the execution. Or they will not. And as soon as they don't, they will, with ever greater frequency, watch as old Skip waves goodbye to them from the back of the fading caboose.

HEADLINE: Study Says Exxon Will Pay Less in New Spill Pact

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The Exxon Valdez oil spill settlement will cost the Exxon Corporation about $5.5 million less over the next decade than an earlier agreement that was rejected, a state-commissioned analysis says.
That is because the $1 billion deal was structured so more of the payments would be tax deductible, a consultant, Milt Barker, told a House subcommittee on Friday. So even though Exxon is required to pay $25 million more than the previous settlement, its real cost will be far less, said Mr. Barker, a former deputy commissioner of the State Revenue Department. 
 The settlement of state and Federal litigation over the 1989 spill in Prince William Sound was signed early this month. A Federal judge in Anchorage approved the settlement on Tuesday.
The analysis said the state gained about $40 million more under the new settlement, after inflation, than it would have under the old agreement. That is because more money is going into a trust to restore the sound than into the Federal treasury.
The inflation-adjusted value of the settlement to the state is $754 million, as against $713.7 million under the old settlement, the study said. The value of the new agreement to the Federal Government is just $6.5 million, as against $52.3 million under the previous one.
"The Federal Government clearly comes out the loser in dollar terms," Mr. Barker said.
His analysis said the after-tax, inflation-adjusted cost of the settlement to Exxon was just $462.9 million, $562.1 million less than its paper value of $1.025 billion.
The financial burden to Exxon is also reduced because a large part of the money will be paid seven months later than it would have been paid if the first settlement had been accepted last spring, Mr. Barker said.
Under the original settlement, Exxon would have paid a $100 million criminal fine, split between the state and Federal Government. Fines cannot be deducted from state and Federal taxes.
But under the new agreement, the fine was restructured. The net result is that Exxon will pay a fine of only $25 million to the Federal treasury, and $100 million in "restitution" to restore the sound. Restitution generally is tax deductible, Mr. Barker said.
The civil portion of the settlement, which requires Exxon to pay $900 million over 11 years to the restoration fund, was unchanged. That money can also be deducted from the oil company's taxes.
The Exxon Valdez oil spill, the worst ever in United States waters, occurred on March 24, 1989, when the company's supertanker struck a reef.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Climbing Back;
New York City's First Hurdle: Defeatism

 BODY:
New Yorkers are losing heart. And it is no wonder that many fear their city is disintegrating. A huge budget deficit probably means dirtier streets, unkempt parks and shorter library hours. Almost a million New Yorkers are on welfare, supported by an ever-thinner base of taxpayers. Homeless mental cases huddle in corners everywhere, or beg aggressively. Drugs so ravage neighborhoods that desperate parents in the Bronx are driven to chain their daughter to a bed to save her from the streets. And every macho teen-ager seems to be packing a gun.
Who can feel safe in an era of random shootings? Who does not fear the flare-up of race hatred when vicious whites from Queens club a black athlete senseless in Atlantic Beach and vicious blacks stab a young Jew to death in Crown Heights? 
 At a time when we crave strong leadership, Mayor David Dinkins has been dishearteningly passive and Gov. Mario Cuomo has been irresponsibly remote -- only rousing himself a few weeks ago to propose a revival plan whose payoff lies chiefly in the future.
But despair is an overreaction. New York has emerged from worse crises, over and over again, and been stronger than ever.
New York is no longer a great port, no longer a major manufacturing center, and even its role as a headquarters city is eroding. But new roles will emerge, just as they did the last time around. Great cities don't die; they adapt.
No one knows when a turnaround in the economy will start increasing municipal revenues. The urgent task now is to lay the groundwork for revival. New Yorkers need to set their governmental house in order and also make inspired investments in the future. That will require leadership from the Mayor and Governor -- and unselfish support from labor, business and all New Yorkers.
There are specific tasks. In coming weeks, we'll offer suggestions for economic development, for getting guns off the streets, repairing the infrastructure and education, among other pressing issues. But beyond specifics, what New York needs most right now is to put pessimism aside and start building, start coming back. With a determined attack on its problems, there is no reason why New York City must simply endure; it can once again prosper.
New York is suffering from four overlapping crises. All will be tough but none is insurmountable.
 
 
The Crisis at City Hall
 New York faces enormous budget gaps; taxes and other revenues have plummeted below projections. The city barely balanced its budget this year. Now it faces gaps of about $1.5 billion in each of the next three years.
One can blame the Reagan and Bush Administrations. A steep withdrawal of Federal payments to cities has deprived New York of billions of dollars. But this crisis is not nearly as severe as the one that brought the city to its knees in the 1970's.
At that time, the city resorted to gimmicks and up to $6 billion in short-term borrowing to hide the chasm. It accounted for more than 40 percent of all tax-exempt short-term borrowing in the United States. Ultimately, no bank would lend the city more and it teetered on the edge of bankruptcy.
Today's crisis is far more manageable. The city's accounting practices are honest, and monitors stand ready to force the budget into balance.
The chief difference now is the lack of leadership and help from higher levels of government. In the last fiscal crisis, Gov. Hugh Carey made it his historic mission to save the city. He was able to advance needed funds, created institutions to monitor and manage city finances, lobbied successfully for Federal help and knocked heads to enlist labor and business in a rescue effort.
This time around, Washington seems indifferent to the cities, and Governor Cuomo confronts his own budget crisis. The Governor's new plan to take over Medicaid costs in future years and to back several big public works projects offers a welcome energizer. But much more is needed.
The city, which grandly expanded its work force by some 50,000 during the flush 1980's, now must scale back. Labor leaders, who have stoutly resisted layoffs and more productive work rules, need to think of the city's future. And business needs to get much more heavily engaged.
Unless New Yorkers are willing to accept higher taxes, declining services, or both, the work force must be made much more productive, delivering the same services on a smaller budget. The city has an extraordinary opportunity to achieve workplace reforms under the discipline of hard times.
 
 
The Crisis in the Economy
 The signs of recession are all around. Venerable department stores have closed. Huge office towers stand half empty. Layoffs and consolidations shrink the private work force in sectors synonymous with New York's pre-eminence: Wall Street, banking, the great law firms, the renowned retail merchants, television, publishing.
But this recession is less punishing than the recession that triggered the last fiscal crisis. Between 1969 and 1977, the city lost more than 600,000 jobs and unemployment climbed to 11.2 percent. In the current recession, the city has lost 150,000 to 200,000 jobs since a peak in September 1989; unemployment averaged 6.8 percent last year and reached 9.3 percent in August.
What makes the current downturn frightening is that no one is sure that the city's fortunes will turn up when the national economy eventually revives. The city was propelled out of its last recession by an unforeseen boom in finance, real estate and business services. No one can guess what sectors might rescue the city this time. The only sensible policy is to stabilize the city's budget while searching for ways to propel the next cycle of growth.
 
 
The Social Crisis
 The city's social problems sometimes appear overwhelming. Beyond the age-old scourges of poverty, drugs and disease, guns have proliferated beyond imagination. And New York must deal with the nation's largest caseload of AIDS victims, and probably the largest outpouring of homeless people.
The most intractable problem is poverty. Some 945,000 New Yorkers were on public assistance in mid-1991, the most since the total soared above a million in the 1970's. By some counts, more than half the city budget goes for services to poverty-stricken people and areas.
The poor live disproportionately in New York and other cities; supporting them is a problem that can only be addressed by higher levels of government. Unless Washington and Albany pitch in, the poor will remain a drain on the city and its taxpayers.
 
 
The Morale Crisis
 New York's problems are magnified by pessimism. When The New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll asked in June of 1990, "Do you think that 10 or 15 years from now, New York City will be a better place to live than it is now," only 20 percent said yes, the lowest percentage in two decades. One big question is whether some of the loss in confidence -- at least among whites and the business establishment -- is related to the shifting power balance that produced the city's first black mayor. The polls show that blacks are somewhat more optimistic than are whites.
The danger is that pessimism can become self-fulfilling, accelerating the city's decline. Major businesses might bail out, as Morgan Stanley is threatening to do, taking jobs as well as taxes. Or the young and the talented who traditionally flock to New York might look elsewhere to make careers.
The surest antidote to exaggerated negativism is reality. The subways, once dangerous and dirty, have become dramatically cleaner and more reliable. Huge capital investments are improving the infrastructure and housing stock. Reading and math scores are rising a bit, and school attendance has reached the highest levels in a quarter century. Infant mortality is down, as are complaints of child abuse, despite a few highly publicized cases. And, for all its pain, the recession is tempering the high cost of living, making it possible for young people to think about staying, or coming back.
This city remains a beacon for the world. Its cultural offerings are unequaled; its professions and businesses are often tops in their fields; its academic and medical institutions often first-rate. Immigrants flock here in astonishing numbers: almost 30 percent of the population is foreign-born, infusing energy and aspiration into the economy.
New York's ills are common to many American cities but its strengths are unrivaled. New York will come back. Strong leadership and committed citizens can hasten the day.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Tough Times, but Not the Toughest" shows New York City public assistance recipients from 1970 to 1991, Job gains and losses from 1970 to 1991, and New York City unemployment rate from 1970 to 1991. (Source: N.Y.C. Human Resources Administration; U.S. Buraeu of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: When Hateful Words Lead to Hateful Deeds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Prof. Michael Levin of City College, in "The Lessons of Hate" (Op-Ed, Sept. 26), his blatantly self-serving defense of freedom of speech for hatemongers and racists, skillfully recasts the child's nursery rhyme "Sticks and stones will break my bones, but names will never hurt me" in terms of John Stuart Mill's philosophy of liberty. I would certainly agree that odious deeds count for more than odious words. The sound of a truncheon cracking a skull in Soweto is more ominous than the half-whispered epithets that hover, like escaping sewer gases, over so many public arenas in New York City these days. 
 Professor Levin implies that theories linking race and temperament are not to be confounded with such direct hands-on agents of racial oppression as lynch mobs and cyanide gas. He chooses not to grapple with the paradox of a naive interpretation of freedom that sets free the forces of its own destruction by enabling the growth of intolerance. Finally, he seems to be unaware of the historical role that intellectuals have played, not only in setting off social revolutions but far more frequently in creating the conditions of complicity without which the slave ships would not have sailed and the ovens of Auschwitz would not have burned.
Consider the lies that Europeans told of the native Americans that they "discovered" five centuries ago. Both myths -- of the noble and of the bloodthirsty savage -- precluded the possibility of genuine intercultural recognition and coexistence and set the stage for the campaigns of genocidal slaughter that still negate the West's claim to an enlightened vision of political life.
Some lies can aspire to great longevity. The anti-Semitic lie is more than 1,000 years old. The anti-African lie goes back only four centuries to the rise of the sugar and slave economy that catalyzed the growth of industrial capitalism.
Both these lies are being retold and reworked by race theorists like Professors Levin and Leonard Jeffries Jr. around the central lie of 19th-century, pre-Mendelian, genetic science, that is, the notion that race is a fixed and bounded package of biologically critical traits as opposed to an open and evanescent, essentially trivial biological entity, quickly dissolved in the flux of contact, migration and human love.
 
THOMAS BELMONTE
Hempstead, L.I., Sept. 26, 1991
 
The writer is an associate professor of anthropology, Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: DESIGN;
Handle With Care

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
LIKE INFANTS, ANTIQUES SHOWS quickly develop personalities of their own. It doesn't take more than a season before word spreads that a show has a particular look and a particular strength. In Paris, for example, the Biennale Internationale des Antiquaries is known for its sheer spectacle of over-the-top presentations and for its superlative offerings of fine French furniture. Grosvenor House, that other great bastion of showmanship, on the other hand, has long held a reputation for its staid but elegant English antiques. In this country, the International Antique Dealers Show, while only in its third year, is known for its European polish and its strength in decorative objects like the porcelains shown here.
Many attribute the extraordinary porcelains, which will be on view when the six-day antique show opens Oct. 19 at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, to the eye and taste of the London-based organizers, Anna and Brian Haughton. Themselves ceramicists, the Haugh tons are also widely recognized for the specialized decorative-arts exhibitions they pull together, namely the International Ceramics Fair and the International Silver and Jewelry Fair, both held annually in London. 
 "Just because we are ceramic dealers," Brian Haughton says, "when planning the International Show we've tried to cover all aspects of collecting." Nevertheless, the couple have handpicked top porcelain dealers from the United States and Europe, and the offerings are among the most substantial found in any general antiques show. "There's far better variety," says Letitia Roberts, who heads the porcelain department at Sotheby's. "Not just a lot of restored Famille Rose services as you tend to get in other shows. There's serious quality here." Not to mention serious prices. "This is a show for the mature collector," says Allan Chait, a New York-based dealer. "The Winter Antiques Show, on the other hand, plays to a variety of collectors, from the beginner on up."
Yet the International Antique Dealers Show is a great opportunity for beginners to learn more about a field and to meet the top people. Despite the staggering costs of participating (the average booth is about $13,000, not to mention installation and decorating, and, of particular concern to Europeans, shipping costs), dealers find it an excellent place to meet a new group of potential customers. "Shows like this one have become important promotional tools," says Paul Vandekar, president of Earle D. Vandekar, a New York gallery. "This is a way of making ourselves accessible to new buyers, which is crucial. We're merchants and we need to sell." Dominick Jellienk, a director of Bluett & Sons, another London-based shop, agrees: "New York is the center of the art world in the United States, and the show is a good bit of publicity for us."
While good publicity helps business, it doesn't solve another problem: finding fresh pieces to exhibit. Indeed, at a time when the art market is feeling the effects of the recession, collectors who don't have to sell aren't. "They're sitting on things," Chait says, "which means dealers now really have to beat the bushes." But unlike other areas of collecting -- Impressionist and modern paintings, for example -- porcelain hasn't been as badly affected by falling prices. "Chinese porcelain has done fairly well in spite of things," says Khalil Rizk of the Chinese Porcelain Company, a New York gallery. "Prices have held. Perhaps that's because the field has had a slower growth and a sturdier foundation." Still, dealers pride themselves on producing merchandise that is new to the market, a task that becomes harder each season.
"We've entered an era where the so-called speculators have disappeared and those who buy are people who truly love porcelain, which is good," Rizk says. Even so, dealers are holding their breath, hoping they will turn a profit at the International. "Everyone's counting on a return to normalcy, and that moods and attitudes in the art market will improve this fall," Chait says. "But who knows? Dealing is a gamble, and I've yet to find a crystal ball that works. They're all cloudy."

HEADLINE: In Rebuttal to Senate Panel, C.I.A. Nominee Seems Truthful but Incomplete

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates staked his nomination to head the Central Intelligence Agency on an impassioned 20-point rebuttal to charges that he slanted analysis. But a review of his testimony suggests that he was both truthful and evasive, careful and incomplete, that he effectively rebutted some allegations but offered technical and misleading denials of others.
The Senate Intelligence Committee, which is to vote on his nomination on Friday, is struggling with the daunting task of sorting out the facts on a number of complicated, often murky issues. 
 While most of the Senate spent the week transfixed by the sexual harassment accusations against the Supreme Court nominee, Clarence Thomas, the intelligence committee's staff has been assembling thousands of pages of documents, testimony and affidavits dealing with accusations that Mr. Gates tailored intelligence reports and suppressed dissent, either because of his own pessimistic view of the Kremlin or to please his boss, William J. Casey.
The issue is so divisive, and senators and staff members so sensitive to accusations that they themselves may inadvertantly slant the data, that the report to committee members will not draw any conclusions about the seriousness of the assertions or the truthfulness of Mr. Gates's responses, some committee members said.
After the committee votes, it is expected to write a comprehensive report that will try to address and resolve some of the most sensitive issues as a guide for the full Senate.
Mr. Gates's rebuttal before the committee on Oct. 3 reflects a strategy of concentrated counterattack in which he focused primarily on the accusations of Melvin A. Goodman, a former senior analyst who now teaches at the National Defense University. Mr. Goodman said that the output of the Directorate of Intelligence under Mr. Gates "was systematically politicized" and the agency's mission to provide objective analysis "was compromised and the professional integrity of its analysts undermined."
Mr. Gates did not directly rebut two other analysts who testified against him, and it was only when pressed that he addressed a number of issues raised by Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who has taken the lead in questioning the quality and veracity of much of the intelligence analysis produced under Mr. Gates's management.
 
Nominee Mentions Only Some Facts
 Mr. Gates's rebuttal illustrates his own approach to intelligence, as he put it at the hearings, "telling it like it is, with the bark off." But in defending himself, Mr. Gates also seemed to exhibit some of the same traits that his critics say flawed his tenure as the C.I.A's top analyst: selectively choosing his facts to make his case.
Both Democrats and Republicans on the committee have praised the chairman of the panel, David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, for making an extraordinary effort to be as thorough as possible. But the issue of tailoring intelligence is so broad that as of now, a number of accusations have not been fully aired before the committee.
The panel has not subpoenaed potentially important witnesses, like Morton I. Abramowitz, the former director of the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research, which was critical of some of the agency's analyses. The staff is still petitioning the C.I.A. for relevant documents, and in the last few days has received sworn statements from two more former agency officials who are also critical of Mr. Gates, said people who have seen the statements.
The White House, meanwhile, has sought to bolster Mr. Gates's standing by soliciting laudatory letters from four of the five former Directors of Central Intelligence.
After receiving phone calls from Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, Richard M. Helms, William E. Colby and William H. Webster wrote strongly supportive letters, while James R. Schlesinger praised the nominee, but added that he had no knowledge of whether accusations made against him were true. Stansfield Turner, who has privately told former colleagues of his opposition to the nomination, said he was not asked for his opinion.
In some instances in his rebuttal, Mr. Gates both narrowed the allegations and gave partial answers. For example, in denying that he repeatedly tried to insert accusations in agency documents that the Soviets had used a chemical toxin known as "yellow rain" in Afghanistan and Southeast Asia, he referred only to Afghanistan. And he said that there was only one instance, in 1985, in which an agency document referred to the subject of lethal chemicals.
But in a letter to the committee, Elisa D. Harris, a senior research analyst at the Brookings Institution and a leading expert on chemical and biological weapons, said that two State Department reports to Congress in 1982 made the accusation against the Soviets, using evidence provided by the C.I.A. The letter said that the accusations were also the subject of special interagency "estimates" produced by the C.I.A. under Mr. Gates's tenure. In addition, from 1984 on, the accusations were repeated in the President's annual reports to Congress on Soviet noncompliance with arms control agreements, she said.
"On the surface his response sounded pretty good, but Gates needs to be more truthful on what the agency line was on this issue," Ms. Harris said in an interview. "In my judgment, the judgments of the scientific community and a large part of the policy community, what the Reagan Administration called toxin warfare was, in fact, bee feces."
 
Denial of Ignoring Analysts' Objections
 In another instance, Mr. Gates denied the accusation that he endorsed, over the objections of his Soviet analysts, an estimate by an independent contractor accusing the Soviets of coordinating terrorist activities in Libya, Iran and Syria. He said that the estimate was written by a C.I.A. analyst, not a contractor, and that the result was a "useful" and "carefully drafted" document that was disputed only by the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research.
Former agency analysts say the report earned the nickname "the three stooges," because of its effort to link terrorist operations in the three countries. They recall that Wayne Limberg, a State Department official and former C.I.A. Soviet analyst, was instructed not to write any footnotes on the terrorism analysis, because Mr. Gates preferred that there be none. Mr. Gates denied that was so.
Since Mr. Gates's testimony, the committee has received a sworn statement from Mr. Limberg citing several instances in which he believed Mr. Gates slanted intelligence and suppressed dissent, people who have reviewed his statement say. He related, for example, an instance concerning a 1984 estimate on Soviet activity in the third world in which he said Mr. Gates instructed him to delete several footnotes stating that there were signs that the Soviets were rethinking their expansionist policy in the third world.
Mr. Gates also dismissed accusations that he influenced analysts on events in Nicaragua, a turbulent subject that provoked sharp disputes both within the C.I.A. and between the agency and outside intelligence organizations, like the State Department's intelligence bureau. But he limited his rebuttal to two points, denying that he inflated the successes of the contra rebels without supporting evidence between 1984 and 1986 and that he killed a paper that doubted the likelihood that the Soviets would send jet fighters to the Sandinista regime.
In his defense on the contra accusation, Mr. Gates cited two C.I.A. estimates on Nicaragua, one in 1985 and another in 1986. He said that each described "serious contra problems and forecast of further declines in effectiveness and unlikelihood of real improvement in contra performance."
Long before the issue of slanting intelligence arose at Mr. Gates's hearings, the House and Senate investigating committees examining the Iran-contra affair concluded in a November 1987 report that the C.I.A. under Mr. Casey "misrepresented or selectively used available intelligence to support the policy he was promoting, particularly in Central America."
But the record compiled in several investigations into the affair and the writings of several officials suggests that at times agency officials did inflate contra successes in recruiting fighters, magnify their difficulties in obtaining supplies and exaggerate the significance of Sandinista military incursions into Honduras as well as the threat of Soviet aid in the form of fighter jets.
 
Agency Perceptions About the Kremlin
 At times in his testimony, Mr. Gates selected one or two documents to support his point, while ignoring those that seemed damaging. For example, in rebutting the accusation that he and Mr. Casey created a view of the Soviet Union that ignored Soviet vulnerabilties, he referred to a memo he wrote in 1986. The memo spoke of his concern that the agency "was not being creative enough" in its analysis of Soviet economic and political developments, failing to give adequate attention to the achievements of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
What Mr. Gates did not mention was his own bleak view of Moscow that he detailed in more than a dozen speeches and articles between 1986 and 1988. His testimony that the agency was writing about Mr. Gorbachev's commitment to economic reform and his mixed record on political reform even before he came to power was at variance with accounts by Douglas J. MacEachin, the chief of the agency's arms control staff and a former head of Soviet analysis. Mr. MacEachin told the committee that the agency never approached the Soviet Union "as a society, and therefore, I think we were really not ready for the way to deal with the reactions when finally the lid did come up."
While Mr. Gates conceding under questioning that he should have done more, he said that he had trouble getting his economists to talk with respected emigres like Igor Birman, who has written several studies on the Soviet economy for the Defense Department.
But in December 1984, nearly two years before Mr. Gates's memo urging more creative analysis on the Soviet Union, Dr. Birman sent him a letter stating his opinion that the Soviet economy was not nearly as strong as the C.I.A. thought it was. In a second letter, Dr. Birman invited Mr. Gates to his home for "a dinner, Russian style," to discuss their differences. Instead, Mr. Birman said, he was interviewed in a rather cursory way by analysts who did not take his views seriously.
"I tried to tell Gates in the letter that his people were not convinceable," Mr. Birman said in an interivew. "Now he's castigating his people for not listening to me. Why couldn't he talk to me, especially since I was right?"
In his rebuttal, Mr. Gates also did not respond to a number of key accusations. These include the allegation that he misled the Senate Foreign Relations Committee about Soviet influence in Iran in January 1987, and that he verbally attacked an analyst for writing a report on the effect of sanctions in Libya that was inconsistent with American policy.
In those remarks, he did not seek to defend his memo to Mr. Casey in 1984 advocating the bombing of military targets in Nicaragua, nor did he mention a speech that he repeatedly gave in 1986 and 1987 that detailed Soviet expansionism in the third world despite the absence of intelligence data, although he later addressed those issues in questioning.
 
Convincing Rebuttal On Attack on Pope
 Mr. Gates's rebuttal, along with sworn statements of other agency employees, persuasively demonstrated that some actions attributed to him were actually undertaken by subordinates without his knowledge.
For example, Mr. Gates effectively parried Mr. Goodman's charges that he had stage-managed a 1985 study examining the likelihood of Soviet complicity in the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II. Mr. Goodman said that Mr. Gates personally rewrote the paper's summary and conclusions, removing all references to inconsistencies that suggested the Soviets were not behind the shooting in 1981.
Mr. Gates provided four sworn statements of analysts who participated in the study. Each said that Mr. Gates, who ordered the project at Mr. Casey's request, played no personal role in recasting the report and never tried to influence the outcome.
Separately, the committee made public an internal C.I.A. review of how that agency had analyzed the question of who was behind the assassination attempt. The report, by a panel of three senior analysts, absolved Mr. Gates of trying to preordain the study's conclusions. But it found that entitling the paper "The Case for Soviet Involvement" had "stacked the deck" and concluded that managers beneath Mr. Gates did try to tailor their reports to the fit the preconceptions of their superiors.
Five of Mr. Gates's 20 points focused on a number of issues regarding Iran. The most contentious remains a 1985 interagency estimate that the Soviets were making inroads into an increasingly unstable Iran. The estimate was used by the White House as the basis for a directive to sell arms to Iran.
In his testimony, he acknowledged that he called Mr. Abramowitz, then the head of the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research, to persuade him not to dissent from the report in a footnote. Mr. Gates said that he, Mr. Casey and other senior intelligence officials believed the difference of view with the State Department was "so scant that it was unwarranted," adding that it only concerned the seriousness of Iran's instability, not Soviet opportunities.
Former and current State Department officials remember it differently. They said that their initial proposal included three dissenting footnotes to Mr. Gates, including one relating to Soviet influence. The officals added that there was so much concern about the thrust of the argument that when Graham Fuller, the National Intelligence Officer who drafted the estimate, wrote a subsequent paper on May 17 that laid out the situation in Iran in even starker terms, they wrote a critique of the paper to Secretary of State George P. Shultz complaining about the politicization of the process.
Photo: Robert M. Gates during testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

CORRECTION-DATE: October 20, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Robert M. Gates's rebuttal of charges that he slanted intelligence information misidentified the Senate Intelligence Committee's source of statements from several analysts. At the committee's request, the analysts provided the statements, which concerned their role in a 1985 C.I.A. study assessing the likelihood of Soviet complicity in the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II. The statements were not provided by Mr. Gates.

HEADLINE: State Assessment A 'Horrendous' Process

 BODY:
At a time of weak real-estate markets and disturbing increases in foreclosure rates, the New York State Equalization and Assessment Board is again seeking to perform its destructive "hatchet job" on the homeowners of Long Island by once more calling for reassessment of residential properties. In some unsuspecting areas where municipalities have acquiesced, it has been a painful and horrendous process.
 The state government has already done a great deal of harm here by forcing Long Island to bear the greatest brunt of the reduction in state aid to education of any area in the state, thereby causing increased taxes and major disruptions in education. 
The State of New York has also recently let the businessmen of Long Island down by reneging on last year's promises of economic development assistance which would have helped to increase employment and would have brought a lift to business here in general.
 For those who may not be aware, currently Nassau County performs the assessments, which remain constant until new construction is added. It is only the tax rate which we must thus keep our eye on.
 To consider (as the State E 7A would have us do) giving the County Board of Assessors the ability each year to use both increases in rates and assessments as a means of increasing the pipeline to our wallets would be a major blunder.
 Not only would such a system cost about $30 million to $40 million to initiate, but the constant instability would also cause a surge in foreclosures as has not yet been seen here.
 Who would then be interested in buying a home here? Who could afford to go on living here? The new families and the elderly would have to make tracks for some more affordable area elsewhere.
 
ROSE EISNER

 Valley Stream The writer is executive director of the Civic Action Council of Nassau County, a group of civic associations.

HEADLINE: Lieberman Thrives on His Fast-Paced Life

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
IN the quiet of his French country-style home in the Westville section of New Haven, Joseph I. Lieberman settled into a living- room chair and cradled a cup of tea. Cutting a lean, athletic figure in a denim-blue shirt and red tie, Connecticut's junior United States Senator said he had just returned from a conference in Budapest that explored the political transitions taking place in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. He said the region's academicians, writers and politicians were both tense and optimistic.
"Most people are worried about whether Yugoslavia is an indication of the whole region," he said. "The situation is very similar to a bottle with a cap on it with all sorts of pressures building up inside." 
 As he talked, his 3-year-old daughter, Hana, crossed back and forth through the room, followed closely by an au pair. Meanwhile, Mr. Lieberman's wife, Hadassah, a math and science-education researcher for the National Research Council, organized clothing for the family's return to Washington. The shuttle between New Haven and the Liebermans' town house in Georgetown, four miles from the Capitol, has been one of many adjustments the family has had to make since he was elected in 1988, he said.
 
'Invigorating and Incredible'
 The 49-year-old Democratic Senator, who marked his 1,000th day in office last month, described political life as a continuing exercise in research and development. He said his first term in the Senate has been highlighted by several major international events, like the fall of communism and the Persian Gulf war, and the opportunity to write several laws on environmental and consumer protection.
"It's been an invigorating and incredible two and a half years," Mr. Lieberman said.
Since narrowly defeating the incumbent, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., in 1988, Mr. Lieberman, formerly a State Senator and Attorney General, has been praised by members of both parties for his proficiency and grasp of issues. While his voting record is similar to that of his Democratic colleague, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Mr. Lieberman has shown an independent streak in several major areas.
He supported a cut in the capital-gains tax rate, which his party opposes, and an aggressive foreign policy. Last January, for example, the Senator became one of the handful of Democrats who voted to authorize military action in the Persian Gulf region. He also supported President Bush's use of military force in Panama in 1988.
On issues concerning the environment, Mr. Lieberman has helped to create several significant pieces of legislation. As a principal author of the 1990 Clean Air Act, he was instrumental in establishing a review board for toxic chemicals and an interstate commission in the Northeast to monitor air pollution and enforce regulations.
He noted that passing the air-quality law required a great deal of legislative wrestling. "The end result, I thought, was good," he said. "But to get there required a lot of compromising."
 
Worked for Alar's Withdrawal
 A member of the Environment and Public Works Committee and chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee on Consumer and Environmental Affairs, Senator Lieberman wrote parts of the law passed last year that imposes penalties on companies that refuse to follow Government orders to clean up after oil spills.
He also wrote the Pollution Prosecution Act of 1990, which increases the number of investigators for the Environmental Protection Agency, and he served as a vital figure in legislation that led the Uniroyal Chemical Company of Middlebury to withdraw the ripening agent Alar from use on food. The chemical had been linked to cancer in laboratory animals.
An ardent spokesman against oil drilling in the Arctic National Refuge in Alaska, Mr. Lieberman said he would like to see less oil exploration and more Government tax incentives to encourage businesses to develop alternative energy sources, like solar and geothermal power. In May the Senate Energy Committee passed legislation that would allow drilling in the refuge, and the full Senate is expected to take the matter up this fall.
"To me, the Arctic National Refuge is one of those issues that says a lot about who we are as a country," he said. "The prospects of oil being found there are limited. And even if it is found, we can't justify the risk of destroying this unique system. Drilling in this natural resource is encouraging a policy that says we can't produce our way out of our energy problems."
Of particular interest to Connecticut residents is that the Senator was successful in urging the Environmental Protection Agency to create a Long Island Sound office, and he helped obtain $2.5 million for Federal studies of the Sound. In addition, last year he worked to establish the first National Historic Site in Connecticut at the J. Alden Weir Farm in Wilton and Ridgefield. Weir was a leader of the American Impressionist movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
Mr. Lieberman has been a staunch critic of the national Democratic Party, saying it has retreated from its traditional emphasis on foreign policy and economic growth. While the party's commitment to social programs had been important, he said, it cannot regain the Presidency unless it begins developing policies to stimulate the economy, like Federal tax incentives for businesses and interest-free business loans, and encourages a strong economic and military presence abroad.
 
Constituents Opposed War
 "One of the biggest problems is that the Democratic Party has too often been seen not as an advocate but instead off on a tangent that really didn't matter to the great majority of people," he said. "And unfortunately, we're still going through that struggle."
Mr. Lieberman was one of only 10 Democrats who voted to authorize force in the Persian Gulf region last January, despite letters from Connecticut residents that overwhelmingly urged him to vote against such measures. During the war his home in New Haven was picketed by anti-war protesters five times, he said.
"It was a very serious time for me and an unsettling time for my family," he said. "It was the first time that I ever had to cast a vote that I knew would probably mean the lives of people.
"Yes, I listen to my constituents. But this was one time where I had to decide what was right. And there are simply times when governments have to use force to stop the bad to protect the good. And this was one of those times. And I hoped people would accept that."
One of the great lessons of the gulf war, he said, was the lack of Government control over the oil pricing system. Last spring Mr. Lieberman introduced a measure that aims to curtail price gouging by imposing a tax on oil companies' windfall profits.
Since taking office Senator Lieberman has conducted 17 town meetings across the state. His program of service to his constituents includes an office in Hartford and a van that has traveled to 55 communities to provide help and allow staff members to hear people's concerns.
 
Help for Lyme Disease Group
 After hearing the story of one Connecticut resident's ordeal with Lyme disease, Mr. Lieberman obtained $7 million for research and education on the illness. Karen Forshner, a Tolland resident, became infected with the disease while she was pregnant in 1985 and passed the bacterium to her son, who was born with severe disabilities.
Mrs. Forshner said in a recent telephone interview that at the time, lack of research prevented doctors from diagnosing her child with the disease until two years later. He died in June at the age of 6.
In 1988 Mrs. Forshner co-founded the Lyme-Borreliosis Foundation, a privately financed nonprofit group dedicated to educating the public about Lyme disease. With the help of Senator Lieberman, she said, she will be receiving $210,000 in Federal funds for an education campaign.
She added that before she talked with the Senator about the need for Lyme disease research, she had approached dozens of other government officials.
"Senator Lieberman was one of the few people who came through," she said. "He's the type of person who, when he tells you he's going to do something, he does it."
Before her son's death, Mr. Lieberman wrote her a handwritten note, she said, "to tell us he was there for us."
 
'A Time to Step Back'
 While in Washington, Mr. Lieberman said, most of his social time is spent with his family. An observant Jew, he remains deeply committed to his faith, he said. He did not campaign on the Sabbath but has worked on some Saturdays when there were votes in the Senate, he said.
The Sabbath is "a time to step back, reflect and appreciate what we have," he said. "For me it's a substantive celebration of life."
Mr. Lieberman said that one of the highlights of his recent trip to Europe with his wife was a stop in Prague, where Mrs. Lieberman was born. Her parents, who were Holocaust survivors, brought her to the United States when she was a small child. While she was growing up in New York City, Mrs. Lieberman recalled, her father would tell her stories about Prague and its people, and she longed to return.
"Going back there gave me the feeling that I had at last completed the cycle that my parents had started," she said. "Here we had survived Hitler, and now, after all this time, I was returning, married to a U.S. Senator. And that was a very special feeling."

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 17; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 750 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Questions on Questions In 'The Engagement'

BYLINE: BY ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
TOM, Pat and Jeffrey agree that "marriage ruins friendships." So when their buddy, Tony, who has a "great business, money and all the women he wants," tells them he's going to get engaged to Susan, they set out to put a stop to that at once.
Even though Susan rejects Tony's roses and his ring, Jeffrey, a lawyer and a self-described "expert in relationships," knows just how to change their minds. He'll tell all: Sexual and financial transgressions. Names. Places. Dates. Details. Jeffrey, you see, keeps files on his friends. And on their girlfriends. On himself, too. He carries them around in his attache case. Just in case. 
 Don't ask why anyone would care to spend a couple of hours with the adolescent-fixated likes of Tom, Pat and Jeffrey. Especially Jeffrey. Or Tony. But then it isn't clear what they see in each other. Except that they like to "go out and break things."
In "The Engagement," which unaccountably opened the George Street Playhouse's new season, the playwright, Richard Vetere, fails to invest such off-putting characters with stage life, or for that matter, to validate their bonding. It's tough to find ways where he, positively, succeeds, save for those moments where the "guys" have moments of shared truths ("If you weren't my friend, I'd swear you were an idiot") or self-revelation ("I'm a selfish creep"), though one such declaration ("I'm no dope") is arguable.
For all that, it isn't just a playwright's faulty craftsmanship that casts an almost irredeemable pall over the proceedings. "The Engagement" raises questions, mostly rhetorical, unanswerable or just plain random and unavoidable, but distressing all the same. Innocuously inept plays may not invite such sorts; only insistently inept ones do.
Is theater a real alternative to television? What was on the tube the night we saw "The Engagement" and why did we miss it? What manner of works were rejected by the theater in favor of this play? Does this one reflect the sensibility of the George Street Playhouse and its audiences? Or is it just one of those crazy things?
Come to think of it, Rosemary Clooney's classy rendition of that Cole Porter standard is played at the top of the second act, before the pall is reset. It is in that second act, after the moment of redemption according to Porter and Clooney, that Mr. Vetere, with redundance rather than facility, makes it obvious the torturous first act was indeed leading up to something.
These emotional wrecks, who brag about "what women'll do," who know that "women say these things" and who insist that you "gotta take possession" of them, are really panic stricken by commitment. They get to have a meaningless little insight while, with a single possible exception, keeping their sexist sensibilities intact. There is a plot turn that should not be divulged though the theater's newsletter, in cavalier disregard for the denouement of Mr. Vetere's play, blows the whole thing, and in further disservice to the playwright, allows him to explain, with scant attention to economy or syntax, his reasons for writing "The Engagement."
Failing to differentiate between farce and fatuity, Mr. Vetere has contrived a series of sight gags that the director Matthew Penn, who appears unable to find a connection between one scene and another -- Melinda Mullins as Susan is lost in befuddlement at the end of two of them -- makes neither sense nor good nonsense of. Most incoherent is a desperate attempt to wring laughs from Jeffrey's plight, when he gets his hand caught in a mailbox during a rain storm, all the while trying to make a telephone call with the other.
Although Jeffrey is by far the play's most odious and finally buffoonish character, none are authenticated by interesting characterizations or stage worthy, as opposed to overheard, dialogue. Unsupported, the cast flounders, Miss Mullins especially, and ought not to be appraised by these performances, especially Joseph Siravo, whose exaggerated whining as a stereotype of an Italian restaurant owner is in itself cause for indignation.
Given such an appalling piece, one can even fault the extravagant production design -- three spiffy apartments, or parts thereof -- by Deborah Jasien. In an economic pinch, the mailbox and the phone booth were hardly necessary. Nor was the rain.
"The Engagement," by Richard Vetere, at the George Street Playhouse, 9 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. Performances through next Sunday. Box office: (908) 246-7469.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Countryman, left, during scene from "The Engagement" with Melinda Mullins and Joseph Siravo at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. (Miguel Pagliere)
