HEADLINE: Executives Ponder Urban Problems

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 12

 BODY:
Corporate America must broaden its horizons to include an attack on drugs, crime, welfare dependency and poverty, a panel of specialists on problems of inner-city areas told the nation's most elite business club. Business has "gotten the message," the panel said, about the need to help improve education.
Businesses "need to be part of the solution" because they cannot escape being hurt financially by unaddressed urban pathologies, Jerry E. Abramson, the Mayor of Louisville, Ky., told reporters after addressing a closed-door session of the Business Council, whose fall meeting here at the Homestead Resort ended today. "And once you hit them in the bottom line, their hearts and minds and pocketbooks and wallets will follow," he added. 
 Mayor Abramson was joined by five others, including Prof. Shelby Steele of San Jose State University in California, in challenging 100 chief executives to expand their social commitments to embrace issues of housing and transportation and to lobby for Federal programs like Head Start, the preschool program for poor children, and the nutrition program WIC (Women, Infants and Children).
The others in the group, whose presentation constituted almost half of the meeting's formal agenda, were Harold L. Hodgkinson, director of the Center for Demographic Policy at the Institute for Educational Leadership; Peter H. Reuter, director of the Drug Policy Research Center at the Rand Corporation; Geraldine L. Carter, executive director of the Survival Skills Institute, and David T. Ellwood, a professor at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
But while Professor Ellwood said he was "quite astonished" by the attention of the businessmen -- the council has no female members -- to urban problems, the dominant view of the executives was frustration about the magnitude of those problems and doubts about how to tackle them.
"People are struggling with how to do it," said Charles S. Sanford Jr., chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, which he said had "all along" made low-profile efforts to address social problems in New York.
Andrew C. Sigler, head of the Champion International Corporation, said that while businesses had immense amounts of knowledge, it was mostly "in a very narrow area" that is not easily harnessed for explicit social goals.
And Howard P. Allen, chairman of the executive committee of SCE Corp, the holding company for the Southern California Edison Company, said that while he thought new initiatives were likely, regulators and other authorities were more often obstacles rather than facilitators. "Government doesn't create an environment to let us help," Mr. Allen said.
 
An 'Encouraging Sign'

Kay R. Whitmore, head of the Eastman Kodak Company, agreed with the panel that the problem was not one-dimensional but insisted that education, which he said was far from being adequately addressed, should be pre-eminent. "We still believe that education is the key issue," Mr. Whitmore said.
Hamish Maxwell, chairman of Philip Morris Companies, took the Business Council's agenda itself as evidence of increased interest in helping improve conditions in urban areas. "The fact that everybody is talking about it is a pretty encouraging sign," he said. Philip Morris has interests in beer and cigarettes, two businesses that are sometimes criticized for targeting inner-city and minority populations.
But while the panelists talked about a host of inner-city problems, which they said would inevitably become more widespread if not dealt with, Kenneth H. Olsen, president of the Digital Equipment Corporation, said he wished they had also mentioned the doleful effects of television.

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Three Issues of Bills

 BODY:
A total of $21.6 billion of three- and six-month Treasury bills are scheduled to be auctioned tomorrow. The auctions, usually held on Mondays, were rescheduled this week because of the Columbus Day holiday today. On Thursday, the Treasury will offer $12.5 billion of one-year bills.
By late in the day on Friday, the outstanding three-month bills were being bid at 4.94 percent, and six-month bills at 4.99 percent.

HEADLINE: A Page From Fast Food's Menu

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Inspiration recently struck George Loesch during breakfast at Denny's. In scouting the competition, Mr. Loesch frequently holds breakfast meetings at fast-food restaurants, where he picks apart the sausage biscuits and eagerly devours new menu items.
Mr. Loesch works not for a rival restaurant chain, as his fast-food fieldwork might imply, but for the Campbell Soup Company, best known for its home heat-and-serve offerings. Inspired by the popularity of a large-portion breakfast on the Denny's menu, Mr. Loesch recently shepherded to market a line of "Big Start" home breakfasts. The meals, which offer such entrees as pancakes with scrambled eggs and bacon, are the newest addition to the Great Start brand sold by Swanson's, a division of Campbell Soup.
 
Boasting About Borrowing

Mr. Loesch freely acknowledges that he got the idea from Denny's, a restaurant chain owned by TW Services Inc. He even boasts of it in a sales brochure for grocers that invites them to "take a bite out of the restaurant business" by stocking the new Swanson product line, which was introduced in July. 
 More and more makers of packaged foods are taking cues from fast-food menus. In addition to breakfasts like eggs and sausages on biscuits, the supermarket freezer case is filled these days with products like the Geo. A. Hormel & Company's Bacon Cheeseburger, Swanson's Chicken Nuggets and Tyson Foods Inc.'s Hot 'n' Spicy chicken wings -- all products that food experts say were prompted by the success of similar offerings in restaurants.
Such are the tactics in the fierce fight over "share of stomach," the food industry term for the consumer's food dollar. Americans spend more than $500 billion a year on food, and restaurants account for an increasingly larger portion of the total.
Consumers' restaurant spending will reach $262 billion this year, or 48.5 percent of total food spending, according to estimates by Technomic, a Chicago food consulting firm, while grocery store food sales will reach $278 billion, or 51.5 percent.
For packaged-food retailers, that is a disturbing drop from 1980, when supermarkets attracted nearly 60 percent of food spending. The trend reflects the growth of single-parent households and of households where both parents work -- situations that create a time squeeze that has benefited fast-food chains in particular.
To fight back, supermarkets are devoting more and more space to salad bars and deli sections. And increasingly, food companies are offering grocers packaged foods that mimic items popular in restaurant settings.
"Instead of having a breakfast sandwich at McDonald's, you can pick one up from the freezer of your grocery store," said Ron Paul, president of Technomic, who predicted that many more fast-food products will show up on the grocers' shelves and freezers.
In recent weeks, for example, Conagra Inc. and the Quaker Oats Company have joined other food companies by introducing low-fat ground beef products. The Conagra offering, which is sold at the meat counter of grocery stores, has only 4 percent fat, compared with the 20 percent or so typically found in regular ground beef.
 
Stalking the Mclean Deluxe
 The lean-beef trend follows McDonald's introduction last spring of Mclean Deluxe, a 91 percent fat-free hamburger that has received widespread attention.
"McDonald's stirred up an awful lot of interest," said Bill O'Neill, vice president of sales and marketing at Fairbank Farms, a maker of low-fat ground beef in Ashville, N.Y., 75 miles southwest of Buffalo. "We piggybacked off that, big time," he said gleefully.
As McDonald's introduced its Mclean in various parts of the country, Mr. O'Neill's sales force was there at every turn. "We tried to get the scoop on where they were moving next and take the information to retailers," Mr. O'Neill said. That allowed retailers to tie their advertising to McDonald's Mclean introduction.
In the case of Conagra, however, executives said their company had been working on low-fat ground beef for a year, and the timing of its introduction had nothing to do with McDonald's. With its Healthy Choice line of low-fat, low-sodium frozen dinners, Conagra has proved a nimble innovator in recent years.
But the influence of McDonald's on the packaged-food industry is clearly evident. Mary Adolf of the Beef Industry Council in Chicago said she was deluged by calls from meat buyers at large supermarket chains seeking the names of suppliers of low-fat ground beef after the McDonald's announcement.
"Retailers and food service operators are duking it out for consumer dollars," she said. "The move by McDonald's prompted retailers to want to market a similar type product for home use."
Tim Hammonds, senior vice president for the Food Marketing Institute, a supermarket trade group in Washington, acknowledged that the growth of the fast-food chains over the last 20 years had hurt grocers. "That industry has gained largely at the expense of the supermarket industry," he said.
Recently, he said, there are indications that the weak economy has led people to eat out less and buy more food at grocery stores. With the new products, Mr. Hammonds said, "There is a real opportunity for us to hold on to some of those customers as the economy improves."
Armed with stocked freezers, supermarkets are ready to do battle with the Egg McMuffin. Although McDonald's introduced the Egg McMuffins in 1975, it was not until the company expanded its menu with a variety of breakfast sandwiches in 1986 that the category caught fire -- and the food companies' attention.
 
'Clones of Fast Food'
 "We've had a tremendous onslaught of frozen breakfast products that are the clones of fast food," said Martin Friedman, editor of the Chicago newsletter, Gorman's New Product News.
Executives at large food companies, however, reject the notion that fast-food restaurants act as product development labs for packaged food makers. And they argue that their companies have done a better job than restaurants of making healthy food availble.
"It's a real race to see who is picking up on these trends and responding," said William Zick, a vice president with International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., a company that makes flavorings for the prepared-food industry.
For several reasons, restaurants tend to be more nimble. Introducing a product can cost a major packaged-food company up to $30 million, because it involves retooling production lines, creating television advertisements and new packaging.
To test a breakfast burrito, however, McDonald's can simply ask a few stores to start serving the product.
"The cost of trying a new item is very small for restaurants," said Mr. Paul of Technomic. "They can literally change production runs everyday."
 
Blurring the Boundaries
 Based on the number of restaurants now experimenting with skinless fried chicken, Mr. Paul expects such products to show up soon at the grocery store.
The very boundaries between supermarkets and restaurants are becoming increasingly blurred. In a striking illustration of the overlap, Taco Bell, the fast-food Mexican restaurant operator, opened a small kiosk in a supermarket in Phoenix earlier this month.
"The lines between the segments are starting to come down," said John E. Martin, president and chief executive of Taco Bell, a unit of Pepsico Inc.
"Everybody is looking at everybody else," he said.

The Economy
The Fed is expected to report that blacks and other minorities are denied mortgages far more frequently than whites with comparable income. While the Fed has not yet made public its data, one official warned a meeting of the American Bankers Association last week that a study would show "dramatic disparities in loan rejection rates." In advance of the report, a detailed picture of some lending policies along racial lines has come from large banks involved in mergers. [Page D1.] Corporate America must broaden its horizons to include a broad attack on urban problems like drugs, crime, welfare dependency and poverty, a panel of specialists on the inner city told the Business Council. [D2.] 
 A leading lobbyist for the insurance industry has succeeded in twisting the banking overhaul bill from one that would help banks to one that would roll back advances that bankers have already made in getting into the insurance business. But the reputation of the industry has been tarnished in recent months, and he runs the risk of overplaying his hand. [D1.]

 Companies

 International

HEADLINE: Far Rockaway Journal;
Weeds Hide a Precious Patch of Past

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
Alberto Garcia has been living on New Haven Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens, for 10 years, but it was news to him that across the street from his apartment building, behind a row of small houses, was an official New York City landmark.
"I don't know anything about it," Mr. Garcia, a hotel worker, said of the Richard Cornell Graveyard, a cemetery dating from the 17th century. 
 Even if Mr. Garcia had ventured behind the houses, or the nursing home or the overgrown vacant lot that also hide the cemetery, he still would not have known that he was standing on a precious patch of past.
The 75-by-67-foot cemetery, which the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated a landmark in 1970 because of its "special historical and esthetic interest and value" in New York City's development, is a long-neglected tangle of weeds, fallen tree limbs and construction rubbish dumped there in the last two decades.
What's more, there is not a single gravestone to mark the graves of Richard Cornell, the first white settler in the Rockaways, who died in the 1690's, or nearly 30 of his descendants and relatives.
The half dozen or so gravestones that local history buffs say stood there in 1970, when the cemetery was already in decline, have disappeared. So have pieces of the other stones that were scattered on the site then. The history buffs, who have followed the cemetery's decay with dismay, say the city took the stones for safekeeping shortly after the cemetery was made a landmark. Then, there was talk of a restoration, which never fully materialized. The city has since lost track of where it stored the gravestones, the buffs say.
The chief of staff of the Landmarks Commission, Joan R. Olshansky, insisted recently that any removal of the stones "was not done under city auspices."
In any case, all this is the lamentable legacy of the past. Now, if Ms. Olshansky's agency can convert aspiration to actuality, a new chapter will be written in the site's long history.
Working with the local historians, Rockaway's civic leaders and some Cornell descendants, the Landmarks Commission has spurred still another effort to restore what it hailed in 1970 as "one of the few old burial grounds in the city which have survived to the present day."
"About a year or so ago a couple of my staff people were in the neighborhood and went to see it and were appalled," Ms. Olshansky recalled. "The Cornell family, who owned the property, didn't have a great deal of interest or the necessary funds to maintain it."
As for the commission's own role, she said, "We've always had a small staff and not enough funds to monitor all the landmarks."
Mary Cornell, the wife of Richard Cornell of Kew Gardens, Queens, a 14th-generation descendant of the first Richard, said: "The family really didn't know they owned it anymore. We thought it belonged to the city."
At the cemetery the other day, Stanley Cogan, president of the Queens Historical Society, who heads a 13-member task force to carry out the renewed rescue effort, described the effort's theme as "bringing the Cornell cemetery back to life."
He and some other task force members guided a visitor to the site by stepping gingerly through the garbage and weeds of a city-owned lot fronting the cemetery near New Haven and Caffrey Avenues, a lot they hope will be converted to a park-like access.
After removing the debris in the cemetery, which the task force hopes to start soon, the cemetery will be returned to its 18th-century appearance, they said. The disappeared gravestones? Emil Lucev, another member, said they still might be found, possibly buried in the graveyard itself. If not, there is always the possibility of producing "facsimiles" of all the markers once in the yard, said the other members on the visit, Mel Cantor, Leon Locke and Craig Bachrow. Preservation purists, however, could object to reproductions.
Peering beyond such details, Mrs. Cornell, also active in the restoration, focused on the ultimate concern. "People shouldn't be forgotten," she said, "especially people who did so much in getting the area started."

HEADLINE: 7 Rich Nations To Help Soviets Plan Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The leading industrial democracies took a major step today toward helping in the reconstruction of the Soviet economic system and its integration with the West, announcing that they had accepted a plea from Soviet officials to help devise a reform program.
"They have asked us to come be a part of a process that sets up a new system in the Soviet Union," the United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, said at a press conference after a series of meetings he and other top officials had with senior Soviet financial officials. "That's a very important statement in my view." 
 Norman Lamont, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, said: "It was a very useful, historic meeting. They clearly feel that support from the West in their efforts enhances their credibility and chances for reform."
 
Visit by Western Officials
 The first practical step is that the deputy finance ministers of the world's seven leading industrial nations, the Group of Seven, will go to Moscow in a few weeks to consult with Soviet officials on their reform plans and to study current Soviet financial difficulties. This means that the industrialized nations have started to treat the Soviet Union in some ways as a developing nation mired in debt and in need of basic reform before new aid can be granted.
The two days of meetings between the top financial officials of the Group of Seven, and a Soviet delegation led by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a top Soviet financial planner, resulted in a conceptual leap in the West's dealings with the Soviet Union, moving toward far greater cooperation and an increase in the West's influence over Soviet affairs.
The economic leaders here said pointedly that Mr. Yavlinsky and the other Soviet officials did not ask for and were not offered direct financial support, although they acknowledged that Soviet economic problems were reaching a critical stage. Inflation is rising swiftly, they said, and there is a looming prospect that the Soviets will not have the hard currency to repay billions of dollars in debts coming due to Western banks and governments.
But there was clearly an implicit promise of large-scale aid if the Soviets are able to effect a program to transform their collapsing centrally planned system into a market-oriented economy, a reaffirmation of Western policy that has so far been blocked by Soviet inability to agree on concrete details for such a plan.
Although most Western officials went out of their way to avoid direct discussion of money today, their comments underscored the general idea that if the Soviets do move toward reform and greater openness, they would be rewarded for doing so.
 
Signs of Disagreement
 The Western commitment seemed to be an inducement Mr. Yavlinsky wanted to use to prod the paralyzed Soviet decision-making apparatus. "The goals which we jointly are trying to achieve are not far from us," Mr. Yavlinsky said in a break from the meetings.
There were some signs of disagreement among the seven nations meeting here on the topic of aid, but they issued a one-page communique this afternoon outlining their agreement. In addition to the United States, the group includes Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy.
The group said that the Soviet Union had to undertake "appropriate adjustment and reform policies with the support of the international financial institutions," like the International Monetary Fund, in which the Soviet Union recently became a special associate member. That meant the Soviet Union must take measures to bring down inflation by cutting its soaring budget deficits.
The group said it "strongly endorsed" the plan of the central Government and the Soviet republics to work out the terms of their economic cooperation, but insisted that these plans should make certain the Soviet Union will honor its debts to the West, currently estimated at $70 billion. The leaders of 10 Soviet republics said Friday that they had agreed on a pact to form an economic community.
The Group of Seven communique went on to say that an effective reform program and a workable financial relationship between the central Government and republics would insure that the Soviet Union would continue to have access to the loans on which it has grown dependent.
The communique was issued here just before the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, and the terms sketched out were very similar to the doses of bitter medicine that the fund has meted out to countries such as Mexico and Brazil.
The sketchiness of the agreement means numerous questions remain. One is whether there really is broad agreement in the Soviet Union to have the Western countries so actively engaged in their affairs. Another is whether the republics will agree to shoulder the central Government's debt.
The seriousness of the debt problem was underscored here when Mr. Yavlinsky confirmed his earlier assertion that the central Government has only 240 metric tons of gold in reserve, a fraction of what the reserves had been estimated to be. Gold is an important financial cushion for governments and can be used as collateral for loans.
 
Conditions for Major Aid
 The Western leaders here were careful to deny that they were getting involved in domestic Soviet politics. But they made it clear that, if the Soviets wanted the large-scale aid, a certain pattern of reform would have to be instituted.
For instance, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve Board, said, "A single currency and a single central bank would make the transition easier."
As the Soviet republics continue to negotiate over the terms of a pact on economic community, the communique issued today is likely to add impetus to the drive to complete an accord. The subject of the accord took up much of the closed-door discussions between the Soviet officials and the Western officials.
 
'Inestimable Value'
 "There is no blueprint in the sense of a detailed articulation of what the program might be," Mr. Brady said. "What they really asked for today was for us to help articulate what the program might be. They said, 'Your help will be of inestimable value to us.' "
The agreement was something of a coup for the 39-year-old Mr. Yavlinsky, a tireless proponent of fundamental economic reform who has run into resistance from conservative members of the Communist old guard and even President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Mr. Gorbachev failed to win the enthusiastic support of Western countries when he sought financial aid at a group of seven meeting in London in June and left the meeting empty-handed, an embarrassment that some believe contributed to the failed coup against him in August.
Some signs of discord among the Western nations were apparent today. The United States has made clear it believes the Soviets may need some form of debt relief soon. Previously the Soviets have suggested they may be unable to make about $5 billion in debt payments coming due in the next several months, but today they were quoted as saying they would not default on loans for at least the next two months.
But when the American delegation proposed a postponement of Soviet debt payments at a meeting this morning, the idea was rejected by both the European countries and the Soviet Union, French officials said.
A senior American Treasury official told reporters this afternoon that the differences were a matter of "nuance" and that "a consensus exists."
The Germans have also been frustrated by the unwillingness of the United States and some other countries to take on a greater share of the immediate financial burden of aid to the Soviet Union. The Germans reportedly sought to raise this issue of "burden sharing," but were rebuffed as the talks focused more on what the Soviets needed rather than where it would come from.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Officials of the world's seven leading industrial nations said that they will help Soviet officials devise an economic program. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, left, talked with the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, during meetings with the Soviets yesterday in Bangkok. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A7)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
An Eloquent Man And His Musings On the Presidency

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
For a man of his words, Mario M. Cuomo spends a lot of time explaining why he has been misunderstood. The Governor's musings evoke a political version of "Rashomon," leaving some listeners hearing only what they want to believe.
On Friday, his wife, Matilda, left a breakfast for potential campaign contributors with the distinct impression that Mr. Cuomo had said he intended to run for Governor again. 
 After the same breakfast, John Marino, the Democratic State Chairman, reported that Mr. Cuomo's remarks represented "a step toward making a decision" about running for President and that "in the next couple of weeks he'll have more to say."
Mr. Cuomo insisted later not only that he had said nothing new, but also that "nothing happened this morning that changes anything."
What did happen? Before or after he was importuned by supporters to reconsider his no-plans-and-no-plans-to-make-plans position on the Presidency, Mr. Cuomo delivered an unusually detailed account of his plans not to make any over the next few weeks.
"What am I going to say, no?" he asked later, maintaining that it would have been impolite, if not impolitic, to summarily rebuff entreaties from contributors.
Instead, he said he would think about running. But would he really think about it? "I'll try to keep it out of my mind," Mr. Cuomo replied later.
What was on his mind Friday? As supporters who had leaked his ambiguous remarks were still wiping the Regency Hotel's eggs off their faces, reporters were finding his words tough to swallow. At one point, what he said he had said was, "I'm disinclined to vote for president." Even if that wasn't what he meant to say, it might have been what he meant.
"Whatever is going on is not because I want it to go on," the Governor argued. Nonetheless, he risks being dismissed as a tease for insisting that no Sherman-like disavowal of candidacy would be credible or sensible.
Indeed, the Governor's previous attempts to do so were greeted skeptically, despite his consistent record. In 1987, on Art Athens's WCBS radio program, Mr. Cuomo flatly announced that he would not run for President the following year. Last week, when Mr. Athens asked the Governor to drop the other shoe, Mr. Cuomo playfully did so, literally. The Governor is due on the program again this week and may bare his soul.
After being told that his plans to make plans for a fourth term had been disclosed by no less a source than his own wife, Mr. Cuomo mused: "Either she knows all about me or I am an enigma; I pray I am an enigma."
For domestic consumption, Presidential rumors may divert attention from New York's problems to the nation's and promote ticket sales to Mr. Cuomo's fund-raiser in December.
But Mr. Cuomo is conflicted. He genuinely does not want to run for President, particularly while serving as Governor, although he seems more confident about his ability to be President.
Mr. Cuomo is unequivocal about one perceived consequence of noncandidacy: He is frustrated and even furious that reporters are more interested in a hypothetical campaign than in the condition of the country.
"I cannot get two minutes to talk about the economy," he complained, "but I can get a half hour to talk about a candidacy."
And yet, he said, the nation is yearning for "a debate on national policy." In between breakfast and eating his words for lunch, Mr. Cuomo delivered an inspiring address to several hundred students from Alternative High Schools and Programs of New York City.
Sounding the theme of what could be a Presidential campaign, he belittled the American role in Iraq and redefined patriotism to include winning "the war in the streets."
Mr. Cuomo's remarks might have been inspired by the previous speaker, Bill Cosby, who pressed one youngster to admit that in leaving school he had "made a decision." Another student said she decided to return to school because "you look around you and see people passing you by who are younger than you."
The 59-year-old Governor told the students that even he still searches for the meaning of "What is it that's important?" He invoked the theologian Pierre de Teilhard de Chardin, who concluded, "You've got to believe in something bigger than yourself."
The Governor also recalled the Simon and Garfunkel song from the film "The Graduate," which asked in the political void: "Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio? A nation turns its lonely eyes to you."
Two decades later, he said, the nation is still searching for leadership. It doesn't have to look far. Today, Mr. DiMaggio will be marching on Fifth Avenue as grand marshal of the Columbus Day Parade. Nearby, Mr. Cuomo will be walking, but not running.

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS NOMINATION;
With Each Round of Testimony, The Mood at the Hearing Sways

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Like a tree in a storm, the mood in the Senate Judiciary hearing room has bowed in one direction or another, pressed by the force of testimony, first by Anita Hill, then by Clarence Thomas, and again today, by witnesses who backed up her story and then by witnesses who praised his character.
After a day in which Judge Thomas succeeded in cowing the skeptical Democrats on the panel, blasting them with a gale of words about a bruising process and racial discrimination, the four impressive witnesses who backed up Professor Hill succeeded in refocusing the issue: It is her word versus his. Did he, as her superior and as the nation's top enforcer of employment discrimination laws, sexually harass her or not? 
 Saturday had belonged to Judge Thomas. Today, the wind shifted back the other way for most of the day, as friends eloquently defended Professor Hill with hard testimony that she had told them that her boss had made inappropriate advances long before it became a public issue.
 Then, late in the day, a panel of women who had worked for Judge Thomas tried to shift it again, defending him in broad terms of rectitude.
 
Fox in a Hen House?
 Joel R. Paul, an American University law professor who said that Professor Hill told him in 1987 that she had left the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission because she had been sexually harassed by her superior, described her story by echoing the phrase of a colleague, "This was a case of the fox guarding the hen house."
In trying to discredit Anita F. Hill, Clarence Thomas and his supporters have protrayed many faces of the Oklahoma Law School Professor.
Indeed, they painted so many pictures that some of them seemed contradictory. She was said to be malleable enough to become the tool of special interest groups or, on the other hand, so strongly opinionated that she would stomp out of meetings if she did not ger her way. His supporters have suggested that she was a troubled woman who fantasized about a relationship with him that did not exist, and, on the other hand, that she was a ambitious woman with her eye ever on her career. Judge Thomas has claimed that Professor Hill was so conscious of blackness that she criticized him when he dated or promoted women with lighter skin than hers, but also that she was now capable of using racial stereotypes damaging to blacks to destroy him.
In a panel tonight, women who had worked at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission with both Judge Thomas and Professor Hill also offered contradictory images: One witness described her as stridently aggressive; another as reserved. They all called her aloof; yet J.C. Alvarez, a former aide to Senator John Danforth and staffer at the E.E.O.C., suggested that she might want to turn her experience before the Senate into a book or movie, saying she wanted to be "the Rosa Parks of sexual harassment."
 While one witness, Phyllis Berry, gave her theory, without illustration, that Professor Hill might have had a crush on Judge Thomas, Ms. Alvarez said that the two were not romantically interested in each other at all.
 A third, Nancy Fitch, prompted by Republican Senator Arlen Specter, suggested that, based on her non-professional reading of psychology, that perhaps Professor Hill was engaged in "transference," a psychological condition where you transfer your feelings about one person to someone else.
 They all said that the incident she described could not have occurred, that she was not telling the truth, but that they also were firm in the view that she was not the sort of person to lie or make things up.
In the first panel, four people who knew Professor Thomas, including Susan Hoerchner, a workers' compensations judge in California, and Ellen Wells, the project manager for the American Welfare Association in Washingotn, and a former beau, John Carr, a Wall Street lawyewr, said that Professor Hil told them she was being sexually harassed by her boss.
Her friends described Professor Hill as neither malleable nor vengeful. They said she was a private, reserved, pragmatic, moralistic woman who did not have fantasies.
"She's one of the most level-headed people I have ever known," Judge Hoerchner said.
Mr. Paul appeared to blow a hole in the Republican contention that Professor Hill was a pawn of liberal interest groups when he revealed that she had ardently defended the nomination of Judge Bork to the Supreme Court during a lunch at American University in 1987.
The "he said, she said" drama, with its attendant circus of spin doctors, interest groups and partisan lobbyists, continued to confuse and frustrate the Senators sitting in judgment. Professor Hill's lawyer scored a public relations coup by offering the results of a two-hour lie detector test that she took today, showing a result of "no deception."
"It may not be admissible in a court of law, but it's certain to weigh heavily on the minds of the Senate," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.
 
'Like a Football Game'
 All around the Russell Office Building, the two sides collided.
Outside the hearing room, women's groups defended themselves from Republican charges that they had concocted a plot to "get" Judge Thomas and fed the words and images to Professor Hill. Nearby, conservatives supporting Judge Thomas insisted that if she was telling the truth, she would have come forward eight years ago.
Outside the building, women lined the steps, holding signs that read, "Black women for Thomas," as other women chanted "Hey, hey, ho, ho, Clarence Thomas has got to go."
"Look, it's just like a football game," Fred McGrath, a lawyer from Arlington, Va., told his 3-year-old daughter, Mary.
Int he second panel of the day, the four women who worked with Judge Thomas at the Equal Employment Oportunity Commission defended his management style with women as progressive and professional.
 They echoed each other in saying the probability was "zero" that Judge Thomas could use the type of obscene language that Professor Hill described her former boss using with her. In response to a question by Senator Leahy, who noted that some of the Judge's Yale Law School colleagues have said that Mr. Thomas liked to go to see X-rated movies and then humorously describe the plots, the women said they had not had such experiences at work with the Judge.
The judge's supporters offered sometimes-contradictory descriptions of Professor Hill, with some presenting her as completely professional and confident and one presenting her as a scorned woman.
 Ms. Alvarez said that Professor HIll's testimony seemed "like schizophrenia" and that she had a view of herself that was so confident that it "did not seem to be based on reality."
 On Friday, she played the role of a meek, innocent, shy Baptist girl form the South who was the victim of this big bad man," she said. She said that the woman she knew was "a very hard, tough woman."
 
Explaining Moves
 While Ms. Alvarez said she saw no evidence of romantic interest between Anita F. Hill and Clarence Thomas, Ms. Berry repeated her now-familiar charge, not corroborated elsehwere, that "she had a crush on the chairman" and "wished she could have had a greater relationship with the chairman than just professional."
 For Mr. Thomas's supporters, the crux of the issue has been this: They contend that Professor Hill would not have followed the Judge from one job to another or kept in touch with him if he had done what she said.
 Today, her two friends, Ms. Wells and Judge Hoerchner, tried to explain, from the woman's point of view, why a woman would not want to penalize herself economically after suffering emotionally, and why women must sometimes swallow insults from bosses just as men do to get the best opportunities in their careers.
 
'Don't Burn Your Bridges'
 "If you hope to go forward," said Ms. Wells, who said she had been the victim of sexual harassment herself, "and, by going forward, move out from under their power and control, you sometimes have to put up with things that no one should be expected to put up with."
Ms. Wells added, at another point, in trying to explain why Ms. Hill would not cut off all contact with someone as well-known and helpful to her career as Judge Thomas had been: "We're all told about networking, I mean my goodness gracious, you can open up any woman's magazine and you can go to seminars on how women are supposed to learn to network, since we don't have the old boys' club. Take up golf, ladies, take up tennis, learn to get there so you can do these things to maintain these contacts. And so you don't burn your bridges.
 Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the chairman of the panel, defended male sensitivity, noting that he could see the issue from the male point of view.
 "I wonder how men there are, if in fact they were approached by a man on the job who was, had a different sexual preference than they do, I wonder how ready they would be to go open and say, 'By the way, my boss, that fellow up there, approached me.' "

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS NOMINATION;
Blacks Say the Blood Spilled In the Thomas Case Stains All

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
Wherever black Americans gathered this past week -- in churches and hair salons, in offices and on college campuses -- they talked of little else but the sexual harassment accusations against Judge Clarence Thomas.
Some said they believed him. Some said they believed his accuser, Prof. Anita F. Hill. But regardless, what stood out was dismay: a sickening feeling that the episode had damaged lives and tarnished reputations far beyond those of the two principals. 
 While white Americans tend to view the case as a dispute over sexual harassment and the credibility of two believable witnesses, many blacks say it is much more: an embarrassment to their race, one that will be caricatured in history.
And they are angered that two highly accomplished black people, in whom they might otherwise take pride, are at the center of such a nasty, lurid political soap opera.
"We have two African-American people pitted against each other," said Raymond A. Anderson during a break in choir rehearsals at the First African Methodist Episcopal Church in Los Angeles. "It really doesn't matter whether Judge Thomas is guilty or innocent. It doesn't matter whether Ms. Hill has credibility or not. What the image is throughout the country, throughout the world, is that we are not credible, trustworthy people, but vulgar, shiftless . . . . I could go on."
Another choir member, Victoria F. Hicks, agreed. "There are so many educated, just stellar lawyers who are African-American in this country that I am embarrassed that President Bush put someone up there who he knew had skeletons in the closet."
Conversations this past week with four dozen blacks around the country of varying ages, professions, political persuasions and socio-economic groups revealed those who suspected the allegations were a conspiracy to scuttle the nomination and those who were offended a black woman's claim of harassment could be ignored.
But there was wide agreement that the case would have deep social, cultural, political and professional repercussions for all blacks, particularly black men.
Even if it did not reveal how they felt about Judge Thomas himself, or the allegations against him, Judge Thomas's words struck a chord deep in the black male psyche. Many were swayed by the nominee's comments that the sexual allegations against him perpetuated the worst stereotypes about black men and their views of sex.
"Black men will feel it reinforces negative stereotypes about them as sexual animals out of control," said Dr. Alvin F. Poussaint, the Harvard psychiatrist, from his home in Cambridge, Mass. "It will increase their level of tension and vulnerability around charges of this type and make them tiptoe carefully because they may feel they will be more likely targets."
No less than the 100 senators who are to vote on the nomination on Tuesday, black Americans have agonized these past few days over separating their judgment of Judge Thomas, his conservative views and the accusations against him from the larger points he made in defense of himself.
"We can't let our feelings toward him get in the way of whether there was sexual harassment," said Ronald Prince, a hair stylist at Details Hair Design on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. "He's not on trial. Even if he were, none of us, especially those white men on that committee, have the right to stand in judgment of him."
 
Seeing a Racial Element
 John McGee, a 23-year-old legal assistant who lives in Washington, said: "As a black man, as a black American, it's been painful for me to watch this. I feel for both of them. And I know what Thomas is going through because this happened to me once. My crime was saying hello to a white cheerleader at my high school. She read that as me hitting on her and told my coach she felt intimidated."
While many said they were at first reluctant to believe the case had a racial element to it, their minds were changed when they watched Judge Thomas having to defend himself to a panel of white male politicians.
"Those who are very insightful saw the racial overtones," said Randy Treece, 43, of Albany, who has represented women in sexual harassment cases in his 15 years as a trial lawyer. "What are the ramifications on the black community when you have two stellar personalities talking about some of the most private, offensive things that could ever be brought up. Will it mean that black professionals may be judged on their private, personal lives rather than their ability to do the job? I don't know."
Black men and women alike spoke of fears that the allegations would kill Judge Thomas's chance to be confirmed and make it impossible for another black to be nominated. Others questioned Professor Hill's motivations, asserting that she was acting as "a tool" for white men to ruin the life of a black man at the peak of his career.
 
Deepening Resentment
 And many said the controversy would undoubtedly strain the already fragile state of relations between black men and black women.
"There's a high level of anger among black men," Dr. Poussaint said, "be they low-income or professional, that black women will betray them; that black women are given preference over them; that white men like to put black women in between them to use them. Black men feel that white men are using this black woman to get another black man. It's troubling."
From the moment Professor Hill's allegations were made public, there were blacks who saw racial overtones. The hearings, which many had hoped would reveal who was telling the truth, only seemed to fuel some of their suspicions: why Professor Hill, given her legal background, had not confronted Judge Thomas when the offenses first occurred? Why, despite feeling sexually harassed, she had followed him to another agency? Why had she maintained friendly contact with him throughout the past 10 years?
"I think it's just another plot for the white man to put the black man down and keeping us against each other," said Clarence M. Brown Jr., a collection agent who was attending choir rehearsals at First A.M.E. Church, which has one of Los Angeles' largest black congregations. "It's another black role model shot down."
Kenneth Alberty, a client at Detail Hair Designs in Manhattan, said: "Who knows, maybe this is a sister who doesn't want to see a black man get ahead. They used a black woman to get to Marion Barry, remember."
 
The Lens of Race
 Some wondered whether Professor Hill would have been taken more seriously if she had been white. "I think that if they were white, this would have been handled in closed-Senate chambers, rather than aired all over national television," said Monica Scott, a 50-year-old visiting nurse in New York City. "If Anita Hill were a white I think the Senate committee would flown her in and asked her face to face about this, rather than dismiss it out of hand."
Dr. Robert T. Carter, associate professor of psychology and education at Teachers' College at Columbia University, said the differences in how blacks and whites view the situation reflects the "continuing significance of race in American society."
"There is a lot of diversity of blacks with respect to where they fall in terms of identity," he said. "A lot also depends onon where they are and what's going on in their lives."
Some blacks theorize that Judge Thomas's personal life, in particular his marriage to a white woman, has left him more vulnerable to to criticism, especially from black women.
Other blacks, however, don't think race is a factor and view this as a case of sexual harassment, pure and simple.
"This is a personalized situation that deals with relations between two individuals," said H. Carl McCall, senior vice president at Citibank and a president of New York City's Board of Education. "We shouldn't draw any implications that it goes beyond that. Nor as a black man should I feel threatened by anything I've heard. Thomas doesn't represent all blacks."
Others argue that Mr. Thomas's race should not be an excuse for harassing women. Nor, they say, should a black woman, or any woman for that matter, stand by silently and take such treatment. "It's the coming of age of black women," said LaShaune Armstrong, a 21-year-old student at Lehmann College. "She's bringing to the fore a decade of mistreatment by men of all races, and that's something all women can identify with."
The split in opinion in many ways mirrors that of the white community about sexual harassment. Some black men interviewed tended to identify most with Judge Thomas and what they view as his persecution for an act that many men could well have been guilty of.
"I've got a husband and two sons," said Brenda Canty, who is majoring in elementary education at Hunter College. "As a woman, I can relate to Anita Hill. God knows we've all been subjected to some form of sexual harassment in our lives. But as a mother and wife, I know this society has a history of mistreatment and abuse toward black men. You have to wonder, what if my son is accused of this. Is he going to get a fair shake?"
But others said the case reflected badly on the race as a whole. "This is going to come back to haunt all blacks, just watch," said Tan Wood, a professional model who was discussing the case with friends at the hair salon. "They, I mean whites, won't just see this as a case of did he or didn't he sexual harass her? No. They're going to say a black man had a shot at the Supreme Court and blew it. If he's not confirmed, you can bet the next nominee won't be a black man, that's for sure."

HEADLINE: This Lottery's Jackpot Is Green, but It's Not Money

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MERRIFIELD, Va., Oct. 13

 BODY:
They were not huddled masses exactly: a Swiss investor, a Polish carpenter, a ski instructor from Ireland. But they came by plane, train and automobile, slept in cheap hotels and parking lots, and fought long, jostling lines outside a post office to fill mail bins with the pristine white envelopes that might prove to be their passage to America.
If there was one thing they all agreed on, it's that this was no way to run an immigration program. 
 "I just love it here, but I just can't understand why they distribute the their green cards they way they do," said Torsten Murat, 24 years old, a German student who made a 15-hour, overnight drive from Nashville to drop off his applications for a much-criticized lottery for the cards, which offer permanent legal residence.
Under a 1990 law, the Government will accept the first 40,000 applications it receives from citizens of 34 countries, mostly in Europe, to correct what some have described as their underrepresentation among immigrants. By law, 40 percent of those accepted for the first three years of the lottery, which will be an annual event, must come from Ireland.
 
Long Shots
 Applicants can mail as many letters as they want, with many sending hundreds and even thousands, and the Government expects as many as five million applications to arrive by the Oct. 20 deadline. Those odds have had would-be legal residents, who otherwise might have to wait as long as 10 years for one of the 700,000 cards the Government grants a year, spinning elaborate strategies for getting letters to the head of the line.
One problem is that those received before 12:01 A.M. Monday are being disqualified. Another is that the Government has not announced how it will decide which among the millions of pieces of mail got there first. A previous such lottery simply registered them all and chose the winners by computer, a process that many immigration lawyers say would relieve the current process of its chaos.
The Government designated the post office in this Washington suburb as the sorting site for the letters. While officials say that delivering them by hand here brings no special advantage, the crowd in the parking lot surged to as many as 3,000 at 7 P.M. Saturday, rumored to be prime time, since letters that arrive afterward are not processed until the first thing Monday morning .
"It was a mob. It was like Berlin Wall," said Cezary Smulski, 22, who already has his legal status but was helping two Polish friends from Staten Island seek theirs. Some of those in the rear of the crowd threw their boxes of letters, and one man was knocked into a bin.
By this morning the line had thinned to throngs only hundreds strong, some making multiple strolls past the two dozen canvas bins, to space their letters at strategic intervals.
 
500 Letters and Strategy
 Lester D., 29, once of Dublin and now illegally of Northern California, flew in from San Francisco on Thursday, armed with 500 letters that he and his girlfriend had printed on her personal computer.
He mailed some before he left. He had friends in Maine, Utah, England, and Ireland do the same, in his name. He rented a car and mailed others from various Washington suburbs.
Then he came to Merrifield on Saturday night, and at three different times on Sunday, making as many bets as he could.
"I'm just trying to spread it out to cover as many possibilities," said the ski instructor, who refused to give his last name for fear of being arrested by immigration officers. "They're not releasing very much information about how they're going to do this."
Lester D. said that Irish community organizations in San Francisco were collecting letters and offering to deliver them for free, but he spent $500 on the trip in order to get a little peace of mind. "There's a lot at stake for a lot of people here," he said.
 
Hoping to Lick the Odds
 With applications limited only by the price of a 29-cent stamp, one of the toughest questions everyone faced was: how many letters are enough? On Sunday morning, Monique R., from Poland, sat on the ground in the parking lot where she'd spent the night, glumly licking her way to an answer.
After reading about the lottery in a Polish newspaper in New York, she drove to Virginia with 10 letters, only to find herself among competitors with thousands. She scrounged enough money to copy 200 more, and a roll of stamps, but argued that the process was biased toward those from wealthier backgrounds.
"Japanese people send million letters per person," she said in tentative English. "This is crazy idea. This is big job, preparing million letters."
Exasperated, frightened and hopeful, many of the would-be immigrants milled about the parking lot, even after mailing their letters, telling their stories of hard work and old-fashioned values to reporters, one another, and anyone else who would listen.
"I work! I pay taxes! I never get one dollar from unemployment," said Mark O., a carpenter on Staten Island, who said he arrived from Poland illegally seven years ago and has proved his mettle with 90-hour work weeks that recently allowed him to buy a $100,000 house with cash. Wearing a black leather jacket, three days' stubble and the musk of Marlboros, he described himself as a captive of his chosen country, unable even to return to Poland last year for his father's funeral because he feared being unable to come back.
Joining him, a Swiss man wearing a gold chain and designer jeans offered his angry agreement.
"Yes, we are in prison here, though we chose it," said the man, who gave his name only as Michael, and said he had flown in from Florida with 600 letters. He said he was living off his assets of approximately a half-million dollars in Switzerland, needing twice that to immigrate under a special program for foreign investors.
Michael looked suspiciously at the television cameras in the parking lot and asked the reporter to strike a detail about his family that might identify him. "I worry," he said.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
CARMEL QUINN, who sings Irish songs, is philosophical about performing at benefits. "If it's a good dinner, the guests get logy and the act suffers," she said. "If it's a bad dinner, they get cranky and the act suffers. So I just put my faith in God, say a couple of prayers and do my best."
That approach will come in handy on Wednesday, when she is to sing for six cardinals: JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR of New York; ANTHONY CARDINAL BEVILACQUA of Philadelphia; JAMES CARDINAL HICKEY of Washington; BERNARD CARDINAL LAW of Boston; G. EMMETT CARDINAL CARTER of Toronto, and MIGUEL CARDINAL OBANDO y BRAVO of Nicaragua. 
 Ms. Quinn, who will perform at the Michigan League at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, will help raise money to build a new cathedral in Managua. The new cathedral will replace one that was nearly destroyed by an earthquake in 1972. The Catholic community there has been struggling to rebuild it ever since but has been hampered by the depressed economy.
When she was younger, the prospect of entertaining such an audience would have unnerved her. "The biggest person in my life was the parish priest, now we're talking cardinals -- and six of them at that," she said. "I'm delighted. I must remember that they were once struggling young priests hoping to make it to monsignor."

HEADLINE: Farmer Suicide Rate Swells in 1980's, Study Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WAUSAU, Wis., Oct. 13

 BODY:
More than 900 male farmers in the Upper Midwest committed suicide in the 1980's, and in some years the incidence of suicide in that group was nearly double the national average for white men, a study shows.
The National Farm Medicine Center, which conducted the study over nine years, said it planned further research to determine if there was a link between the suicide rate and the economic hardship that affected many Midwest farmers in the 1980's. The group plans to make the survey public on Monday. 
 The decade was a particularly stressful time for farmers, with record indebtedness, unstable prices, declining land values and drought. There were thousands of foreclosures and bankruptcies.
The study reported that 913 male farmers killed themselves in the 1980's in Wisconsin, Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana.
 
Rate Peaked in 1982
 The farm medicine center, founded at a clinic in the central Wisconsin town of Marshfield in 1981 to conduct agricultural health and safety research and education, also found that 71 female farmers, 96 farm children and 177 farm workers killed themselves from 1980 to 1988, the last year figures were compiled.
Using information provided by public health agencies, the study found that there were 44 suicides for every 100,000 farmers and ranchers in 1980, said Paul Gunderson, who helped conduct the researchn.
Nationwide in 1980, 31 suicides occurred for every 100,000 white males age 20 or older, he said.
After peaking at 58 suicides for every 100,000 farmers in 1982, the rate fell to 42 suicides in 1985, then climbed slightly again. In 1988 there were 48 suicides in 100,000 farmers, as against a national rate of 22.
A study of the first half of the decade, conducted by Mr. Gunderson and others for the Minnesota Center for Health Statistics, showed many of the suicides were prompted by serious injuries, alcoholism, terminal illness and family problems. It also found the depressed ecomony contributed to the problem.

HEADLINE: Ron Silver Hits The Ground Running At Actors' Equity

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
Ron Silver received rave reviews as Alan M. Dershowitz in "Reversal of Fortune" but he won't rest until he knocks 'em dead as Eugene V. Debs. Mr. Silver is the newly elected president of the Actors' Equity Association, perhaps the only union in the country with a 90 percent unemployment rate. For a man whose idea of a great time is to invite 10 people to dinner who won't get along, it's a perfect fit.
At his desk in the Equity offices in mid-Manhattan the other morning, Mr. Silver was jazzed and ready to go. He was meeting with union officials about his pet cause: establishing a national health care system by organizing a coalition of labor organizations and public interest groups to lobby it through Congress. He had researched the health bill exhaustively and when he discussed it, his sentences were crammed with legal jargon. You could hear the results of the semester he spent at Yale Law School last spring studying the First Amendment. 
 The three men sitting across his desk, actors of course, played their supporting roles eagerly. They nodded in all the right places, shuffled their documents, laughed at their new president's jokes. Mr. Silver was clearly the star. He had the deepest tan, the longest hair and, in a roomful of caps, the best teeth. The truth is, it has probably been years since the union has had someone as informed and committed in the unsalaried post, which has often been little more than a figurehead for public appearances.
 
An Actor's Instincts
 But the staff is still not used to him. In the middle of the meeting, one official launched into an overheated monologue on the government's unjust distribution of health benefits to AIDS patients. Mr. Silver interrupted, saying, "The best way to counter that is not with a surplus of passion." He knows a bad performance when he sees one.
As president of Actors' Equity, Mr. Silver has the unenviable task of succeeding the late Colleen Dewhurst, the earth mother of the American theater who was beloved by the staff not only because of her warm personality, but also because she let them alone. "Ron is very different from Colleen, who was really nice and sort of spacey," says one employee who spoke on condition of anonymity. "He's very focused, very intense. He reads everything, and can grill people for 45 minutes on one issue. We all can't wait for him to get a movie."
Overdrive is Mr. Silver's normal speed, but he's easy to like, and his management style at Equity is based on communication. He wants everyone to know everything all the time. (Except his age. He says he needs to protect his job prospects.) In public, he is quite amiable, smiling and shaking hands, acknowledging every compliment.
At Delsomma, an Italian restaurant in the theater district, he is greeted like a long-lost son. Other customers must order from the lunch menu, while he's allowed to turn to dinner. "Hey, how's 'Blue Steel'?" calls out the only man sitting at the bar, referring to a movie Mr. Silver was in with Jamie Lee Curtis. Mr. Silver waves.
 
Other Reputation-Makers
 He is also frequently recognized for his role in the Paul Mazursky film "Enemies, a Love Story" and for his Tony Award-winning performance in David Mamet's "Speed-the-Plow." His career has never been better. Why bother with this job? Not to mention the presidency of the Creative Coalition, a nonprofit political education advocacy group he founded in 1988.
"Everyone has a duty to be an optimist," he says. "If you get everybody talking and yelling and participating, you can go beyond cynicism or apathy."
"I also love actors," he continues, "and I think what they do is an underappreciated resource in this country."
It sounds good, but it is early in his tenure. Mr. Silver missed the controversy his predecessor endured last year over the multi-ethnic casting in "Miss Saigon." The producer Cameron Mackintosh wanted Jonathan Pryce, a Caucasian, to play the role of a Eurasian pimp on Broadway as he had in London, while members of Actors' Equity insisted the role be played by an Asian.
 
Big Issue; Two Sides
 "I would have considered myself fortunate to be the president then," Mr. Silver says. "There are very few times an organization has an opportunity to take a position on an issue with such broad implications. Clearly, the unfairness of this business is magnified if you are a minority. But I am very much against taking away the autonomy of a producer and director on casting decisions."
What would he have done differently? "With hindsight," he says, "I would have had a very good internal debate and not taken action until everyone's point of view was on the table. I would have made up a briefing booklet, so all the members would have known what the objectives and implications were."
"I think I deserve many roles I don't get either," he continues, "but this business we're in is not a meritocracy. The minority actors are laboring under even more hardships. The union's job is to sensitize people to the issue. Before we go to the mat we have to get information. Be educated. Make colorblind casting a goal to increase minority employment. But that's a long way from mandating what directors, producers and writers can do."
Mr. Silver is presiding over another nontraditional casting dispute in "The Will Rogers Follies." Actors' Equity has filed a grievance against the show's producers, for excluding minorities from a musical that glorifies the life of a man who made his reputation denouncing discrimination. "While the grievance is going on I have no right to comment on it," Mr. Silver says.
 
Things He Hasn't Done
 Though Mr. Silver is adept at handling the job's messy politics, he admits to shortcomings in other areas. "There are definite gaps in my experience that are a weakness," he says. "I've never been in a national road company or a bus-and-truck tour. I've never done a musical. So I'm not up on those details."
"But," he continues, "what I hope to do is to use our weight as a union more effectively. Actors' Equity should have a stronger voice in city affairs, because our well-being is vital to the city. Forty-nine percent of tourists list the theater as the first reason they come to New York. And the voices you do hear representing theater in the city are heard from the employers' side. Hopefully, now, we will have a louder voice."
The playwright Wendy Wasserstein, who is on the board of directors of the Creative Coalition, became friendly with Mr. Silver when he played a driving instructor in a short play she wrote for "Trying Times," a public television series. "He kept asking all these questions about the driving instructor," Ms. Wasserstein says, "and finally I said, 'Ron, please, it's a half an hour on PBS."
"The reason he will be a great president of Equity," she continues, "is that he really wants to keep the theater alive, and he's interested in politics generally, not just the politics of Equity. He always has an opinion, he's lively and he's got a great wife. He also gives a great seder."
 
'Nothing Is Skipped Over'
 This Passover seder given annually by Mr. Silver and his wife, Lynne Miller Silver, a magazine editor, is something of an obsession for people in the entertainment industry, because over the last few years it has become the toughest invitation in town. With guests like Madonna, Paul Simon, Rudolph Giuliani and Ron Darling, the Four Questions are suddenly the epitome of chic. But glitter aside, Mr. Silver says: "We read every word of the service. Nothing is skipped over."
And because such a variety of people are invited, he gets to have his arguments. "In L.A., you're soiling paradise if you yell at a dinner party," he says, laughing. "Not at my house."
He learned to speak his mind, he says, growing up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "I've always had a sense of responsibility to a greater community other than myself. The most intimate community, of course, is your family. And in the Jewish religion, when you pray for salvation, it's for the community, not the individual. I never forgot that."
He was back in his old neighborhood recently to cut the ribbon, along with Mayor David N. Dinkins, at the new Variety Arts Theater on Third Avenue at 14th Street. A large crowd was assembled out front and Mr. Silver was in top form. He hugged and kissed a paparazzo. He embraced the Mayor. When he stepped up to the microphone, a middle-aged woman behind one of the sawhorses suddenly became distraught. She and her friend had waited an hour, protecting their view, and now, the Mayor's security men had blocked her. She spotted a professional photographer who was allowed up front, and waved her Instamatic.
"Please, please, this is a great moment for us," she begged, until he agreed to photograph Mr. Silver. "I just love him," the woman said, "especially in that film. You know, 'The Enemy Within.' "
Before Mr. Silver helped cut the ribbon, he made a brief speech in which he said: "The city and state reflexively support sports, thinking that they build character through adversity. I would argue that the arts build character better. Not on competition, but through compassion."
The woman behind the barrier sighed. The crowd applauded. Compared to this, Alan Dershowitz was chopped liver.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: 4 Killed and 2 Are Wounded in Queens Rampage

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
A 47-year-old neighborhood eccentric went on a rampage with a rifle at his Queens home early yesterday and, leaving his father and three other men dead and two neighbors critically wounded, broke into a Nassau County home nearby, took a retired couple hostage and held off a cordon of police firepower all day.
In a drama that the police said began with killings and a manhunt and brought terror to a quiet neighborhood of elegant homes and leafy streets, the rifleman, Andrew T. Brooks Jr., holed up at a home in Lake Success, L.I., fired on a gardener, punctuated the afternoon with gunshots at the police and talked sporadically by telephone with hostage negotiators. 
 The police said Mr. Brooks, who had no criminal record or history of mental illness, was coherent and did not seem to know his captives, apparently having chosen their home at random. He demanded only a six-pack of Coke, which was hoisted by rope up to a bedroom window where he sat most of the day, taking potshots at the ground, at nearby homes and at officers besieging him outside.
 
Hostage Escapes After 13 Hours
 But he was persuaded to release one of the hostages, Dr. Paul Gregory, a 71-year-old retired psychiatrist from Hungary, unharmed in the morning. And late in the afternoon, after being held for nearly 13 hours, Dr. Gregory's 61-year-old wife, Paige Eva, escaped without injury, running out the front door when her captor began to doze off.
"Come on! Come on!" an officer shouted as she fled to freedom. The police said Mr. Brooks might have shot at her but did not do so.
As searchlights played over the scene, the standoff lasted into today, with the gunman adamantly refusing to surrender and surrounded by a small army of officers in flak jackets with high-powered rifles behind the cover of trees, cars and the evacuated homes of neighbors.
Late last night, however, the police began closing in. A robot with a camera eye trundled into the house to spy on the gunman, who fired at it. A special weapons assault team then crept in and seized the ground floor, leaving the gunman isolated upstairs.
Earlier in the day, the police said Mr. Brooks had shot all six victims many times with a .22-caliber rifle at his home at 53-42 254th Street in Little Neck, about four blocks from the house where he took refuge and hostages. But authorities said it appeared that not all of the victims were slain yesterday.
They said the gunman's father, Andrew T. Brooks Sr., a 75-year-old retired teacher with whom he lived, and Brian Ducker, 30, of 53-26 254th Street, a neighbor who had missing since Thursday, were found dead in a backyard toolshed and may have been slain several days ago.
The others -- two men killed and two others wounded -- were believed to have been shot early yesterday in the assailant's home. The police said all four were residents of the Little Neck neighborhood and were longtime acquaintances of the man who shot them.
The police identified the slain men as Daniel Gantovnik, 23, of 53-15 254th Street, whose body was found in the living room, and Michael Zarabi, 27, of 60 Fairview Avenue, found dead in the kitchen. Mr. Gantovnik worked in his family's garment business and Mr. Zarabi worked in an auto body shop in Great Neck, L.I., friends said.
The wounded men, whose addresses were not released because they are potential witnesses in the case, were identified as Stanley Sultan, 25, and Andrew Lazan, 22.
 
Spotted by Wedding Guests
 Mr. Sultan, who managed to stumble out of the house after being shot, was spotted by guests who were leaving a wedding reception at a nearby synagogue. They called the police, and Mr. Sultan was taken to Booth Memorial Medical Center in Queens. Mr. Lazan, who was found shot in the Brooks's kitchen, was taken to North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Both were listed in critical condition today with multiple gunshot wounds.
A 12-gauge shotgun was found in the Brooks home, but it had evidently not been used in the assaults, the police said. They said Mr. Brooks had shot his victims with a .22-caliber rifle with a sawed-off butt. Numerous shell casings were found in the house and he apparently still had considerable ammunition, investigators said.
The police said the suspect's mother, Marion Brooks, was missing yesterday, and investigators said they feared she, too, had been a victim of what they called her son's unexplained rampage, though they said they had no evidence. A search was under way for her.
The shootings echoed another multiple slaying in another New York City suburb last week. On Thursday, a dismissed postal clerk killed his former supervisor and her boyfriend in Wayne, N.J., then descended on the post office in nearby Ridgewood and killed two mail handlers before surrendering to a police siege.
While the police said they did not know of any motive for the shootings, neighbors said they were not surprised at the eruption of violence. Andrew Brooks Jr., who had lived with his parents and been unemployed nearly all his life, was known as an eccentric who prowled the neighborhood swinging a golf club, peered into windows, talked to himself and stared at and followed young women on the street.
A heavyset man with long, grayish-brown slicked-back hair who often wore the same black-and-white plaid shirt and usually appeared unkempt, Mr. Brooks was said to do occasional odd jobs for neighbors, watching homes while people were away, but more often made money by renting or selling pornographic videotapes. He also occasionally lent a little cash to young people who otherwise spurned his company, neighbors said.
 
Especially Strange Recently
 A woman who spoke on the condition of anonymity said she had grown up next door to Andrew Brooks. She said he had always acted strangely, but had begun to behave especially so in recent days. She said he had told her that he was taking medication for allergies and that it was damaging him.
"The damage is irreversible; it's in my blood," he told her a few days ago, she said. And on Wednesday, she said, he told her: "You won't be seeing me around." She also quoted him as saying that his mother and father were "bothering" him, preventing him from healing his allergies.
Another neighbor who identified herself only as Wilma said she had known Mr. Brooks for more than 20 years. "He treated his parents like garbage and they were afraid of him," she said. "I told his father, 'How can you live with someone you're afraid of?' I told him, 'He's going to kill you.' "
But another neighbor, Dan Gallo, 24, said: "He wasn't bothersome. He was just a local hobo trying to wheel and deal to make a quick buck."
The exact sequence of events that led to four deaths and the critical wounding of two neighbors was unclear, the police said. But they said Mr. Brooks's elderly father and Mr. Ducker, who was reported missing Thursday after a friend who was unable to reach him by phone and found the door of his home ajar, may have been slain Thursday or Friday. Their bodies were found in a 4-foot yellow toolshed in the backyard.
The four other victims may have been shot early yesterday, the police said, probably about 2 A.M., after going to the Brooks home, a two-story red-brick detached ranch on 254th Street, near Little Neck Parkway, which skirts the Nassau border a few blocks inside Queens.
Julio Gantovnik said his brother Daniel and Mr. Sultan went to the house to discuss money that Mr. Sultan owed Mr. Brooks, but it was unclear why Mr. Zarabi and Mr. Lazan went there.
Though critically wounded, Mr. Sultan stumbled out of the house and made his way toward Temple Torah at 55-27 Little Neck Parkway, where someone called 911 at 2:20 A.M. to report the shootings. But even as the police rushed to the house to find the victims, Mr. Brooks was escaping with his rifle in a family car.
He apparently did not drive far. The car was found abandoned a few blocks away in Lake Success. Mr. Brooks left the car and apparently wandered around, trying doors in search of a place to hide. Several homeowners reported that their locked doors were rattled in the early-morning hours.
 
Awoke Hostages Before Dawn
 While the police searched the tree-lined streets and large, manicured yards of the uppermiddle-class neighborhood on foot and in prowl cars and helicopters, Mr. Brooks broke a window pane in a rear door about 5 A.M. and entered a two-story red-brick and white-shingled house at 44 Bates Road in Lake Success.
Two hours before sunrise, he awoke Dr. Gregory and his wife and held them at gunpoint for hours. The police, meantime, discovered where he was -- and the hostage situation -- about 8:30 A.M., when Mr. Brooks fired four shots at a gardener arriving for work at the Gregory home. The gardener was unhurt and called 911.
Although the jurisdiction had shifted from New York City to Nassau County, city and county police joined forces in the siege at the Gregory home.
After evacuating eight homes nearby, the police stationed sharpshooters behind trees and cars, sent a rolling robot with a camera up the lawn in front of the house and formed a command post in a home next door. There, hostage negotiators called him up.
 
Hostage Hoists a 6-Pack
 Inspector James G. Courtney, the executive officer of Queens detectives, said Dr. Gregory was released at 10:30 A.M. as a result of negotiations with Mr. Brooks. Dr. Gregory was admitted to Long Island Jewish Hospital where he was treated for trauma and listed in stable condition last night.
Later, Mr. Brooks requested a can of Coke, and then a six-pack of the soda, which Mrs. Gregory lifted on a rope to a second-floor bedroom window where the rifleman was holding her at gunpoint. Several hours later, Mr. Brooks closed the window and took the telephone off the hook.
But a negotiator re-established contact with him over a bullhorn: "Andy . . . pick up the phone. We have a message for you. Pick up the phone."
At 5:40 P.M., when Mr. Brooks began to nod off, Mrs. Gregory crept downstairs and fled out the front door. The police said she was unhurt, though shaken. Mr. Brooks did not fire at her. But, stripped of the leverage of hostages, he still declined to surrender, and the siege continued early today.
