HEADLINE: Washington Voters Weigh Aid of Doctors in Suicide

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Early next month voters in this state will decide an issue that has never appeared on a ballot in the United States: Should doctors be allowed to kill terminally ill patients who have asked to die?
The ballot measure, Initiative 119, would make Washington State the first jurisdiction in the Western World to legalize euthanasia. And it raises the possibility of overturning a 2,000-year-old tenet of medical tradition. 
 Called the Death With Dignity proposal, Initiative 119 earned a spot on the Nov. 5 ballot after more than 223,000 signatures were gathered by people who believe that the timing of one's death is a basic right. If the initiative passes, terminally ill patients would be allowed to commit suicide with the help of their doctors, and it would clarify the conditions under which life-support systems could be withdrawn from patients who have already stated their intentions in a living will.
And in the most controversial part of the initiative, doctors would be allowed to kill patients who had been told they had fewer than six months to live and had made a written request to die. Many doctors say lethal injection is the form of euthanasia that is most likely to be adopted, although specific procedures will have to be worked out later if the initiative passes.
Unlike the other dramatic proposal on the ballot here this fall, a term limit initiative that would throw out the entire Congressional delegation three years after the vote, Initiative 119 is not likely to be held up by an immediate Constitutional fight. Opponents say it is unclear that a basis exists for a court injunction, but they say they may still mount a legal challenge.
The campaign has brought out into the open the private anguish of doctors, some of whom say they wonder whether their role as healers would be compromised if they become agents of death. Other doctors see the initiative as a humane and long-overdue response to patients who want as much control over their own deaths as they have in their lives.
 
'Not an Alarmist'
 But no matter which side of the issue they are on, doctors from around the country say voters in Washington State would change the nature of American medicine with passage of the initiative.
"I'm not an alarmist by nature, but I am absolutely terrifed of what this could mean," said Dr. Carlos F. Gomez, a doctor at the University of Virginia Health Sciences Center and the author of a book on euthanasia. "The proponents talk about physician-assisted suicide as a right. But I don't understand how you can have a right to be killed."
For the Hemlock Society, whose supporters nationwide are backing 119 with a flood of donations, the initiative is a chance to put into law what the membership has long believed: a philosophy of death that was once dismissed as a fringe belief.
With the help of "Final Exit," by Derek Humphry (Hemlock Society/ Carol, 1991), a suicide-manual that has become a best seller, the society is also trying to make a mainstream concern of a topic that was once taboo. Having failed to place a similar measure on the ballot in California and Oregon, the society succeeded in Washington, which has a tradition of creating novel legislation through a vote of the people.
Around the state, at gatherings in high school gyms and churches and on television, voters are drawing on images of dying loved ones and quoting scripture as they debate the last act of life. In early private polls, a majority of people backed the initiative. And with more than $1 million raised, the initiative's supporters have a 5-1 fund-raising advantage. But the lead could slip as the euthanasia part of the measure is highlighted.
The campaign has been high on emotionalism and personal stories and low on sound bites from politicians, most of whom have not taken a position on the initiative.
In one television advertisement in favor of the initiative, an unconscious man is shown hooked up to a feeding machine in a hospital. "This isn't what Dad wanted," an announcer says, referring to "patients kept alive by machines against their will." Another advertisement, this one against the initiative, features a middle-aged nurse speaking directly to the camera. "I'm a hospice nurse," she says. "Initiative 119 would let doctors kill my patients."
 
2,000-Year-Old Traditions
 For the Roman Catholic Church and the medical establishment, the ballot measure portends a dangerous precedent because it removes some of the onus of suicide and sanctions an act that goes against more than 2,000 years of religious and medical traditions.
Two weeks ago, the Washington State Medical Association's House of Delegates voted by a wide margin to oppose the initiative. But the full membership, polled last spring, was split nearly 50-50.
Regarding people without means, some social workers have said they fear that, faced with choosing between months of costly medical treatment or a quicker and less expensive, deliberate death, the terminally ill patient who is poor or without health insurance is more likely to choose death.
As written, the initiative says a patient can request "aid in dying," doctor-assisted suicide or euthanasia, only if two doctors have concluded that the patient has less than six months to live. Also, two people who have no family or financial ties to the patient must witness the written death request. A person in a coma, without a living will -- that is, a set of written instructions in which a patient will outline in advance how they would like to be treated if faced with a terminal illness or if they fall into a coma -- would not qualify under either circumstance.
More than anything else, proponents speak of a desire for control and choice over the last months of their lives. But many doctors say estimates of how much time a terminally ill patient may have are often wrong. It is not uncommon, the doctors say, for someone who is expected to live for only three months to live another three years. These doctors say they worry that patients may choose death when a considerable burst of life may still be left inside them.
If the measure passes, doctors in this state will be grappling next year with a medical procedure for which there is no set of standards -- death by physician.
 
Bad Medicine and Policy?
 And while supporters of Initiative 119 see the vote as an attempt to take perhaps the most important decision of all out of the hands of doctors, many physicians say the proposal could have just the opposite effect.
"If people are sick of us playing God now, wait until they see what happens if 119 passes," said Dr. Peter McGough of Seattle, who is a leader of a group of doctors opposed to the measure. "I would be placed in a position where I would be asked to take the life of a patient. That is bad medicine and public bad policy."
But supporters argue that mercy killing, by back-alley or home-rigged operation or by covert assistance of doctors, is already a fact of life.
"Allowing a terminally ill patient to make the decision on when to die is the ultimate extension of patients' rights," said Dr. Linda Gromko, who favors the initiative. "The reality of life is that not all illnesses are treatable."
Dr. Gromko, a Seattle family physician, says she formed her philosophy on dying after watching patients suffer through the last months of their lives.In the case of the 60-year-old man with a terminal lung disease, Dr. Gromko said, she was frustrated by her inability to honor his last request.
"I felt so bad," she said. "I felt like I let down this dying man, who had withered away to less than 100 pounds. I could not, by law, honor his last request."
Whether doctors can honor a dying patient's request to end a life has been debated since the time of Hippocrates, the Greek scholar who is considered the founder of Western medicine. This year, the American Medical Society's ethics committee quoted Hippocrates in reaffirming its opposition to doctor-aided suicide and euthanasia.
Patients already have a right to refuse life-sustaining treatment, the committee said in a report. What terminally ill people really want is an assurance that they can die with dignity and without prolonged pain, the ethics group said.
"Medicine is a profession dedicated to healing," the doctors wrote. "Its tools should not be used to kill people."
 
'The Dirty Little Secret'
 But other health professionals argue that the medical establishment is insensitive to the needs of the dying and that it too often favors measures that needlessly prolong life through costly technology.
"Death has been the dirty little secret within the walls of the medical community," said Sara McMacken, a Seattle nurse who favors the initiative. "Patients and their loved ones are not given any choice. Doctors make all the decisions, and that's the way they would like to keep it."
Initiative 119 will be a very personal decision for Ms. McMacken. Two years ago, she was told that she had breast cancer. Her disease is in remission. "But the cancer forced me to think about death, and I would want to have that option to make the decision for myself," she said.
Since 1984 euthanasia has been tolerated, by agreement between prosecutors and doctors, in the Netherlands; it is not technically legal.
A study by the Dutch Government released last month found that less than 2 percent of all deaths in the Netherlands were brought about with the assistance of doctors and that figure is being used by supporters of the Washington initiative.
But Dr. Gomez, author of a just-published book, "Regulating Death: Euthanasia and the Case of the Netherlands," (Free Press) argues that a significant number of terminally ill patients in the Netherlands have been killed against their will. He said that though these cases are underreported, they were substantiated by interviews and anecdotal evidence.
"My real fear is that euthanasia will be used, as it sometimes is in Holland, as a tool of social and economic control," he said. "Poor people, especially in this country where we deny medical services to many of them, are the most vulnerable to be euthanized."
If Initiative 119 passes, some medical experts say, they fear that Washington State could become a magnet for people who want help in dying and that profit-minded doctors might set up shop to cater to that demand.
"There will be a flood of persons seeking aid in dying, coming from all over the United States and Canada, since only in Washington will their desire to end their lives be honored without fear of prosecution," wrote Dr. Albert R. Jonsen, chairman of the ethics department at the University of Washington's medical school, in a recent issue of the magazine Commonweal.
But the Rev. Marvin Evans, a Unitarian minister and leader of a group of clergy supporting the inititive, says Dr. Jonsen's argument assumes that any hastening of death is wrong.
"Death is not the enemy," said Rev. Evans. "Death is part of life. People want control over their own lives, and this is the final and perhaps most important thing in a life."
In one respect both sides agree: the voter turnout on Nov. 5 will set a record.

HEADLINE: Robbers Rape 3 Girls in Inwood Home

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Three young girls were raped by two armed men who pushed their way into an upper Manhattan apartment, tied up the five children and one man who were there and ransacked the home, the police said yesterday.
The oldest of the girls -- a 17-year-old, who was in the apartment with her sister, 12, and another girl, 14 -- was led at gunpoint through the apartment Saturday night as the robbers demanded that she point out her family's valuables, her father said yesterday. 
 "They said it was not enough, they wanted more, and started hitting her," the father said yesterday afternoon outside the building where he had lived since 1960. "They took the two youngest and raped them first, and my oldest was raped last."
 
A Pistol and a Knife
 Investigators believe that the two suspects -- one carrying a semiautomatic pistol and other a knife -- may be responsible for several other incidents of rape and robbery in the Inwood section, said Sgt. Angel Flores of the 34th Precinct detective squad.
The two men pushed their way into the apartment about 9 o'clock Saturday night when the 14-year-old girl arrived with two young children, 8 and 6, in tow at the apartment where the two sisters had been watching television with a 26-year-old male friend, said Officer Scott Bloch, a police spokesman. The suspects bound the occupants with cords and took the girls into another room, where they each raped them, he said.
The parents of the two sisters came home from celebrating their 19th wedding anniversary in Connecticut to find police officers scouring their apartment for clues after their children were hospitalized. The robbers took jewels that were family heirlooms, as well as $800 in cash.
The father said the suspects called a car service to make their getaway.
Like hundreds of his fellow Irish and German neighbors who once packed the apartments along Inwood's wide and sloping streets, the father could have made his own getaway decades earlier, when the neighborhood changed and became a haven for Hispanic families, especially those from the Dominican Republic.
 
A Neighborhood Commitment
 But the girls' father, who moved to Inwood as a teen-ager and married a neighborhood girl, was committed to raising his children in the same apartment where he grew up, and remained one of perhaps four what he called "American" families in the building. It was important they develop a sense of acceptance and open-mindedness toward other ethnic groups, he said.
"I felt my children needed to get to be a part of New York," he said, speaking with the broad, easygoing cadences of his native Bronx. "Why should we run if they can stay here and be a part of it? I grew up in a mixed place in the Bronx, until it was ripped up."
He has been active in community groups over the years, helping establish and run an athletic club for neighborhood youths until a recent schedule change at work cut into his spare time. He also volunteered to work with disadvantaged and homeless people.
A solidly built man with tousled salt-and-pepper hair, he walked slowly toward his home after filling a prescription for his daughters yesterday. They were upstairs in the apartment after being treated and released from Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
A neighbor approached and placed his hand gently on his arm.
"I'm so sorry," the neighbor said quietly in a Spanish accent.
 
'Darkest Day for Me'
 The father raised his hand to his forehead and sobbed, his large shoulders heaving inside his dark pinstriped suit. His hazel eyes were puffy from crying all night.
"This is the darkest day for me," he said later, speaking on condition of anonymity. "I hope the system takes care of it the way it's supposed to."
He took care of his family as best he could, he said, sometimes supplementing his income from a job as a midtown Manhattan doorman with a second job on Wall Street or selling sneakers at athletic-supply stores.
"I tried to be a good father, and my daughters know that," he said. "They call me Mr. Softee because if they need something they know who to come to. Mom is always a little harder on the daughters."
 
'A Part of New York'
 He and his wife sent their daughters to parochial school, where they both did well. His oldest daughter, a college freshman in the City University system, had hopes of becoming a police officer after college and had already taken the department's written test. "She's a tough girl, very open-minded," he said. "She just wanted to be a part of New York -- she didn't want to just be the person wearing the uniform; she wanted to go higher than that."
He and his wife had returned from having a belated anniversary dinner in Greenwich, Conn., when they were met by police at their apartment Saturday night. Their anniversary had been the week before, but they stayed home that time because of a weekend downpour.
"I think we were watched for when we went out," he said.
His neighbors agreed with him that while the building has been untouched by serious violence in the past, some of the nearby streets had changed for the worse since the advent of crack. Sometimes, strangers would enter the building when the lock on the front door was broken and lie in wait for possible robbery victims in the stairways.
 
An Overworked Precinct
 The father lamented the drug dealing that has scared people off some nearby streets at night, and he said the local police precinct was too overworked and understaffed to grapple with the problems.
"If you pick up the phone to call the 34, it'll ring and ring," he said. "And 911? They're slow to answer in this neighborhood."
In the face of this, he said he and his neighbors were determined to forge a sense of community despite ethnic differences. "It's a neighborhood trying to stay together," he said. "Nobody is against anybody. It's a little difficult, but people are trying to do so. Otherwise I would have moved a long time ago."
Competing for attention in the crush of emotions since the crime is the nagging thought for him that perhaps the time has come to give up on the neighborhood. Of course, he said, this could have happened anywhere, but given his modest salary as a doorman, he cannot move to just anywhere.
"Where do you go; what do you do?" he asked. "We tried to have an open mind. You try to hold a job, but at the same time the economy tells you where you live."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Total War Almost Over for Arkansas Papers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
With a combination of business acumen, ruthlessness, deep pockets and near obsession with winning, Walter E. Hussman Jr. has made his Arkansas Democrat the dominant paper in Little Rock and seems poised to run the long-dominant Arkansas Gazette out of business.
 Since 1974, when his family-run communications company acquired The Democrat, Mr. Hussman has twice beaten The Gazette in a bitter war for advertising and circulation. 
The victory has come despite arguments by some that the politically conservative Democrat is inferior journalistically to The Gazette, the state's main liberal voice and long one of Arkansas's most powerful institutions. For instance, The Gazette won two Pulitzer Prizes for its coverage of school integration in the 1950's and has traditionally dominated Arkansas journalism competitions, winning the top award in the three main contests for the last two years.
 
Slashing of Ad Prices
 Mr. Hussman principally used extreme slashing of advertising prices to force the Patterson family to sell The Gazette to the Gannett Company in 1986; he then shifted tactics and has whipped Gannett, one of the most sophisticated newspaper chains.
 Though Gannett does not acknowledge it, the company is known to be trying to sell The Gazette to Mr. Hussman, who is widely expected to close it. An executive familiar with the situation who spoke on condition of anonymity, said The Gazette would probably cease publication within 10 days. A last-minute local effort to buy The Gazette is currently under way, but its chances look slim.
 Though both The Gazette and The Democrat are unprofitable, Gannett is said to be losing more than $30 million annually and is apparently unwilling to sustain such losses as a public company with an obligation to shareholders. Mr. Hussman has voting control over his far smaller but private company, which effectively has given him a free hand to absorb losses.
 
Profit Seen if Gazette Closes
 John Morton, a newspaper analyst for Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, estimated that if The Gazette closes, The Democrat could earn about $30 million annually on revenues of about $110 million.
 In one sense, Mr. Hussman's success is an inspiration to the underdog small businesses competing with bigger, entrenched rivals or leviathan conglomerates.
 "Given a certain level of ability, I don't think anyone can beat an owner-operator," Mr. Hussman said late last week. "Unfortunately, there aren't that many of us left in the newspaper business."
 But Mr. Hussman's success is also a demonstration of how price cutting and shrewd public relations can win a newspaper war where, on the surface, the battle should be over quality.
 Hugh Patterson Sr., who ran The Gazette for his family, said that the Pattersons were actually the only independent operators in the fight and that Mr. Hussman unfairly used his family's profits from other papers and cable television to subsidize losses that the Pattersons, with no other properties, could not sustain.
 Gannett, which had revenues of $3.4 billion in 1990, cannot claim any economic handicap, and the newspaper industry generally expected Gannett to make fast work of Mr. Hussman. But Mr. Hussman won again with hardball business tactics, aided by some Gannett misteps and by successfully portraying himself as the local boy beseiged by an exploitive conglomerate.
 In one typical move after Gannett became the competition, Mr. Hussman changed The Democrat's front-page slogan from "Arkansas's Largest Newspaper," which had helped beat the Pattersons, to "Arkansas's Newspaper." He labeled the opposition "Gannett's Gazette."
 "The Democrat systematically painted a picture of Gannett as a company not committed to Arkansas," said J. Keith Moyer, editor of The Gazette since March 1990.
 
From Survivor to Competitor
 Mr. Hussman, who is 44 years old, said his only goal at first was The Democrat's survival. The event looked very unlikely when the paper was acquired in 1974 by the Camden News Publishing Company, the Hussman family's holding company situated in Camden, Ark., about 100 miles from Little Rock.
 The family business, started by Mr. Hussman's grandfather, now includes six small dailies in Arkansas and Texas, including The Camden News; KTAL-TV, an NBC affiliate in the Shreveport-Texarkana market; AM and FM radio stations in Camden and Shreveport-Texarkana, and about 100,000 cable subscribers in 17 cable systems, mostly in Arkansas.
 In 1974, the afternoon Democrat was in decline. Mr. Hussman thought he saw an opportunity and purchased the paper for $3.5 million.
 His initial strategy was to cut costs, and he did so largely by combating and eventually removing the paper's unions and installing labor-saving equipment. But The Democrat's advertising and circulation were so marginal that the paper lost money despite efficiences.
 In 1977 and 1978, Mr. Hussman tried unsuccessfully to persuade Mr. Patterson to forge a joint operating agreement in which the business and production aspects of both The Gazette and The Democrat would merge but the papers would remain separate new organization.
 After calling other No. 2 papers in competitive markets for ideas, Mr. Hussman increased the size of the paper, especially its sports coverage, and offered unlimited free calssified advertising to individuals, though not to businesses. The Democrat's circulation began to rise.
 He then offered to sell large advertisers ads for $1 and inch, compared with about $9 an inch in the Gazette.
 
Deal With Dillard's
 Dillard's Department Stores Inc., a Little Rock-based chain and the city's top advertiser, was spending $150,000 on The Democrat in 1983, compared with $1.1 million on the Gazette Mr. Hussman offered Dillard's all the advertising it wanted for $500,000 a year, thus raising his revenues and giving The Democrat more credibility with other advertisers.
 The Democrat continued to lose money, but The Gazette had to cut its own ad rates and its profits went into steep decline.
 Mr. Patterson brought an antitrust suit against Mr. Hussman, and when he lost that case in 1986, he quickly sold to Gannett for $51 million in cash and assumption of a $9 million debt.
 Gannett invested heavily in new presses, a bigger staff, more color and a thorough revamping of what had been known as the "gray lady" of Arkansas. It also changed its senior manager repeatedly.
 The Democrat noted every change as a departure from the tried-and-true old standards and an attempt led by outsiders to make The Gazette into USA Today.
 When The Gazette cut circulation rates drastically. The Democrat successfully countered by casting the new reduced price as reflecting a decline in value.
 Gannett adopted the expensive strategy of offering free classifieds and cut ad rates in a free-for-all of discouting.
 Dillard's stopped advertising in the paper in 1989 when Mr. Hussman used invoices from The Gazette to prove that small advertisers were getting better rates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Goodrich Has a 59% Decline

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that its third-quarter net income fell 59 percent from the 1990 third quarter, when the company reported one-time gains that lifted earnings.
Third-quarter 1991 net income totaled $20.7 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with net earnings of $50.6 million, or $1.91 a share, in the third quarter of 1990. Sales reached $649.5 million, up 2.4 percent from $634.5 million. 
 Special items in the 1990 period included gains on the sale of its Uniroyal Goodrich tire operations to Groupe Michelin of France and a loss on the closing of two vinyl production operations in Canada.
John D. Ong, chairman, said the company's results improved from the second quarter of 1991 because of a stronger performance in vinyl products and some specialty chemical businesses. "Nevertheless," he said, "we continue to experience the effects of weak economic conditions, and we remain cautious about the near-term outlook."
Goodrich shares closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $43.75, down 12.5 cents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher in Light Day; Gold Declines in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained against most major currencies yesterday in a lightly traded session dominated by speculators.
Gold prices fell, with gold for current delivery declining $1, to $358.90 a troy ounce, on the New York Commodity Exchange. A late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York quoted fold at $358.40, down $1.10. 
 Most banks and currency dealers had skeleton crews on hand during the quiet Columbus Day holiday.
Traders said there was no significant economic news during the day to affect trading. Some players were speculating about what interest rate policy might emerge from a meeting of finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Thailand, said Debra Middleton, assistant vice president at the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
"The only thing I can still sink my teeth in is that rates in the U.S. are still going to be coming lower," Ms. Middleton said.
Lower rates would likely cause the dollar to fall. All currencies are supported by higher rates, and undermined by lower yields.
Ms. Middleton said most of the trades were speculative, although some customers were buying dollars to protect their positions, she said.
Most of the action surrounded trading of Japanese yen against the German mark.
The dollar fell sharply against the yen in Tokyo trading, closing at 128.70, its lowest level since Feb. 13. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 129.40 yen. The dollar recovered somewhat in New York, closing at 129.95 yen, up from 129.58 late Friday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7145, from $1.7195 late Friday. At closing in New York, sterling cost $1.71225, less expensive than the $1.7235 late Friday.
The Italian lira advanced, with the dollar closing at 1,239.00 lire, down from 1,264.00. But traders took little interest in the movement in light of the weak volume.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.70175 German marks, up from 1.6895; 1.4865 Swiss francs, up from 1.4793; 5.79175 French francs, up from 5.7575, and 1.12925 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1285.

LENGTH: 327 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Inch Up Overseas

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in thin overseas trading yesterday.
With banks and other major institutions closed in observance of Columbus Day, the cash market for Government bills, notes and bonds was closed in the United States. 
 Trading in bond futures contracts did take place in Chicago, however, although the hours of operation were shortened. Prices of bond contracts dipped modestly at the Board of Trade.
The bulk of the day's activity was concentrated in short-term Treasury bills.
After reviewing economic data released on Friday, which included a report on modest inflation and poor retail sales results for September, foreign traders seemed to concur with their American counterparts that signs pointed to a move by the Federal Reserve Board to lower short-term interest rates to help stimulate the economy.
 
Auction Reset Today
 Because of the holiday, the weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills will be held today.
At the close of trading in Europe, three-month bill rates were offered at a discount rate of 4.94 percent, down six basis points, or six one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were offered at 4.99 percent, down five basis points.
Movement in prices of Treasury notes and bonds overseas was minimal. The 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at 102 26/32, up 2/ 32, to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.88 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 27/32, unchanged from late Friday, to yield 7.45 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 15/ 32, up 1/32, to yield 5.86 percent.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, the nearby December bond contract closed at 99 25/32, down 3/32.
Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets was nearly invisible, traders said.
In both markets, prices of most issues were flat.
